reviews.review: Beautiful family collection of art and music. This was our 1st visit to Prague. The city is an enchanting Bohemian fairy tale town. The Lobkowicz dynasty was unknown to us before. IT was fascinating to hear the history of this noble family. The weapons collection is small, but all pieces are in pristine condition. Wrapping up the visit with a small concert in one of the family rooms was wonderful.

Amazing Palace. This unique palace within the Castle complex is special for its narration by the current head of the Lobkowicz family. The story of there 600 year history is amazing. The pictures, china, and arms pale in comparison to the family's music connection and the originals of music by Strauss, Hayden and Beethoven. This is a special and unique tour.
Worth a Visit. You should include a visit to this palace whilst visiting the castle and make a day of it. Lots to see and very interesting.
Lobkowicz Palace. An absolute must see. Plus the story of the Lobkowicz family is inspiring. They have been working to restore several castles against all odds. And, they are prevailing.

An amazing collection of historical items, and a great family story spanning centuries.. We visited Lobkowicz Palace after taking a walking tour of the Prague Castle area. The audio tour was great in giving a perspective across many generations of the Lobkowicz' family history, and many great artifacts. Particularly cool were the collection of armor, and the musical instruments and Beethoven manuscript (as we learned, they were benefactors of Beethoven). Worth the visit.
a fascinating glimpse. This museum on Castle Hill has fascinating collections, It gives one a view of one family's history, shedding light on the history of Prague and the culture in general.
Nice place. Place has a great collection of paintings and other objects of art. I think the entrance fee was a little overpriced.

Great palace. The Lobkowicz palace is a part of the Prague Castle, but this is the only privately owned edifice inside it. It belongs (again) to the noble Lobkowicz family.Located in the lower part of the Castle, opposite the Golden lane it is excluded from the combined ticket variations offered by Prague Castle.You have to pay an extra admission but it's really worth it. Audio guide is included and it tells an interesting story, familiar to us from the ex Eastern block, about Nazi and after them Communist property nationalization. Inside great artistic artifacts are displayed from Velasquez paintings, over fine chinaware and arms collections to Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts.

Beautiful Palace within the Castle. Restored and still maintained by the Lobkowicz family, there is an interesting museum, occasional concerts and a great terrace where you can have such overlooking the city.

A real surprise behind the plain facade. The Lobkowicz Family has an amazing story regarding the world wars. They lost everything to the Nazi's and Russians. A family member has stepped up to find all of the treasures. Their museum and tour shows you 5 centuries of their recovered family wealth. Don't forget to read the story, it will make you appreciate it more.

Best Attraction of our 10 day tour!. We took the #15 & # 22 tram to the palace top then walked to far end of grounds (#9) and entered museum. Fabulous story on audio tour narrated by family members followed by hour long classical concert by pianist, violinist, and flautist. Lunch in cafe overlooking city and river. Discovered we could walk down steps outside and catch #15 bus directly back to Republic Square.This is a "Don't Miss" attraction.

Family Art Collection. We visited the Palace for morning tea and a tour of the Family Art Collection. The art collection is varied and is an interesting collection. The palace is spread out , so there is a lot of walking. We had a guide with us so we did not use the audio guide that is available. The human guide only spoke at length on the highlights and we wondered whether we missed anything by not having the audio guide. It is worth a visit when in the Castle complex.

A nice tour of the history of wealthiest Czech family in the past, a good break from the walking. I went to the mid-day concert at 1:00pm, then stayed behind to tour the palace. Make sure you get the audio tour as it's very helpful. I spent a total of 2.5 hours at the Lobkowicz Palace on a hot sunny day. What a good break to take from so much walking.

One of the highlights of our Prague visit. We visited this Palace with our Viking tour, we had a lunch in a private dining room and then a short concert and tour of the family art collection. Something not to be missed! Lots of walking!

great place to visit. I was lucky to visit it and even to have a tour with one of family members at the special occasion... other than that, you can visit palace and take an audio guide. there are lot of things to see...
great fascinating collection. some of the artefacts here are of great rarity - original Beethoven scores and the Canaletto's of London are totally unique - great little ish gallery

Great Museum. I was surprised by how interesting this was. While we all understand that nobility marries nobility to create and consolidate wealth, to see/hear it about a specific lineage was interesting. The art was great. How many families have had their portraits painted by Velasquez? The 6th Prince was a serious patron of Beethoven and financed premieres of works such as Haydn's The Creation. The covers of several manuscripts, with dedications, are on display as is a list of the expenses for one musical premiere. Perhaps the most magnificent piece is The Hay Harvest by Brueghel the Elder--in a room by itself with helpful information and absolutely nobody else jostling to see it. Admission (if you are over 65 remember to ask for the reduced rate) includes a good audio guide narrated by the current Prince. The story of how the family reclaimed its properties and wealth after confiscations by both the Nazis and Communists is interesting. It felt a bit heavy handed to hear about their other palace that is open to the public and to hear repeatedly about all the donations that have made art restorations possible. These were small matters and didn't ruin a great museum experience. So different from most of the “attractions” in the castle complex.

Spend two hours away from the crowds at Prague Palace. I was lucky to hear Prince William Lobkowicz speak at a private event about the epic adventure of having centuries of family treasures confiscated and returned twice; first by the Nazis and then the Communists. The dedication and perseverance of his family to make these treasures available to the public is remarkable. The prince and other family members speak on the audio tour, which is punctuated with period music. Spend an hour or so touring the museum, looking at paintings, porcelain, weapons and musical scores (including original Beethoven scores) and then enjoy the hour-long concert in the music hall.There is also a lovely and quiet courtyard restaurant and nice gift shop adjacent to the palace.
Did not live up to expectations. Was an optional side trip on a Viking Cruise. Included meal ( not good) and concert (not great). Paintings more of a family history than just plain history

No crowds here!. We dropped in here on a whim, and partly to avoid the throngs of tourists milling around St Vitus' Cathedral and Golden Lane. As it isn't included on tour group itineraries there was no-one here. It is an interesting gallery, and the story of the Lobkowicz family's loss of their properties and their subsequent restoral post-1989 is fascinating. The views from the third floor, over the river and old city are fabulous. Well worth the entrance fee and needs about 45 minutes.

Lobkowicz Palace. The Lobkowicz Palace was fascinating. So much to see and absorb; we could easily have taken twice as long in touring the rooms if time would have allowed. The included private concert was also a "not-to-be-missed" experience.

Great with a classical concert. Interesting palace. Just a 10 minute walk below the Prague Place. Worth the admission price to see the family's artwork. Mozart & Beethoven's actual manuscripts are worth the visit. A classical concert in a 16th c. Room was priceless.

Best Museum in Prague. Visited this museum during a recent visit to Prague. It was very interesting and the audio guide was narrated by the present prince and members of his family which brings and appealing personal perspective to it. They must have been amazed when, after the downfall of Communism, they had their properties and possessions, which had been appropriated by the Nazis and then by the Communists, returned to them. an eclectic collection including a couple of amazing paintings of London by Canaletto, musical manuscripts by Beethoven, numerous olde weapons and suits of armour, fine china etc etcAlso best museum shop in Prague with excellent examples of local products
Buy tickets in advance for this gem of a museum. We spent several hours in this museum, during which time we used audio tapes. We also attended the 1 PM concert, which was excellent.

Beautiful!. Smack dab in the middle of The Prague Castle is the privately owned Lobkowicz Palace. It houses lovely works of art and the audio guide is narrated by one of the Lobkiwicz family members which is really special.

Amazing Audio Guide!. This museum went from good to great with the amazing audio guide included in the price of your admission ticket. Very thorough history and details provided for any piece in the collection. Beautiful views of Prague as well, definitely worth your time!

Great value. This is a magnificent collection housed in a family complex in the castle grounds. The audio guide is free and very informative. It tells the story of a powerful family with a long history. There are some great portraits mixed with some porcelain and other art. There is a Bruegel,Canaletto and Valazquez. There are paintings of family pets and birds. It's personal and lovely. Not to be missed

Wonderful Evening. We went to the Lobkoicz Palace as our very last activity on a Tauck tour. We had a wonderful dinner and were entertained by two wonderful musicians. The Palace Museum was well worth the visit. The view from the balcony was outstanding.

Great for art enthusiasts . I went to this gallery with my mum and we loved the exhibits.The portraits were an interesting way to view the family's history, and it was interesting to hear accounts of how art was preserved / restored after the family regained work.ticket isn't cheap, but the art conversation isn't cheap either. ...

Interesting family history. The family owns it again after having it confiscated by the Nazis, and then again by the Soviets. Interesting story. Back in the day, the family was a patron of Beethoven, and the famous 5th Symphony is dedicated to one of the ancestors. After viewing the museum, I also attended their mid-day classical music concert which was quite good.

Great collection of interesting historical memorabilia in a beautiful castle. I enjoyed the whole Palace and particularly enjoyed an extra audio tour of the balcony. It included a wonderful view and stories from the Lobkowicz Family. The Beethoven room was terrific.

Highly recommend!. We went there to see some of the most important pieces of Czech history. Highly recommend you to take the audio guide which is narrated by the owner. Also, we attended the flute-piano concert which was nice, but overrated. No need to pay extra to sit in the first rows, you can hear everything from the other rows since the concert hall is not so big. However, Lobkowicz Palace is the place you should not miss when you are in Prague!

Fascinating History. This is a combined review of lunch and the tour of the palace. We had lunch in the palace as part of an optional tour associated with our Viking River Cruise. The lunch was fine -- I was glad I chose the vegetable lasagne, because the meat option looked brown and undistinguished with a dumpling that tasted bland (another lady gave me a taste of hers.) We also had salad and dessert. But what was memorable was the palace itself. The Lobkowicz family had this palace from the 16th Century until it was taken from them first by the Nazis and then by the Communists. When the Czech Republic was established, they were given the opportunity to regain their property but had to go through a lot of legal hoops. They also were told to open it to the public. But "the public" sees it in small groups, which makes for a more enjoyable experience. A past Prince Lobkowicz gave Beethoven a stipend so he could compose what he chose rather than scrambling for commissions, as did earlier composers such as Mozart. The visit included a concert in a music room where Beethoven had performed. On view in the palace are original scores by Beethoven with his handwritten corrections. The family had a a fabulous art collection--a painting by Velazquez shows the Infanta (King Philip of Spain's daughter.) She married one of the Lobkowicz ancestors, and her mother gave her the statue of the Child Jesus in satin robes that later became known as the Infant of Prague. (Evidently, miracles were attributed to this statue. I just knew it was common in Catholic homes during my childhood.) Visitors are guided through the palace by an audio guide recorded by Lobkowicz family members. The current Prince (I guess you can call him that) Lobkowicz spent his early days in England and married a beautiful Bostonian. The tapes are full of interesting anecdotes. Near the end of the tour, you come to a terrace with a fabulous view of Prague. By the way, if you need to use a rest room on your visit, the one upstairs is much nicer than the one in the basement.

Worth a visit for the Canaletto's and the balcony view alone!. What a well laid out museum with a great audio guide included in the price. This is a great place for gaining an insight in to the lives and influence on one of the major aristocratic families in Europe. Once you get passed the family portraits there are some great exhibits of porcelain and pictures. The family were also major patrons of the arts and it was thrilling for me to see original manuscripts by Mozart, Haydn, Gluck and Beethoven. If you time your visit just before 13.00hrs there is a daily concert which, if you choose not to attend, will provide quality background music whilst you saunter. The two Canaletto's were absolutely stunning and the panoramic views from the balcony took my breath away.
mandatory. A must go in Prague! Nice view of the city, exibitions inside, beautiful garden. Take at least one day to visit the whole castle.
Get the Audio it explains so much. Lots of history here. The palace is very interesting to tour and to see some of the artifacts like Mozarts original music scores is amazing.

We had a private dinner here with perks. You really need to have a guide, in our case it was the wife of the count so we had a wonderful insight of how this Palace came back into the Lobkowicz family. There are a number of wonderful paintings and armament on display but the crown jewel is the number of very old musical instruments. Even some original scores by Haydn and Beethoven which are in wonderful condition. A very surprising evening and well worth it.

Very interesting and they have original Beethoven scores!. We just happened on the Lobkowicz Palace but what an interesting story it has. Very interesting commentary by the owner. I found the illustration of the family tree helpful.This family was a patron to Beethoven and therefore they have some of his original scores on display!
amazing palace, great concerts. very very nice hotel and museum, pleasant classical concerts that we and my four years son enjoyed very much. nice open restaurant

Highlight of the Castle District. We met Prince Lobkowicz. He has a fascinating story to tell. I wish more people could see the palace, the views from the palace and the amazing collection of art and music that is in this place.
Always call in when your in Prague. Great place to visit all year round. Great art very interesting history helpful to English speakers.

Charming. A lovely respite from the intensity of the Cathedral and Castle tour. We wandered around with headsets listening to the gentle narrative by the descendants of the original owners. It gave an insight to the vagaries of fortune due to political upheaval.....beautiful pictures, dinner services and personal effects.
Excellent place to visit. Great views, well presented palace. Great little eateries and coffee....recommend walking visit day or night

Spectacular . This museum was definitely one of the highlights of our trip. You have to pay in separately (the Castle ticket does not cover the museum) but it is completely worth it and you get an audio guide with the ticket. The museum itself is full of wonders which I still cannot believe we had the honour of seeing for ourselves. It is clear that the museum has been lovingly cared for. We also had a delicious and great value lunch on the terrace of the museum with amazing views over Prague. It was the perfect way to end a morning spent exploring the castle and its grounds. An unforgettable experience.

Wonderful tour. This was part of our Viking Ship tour we had booked. We got a couple of extras, including a lunch of traditional Czech food and a wonderful mini concert. The whole story behind this family is very intriguing and mirrors the Czech Republic history. The audio devices give you all the details of the family history and the many painting and other historical documents. The relationship with Beethoven was fascinating. The highlight of our tours in Prague.

Not to be missed during a visit to Prague- truly one of the best museums to see.. The History narrated by the Lobkowicz family is so amazing, hearing how the family had lost such treasures twice, and then rightfully returned back after the fall of communism alone is a fascinating story. Then being able to walk through the museum and seeing the various art works, with the continuing narration of the audio tour providing such an in-depth history of the works, and how they related to the family is intertwined perfectly. A great example is the manuscripts by Beethoven, signed to the prince at the time, of who was an incredible patron of the arts. Standing in a room seeing Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn’s own handwriting of musical scores is overwhelming. The museum does offer a Brueghel and Velazquez, amongst many other worthy artists of the time. Along with an entire room devoted to paintings of dogs, armory and plate ware, all of which make the price of admission worth a visitA side visit which did cost an additional amount was to do the panorama / balcony tour. The tour will add on another ½ plus to your visit, but is so worth it!!! The Lobkowicz’s provide such a fascinating tale of the sites one can view from an amazing vantage point on the balcony of various places around the city. This was an incredible way to learn and see even if off in the distance other places of interest to visit, and the accompanying narration and musical interludes was an ideal accompaniment to seeing the museum. The view is incredible for taking so many panoramic pictures.You will want to plan on more than an hour, to visit just the museum, and then almost another hour with the panorama tour, both with audio narration is a great way to pass a morning or afternoon and then eat at the café, either in the shade of the courtyard or on the balcony-with an amazing view.

Momentous Musical Museum. A highlight of mine was touring this museum, which included viewing priceless copies of original Beethoven, Mozart, and Haydn musical orchestrations! The story of this museum was also inspirational as it survived two very difficult historical periods where all artifacts were confiscated , only to be returned to the Lobcowicz Heirs! Amazing!

Great stop to see. Lobkowcz Palace is part of Prague Castle. They have a lot of the rooms made up into a museum. I would highly suggest getting the audio tour. Take your time and enjoy the history of Praha. Great stop for history buffs.

Best museum, ever. . What a delight. The story of the Lobowicz family is fascinating. The tour includes an audio voiced by the current Prince Lobowicz. He tells about the family losing their home and belongings to the Nazis and then to the Soviets before having them restored by the Czech government after the fall of the Soviet Union. For us, the highlight of the tour was the Beethoven room. Here, there are original scores of Symphonies 3, 4, 5 and 6. At least two are dedicated to the prince at the time, who was an important patron of Beethoven. There is a nice restaurant in the Palace with a wonderful view. At 1300, they have a short classical concert. We visit every time we are in Prague and never tire of the experience. The collections are enormous and we always see something new.
Great museum. Really interesting audio guide made the history come alive. View over Prague (with another great audio guide) also great. Highly recommended, much better than the Prague castle tour.

The highlight of our Prague visit - Museum pass with a mid day concert. Very informative family history and artifacts with interesting art collections but not very overwhelming. The 1-hour concert is just right with smaller audience in a room about 25' by 50' in size.
Great palace inside Prague Castle. Even though you have to pay extra to come in, t was worth the visit. You can see many artifacts from the royalty and has good views of Prague.

Some thrilling moments in this family's collection. Lobkowicz Palace is a lovingly maintained space with some interesting family collections. It is very much just one family which makes its interest a little more limited. That said, for any fan of Beethoven, it is worth the price of admission to see the original copies of a few of his symphonies! Such an interesting story behind this. The midday concert has some talented musicians playing a very accessible program.

Love to come back. My husband and I have been here on numerous occasions and are always happy to return. You can spend your time visiting the museum - the Lobkowicz family unbelievable collection of art, amassed through centuries. The real draw here is the musical collection, original musical scores annotated by Beethoven, Mozart and Haydn. Beethowen dedicated three symphonies to Prince Lobkowicz. There is also an impressive musical instrument, porcelain and gun collection, and of course all the celebrated paintings ...We did the video tour once, it is charmingly narrated by the current heir and owner. Their family story of survival and living in exile is equally interesting.  If you don't have time for the museum, go for the hour long midday chamber music concert performed in a room with beautiful fresco ceiling. Great opportunity to rest your feet and a great value too. Last but not least to be included is the Cafe with fabulous views from the terrace.We have done it all in one visit or just stopped for refreshments on the terrace another time. It was a sure bet on a hot July day...Lobkowicz Palace is one of my favorite places in Prague... For the amazing collection of art, for the amazing story of the Lobkowicz family and for the amazing views ...

Absolute rip off. Barely worth the time and definitely not worth 275 crowns unless you're 80 years old and deeply fascinated by paintings of one aristocratic family's portraits (including their dogs). Should have stayed state property if you ask me.

Nice place. Its a nice place with many interesting artifacts.The view from the castle is remarkable.We had to go twice because the first time they didn't tell us it was closing half an hour early, which was a trouble for us.The stories are interesting but it always feels like they're trying to get more money out of you.Even the WC are with extra charge.

Beautiful exhibition. Beautiful paintings and historical artefacts. Especially the music history room is just plain awesome. Beautiful palace in a very nice neighbourhood. Not that expensive and you even have a chance to go listen live classical music 12am. More written information of the objects would be great. Audio-guides were included in the price but I'm not a listen to type person.
Surprise inside Prague Castle.. Wandering along, I found this little gem of a museum. Wish I'd had more time to explore but the gift shop alone was worth stopping.

Interesting private history. It takes about an hour to go round this private museum with an audio commentary by the current American owner of the palace, whose family has been one of the wealthiest and most influential in the country for centuries. An intriguing insight into history with a personal touch. 275 CZK admission fee.

Worthwhile Museum. The Lobkowicz Palace is in the Castle and not to be missed if you want to learn about a family who lost everything and is now trying to preserve their history. Includes original Beethoven manuscripts.

Great treat. The best audio tour I've ever been on, narrated by a member of the family. Keep an eye out for the original folios of Beethoven's 3rd and 6th symphonies. At the end, go to the courtyard and have a cold Lobkowicz beer on draft!

Fantastic! Highly recommended!. While I didn't have any expectations going into this tour I was pleasantly surprised at its contents. The optional audio tour is highly recommended. It is narrated by the Prince of the current generation as well as a couple of other family members. The audio tour feels very friendly and personal which made it unique to other audio tours that I have taken. You are introduced to quite an extensive family history / genealogy as well as being able to view an extensive collection of artwork and artifacts.

Strikingly personable. The Lobkowicz collection is strikingly impressible, insightful and personable. The audio guide - narrated by William Lobkowicz himself and his relatives- provides us with a fascinating family history, from it's powerful political positions to important philanthropic contributions throughout the centuries. With the addition of the daily musical recital and spectacular panoramic view over Prague, the experience truly immerses you within the life of one of Bohemia's most notable family. 100% recommend!!

Interesting Artwork. There are definitely better art museums around the world, but this is worth a visit while in Prague. There are some interesting and valuable works in the collection, and the highlight is most likely a set of musical scores penned by Mozart and Beethoven.

Meet the original full scores of Beethoven's Symphonies. To be honest, all the paintings were boring. But, on the 2nd floor, you could see the original full scores of Beethoven's Symphony No. 3, 4, 5. Also the Mozart's rearrangement of Handel's songs. This is because Lobkowicz family supported Beethoven. This is an absolute gem you must meet in the Prague castle!

Fantastic!. A Rick Steves suggestion...and glad we went. A wonderful collection of top quality art. Original musical scores ( Beethoven,Hayden) as well.Glad we went...easily visited on way down from Castle area.

An absolute gem -- do not miss!. This was the highlight of our trip to Prague, in part because it was so unexpected. I have been to Prague three previous times, mostly recently 20 years ago, and so the Lobkowicz Palace was still in government hands. No matter how tired you are, don't miss this. It is far superior to the many sights that are overrun with tourists. This was a palace that had long been owned by one of the Czech Republic's most prominent families, but which had been seized by the communists. After the revolution, the family (by then based in the United States) managed to get it back. The story is rather amazing, and the amusing and interesting audio tour (narrated by the owner) is fascinating. One of the most priceless Bruegal paintings in the world is here, but there is so much more. It's a small museum but if you do it right, it should take about 90 minutes --and then save 30 minutes for a nice meal or drink in the cafe.

To think - we almost missed it!. We had been poking around Prague Castle for two days and thought we had seen it all. Then someone asked what we had thought of the Lobkowicz Palace and we hadn't seen that gem tucked away near the back (to us) entrance of the castle. We went back to see the Palace and spent a very memorable day poking around, listening to the fascinating audio guide, attending a concert and having lunch with a breathtaking view of Prague at our feet. I didn't get to see everything I wanted to in Prague but I'm glad that we chose to visit this jewel on our last day.

An outstanding complement to the visit of the Prague castle. You'll get an audio player with headsets at the entry. Listen to the explanations and you'll not just see but undertsand how unique the place is, how unique are the Lobkowicz's, and their distinctive story through the turmoils of the Czech history. The collection of old guns and weapons is exceptional.

Spectacular. Spectacular gallery with a focused history on the members of this noble family. The audio tour is narrated by the living members of the family which adds a nice continuity to the collection. Little facts like rings worn by 16th century members in paintings still being owned and worn by the living members. They have original sheet music of Beethoven written in his own hand, some of his most famous and well known symphonies!! My favorite musuem in the city, good shop as well.
worth the price of admission. One could easily spend a full day admiring the art work here. A group of us did the tour and had lunch there. If you do dine there, skip the wine.

So much incredible history. I loved the story of how this tenacious heir reclaimed his family's property. It was hard-fought to get it back, and now there is this beautiful collection which we can all see. The art work is incredible, especially the Canalettos.

Lovely Palace. We weren't sure about stopping at the Lobkowicz Palace but decided after eating in their cute cafe to check it out. It was definitely worth the stop!
The family history and the story of the Czech people in general is captivating and the music by Beethoven was incredible.

So glad we went in!. Our trip to Europe this summer included visit to 10 cities and one of them was Prague. While there, we went to see Lobkowicz Palace. It is a beautiful site with amazing collection. At the time of our visit to Praha castle it was quite crowded and it was a hot day, yet the Palace was very inviting, and with very few tourists. The terrace view was breathtaking! Do not miss to visit this museum.

Insight into how the other half lived.. While the tour imparts some sympathy for the family that had their legacy appropriated first by the Nazis, then by the Commies, I found it hard to believe how an even more intense concentration of wealth has occurred in our era. Granted, not every billionaire can claim to have sponsored Beethoven and his writing of the 5th Symphony or had a great-great-great grandmother who was a princess of the Spanish Empire, but it does make you wonder just how nice life must have been for the 'haves" during the 16th and 17th centuries.

Awesome collection. Praha castle in the summer is crowded of turists. Most of them, however seems to not pay attention to this amazing museum. The only private palace inside the castle has an awsome collection that allows the visitor to learn the cultural and political history of Europe and Czech Republic through the perspective of one family, the Lobkowiczs. Best museum I saw in Prague. The music and the armory room were the most impressive for me. They have some original scores of Mozart and of Beethoven's 5th symphony. This last one was dedicated to the 7th Prince Lobkowicz, which made regular payments to finance beethoven work. Is is also very interesting to see how czech aristocracy were able to remain rich and powerful across the centuries, through international political alliances. Really amazing.

Palace is lovely. Lobkowicz palace is remarkably preserved, well organised, attractive touristic site. Full package provides wonderful historical journey: museum, panorama with audio guides and beautiful midday concert of classical music. Audio material helps remember this place and main elements of this family history. More interestingly it is maintained and tour is designed by trough inherents of the nobel family. Good place to start Prague historical tour. Panorama experience is unique!Maja&Angeĺ
Wonderful Experience. Palace put on a lunch for us, a music concert and then we were on the self guided tour with provided equipment, and could tour at our own speed.

Interesting. Had dinner here as part of a Tauck group tour. Toured the museum afterwards. The music room was the highlight, with compositions on view from famous composers - when you,had to,write everything out by hand!
Unbelievable collection. If you are an art or history buff, this place has an amazing collection of art and even original scores from Beethoven in his own hand. Priceless.

Mainly about the Lobkowicz family. We were hoping to see more art than we did, but most of the rooms in the gallery were dedicated to telling the story of the Lobkowicz family. However I'm glaad we did visit because we attended a lunchtime concert there and did see a couple of beautiful Canalettos and a fantastic Pieter Breughel the Elder painting.

Wonderful exhibition. What a wonderful exhibition! The audio tour helped set everything in its right context and made the visit even more rewarding. Seeing the original sheet music was a great experience. This was the best museum I have visited in a long time. Thank you.

Amazing!. We took the tour which included lunch, a concert and touring the exhibits. First the lunch was very very good; restaurant quality. Then, the concert was a trio - piano, violin and cello. We are both classical musicians and thought the playing was first rate. And the palace concert room was perfect in representing a venue in Europe in the 17th - 19th centuries. Beautiful sound. Last, the exhibits were moving especially the Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts. Nothing like seeing the actual scores they worked on. We also had a chance to meet the Prince who was filming an interview. So very personable and connecting. Happy to be able to thank him for his family funding Beethoven's ability to write what he wanted (instead of just doing commission work) and then saving pieces of history for us to enjoy. A wonderful experience!!!

Fantastic Palace building... Again, one of the Palaces of the Castle complex. Thus one is a little bit different. Instead of being government owned, it belongs to a family who managed to take their ancestral palace back from the government occupation. Quite a story that is. Especially after the palace had been with the communist regime for quite a number of years. You can take an audio tour of the Palace. The narration us by the existing owner who also happens to be the member of the Royal family.Intriguing and fascinating.
Underwhelming !. Not bad, have seen way better castles across Europe. Okay to visit once. The Segway tour groups are very annoying, wish they could be done away with.

A major tourist destination. . Lobkowicz Palace is a superb tourist attraction that can be viewed from most vantage points of Prague.The location is stunning and it looks magnificent especially at night when it's illuminated. The view from Charles Bridge is amazing and it's not uncommon to see dozens of photographers both amateur and professional taking photos of this superb Palace.Tours can be pre booked if you really want to experience the full beauty of this amazing Palace. A must go destination in Prague.

Lobkowicz Palace-Museum and Classic Concert. The Lobkowicz Palace is part of the Prague Castel complex and it was a revelation on our visit in Prague. The private collections of paintings, Delft diner service, musical instruments, arms and armors, photographs spread over 21 rooms are illustrating the very long Lobkowicz family tree and their important role in Boehmia’s history. Family’s properties and art collections were seized by the Nazis in 1939, and, again, confiscated by the Communists in 1948 and were only restituted to the family in the 90’s after the Velvet Revolution and the fall of communism. The family had acted as patrons of arts and artists, Ludwig van Beethoven among them. The highlight of our visit was the classic concert held in the palace’s Concert Hall. The trio performed a program of piano, flute and viola classics. The pianist was particularly virtuoso. We are highly recommending a visit to Lobkowicz Palace, while climbing to see Prague Castle.

On a private tour we had a private dinner here that is memorable. The present owner of the palace addressed us and provided the historic background with a sense of humour blended throughout. Dinner with the orchestra in the background will never be forgotten
Beauitful. A lovely palace so interesting and historical didn't want to leave such a feast for the eyes all so Beauitful .
Amazing Museum. Handwritten works of Beethoven, Mozart and Handel. Absolutely beautiful. A must see. Overwhelming place.

Amazing location. It must have been to difficult to build this so many years ago with its location. The artists on the streets, the little music going on and the views make this a wonderful stop of many wonderful places to see.

Great discoveries. In my concern, the prime attraction of this palace is the musical manuscript sources in the exhibition rooms. You can see music from Beethoven stared in this place, but many other fantastic examples as Haydn and Gluck manuscript too.

Palace Tour and Concert. Visited the privately owned Lobkowicz Palace in September of 2013. The Palace (only in recent years returned to the family) located within the Prague Castle Complex, provides an insight into, not only the family history, but that of the Czech people. On display is a valuable collection of Paintings, Musical Instruments, Manuscripts, etc. After touring the Palace and having lunch at the Palace Café, the icing on the cake (so to speak) was a Concert of Classical Music in the beautiful Baroque Style Concert Hall.
Fabulous. The items on display are wonderful, and the experience of listening to the family tell their story (audio tour) made it very special.

Super nice views of old Prague and nice little museum. Even though this is not a "super touristic site" the views from up there are worth seeing. You can see the little museum and walk around to enjoy the park next to it. From there you can also walk to the tower (looks like Eiffel tower and in fact is the same but smaller). You can also walk to Old town going through the main Castle and several cafes and stores in the way (about 40 min walk).

The self-aggrandizement outshines the art. I am not quite as taken with this museum as other reviewers, but it provides an interesting story of a family recovering properties they had to abandon. Signage (in Czech and English) is good, the guides seem helpful and most speak English, and an audio guide was included with the ticket purchase. Michael Lobkowicz, who graduated from Harvard and is also a prince, narrates the family story. He has a pleasant voice and the audio guide is well paced and interesting. Michael mentions the laws that made recovery possible, but I would have liked to know more about the effort involved in recovering the household possessions. Did the Communists maintain these with the mansions? Had the family hidden them somewhere? The option, “If you are interested in hearing more about the reclamation process of this item, enter #145,” or something similar would have been nice. The collection of musical scores is the highlight of the museum, and I enjoyed the signs that explained, especially for the various china sets, how they had entered the family. These stories provide a fascinating look into the inter- and intra-family marriages made to protect or expand one’s property. The last 5 rooms or so offer nowhere for a guest to sit. Due to a private concert, we couldn’t enter the last 2 rooms but were told they would be available in 20 minutes. If there had been anywhere to sit, we might have taken advantage of this offer. Last, there is a bit of a huckster quality to this that bothered me. When you buy your ticket, you are asked if you want to add the mid-day concert. Then the audio guide plugs items you can see by visiting another Lobkowicz palace outside of Prague, and there are signs in very room that say “Prague Inspires Panorama,” which we ultimately learned meant that, for a small fee, we could “Experience Prague like a Prince and Princess from the only private terrace in Prague Castle.” After paying a minimum of 275 korunas (more with add-ons) to hear about the pedigree and fortunes of the palace owners -- or to eat at their upscale cafe -- patrons have to pay to use the water closet. I’m not surprised when public places do this, but it did surprise me in a private museum.

A place to go if you have seen al of Prague Castle. Very beautifull palace and museum. Lots of paintings and precious furniture in the many rooms open to the public. The view from the terrace is stunning especially at the sunset. Good value for money.

Personalized audio guide by castle's owner. This castle is part of the Prague Castle complex across from the Christmas Shop. (If you like painted glass ornaments, go there) the castle was in the same family for hundreds of years and the present owner was able to reclaim it after the Velvet Revolution and the fall of Communism. He was a Boston, MA banker. It's fascination lies in the telling of the story of the family and its connection to monarchies of Europe and also to Mozart and Beethoven. Well worth a visit.

Best View of Prague. It's one thing to visit one of the most magical and picturesque city's in the world - but I found the VERY BEST place to see the VERY BEST view of Prague. You must stop by the amazing Lobkowicz Palace located on the grounds of the Prague Castle. This was not my first time at Lobkowicz Palace, but this time I was treated to a spot not previously open to the public. The second floor balcony looks out on the most spectacular part of the city where you can enjoy an over 180 degree panaramic view of Prague. As if the wonderful people at LP were reading my mind, they have created the new Panaramic Tour of Prague in the tranquil environment of the balcony. William and Sandra Lobkowicz narrate (on your own personal device) an informative, touching, humorous, and heartfelt tour of the majority of Prague. They tell you about the phenomenal buildings, monuments, and sights right in front of you. They also share amusing and historical stories about their family's ancestry and heritage. I learned more about Prague in 30 minutes than ever before. The tour also motivates and inspires you to visit parts of Prague you may not have known about before.After the panaramic tour, you can wander downstairs and enjoy some of the delicious food and drink in the cafe where you will feel more like a local with a new appreciation of the magnificent city of Prague.Thank you Lobkowicz Palace staff and curators for providing me with this unforgettable experience.

Missed opportunity at the Palace. Our friends took the additional tour and after hearing their story, we were very sorry we missed this. We enjoyed the outside tour and sights, but the extra was soooo good, we were a little upset we missed out. We did get the guide book!

Lovely place to visit. We really enjoyed our visit to the Lobkowicz Palace. The museum was extremely interesting. It had an amazing number of artworks, manuscripts, china and other items belonging to the family. The history of how the Lobkowicz family had lost all their possessions to the Nazis and then to the Communists, but then had them restored to them was intriguing. We then attended the lunchtime concert, consisting of really excellent performers consisting of a flautist, viola player and pianist. The concert was performed with great panache and was of an extremely high standard. I would suggest paying slightly more for one of the front row seats as they are more comfortable than the seats further back.

Please come to this amazing collection and support this family.. The story and travails of the family's recovery of art and histroy from the ravages of war and occupation is inspiring and worthy of your time. Collections are varied from art to musical instruments and arms. Emphasis of the collection is how much this family has contributed to music and art since the 16th century. This is an education on how important Prague has been to western culture for many years. They were sponsiors of Mozart and Beethoven The Lobkowicz family is still struggling to recover from the devastation and cultural "cleansing' of 1939 to 1989. If you can join a sponsored luncheon and concert it is well worth your time. Good Czech cuisine.

Lobkowicz Palace. An unplanned, unexpected treat. The audio tour narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family brought the exhibits to life. They are proud of their heritage and the preservation efforts are amazing. Highly recommend this tour to gain a different perspective on European history.
Worth seeing if you can get in. I attended a private dinner. The food was good and it was interesting to see. The view is super but be prepared for many steps.
overall dissappointed. Museum was uncomfortably hot. I appreciated learning about the Lobkowicz family but didn't expect that it would be the primary focus. Room after room of family portraits.

A fascinating story of one of the most influential families in Czech history. Although its located in Prague Castle you will need to purchase separate entry tickets. But this gives you access to the wonderful private collection of the family. The history and the significance of the items displayed is well documented and the audio guide is narrated by a member of the family. This describes how the family gained economic and political power over the centuries, but had to flee the Czech Republic twice, once in 1939 and then again in 1948. It contains original musical scores by Beethoven, Sevres and Meissen porcelain and Valasquez portraits. Lunchtime classical concerts are staged in the palace, again for an additional price.

Wonderful Historical Presentation. What makes this a wonderful museum is the personal perspective that is portrayed on the audio guide. As others have stated, it is wonderful for the American tourists. It's explanations are simple and just long enough to keep ones interest. It is located at the base of Prague Castle. The midday concert is a nice break. A cafe is also on site. Another plus is the somewhat peaceful tone, away from the swarms of tourists.

Stunning range and quality of exhibits collected and rescued by historic family. Located in the centre of Prague Castle (but separate venue entry tickets) the Lobkowicz Palace has a wonderfully curated collection in this privately owned palace. The history and the significance of the items on display is beautifully narrated on the audio guide by a member of the family who describes how the collection was built, lost and reassembled through wars and political uprisings. Original musical scores by Beethoven sit alongside amazing Sevres and Meissen porcelain and Valasquez portraits. The museum is a calm oasis after the bustle of the castle. There is a high quality cafe and I recommend sitting on the terrace for the view over Prague. Lunchtime concerts are staged in the palace, again a separate price which is quite high but in such a lovely venue it would be a holiday treat for lovers of classical music.

Unique story...exceptional concert, museum and lunch. The Prague Castle attracts most of the tourists, but the only privately owned building on the grounds with a separate fee is the Lobkowicz. We opted for the admission/concert combination and were delighted. The audio accompaniment to the museum tells a fascinating saga of treasure lost and regained. The chamber music was thrilling in an intimate pleasant room. And don't miss lunch at the Terrace Cafe which can be directly accessed without the entry fee. Most tourists seemed to pass by this treasure so it wasquiet and readily available.

For art and collection lovers. You should be really art and collection lover to visit this place. As this palace is in a private ownership, entrance fee is quite expensive and I unfortunately did not find it too interesting to pay it again. Most of the historical ceilings and walls were destroyed during comunism, so collections of Lobkowicz family are one of the only things to see plus unique view over Vltava river.

Escape from the crowds. When you visit Prague Castle you buy a ticket which allows you in to the various buildings ( Cathedral, Basilica, Golden Lane etc.) but this privately owned palace and gallery is not part of the castle visit although geographically it's next to Golden Lane.It's not expensive and an audio guide is included. See the Lobkowicz family history and the influence on it of European history, particularly during the last century with Nazi and then Communist occupations. Lots of artefacts to see; painting, ceramic, armour, weapons of all sorts and a spectacular building. Because it's a little off the beaten tourist track it's quiet too.
Wonderful Tour. The older buildings in Prague have been well preserved other time. The surrounding community is really beautiful.

Very well displayed relics of exceptional quality. A version of Handel's Messiah arranged by Mozart? An original of Beethoven's Eroica? A Bruegel that is astonishing. And, get this, not one but two Canaletto's! Of course there is also the "bird room" and the "dog room" which don't compare. But there are three things that make the Lobkowicz great: Not too many tourists, so a more peaceful and enjoyable visit than the castle venues which are insanely crowded and noisy; audio recording is included in the price, so you get context; and the displays are sensitively laid out with good lighting, much better than the haphazard mish mash of the Golden Lane.

Very nice plase to visit and the personal was pleasant with us. We went to the palace in raining day and passed for free (one day in the month is free but I am not sure which day betwwen 01.05-06.05. On the reception were 2 womans, very nice with us. Audio guide was excellent and made the extensive displays much more meaningful. Recommended. Have to go and see !

A fascinating history about the Lobkowicz family. This still family owned palace boast a lot of history about Prague, the family Lobkowicz and some famous musicians as Mozart and beethoven.After the great war in 1945, the family Lobkowicz had to reclaim the palace.The nurture it and gave it a fresh new start so visitors from all over the world can learn from their history.The palace is still used for special occasions and some very famous world citizens payed a visit.There's a nice museum shop and a lovely restaurant to enjoy either a sandwich or gourmet food.A must see when in Prague!

First-rate art and exhibits, with a presentation style tailored to Americans. The Lobkowica Palace within the castle complex is undoubtedly a must-see experience for tourists, especially American tourists. It must be the best-run museums in the city of Prague, and the reason is that one of the American-educated scions of the Lobkowica family is in charge of it. Everything having to do with lay-out and presentation of information reveals the most careful planning and logic. Of course that means there is a charming museum shop and a good place to eat. Aside from that, the museum contains art of the highest quality that is essentially unknown to art lovers in western Europe and North American, including masterpieces by Breughel and Canaletto. For music lovers, the connection of the Lobkowicz family to Mozart and Beethoven is fully explained in fascinating ways.

Fascinating. Decided to take a trip found the palace and used the audio guide which is a must. As is the panoramic view . We spent a couple of hours on this trip and lived every minute of it. The audio Gide is the family describing what your looking at and explaining as well . Well worth the time and money

Best of Prague. In an overly crowded touristy area Lobkowicz Palace provided a fresh, open feeling for the tourist. No huge crowds.... Apparently most people miss the charm of this beautiful palace and overlook its significance in the relationship to art and music. The six of us are very glad to have been there and to have seen the room devoted to Mozart, Beethoven, and classical music.

Actually very good!. Went to the palace right on opening time and had a deserted palace to visit. Audio guide was excellent and made the extensive displays much more meaningful. Finished off with an early lunch at the adjoining palace cafe: also excellent. We came away feeling that the entry price was well worth it. Recommended.

Do NOT miss it!!!. The fates smiled upon us when our flight to leave Prague was cancelled and we needed to stay another day. We decided to go to the Lobkovicz Palace. The place is amazing. It houses a collection of the Lobkovicz royal family that survived confiscation by the Nazis, then by the Communist regime, and was restored to the family after the Velvet revolution in 1989. The collection includes many paintings, porcelain, armaments, musical instruments, etc. In the usic room are original scores by Mozart, Beethoven, and Haydn. (one of the Lobkowicz princes was a great patron of music and had Beethoven on a retainer, but didn't dictate what the composer should write. What he got was Beethoven's 3rd and 5th symphonies!) There are concerts every day at 1 pm. You can get tickets for the concert for an additional 100CK added on to the ticket price of 590 CK. The museum has an excellent audio guide narrated by one of the family of Lobkowicz. It took us nearly 2 hrs to see everything, we had a quick break, then the concert. (1 hr.) There is an adjacent cafe that was decent. Open daily from 10 am to 6 pm. The story of this family and the beauty and breadth of the collection was amazing.

Engaging history, cultural treasures, and beautiful music. Classical music lovers will enjoy the daily 1p concert (flute, viola, piano) in this historic palace that was finally returned to the Lobkowicz family after 40 years of Nazi and Communist rule. Before or after the concert, tour the palace using the excellent audio guide to see the family's collections including original Beethoven manuscripts, art works, and much more. Lunch on the onsite café terrace provides incredible views over Prague.

Museum, Midday Concert, Cafe. Lobkowicz Palace is located in the Prague Castle across from the Golden Lane. We toured the castle and then ended here for the 1pm concert and museum which features the original manuscripts of Beethoven's Fourth an Fifth symphonies. The Lobkowicz's were Beethoven's patron. The concert was very nice and had a wonderful selection of music. There was a pianist, flutist, and violinist. We also had a late lunch at the cafe which was wonderful but only if you can get a balcony table. This is a great outing and I highly recommend.

Lobkowicz palace in Prague. Our tour had arranged for dinner in the palace and afterwards we had an opportunity to walk through the family collection of art work, documents and instruments. We were unable to spend much time because we had to get back to our hotel for an early departure the next day

History found. We were stunned by what we did not know about this wonderful family. Their history is absolutely a story tht needs to be told. From the treasure trove of musical instruments, scores penned by Motzart and Bethoven, to a family torn by politics and war,

Surprisingly Wonderful. We went there right after visiting Castle Square in Prague. We got the Audio guide, of course, and thoroughly enjoyed our tour. We had no idea it would be so great. The audio guide was fantastic, easy to listen to and the exhibit was out of this world. The story of the family is astounding and all the pieces they have collected since they got their properties back were so interesting. Original Beethoven writing!We ended up having lunch there as well with a view of Prague. Highly recommend.

Where else can you see Beethoven's signature. Wonderful palace as you are walking down from the cathedral. Great views of the city. Even better if you play extra for the Panorama tour. The audio guide is excellent and very personal, narrated by one of the family members. To me the most exciting items were the musical scores of Hayden, Mozart and Beethoven. There was Beethoven's signature on the score of symphony #3.

No Place Like It. On a bright day, there is no place in the city quite like it. The gardens are pretty, there is also a trail to walk down through the trees. Also there are lovely restaurants alone the street that have decks with a view.

Fantastic building and Museum. We went with a private party and had lunch and a concert as part of the visit. We were shown around the magnificent building and saw several private rooms.The real gem of the visit is the museum however. There are displays of pictures, decorative arts, porcelain, priceless musical manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart, Musical instruments, hunting and shooting, all part of the Family Collection which goes back to the 16th century. There is a superb audio discription which is personally spoken by the family, which tells of the history of the family and the museum collection. This explains how the family lost everything twice, and yet got it back.

" Excellent ". You have to visit this Palace to understand the History of Czech Republic, especially Prague and it famous people. The Palace is well maintained and during the tour of the palace rooms you can see the personal items belonging to the family over the years. It was very interesting and some of the paintings and ornaments etc. were stunning. The Palace is an attractive part of Prague Castle.

Good to visit. To understand the history of Prague and its famous people, you should visit this house. After your tour, you may have a coffee inside the garden of this house. I impressed original documents inside.

A warm welcome at a lovely family home. We were invited to lunch at the palace as an extra excursion from our Viking cruise. We had an excellent lunch in a very comfortable and well appointed dining room with a guide to explain about the special items in the palace collection.After lunch we went up to the balcony outside the main reception room to see the magnificent views over the city followed by a small concert. After that we took the self-guided tour of the palace rooms to see the personal items belonging to the family over the years. It was very interesting and some of the paintings and ornaments etc. were stunning. They were all beautifully displayed, especially the musical instruments and scores by Mozart and Beethoven. We were made most welcome and had a great afternoon. The palace is a particularly attractive part of Prague Castle.
Headset guide tour. wonderful time to walk around. The history was narrated by using headset guide so a lot of great story absorbed. Need hours to explore it

Canalettos and panoramic balcony were the highlight of our trip. Thought this might be good and we were not disappointed. We were lucky enough to get a table for lunch with a fabulous view over Prague. We then took the audio tour including the panoramic balcony which we enjoyed enormously. Very informative and very well done! We flitted around the highlights of the gallery and were lucky enough to get the two Canalettos of London all to ourselves for quite a long time. My wife is the art buff but for me, the whole trip to Prague would have been worth it just to see those. Absolutely stupendous,. We felt very privileged. Thank you.

Beethoven and Mozart original scores!. There is a great 1 hour self-guided tour with audio guide. The story of the Lobkowicz family is interesting and there is a nice display of antique string instruments and, of course, the musical scores. We enjoyed this a lot

A Great Castle and History tour. We had a castle tour, concert, and lunch after a 3 hour long walking tour of Prague. It was well worth it; the lunch was great along with the beer that went with it. The concert was about a 30 minute concert with a trio of strings and piano. The tour was great in that it showed the history of the family and its impact on history and even today. One of the families Princes was Beethoven's benefactor which allowed him to work on composing which resulted in many of his great works.
Don't Miss It. Room after room of treasures beautifully displayed with one of the best audio guides I have every used. Highly recommended.

So so. The time I visited the museum they had a wedding going on on the 1st floor, so only the 2nd one was open (yet, the price of the ticket remained the same). The ladies tried to be helpful, so they offered, that I can come the next day to see the 1st floor - well, I appreciate that, but it would be better, of they simply close the museum, if the entire level is unavailable. I didn't take me a lot of time to go through the 2nd floor. What I liked the most was the manuscripts of Beethoven, apart from that, I found the exhibition rather average. But maybe it's because I couldn't fully enjoy the palace that day. The audiobook was very good, though.

Beuatiful as ever!. I have been here several times over the years and always like to revisit. The palace continues to be refurbished and looks beautiful now. My first visit was in 1974 so there have been lots of changes. Go outside the wall at the back of the complex to see the artisan shops. They are a treat!

Nice place. We went to this palace for the concert and the visit of the family museum. The concert venue in the music salon was excellent. And the mudicians were good. Ditto for the selections. The cafe was crowded, service slow. Food ok. But the views from the terrace were superb and make up for the rest. As for the museum, it was I crowded, staff were gracious and accommodating. Without the (free) audio guide, one could gloss over the rest, concentrate on the Velasquez, Breughel and Canalettos of London. But we very much appreciated the quality of the narration and also hearing of the family history. Great way to spend the afternoon

Absolutely Fabulous. Palace was a bit hard to find but we were so glad we persevered. Took an audio tour and went to an afternoon concert. Both were excellent and well worth the effort to find the place.

Interesting Building - but skip any included meal. We visited the place as part of a tour. The gallery is interesting and family history one of real dedication to homeland and ancestry. The Lobkowicz family were expelled from their property by the Nazis and returned after WW2 only to be re-possessed when Hungary became part of the Communist Bloc. Maximilian Lobkowicz returned from the States to set up the property as we see it now. It's a story of wealth and property accumulated over the centuries which is documented in the Gallery of paintings and artefacts.Our tour included a luncheon and concert. The lunch included a meagre salad, cold goulash and tasteless dumplings. The concert was by a trio the members of which seemed bored and the playing quite mediocre. IF you can, see the Palace without the lunch and concert.

History buffs will love!. I found this place so interesting. The Lobkowicz family lost everything twice, once to the Nazis and once to the Communists and were able to get it all back twice. They have a great collection and a great and interesting history. It was not too expensive and narrated by the family members.

Interesting and Informative. Self guided recorded tour that shares information about the Lobkowicz family and their art collection. Their story is most interesting and display worth seeing. Would recommend if you are in Prague.
Beautiful collection and family history. Beautiful collection and family history. Mainly portraits of the family and their ancestral history but beautiful and well explained with their audio guides.

Lobkowicz Palace. The only privately owned section of the Prague Castle - the Lobkowicz Palace offers great exhibit of private art collection of the Lobkowicz aristocratic family. Using the audio guide you get to learn not only about the beautiful art collection but also about the interesting family life story. Some of the admissions include also little classical music concert. After your visit of the art gallery you can enjoy refreshment in the Cafe with beautiful views of the city.

Unbelievable audio tour. This is an absolute must-see if you go to Prague. It is incredible how connected the Lobkowicz family is to many crucial parts of history, and the audio tour is incredible at conveying this information (spoken by members of the Lobkowicz palace themselves!) This was the highlight of Prague for me

Nice guide and palace!. We were not impressed but we didn't feel bored either. The armory room was very intresting. If you want to get to the veranda, you have to pay an extra ticket and use a new guide machine.
wow. great collection of art, renaissance paintings, nice collection of china, Beethoven & Mozart´s manuscripts, very unique experience

Audio tour narrated by the owner!. I learned so much about the occupation of Prague by the Nazis and the Russians and the repatriation process. Each room contained a different segment of the family's collections such as musical instruments, porcelain and china.

Gorgeous palace, very interesting tour. We walked up to this palace in the pouring rain but it was well worth it! The tour itself is really interesting, but it was the palace itself that made it. The paintings and antiques on display were beautiful. It was great to hear the history of the family that lived here. Highly recommend a trip here!
Excellent collection. The palace contains an outstanding collection of Hapsburg era art and crafts. It is discounted on the Prague card and worth your time.

Terrific private historical collection. Lobkowicz Palace, located in the Prague Castle complex, is privately owned and has unique collections of artifacts that are museum quality. Very interesting self guided tour.

When in Prague you must visit if you love history. . Fabulous and beautiful. Hire the audio handset worth every penny. It explains the history of this beautiful palace and it's contents. This one of my favourite places. If you love classical music treat your self to a lunch time 1hour concert in this stunning palace.

Such history in this Palace! A must see!. This was one of our favorite places to visit. My husband, being a music buff, was very surprised with the instruments and music sheets from Mozart, Beethoven. The self guided audio tour was narrated by Lobkowicz family and was very informative! A must see!
Well organized and interesting. Try to get a private presentation to first understand the importance and enduring nature of the family and their palace. The audio tour is good, though.

Definitely worth a visit and especially the Panorama tour. Took a tour of the palace which was absolutely wonderful. So much history, paintings, manuscripts from Mozart, Beethoven, etc. Finished with the Panorama Tour from the balcony overlooking the entire city. An audio tour with 16 or 17 different topics, short and to the point, told by the Lobkowicz family and with great music in the background. The best part was you just had to stand there and admire the different sections of the city without really moving. This was a fantastic overview of the entire city from a great viewpoint.

Wonderful surprise. The palace is sublime, the music heard was magical and we even met the prince! However the surprise for us was the unbelievable selection of artwork and the original Beethoven's 5th and 3rd symphonies with handwritten notations as well as many other priceless musical artifacts. We were moved not only by seeing all of the art and musical treasures but by hearing the story of how the Lobkowicz family lost all of this under different regimes and were able to reclaim it. After the war the family lived in Boston and after the fall of the Communists they were able to reclaim this fabulous treasure. As the palace is open for concerts, don't miss this. This was a wonderful experience in Prague.

Nice place. We visited the museum even though we first wanted to visit the Castle, but there were too many people at that time. There is an audio guide in English and some different languages. Even though you learn many things about Lobkowicz family history, I would have expect to see many more during the visit. I think the only thing that got my attention was the armory room. We had to end the tour without visiting the last two rooms, because the rooms were closed for a private tour, but nobody told us until we got there. And it was also forbidden to go out to the balcony where the view is great, because of that private tour. I think that is not nice at all, since I pay like everybody else.

Special Place to Visit. After visiting the Prague castle and the Cathedral, don't miss to stop by the Lobkowicz Palace. Visit the museum, understand the history of the owners, and finish at the cafe to drink a local beer or a tea enjoying the magnificent view.

Privately owned and beautiful.. This palace was so lovely to visit. It is the last part of the castle and very well kept. We also bought tickets for a one hour concert at noon which was very nice. After the tour we ate in the lobkowicz Cafe and had fabulous potato soup. They provided blankets and a heater since it was a bit cool on the balcony.

Castle Visit Must Do!. Excellent history lesson involving the Lobkowicz family, with good audio interpretation, something fascinating in every room. Curators could smile a bit more, but then I suppose they get bored. Not really a children's visit this one, more stimulating for the post teenage mind unless you are a serious student of history.

First editions and original scores. Much of the well-presented collection is portraits of the andestral family and the decor of the palace's rooms.For me, studying music, the best room was that devoted to music. (The Lobkowicz family were active musicians and very active supporters of composers, and in particular, Beethoven. The display includes some original scores and a number of first editions of works by Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven. Many of them are pieces that I have studied in the past year. For example, I know that Haydn's Op. 76 string quartets were commissioned as a set of 6. This was 7-8 years before his death but he lacked enough energy to complete more than one (if memory serves me correctly ) and reluctantly published that and another one comprising the inner movements when he realised that he was never going to have the energy again to complete them. So it was a bit emotional for me, not that I expect anyone else to see those scores as mildly interesting.

Very interesting family collection. Very interesting family history and collection of items in the castle area. Audio guide in english is excellent. Definitely worth visit as this place puts many castle exhibitions to shame.

The highlight of our trip to Europe.. We wandered the halls with an audio guide and thus, were escorted by generations of the Lobkowicz family hearing their stories. At the end we went into a beautiful room and were treated to a brief concert. All magical.

Small, but perfectly formed.. A small museum, but full of unexpected delights. The artwork and artefacts are curated well, and displayed sensitively. Not too big, nor too small, it passed a pleasant hour - with another pleasant hour listening to the lunchtime concert. Enjoy, we did.
Brilliant . A wonderful selection of art and relics of history, presented in an intellectual yet accessible way. The audio guide is by far the best I have ever used. Wonderful.

Lobkowicz history. Great palace. Fully recovered. Audio gide is availabe. Without it visit would be probably boaring. Owners' story and passion about this story makes the tour exited. Much better experience than Prague Castle itself.

This is what a museum should be!. I love well thought out and well presented museums, with lots of interesting collections, and this is just perfect. The audio guide is as interesting as all of the other reviewers have commented, it gives a really great background and history and made me wish I had another few days to visit some of the other Lobkowicz's residences near Prague.The collections contain beautiful artwork, ceramics, instruments and guns and I think most anyone will enjoy it, even those that normally consider museums a bit 'dry'.I would make this a top priority during a trip to Prague, definitely try to include it when you visit the castle!

Remarkable collection, a pleasure to visit. If you are interested in history and/or art, this palace can be fully explored in the space of an hour, allowing you a chance to view remarkable art by Velazquez, Bruegel or Canaletto, and learn about the past four hundred years of czech history as told by the chronicle of one of the country's most prominent aristocratic dynasties. The admission ticket includes a free audioguide, which takes you through the palace's collections and rooms and through its owners' history as told by the contemporary family members. In my opinion, the audioguide truly enhances the experience, but the pieces on the collection are worth the visit by themselves (for example original scores by Mozart, Beethoven, weapons, musical instruments, porcelain, etc.). In addition to the tour you can purchase a concert add-on which consists of a 1hr chamber music concert. Whilst sone of the performers might not be master performers, some of them are quite good (for example, the viola player) and the concert played in an original baroque setting makes the visit more worthwhile. The prices are quite reasonable and you can easily locate the palace since it is right at the beginning of the castle complex on the golden lane side. Definitely an interesting visit.

Prague Inspires Panorama. This is a half hour tour of the city. You don't have to get on a bus. You don't have to be pushed around by tour guides. Instead this tour introduced us to dozens of Pragues most important sites- From the balcony of the Lobkowicz Palace - with an audio guide and an incredible view of all of Prague- this half hour tour helped us understand a bit of history and where many of the sites were and their significance. Once we had a sense of the area we were able to plan the day trips we wanted to make- really helpful. The palace itself is amazing! The food at the cafe delicious. Check out the stunning stain glass in the church. But start with the audio tour- worth the time.

Top of the hill and the attractions. . A wide variety of exhibits which are pretty interesting but he star is the palace itself and getting an understanding of the Czech history. A bit hard going with young children but worth it. Don't miss the expensive cafe with great food and views.

Classical music + Amazing museum. The Czech Republic has had a somewhat checkered history over the last century and nowhere is this better expressed than in the story of the Lobkowicz family. The museum itself is spread over two floors, and you need the audio tour in order to fully appreciate this. The English version is narrated by the current generation of Lobkowicz's (which takes some getting used to due to their American upbringing and hence accents) but has huge amounts of interesting details included. If you head there before 1300 local, there is normally a concert on the weekdays; this costs substantially more (it cost us 1000Kr for the concert and museum); as fans of classical, we decided that it was worth the cost. The musicians were of a good standard and the pieces typically well performed. Given they were arranged for limited instruments, it worked quite well! I wouldn't recommend it to everyone, but if classical music is your thing, I'd recommend it.
Absolutely stunning!. This is a must see when in Prague. The beauty of the palace is unbelievable. While we were there we had a wonderful luncheon and then a private concert. Unforgettable.

worth the walk. This was educational. The story was narrated, about all the history, by a great headset-self-guided tour. A lot of history to absorb. The building was a long walk from the castle, so allow plenty of time to get there.

2 floors and worth every cent!. The Lobkowicz family treasures are stored here. One of the interesting details you can find out is the fact that they were a patron of Beethoven. Some of his famous symphonies is dedicated to prince Joseph.

Most informative ands personal tour in Prague. This is a must-do. William Lobkowicz, who would be a Prince and the wealthiest man in Czech Republic before titles were abolished and the Nazis and Communists stole the family property, gives a very personal audio-tour of his family's history, which is basically the history of Czech Republic. Priceless art and artifacts, wonderfully displayed and described in this beautiful palace near Prague Castle. I suggest this be one of your first stops in Prague, as it lays the foundation for so much else of what you will see.
Worth the walk. Fantastic place to visit, a street market adds to the buzz. Loads to see and shady trees and spots to sit and take in the views. A great place to look at Prague from.
Perfect setting for a Classical Concert. It was such a privilege to hear classical music played in such a beautiful setting. It was very special

Personal family story illuminates history. Today was Monday so most museums were closed, but fortunately not this one. While I didn't initially want the audio guide, it was free and actually very insightful. I found following this family helped me understand a little more about this country's complicated history with the Holy Roman Empire and the Hapsburgs. It's amazing that the current generation has taken on the task of maintaining and curating much of their holdings. A nice cafe and gift shop completed my visit.

Lunch time concert followed by a tour of this palace. With our with out the lunch time concert this Place/museum is a very good place to visit. With the entrance come a Audio Guild that talkes you through the history of the Palace and the Lobkowicz family. Very emotional in how the family last every thing twice and regained it twice. Verry emotional on how commumism took every thing away and then the family magaged to get back in 2009.

Very Nice, Varied Collection. Located in the Prague Castle complex, this museum has a separate but rather reasonable admission charge. Do use the audio guide, as it is very informative and well presented by members of the Lobkowicz family. The collection consists of art, instruments, arms, and other valuable possessions from the family collection, all nicely conserved and displayed. The family has had much historical influence, and you do indeed take away a sense of this from touring the museum. There is much to see, but you can cover it nicely in a little more than an hour thanks to the audio guide.
