Beautiful. Very beautiful place. Midday concert was very nice. After the concert you can walk around the palace and enjoy the beautiful painting.
Lovely tour through the histiry of this family. What a lovely find! Beautiful art collection and a very good audio tour. Great insight of the history from this family's point of view.

Amazing. Really enjoyed our tour. It is so impressive when a guide is speaking in a second language and can actually be really funny. She made the tour informative and enjoyable. The highlight was having a wine tasting in the cellar. Bathe wines are delicious and the ambience was second to none.

Go to the correct palace!. I stayed in the prague castle area and asked directions to lobkowicz palace. Everybody pointed me to the german embassy, which turns out also to also have been a lobkowicz palace in prague! But you can't visit this palace. A nice gentleman who works at the embassy pointed me in the correct direction. The palace which is visitable for tourists is located behind the saint vitus church. Opposite the visitable lobkowicz palace there is a toy museum. So those things might be helpful to point out when asking for directions. The palace itself is not too big and can be finished within an hour - hour and a half if you listen to the audio guide (which I highly recommend). There is a discount price for students so be sure to ask for that. They are also willing to store your jacket and bag if you'd like in a closed room for no extra charge. If you have seen all the major attractions, then this should definitely be the next thing on your list
Fabulous private museum. If you have a chance tour the private museum. We got to see an original Beethoven manuscript. History of how the family got their belongings restored to them memorable.

Wonderful collection and Great cafe. We spent the greatest afternoon at this castle. We started with a delicious lunch at the cafe with a splendid view of Prague, the Ceasar salade was large but great! The audio tours were very well though out and made the collection much more memorable. Several interesting pieces and very interesting history of the Lobkowicz family. Over a great trip for the whole family and wonderful afternoon!!

A piece of old aristocracy. Amazingly the Palace and its collection survived the communism and were returned to the owners family!Very much worth a visit. A very good collection including Rubens, Canaletto and Pieter Breughel the Elder which my wife and I admire (and we were surprised and happy to see his "Haymaking" - a fourth part of the series of six of which three we saw in Vienna just a few days before. The fifth is in the Metropolitan in NYC and we were lucky to see it 20 years earlier! The sixth painting is believed to be lost. Alas!So do not even hesitate and visit. By the way it is the only private building of the whole Prazsky Hrad (Castle).
Beautiful Palace. It is definitely a must see attraction when visiting Prague and the view when there is absolutely worth the trip

Not just another palace. The history of how the Palace was taken over by the Nazis and then the Communists and how it was reclaimed was very interesting. The Beethoven scores and paintings particularly the Brueghel made for a very memorable and special visit.
Beautiful gardens!. The gardens are amazing, and so is the architecture. Beautiful views of Prague, specially in the afternoon. Very charming.

A wonderful visit of the castle. Lobkowicz Palace is in the grounds of Prague Castle and consists of a museum, small concert hall where daily concerts are held and a cafe. This place was one of my favourite places in Prague. Though the palace is beautiful to wander around, the audio tour, combined with the background music is worth the money itself, not to mention some of the amazing artefacts that are in the museum, from paintings to music scores and instruments and weaponry. A midday concert is also held, with works by composers like Dvorak, Smetana, Mozart and Bach being played. The cafe also offers decent food, with small dishes like soups, cakes etc being served. If you are in the Old Town area/Prague Castle, do not miss this place.

Awesome, intimate unexpected experience. We purely went by the high ratings but both of us were super impressed by the experience. The audio guide (a must) is narrated by the patriarch of the family and the stories are incredibly personalized. It's like you're a guest in the family house and get told what has happened. And that's a lot ! With over 6 centuries of family history laid out you can't help but be impressed with the colossal task the current generation has taken on to restore and maintain the rich cultural heritage of this family. My personal favorite was learning how the 6th prince financed Beethoven that led to the 5th symphony and other well known pieces being composed by him, later honoring the prince by dedicating them to him.

Exceptional palace, music, audiotour, and lunch overlooking Prague. Lobkowicz Palace was the highlight of our visit to Prague. Of the many places to go in Prague Castle, this was our favorite. We've recommended it to family and friends since and all have the same great experience. Arrive in the morning to explore the Palace with the audio tour, then have lunch or a snack and see the spectacular view of the city. Stay for the free concert in one of the beautiful rooms of the Palace. It was the highpoint of our time in Prague.

Delightful Concert. Located in the Prague Castle complex, a museum and concert hall. The palace itself is very pretty, and the museum extensive, although very heavy on portraits which are not my favorite. The audio tour was very good. We made it to the castle and palace to catch the Midday Concert, which was just delightful. A piano, flute and viola trio that showed exemplary skill (as I have found in all of my Prague concerts). If you ask my wife, the highlight of the tour was the café, where we got coffee and tea, and a wonderful chocolate cake. It was REALLY good!

The history of a family. Step out of the chaos of the tourists and into the peaceful (and relatively empty) Lobkowicz Palace. The history of the Lobkowicz family is rich and fascinating. The proud yet humble narration is done by the current head of the Lobkowicz family. Whether you are interested in historic homes, a Beethoven sponsor, or local history, this tour has something for you. Take in the views of Old Town.Stop by the attached Lobkowicz cafe for a lovely lunch.

Wonderful place. I highly recommend visiting the Lobkowicz Palace. It is an unbelievable place for history and architecture lovers. We were offered a free guide at the entrance, so we were able to listen to the stories behind the exhibits, spoken by a member of the Lobkowicz family. It was one of my favorite museums in Prague and I would definitely return there.

Narration is excellent and view is beautiful . What a delightful tour. My favorite was the original works by Beethoven that was a dedication to the family. Interesting history and well worth the visit. Make a trip to the bathroom as on the way there are many portraits of famous people who visited this castle or one of the others. I saw a afternoon concert tin the castle that was just beautiful.

Between Beethoven and Velazquez. Lobkowicz Palace is a relatively small castle, but it keeps several precious manuscripts like these of Beethoven' 3rd and 5th symphonies and for my pleasant surprise two paintings by Canaletto and one attributed to Velazquez - famous Infanta Margarita Teresa. Midday concert was pleasant - I couldn't get out of my head "Vltava"by Smetana. Buying a combo ticket (concert+ access to museum) brings 10 or 20 % discount for a lovely Lobkowicz Café with delicious food and nice panoramic views.

What a treat of an experience!. We booked at the Lobkowicz Palace mainly to see the "midday concert" but the ticket includes access to the museum.The concert was amazing - viola, flute and piano. All members of the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra I believe.Contrary to our expectations, the museum visit afterwards was at least as good as the wonderful hour we had just spent listening to live classical music.The Lobkowicz family history is most interesting and the museum is so well put together in terms of access, viewing and listening to a recording as you walk around. Really brilliant!! The narration is mostly done by a (great?) grandson of the patriarch that was forced to leave the country and all his estates and wealth. In total he lost and regained everything three times. A fascinating account.Our best attraction visit on this trip to Prague.

What a great story behind this palace!. I visited the museum and also took in a lovely noon time concert. Both were beautiful Everything was in English and there was even a lovely little cafe to have a coffee and apple strudel. I would highly recommend this site. It was not so crowded that you could not enjoy everything.

Great piece of history!. We toured between Christmas and New Years with a private tour. The palace gives you a real bit of insight into how royalty and the privileged lived back through the ages. Their particular story makes the visit more enchanting. The music room was my favorite spot seeing first hand manuscripts from Mozart, Hayden and Beethoven. The art is great as it takes you through the family history via portraits and classic pieces as well. Definitely worth a stop especially as a break from the very hectic Palace grounds tour.

Amazing art collection. A must go place for everyone who loves fine arts. Famous paintings, beautiful artworks, breathtaking fine art collection from the beginning of the Lobkowitz family's history to recent times, with amazing, classical music covered acoustic guide, provided by Prince Lobkowitz and his family.
Must see!. A delight in the midst of all commercialism which ruins Prague. Elegant palace, lovely audio, no crowded masses. Worth of price.

Great way to see how the aristocracy lived. This is a privately owned home that is open to the public. The home was confiscated from the Lobkowicz family during WWII and returned after the Velvet Revolution. The palace tour has a great audioguide that is narrated by the American born Prince and his family. We actually ran into the Prince while visiting and he was very friendly and welcoming. This was a fun way to spend a few hours while touring the Castle Hill area.

Do Not Miss the Lobkowicz Museum. The museum is located just below the main Prague Castle complex and is a small, private operation. The building itself is lovely but what made it special was the audio tour (included in the admission price) by members of the family. The story of the family is very personal and the art is excellent. We were blown away by the music rooms and the amazing things inside (no spoilers!). Do not miss this place!

Beautiful building, well worth a visit.. A visit to the Palace is well worth the trouble. Be careful when approaching it because it is very hilly one side and there are many steep steps to climb if you go in the wrong way. The actual palace is very Grand, and is only open once a year to visitors. Still worth the trip to view it.
Beautiful palace. A very impressing palace with very elegant architecture. I loved observing the magnificent details of this iconic building.

A must see in Prague. Touring the Lobkowicz Palace was a highlight of our trip to Prague. It’s located in the Castle complex just down the hill from the Cathedral. The building itself is interesting but what’s inside is the fascinating story of the Lobkowicz family – how they made their fortune, lost it twice and gained back what they could. Through the family story, we learned a lot about Czech history too. Be sure to listen to the museum’s audio guide. Through it William Lobkowicz tells his family history through the museum’s vast, quite varied and very interesting paintings, sculpture, jewelry, collection of antique guns, musical scores, musical instruments and more. All of this is part of the Lobkowicz family collection. Also, the staff at the museum is quite helpful. They pointed out the most interesting items to see and made sure we saw all the stops on the audio tour. The Lobkowicz Palace is quite amazing and shouldn’t be missed when visiting Prague.

Small but personal . I really liked this museum. It's a private museum, so you'll have to buy tickets at the palace itself instead of at the Castle ticket office, but it's really worth it. The audio tours makes it very personal; the current prince tells you about the history of the family and the things and paintings you see. All in all a couple of hours well spent.
Lovely palace. Part o fthe main castle complex so if you visit the castle area you can take the option to visit the palace itself a really nice museum and well worth a visit on a cold or rainy day

One of the best museum experiences possible.. I have just returned from a really lovely afternoon at this museum. I started with the 1pm concert and then toured the museum with, as others have described, the absolutely delightful audio guide (I felt like sitting in the cafe and just playing the audio through for a second time!). It's a lovely journey through the family history of treasures lost and gained, not once but twice. There are some amazing items on display and enough diversity to appeal everyone's interests without anything being overwhelming.The museum is small, intimate, uncrowded and very friendly. While I was there a woman was taking photos where she shouldn't have been - there was no loud admonishment- just a friendly smile and a reminder that no photos were allowed. Lovely experience.

Great ambiance and excellent audioguide!. During a visit in Prague with my boyfriend in November 2015 we visited the Lobkowitz Palace. We are both arts historians and were simply impressed about the large collection of artefacts, musical instruments, partitires and weapons from all over Europe the Lobkowitz Family still preserves and exposes in the palace Museum. It is excellently restored and curated and you may observe the exposition's objects very closely. I recommend this place to everyone who bears interest for arts and political history especially concerning rather lesser known dynasties of nobles. The audioguides are underpinned with classical music and informative explanations on the majority of key-points given by Prince Lobkowitz himself and by the curator's of the exposition in excellent English! Simply praiseworthy! :D

Interesting interior, but the library is OOB. The building is part of the greater Prague castle complex, but a little way from the main buildings. The interiors has some very traditional interiors, the library is particularly nice, but I could not enter it, just look from the hallway.
The best of the best. Well worth visiting at the end of the Castle visit. The museum art collection is fabulous and if you can - attend the lunchtime concert in the beautiful music room, a real treat

Great Museum. Of all of the sights in the castle complex, this was easily my favorite. This palace has a very interesting collection but what stood out to me was the audioguide. It is my favorite audioguide of any museum I have ever been to. I loved hearing the story of the family who owned the palace and discovering their journey through history. If you only have time for one attraction in the castle complex, this is the one.

Interesting museum. We took an audio tour of the museum within the palace and found it very personal (narrated by the family) and interesting. There’s a fair amount about the filmily history as you wander through their home and view the portraits, and then there are some wonderful musical exhibits: the original orchestra parts for Beethoven’s 5th and Eroica symphonies for example, and some scoring by Mozart. You are able out take photos on one floor of the building and the ceilings are well worth viewing. There were also two Canalettos to see. A great way to spend two hours.

Great place to spend an hour or two!. I start this off admiting that I popped in here the end of November more looking for a warm place to warm up than initially for the sights. I was so happy I did! The audio guide was excellent - really gave a flavor for the history with humor and insight without being dry and stuffy as so many audio guides were. The front desk staff was very gracious and found a place for all my bundles and heavy jacket. I would recommend this for anyone looking for a really interesting place within the castle complex to get a great understanding not only for the history of the Czech Republic but also for a more intimate understanding of how the Communist takeover really affected the people.

Not worth the price we paid. We were disappointed that it was a self-guide tour with a voice box, when our travel agent had said that we would be getting a guided tour. Best part of the Palace was the armoury & music rooms. Lunch was OK, but nothing special. Not worth the price we paid.

Interesting place to visit. The audio program that accompanies a tour of this palace is really interesting and is narrated by family members who have been responsible for its restoration. At 1 pm there is a classical concert by very talented musicians that is well worth experiencing.

No visit to Prague would be complete without a tour of The Lobkowicz Palace. Let me repeat and emphasize. A group of friends and I had the pleasure of visiting the Lobkowicz Palace last week. As a seasoned traveler, I have often been underwhelmed by museum experiences that are too daunting in scale. In contrast the Lobkowitz Museum is small, intimate and highly personal. You are provided an amazing audio tour as part of the admission. Members of the Lobkowicz family will guide you through their fascinating history dating back centuries with their profound influence on European art, music, politics and history. The priceless collection of paintings, musical scores, firearms and more are brought into context through their flawless narratives. An abridged tour will take only an hour, but one could and should spend more. After our tour, we relaxed on the terrace of the museum cafe with a spectacular view of Prague and enjoyed a Lobkowicz beer, the brewery dating in origin to the 1500s, with perhaps the best burger in the City. Prague has much to offer the curious and discerning traveler. The Lobkowicz Palace is a highlight.
Excellent accessible gallery. Good selection of paintings collected by the family. palace and gallery are small enough to to be personal and not too daunting.

Who knew this would be so cool??. Our visit to the Lobkowicz Palace started as an afterthought. After spending much of the day touring St. Vitus Cathedral, the palace and dungeon, the Golden Lane, we stopped in because it was on our way and we had just enough time for it. We were very impressed with the personal story of the family, provided through a free audio guide narrated by two members of the Lobkowicz family. The personal touch made everything we saw so much more meaningful, as the portraits on the walls were those of someone's ancestors, and the stories were not only historical but enlightening as to personalities and politics. We found most striking the original scores of music in Beethoven's and Mozart's own hands, whose benefactor was one of the members of the Lobkowicz family. Then the 20th Century story of how the family lost everything to the Nazis, got it back, lost it once again after the Russian takeover, and began the long process of recovering its treasures after the Velvet Revolution was also quite fascinating and gives its own perspective on the recent history of the Czech Republic. Check for the midday classic concerts also, which make the classical music history of the palace and its inhabitants come alive. There's also a cafe with food and views way superior to what you'd expect at a regular tourist attraction. All in all, highly recommended.

A well restored residence. We had the pleasure of visiting Lobkowicz Palace as a side tour on our Prague visit. The restoration was superb, given the damages caused by the Nazis and the Communists. During the tour we were treated to a fine luncheon in the palace. Well worth the visit.

Great views. We had lunch at the palace with Viking River Cruises, very nice and great views of the city below. They are building the reputation of this palace and have many interesting pieces of history and art

History and nobility come alive. As part of our Viking tour we visited the palace. Included with the excursion was a lovely lunch followed by a brief concert performed by an amazing trio from Prague's national orchestra. Later we did a walk through the museum using an excellent audioguide. My favorite room was the music room which had on display many manuscripts from such musical greats as Mozart and Beethtoven. A must see when in Prague.

crème de la crème. This is without question the finest museum in Prague. It houses one of the most important Old Masters in private hands--Haymaking by Breughel, Original musical manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart, not to mention its arms collection, among many more things. I never use audio guides, but here that would be a mistake. The audio guide is very well done, succinct, and helpful in appreciating the collection. They also have a wonderful gift shop, and a cafe that is worth the trip in itself--the menu is fantastic and reasonably priced. If you visit Prague and don't see this wonderful palace, you have missed one of the key attractions of this magical city.

Spectacular building and amazing family history. Was able to visit here one evening on a recent trip and highly impressed with the beauty of the building as well as the extensive and interesting art collection. Highly recommend a visit here but check daytime offerings as mid-day musical concerts are offered and leave time to fully enjoy the art collection.

A bit overpriced, but.... Well restored, family owned smaller palace. The museum is interesting (narrated by its owner), the early afternoon concert...not so much...the cafe a bit overpriced, but the food is delicious (we had homemade tomato soup and a tuna melt that were super tasty). This palace and its owners have a great story to tell...It is worth your time.

Amazing view of Prague!. The family history is loaded with the art of great masters and musical masterpieces. Prince William has intimate family stories, including loss of the Palace to Nazis and recent restitution to the family. You are able to gaze at the weaponry, tableware and personnal love letters. Mozart penned Handel's "Messiah" here. Its possible you can enjoy a lunch in the family's original living quarters. This is a priviledged access tour that you will not forget.

Fabulous Palace. My husband and I took a private tour of the Castle and our tour guide recommended we visit Lobkowicz Palace. She even gave us discount tickets. The next day we went online and ended up booking the midday classic concert and tour. Booking online gave us the discount so we didn’t use the tickets but if it were not for that recommendation we may not have gone.We arrived just in time to check in and get front row seats for the concert. There were three musicians – a pianist, flutist and violinist. They played together and also separately. It was a very lovely concert. After that we got our audio guide and went on the tour. The audio guide was excellent and we really enjoyed hearing the Lobkowicz family story and seeing everything inside the palace. The Arms & Armor collection was very impressive! Seeing the actual Beethoven Manuscripts was really awesome. Since we are dog lovers we really enjoyed how the family pooches were also showcased in portraits. This was one of our favorite places we visited while in Prague. It would have been nice if we were allowed to take pictures.We thoroughly enjoyed our time there and if we return to Prague we would like to see the family castles as well.

We got the Prince's private tour.... Due to the Kismet of a choreographer friend who had relocated recently to Prague, we got a tour of this gorgeous edifice, and a feel for the plainclothes Prince and Princess.

Hidden gem. I wish I had spent more time at the Lobkowicz's Palace instead of the Castle. Here you can really a rich path to understand the wonderfuly displayed collection as well as the historic periods involved. The guy at the entrance was REALLY nice. Audioguide turned out to be essential: well done and never boring. We spent an amazing 1.5 hour there. Go and visit!

A magnificent art gallery. Lobkowicz Palace is a beautiful art gallery with an outstanding private art collection. We particularly enjoyed the Brueghel, Canaletto, and Cranach paintings. Check out the concert series, held in a small hall.

Fantastic visit. Loved touring the palace. The audio tour was part of the admission price and very informative. The music room with the original Beethoven and Handel music scores were the highlight for me and my husband.

An Interesting and Excellent Experience. The Lobkowicz Palace is a privately owned building in the Prague Castle complex housing the acclaimed Lobkowicz Collections and Museum. Admission is not included on any of the tickets you can buy for the castle tour but it is definitely worth the admission price in my opinion. Admission includes an audio guide which really adds to the experience. Family members talk you through the collections and their family history which is very interesting. The collection is well curated. The key pieces are highlighted with red numbers so if you are pressed for time on your visit to the castle complex a shorter visit is possible. The attraction also has a cafe with an outside terrace and great views of Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace is definitely high on our list of top attractions in Prague.

Fascanating. This is an excellent place to visit. Taking the audio tour is most interesting. It's a wonderful story with all the artefacts and paintings to see. Most interesting are original music scores with notes from Mozart and Beethoven. You will come away wanting to learn even more. A most pleasant surprise.

Palace & Dinner. Had the pleasure of listening to the owner give a lecture on how they got all there personnel belongings back and the entire family history. Also had the pleasure of dinner at the palace which I highly recommend if your in Prague go see this for yourself.

A real treat to visit.. We were part of a Viking River group that had enough people to have a private lunch, concert, and viewing here. I am very glad we did this extra excursion as it was definitely worth the cost.

This is definitely worth a visit. Despite the reviews, we decided to go and visit and were not disappointed - in fact, it was a great experience, coupled with the lunchtime concert. The audio service was really interesting - I cannot understand the negative comments at all. There is so much to see and so what if it all belongs to one family?!! Do go - it is one area which is not crowded!!

A Magnificent Space. The Lobkowicz Palace, according to the guide, is the largest palace by area in the world. One can believe it. It encompasses many buildings, including the offices of the President of the Czech Republic.The story of how the Lobkowicz family re-acquired the palace after the fall of communism in 1989 is fascinating.Make sure you tour the art collection, including the musical instruments and the manuscripts of Beethoven--great story there, too!
Worth a visit. Really nice building with lots of interesting artefacts on display, part of the Edinburgh Castle and a good part!

History is alive in this Palace. The current heir to the Lobkowicz fortune tells the story of his family, their loss of their property during WWII, recovery at the end of the war, and loss under communism. Their recovery of art objects includes the palace (amazing), some incredible paintings by artists that are also part of state collections, and musical literature/sheets that reflects the long patronage by members of the family of composers including Mozart and Beethoven. The narrative on the audio is clear, personal, and relevant. Our concierge recommended this visit -- however, it is really a must for anyone interested in art and the history of aristocratic families.
brilliant. Really well worth the visit. Amazing to see 1st edition of Haydn's Creation. Really wow factor. Well recommended if you're into classical music in particular

Classic Eastern European castle. This is a classic Eastern European castle, close to the Prague Castle. Loved the tour, the exhibits were fascinating, and the family story is intriguing! I would definitely like to go back again and spend more time here myself!

Amazing. Not to be missed, wonderful story, nice exhibits, so well managed, everyone was extremely polite, helpful and charming An overall positive experience. Great audio guide, check room, everything was perfect and well done.

Private residence adjacent to Prague Castle. After a tasty dinner in the banquet roomfollowed by a concert we freely toured two of the floors as part of a river cruise. There were some unique works of art and weapons in the collection.

Amazing tour of the palace and what a magnificant lunchtime concert. The audio tour was very informative and entertaining explaining the story of this influential family and their successes and tragedies. We all owe them for their patronage of the arts.It was a great escape from the hoards visiting the castle and the musicians were top end and it was a joy to be there in such a perfect location for the amazing music.The original manuscripts on show have been so instrumental on all of our lives.The food was just perfect with views to die for.

Amazing family story. Be sure to spend the time to read/hear about the family history of this palace. The current owner, an american, and his wife brought back the glory after the Nazis and Soviets departed. It houses a very interesting museum.

To Have Breughel, Canaletto and Cranach. An American owns this palace and the paintings. His family had to get it back twice, once from the Nazis and once from the Communists. It's a must-see, to me the best part of the castle complex. Canaletto's view of London and the Breughel season painting alone are worth the price of admission. Hint: there's a lot of walking, so bring your sturdy shoes.

Mostly minor works accompanied by an irritatingly self-aggrandizing narrative. This museum has about 5 significant pieces of art: two Canaletto paintings, one Breughel, and one each of an original Beethoven and Mozart score. All of these are significant and worth seeing. Beyond that, there is a significant number of second- and third-rate paintings of an aristocratic family going back centuries. There is also a fascinating (and irritatingly told) story behind the museum. I don't think it's worth the steep entry fee, but it's not a total bust, either. Several things about the museum undercut the experience. First, its layout is very traditional, with walls of paintings laid out with little imagination, virtually no interaction, and little care for creating a museum experience. Second, the audio tour requires headphones, meaning that you experience this museum solo, even if you go with friends or loved ones. At one point I took off my headphones and just observed the visitors, and it was absolute silence beyond the quiet shuffling of feet. But the most annoying thing that frustrated me was the self-aggrandizing and unreflective narrative. There is a moving story in this palace--one of an aristocratic family owning castles and great works of art, losing them first to the Nazis and then to the Communists, only to be recovered after the fall of the Iron Curtain and through legal maneuvering. So far so good. But the way the narrative is told is uncritically celebratory of the family prior to the Nazis--praising them for patronizing Beethoven with a beaming pride (that was MY ancestors!!) that redirected visitors' attention away from the public significance of these works and the history they were a part of and instead towards the family's private sense of vindication at getting all their stuff and accompanying status, stolen for half a century by bad guys, back. That this wealth was connected to colonialism, to the crushing servitude of God knows how many other Beethovens too poor let near a violin, to brutal wars of pride and power--is a story untold. Perhaps Lobkowicz's beloved ancestors were also bad guys--I don't know. But their recent photos posed with heads of state (including a bunch of the Bushes) suggests that their return to their righteous aristocracy is complete, and they may now once again stand above all of us and we may look up to them in admiration. And so between the underwhelming quality of most (but not all) of the art and the self-congratulatory historical narrative, my wife and I came away disappointed--it could have been so much more than this, and for the price of admission, should have been.

One of my favorite places in Prague!. Can I live here? I absolutely love this museum! I've visited several times, and recently was lucky enough to be part of a 'test group' for a new panoramic audio tour - a tour of Prague from one of the balconies of the Palace - fascinating! A magnificent Breughel, two extraordinary Canaletto paintings that you could stare at for hours, one of the best collections of musical manuscripts and instruments I've seen, even the gun collection (something for which I normally have very little interest) is amazing - and all in a comfortable, home-like atmosphere. Take the audio tour, for sure - and don't miss eating at the cafe - best food in the Castle district - and convenient if you're spending your day at the Castle!

Does the original manuscript of Beethoven 's entice you?. Me too. And Handel 's Messiah with Mozart ' s corrections. And amazing china. And a great, reasonably priced restaurant. And other cool stuff.

Loved the Story behind the Museum. We really enjoyed our visit here and learning about the story and history of this museum. The collection is wonderful. Also, they have classical music concerts here at lunch. We went to one and it was lovely. I would recommend this museum to anyone enjoying a day in the castle district. Don't miss it.

Unexpected Gem. We had heard of this palace from an acquaintance who is related to the Lobkowicz family. We decided to tour it when we went to the Castle. It was lovely - the audio tour was very interesting and the relationship between this family and musical history is fascinating. I would recommend visiting this while you are at the Prague Castle. Tickets are purchased right in this palace instead of with the Castle tours. They have an extensive collection of guns on display, as well, that were very interesting to look at.

Don't be fooled by positive reviews. This museum consists mainly of second-rate portraits. It's high cost is only justified if you want to learn far too much about one wealthy family. So many other far more worthwhile sites to see when in Prague. Read the other negative reviews. We wish we had.

A Definite Must See. Well done tour with great audio guide. We could wander about at our own pace and enjoy this magnificant collection. Easy to get to on the trolly and easy to walk down the hill to town.

Best audio tour, and we have had many. This privately owned palace along with the art and other landholdings was confiscated from Lubkowicz family and only recently reclaimed. This story, along with the family history going back to the 1300's is the story of the Czech Republic through the centuries, illustrated with with fine art, Beethoven symphonies (whom a great grandfather sponsored) and narrated by a family member is a treat to listen to.

Awe inspiring. This Palace was surprising to me, as I had never known about this family prior to going here. Absolutely amazing story of this collection. ..... 1500s porcelain, beautiful guns, original Mozart and Beetoven manuscripts, musical instruments and fine art from Velasquez, Bruegelle (can't spell) and Canneletto....and more!Plus.....surprisingly pleasant all around.Don't go when Viking boats are there.
Lunch at the palace. The palace history has been wonderfully presented with audio tapes. The lunch inn the palace dining room was very elegant and delicious. The concert was a highlite.

Beauty in Prague. We read about this museum on tripadvisor and decided to try it out. We were so glad we did. The audio recording was so interesting and helped us feel like we knew the family. Tying in history with the current family members. We also had a nice lunch at the cafe and stayed for the afternoon concert. The concert consisted of a flute, violin and piano. It was very nice. It was far less crowded than the other things at the Prague Castle. We would recommend this site!

Unexpected Find and a Highlight of our Trip. We were walking the castle grounds, somewhat overwhelmed by the crowds, and having chosen not to pay for the castle complex tour (the lines at St Vitus were so long!) we almost walked right by this palace, but a banner advertising the collection of original Mozart and Beethoven scores caught my husband's eye, and we decided to take a tour. It ended up being one of the most interesting things we did on our trip! The present-day family members narrate the audio guide (included in ticket price) and tell the fascinating story of their family history and the recent history of having lost and regained their palaces and land two times in the 20th century.Most of the museum is comprised of old family portraits of the early Count Lobkowiczs and their wives and children. There's also a display of china and firearms. The music collection really was fascinating. The (7th?) Count Lobkowicz was a parton of Beethoven and thus Beethoven dedicated several of his major works to the Count. The collection includes ORIGINAL scores of the 3rd, 4th and 5th symphonies! Then there is the original re-orchestration that Mozart did of Handel's Messiah in his own hand! My husband, a professional trombone player, really liked seeing this as Mozart's version fleshes out the Messiah with a fuller orchestra, including trombones. He also loved the thought that the original Beethoven works were right there, separated by glass of course, but there's always been a debate over a high note ...if only he could have seen inside the score!There was a concert in session and we heard parts of that as we toured the downstairs rooms. We did not eat at the cafe but everything I read says that it's a nice spot.It was nice to get this glimpse of a family with such history and to do it in relative silence. There were very few people touring the palace when we were there.

Castle Tour with lunch and a concert. A Viking Tour arrangement offered a very enjoyable lunch followed by a three piece concert in the hall. We then were treated to a very enjpyable audio tour of the castle. No pressure, so we took our time. Very interesting and a remarkable story of the Lobkowicz family.

Highligh of my visit to Prague. The museum alone is incredible. The current prince along with his wife and mother narrate the tour through place rooms filled with family treasures. The Lobkowicz family has played a long and vital role in history which is beautifully presented in the museum tour. A concert is presented daily at 1pm in a reception room. The seating is limited to around 60 so reserved tickets are advised. our concert featured 3 artist, a violinist, pianist and flutist. An hour of pure pleasure! Highly recommend buying the combined ticket for the museum and concert. Also the gift shop has very lovely and unique items. After looking at garnets in town purchased garnet jewelry here. The cafe offers light fare with beautiful views. Don't miss this treasure

Only privately owned palace in Pragie Castle.. At least in the English version the owners are the narrators on the guided headsets. If you like classical music it is not to miss. An original works of Beethoven is on display. Stay for the concert.

Amazing palace. In the palace grounds a family owned palace with very good audio service. Take your time to explore the treasures that their ancestors have accrued and the present owners have restored. There was a classical music consert (at 1 PM) while we were visiting, and we could take a break in between rooms. Lovely history, lots of family pictures, and the present owner speaks into your ear. Just right size for a leisurely visit.

A very pretty castle. We got there in time for the changing of the guard, music, crowds but terrific. The Cathedral is spectacular but busy. We were on a tour so walked a lot but worth it. The views are spectacular over the city and the river, very high above Prague.

A Stunning Experience. We went to the Lobkowitz Palace on one of our "free" days at the suggestion of Marketa Hradecka, our Prague private guide. It was the best thing we could have done. First, we had a wonderful lunch outside overlooking Prague at the Palace restaurant followed by an hour concert featuring short sequences by a variety of composers including Bach, Beethoven, Mozart, Bizet, Dvorak, Smetana and others. Then, we toured the Palace listening to the current Count Lobkowitz narrate his family history describing the two different times the palace had been lost and then restored to the family after the departures of the Nazis and the Soviets. The family collection of china, furnishings, paintings and antiques are extraordinary and, yet, I was stunned to see the originals of Beethoven's musical scores of the Eroica and Pastorale symphonies as well as Mozart's adaption of Händel's Messiah to a full symphonic orchestra. Absolutely awe inspiring and a highlight of our visit to Prague!

Best cultural thing we did in Prague!. No guide required. Headphones - narrated by the owner tell the wonderful family history of the Palace and their success in recovering and restoring their truly magnificent collection.

Hidden Gem Not to be Missed!. It's a true hidden gem. Many would go to the more popular Prague Royal Palace and walk past it when exiting Prague Castle Complex without noticing it, however it's definitely worth the visit and the extra ticket price.The Palace holds private family and royal collections of Lobkowicz family. What makes the visit interesting is that the audio guide is partially arrated by two generations of Lobkowiczes. The palace is less crowded than the Royal palace, which makes it more enjoyable. Among the collections are original scores and manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart.

A definite must see in Prague!. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Lobkowicz Palace. In fact, it was one of our favourite experiences at the palace complex. The audio guide is voiced by the current owner as well as other members of the family, speaking to different aspects of the history of this fascinating family. It really makes for a very personal experience. And of course there are the wonderful paintings, artifacts, the incredible musical historical collections, etc. Truly wonderful! Following your visit to the palace, be sure to stop by the Lobkowicz cafe, which offers good food with amazing views of Prague. You may have to wait a few minutes to get a table as it is small but it is well worth it! Also, you will get a small discount at the cafe with your entrance ticket to the palace.
A Hidden Treasure. This was an incredible place. Truly an art museum with art that you would expect to find at the top museums. Just the right size for a visit and such an interesting story.

Musical surprise. The family's story of accumulation, loss, recovery, loss, and restoration is one of wonder and awe. And then there was more. In one room, there were several original compositions, but the two that caught my eye were Beethoven's Third and Fifth symphonies, the manuscripts in his own hand!What helps make this palace's museum a wonderful treat among the many to be found in Prague is the narration by family members in the various rooms. If there is a downside (and it seems there is almost always a downside when visiting such treasures) it is that no photography is allowed on the upper floors. Oh, to have taken a photo of those priceless manuscripts. A digital image is far superior to fading memories!Following the tour, we sat on the café balcony overlooking the Vlata and enjoyed a wonderful lunch. Interesting, the signature dish is a cheeseburger!

A Must See!. We recommend saving a morning to tour the Palace. You can read the translated letters linking the formal portraits to one another in the Gallery and bringing their past lives to life! Original transcripts from Mozart are on display as well as: instruments, rifles, swords, Dutch ceramics, presents to and from the heads of state, two Canaletto masterpieces and a Breughal reclaimed from the salt mines during WWII. The audio is excellent. Such a treasure, and so worth the trip to Prague.

Interesting story and items to see. We spent there an afternoon - very interesting story and great collection of irena from the last few centuries. The manuscripts of Mozart, Beethoven and Hayden were very interesting. Nice way to spend a few hours.

Well worth the stop. The Lobkowicz collection is interesting with some truly remarkable pieces. The collection is small and can be examined reasonably quickly and has a little something for everyone. I was less interested in the china and clothing collections, but found the paintings and musical historical collections fascinating. The included audio tour was excellent and the narration by a Lobkowicz family member was intimate and informative. The Beethoven and Mozart documents in particular were amazing and unique.

Fascinating insight into the history of a family. The original owners of this palace (and many other impressive estates) lost their home and their possessions not once, but twice during the last century. Once under the Nazi regime and then again under the Communists. The audio tour is really good, spoken by the current owner, whose love and knowledge of the family history comes through with every word. There are many interesting artefacts and portraits of family members plus a few famous paintings - one by Brueghel, two by Canaletto. After the tourist trap that is the rest of Prague, this visit was refreshing and worth the entrance fee.

Lobkowicz Palace Museum. The entrance fee is modest (~£5) and has many interesting things to see. The video guide in the vestibule covers all the catagories of items on show and makes it easy to decide whether to enter.
An interesting glimpse in o Czech history. We did the lunch, concert and tour and it was lovely. The museum is very interesting and the family story is fascinating.
A little haven. Try the mid day concert - very enjoyable and a break from the crowds. Book on line or though your hotel. Competent young musicians - nice to support them

Introduction to a family as well as a palace.. The audio tour is a must do for this attraction (it is included in the entry fee). The Lobkowicz family members present the palace and its displays as they speak about their family and history. It brings the palace to life. There are many portraits, but also other precious artefacts. We perticulary enjoyed learning about the family's connection with Beethovan, and the original scores on display in the music room. We also loved the bird room and dog room. Entrance was 200Kc and not included in the castle ticket. The palace took us about 90 minutes to complete thoroughly. There is a cafe, and your ticket to the palace will get you a 10% discount in the cafe. Concerts are held in a beautiful salon in the palace. Tickets to concerts are sold separately.

TOUR OF LOBKOWICZ AND CLASSICAL CONCERT. Loved this beautiful palace, by far the best audio tour of our stay in Prague. We also took in a one hour classical mid day concert here which we thoroughly enjoyed and great value too!

Beautiful family-owned palace. The Lobkowicz Palace is well worth visiting. We took a private tour of the museum and family rooms, which also included a delicious lunch in a lovely small dining room and a three-piece string concert. The family has amassed an extraordinary collection of artwork and other objects, and is proud to share their treasures and history.

Lobkowicz Palace was the highlight of our Prague trip!. We loved seeing Lobkowicz Palace within the Prague Castle complex! The Palace stands today as an original gem with amazing art and family collections that are centuries old. The free concert was inspirational and authentic. Lobkowicz Palace was the highlight of our trip to Prague.

Prague Castle Palace. The Palace tour is an additional charge to the Castle/Cathedral Tour. Its worth it and in my view one of the hils of a trip to Prague in itself a wonderful historic city.The Palace tour takes you on a journey of several hundred years of a family who had everything, lost it all and by sheer perseverance, got it all back. The palace was taken by the Nazis, then the Russians after WW2 and then finally returned to the rightful owners. Great stories and great exhibits including the original score of Beethovens 5th Symphony

We had no idea the connections of the Lobkowwicz family. Our intention was to visit the other sights in the area and merely decided at the last minute to visit the palace. I don't want to take away the ending for those reading who also are unfamiliar with the family so I won't share what I learned. I will say it is a museum experience vs a palace with ornate jewels and fancy beds. It is a museum of significant family artifacts. Quite interesting - worth a visit

History Made Personal. Don't miss this - many people do. A private palace with an interesting collection of family heirlooms and an audio guide that makes history something that happened to real people whose descendants are still living.

Wonderful experience. We were part of a Viking Cruise party and had a wonderful time. Beautiful art collection.The connection and story of the family to Beethoven was fantastic. The music room and original manuscript of Beethoven brought chills down are arms.

An art lover's dream. We had a package-type tour at the Lobkowicz Palace, while in Prague after a river cruise. If you have the opportunity for a similar luncheon tour, I would opt out. [You can enjoy lunch in any number of places rather than there]. The tour was set with a guide and also an audio guide. Although the history and the art were both interesting, I was disappointed that there were no rooms to view, that were kept in tact while this Palace was in use as such. So, there are many places to see while in Prague, and if you love paintings and other objects of art, you'll enjoy this stop. With so many beautiful building we saw while on this trip, it wasn't at the top of my favorites list.
Original notes of Bach on display!. I absolutely loved this place and all the objects on display were amazing. I especially liked the service and the friendliness of the staff.

Wonderful Music!. We really enjoyed the daily lunchtime concert. The trio of musicians were from the Czech National Orchestra and they played a variety of popular classics beautifully. It was a welcome break from the hectic tourist trail of the castle. It’s well worth doing the audio tour of the palace afterwards too, narrated by the current Duke and his family in American English, and what an interesting history the family have! A real highlight of our visit to the city.
Spectacular palace. Easy to reach by tram and entry is discounted if senior. Need a full days to see everywhere. Look for hidden sites

A Cultural Highlight in Praque. The history of this family and their fight to reclaim their property from the Communist regime is impressive. The family were patrons of Beethoven and the museum has hand annotated scores on display.

Wonderful story behind the museum!!. We enjoyed hearing the history and recent story of the Lobkowicz family. The museum is beautifully restored and the narration is well worth it. Family members share stories and information along your walk through their many belongings. Would recommend the listen, visit and enjoy combination ticket. You will need at least 3 hours with it. Can't wait to go see their other properties!

Following a single family makes history more immediate and interesting. We stopped by here in our tour of Prague Castle. It was a high point. The fact that it's the history of one family gives a unique view of history. The narration of the audio tour is by the current family head, which is very cool. Don't miss this!By the way, the restaurant in the courtyard next to this palace is good, too.

Very Interesting and a different angle for a museum. We visited this in the process of visiting the Prague Castle environs. Its different in that its a private museum and the staff are somehow more motivated to assist. We found it interesting in that the museum told a story by use of audio and portraits about how the Lobkowicz family evolved over a very long time. It was genuinely interesting, well told and easy to follow. The main items in the museum are a mixture of artwork, porcelain

Very interesting. This place is quite interesting. We did the audio tour. It was narrated by a descendant of the family. The tour takes you through rooms of the castle and talks about various paintings and the people in them. The family has a remarkable history. We were amazed that the paintings have survived for centuries. Besides the art galleries we viewed musical instruments, weapons, bird pictures made of feathers, china, etc. we went to the concert, which consisted of a cello, piano, and flute. It was terrific! We had a very tasty lunch in the cafe there. All of us liked our entrees. The whole experience took about four hours. It was well worth it.

Owner of palace is from Boston, Massachusetts area.. The owner has a really interesting story regarding his ownership. Music lovers will like this place. He has original manuscripts from Mozart and Beethoven in their own handwriting. Many old musical instruments. Nice collection of guns, and the usual collection of decorative arts and paintings.
A day in the royal quarters. A beautifully maintained Palos. There is a special luncheon with a concert for about €100 a person. It's expensive but well worth the luncheon in the Palos quarters.

Family Home. I felt like an honoured guest in this family home. Everything was shared with commentary by the owner making it a privileged visit. The lunch time concert was the added icing. Wonderful music. Thank you.!Note: tough climb so take it slowly.

Quiet visit worth making amid the crowds outside. A fine little museum: uncrowded, with lots to see and think about while there.Unique in that the palace in which it is located was lost to the Nazis in WWII, then restored to the family, then lost to the Communists in 1948 and finally again restored to the family again after the reds were deservedly run out of town in the 90s.The family has done great credit to itself, to the property and to the Czech government for restoring it to them a third time.Well worth the 200 Kr entry!! (And that gives you 10% off in their restaurant/coffee shop with its fine views of the city.)

A pleasant surprise. The audio tour narrated by the family is well done. There are some tedious section about the ancestor painting but the original scores from Mozart and Beethoven on display were outstanding. The concert at the end was well performed but was only with piano, flute and viola.

Superb. This Palace at one end of the Prague Palace complex is really interesting. Get an audio guide as it is narrated by the current holder of the Lobkowicz title and includes segments from his father and mother and a few relatives. It is really very well done and very down to earth. This is a very wealthy family and they did not have to do this but you can tell how proud they are if being back in CZ after the fall of the Soviet Union. The narrative makes the visit so very real and is the first time in all our travels to have the owner explaining what you are seeing.

Thoroughly enjoyable. I think the highlight of the Lobkowicz Palace is not the art collection as much as the story of the family. The excellent audio guide is narrated by Willaim Lobkowicz and truly draws you into the amazing story of their family. The family lost all of their property TWICE, once to the Nazi’s and again to the Soviet’s. It’s an amazing rare story of restitution in modern times

Wonderful Museum! A must see!!. We loved visiting the Lobkowicz Palace Museum and the audio tour narrated by Prince William was so special. The Lobkowicz family story and all of the art and special pieces that have been restored are amazing. We had lunch at the cafe and it was delicious!! We highly recommend making this stop a priority when you visit Prague.
Nice collection. A good collection that is worth visiting. If it rains this would be a good place to spend some time. they had original manuscripts by Beethoven & Mozart.
Part of the Prague Castle visit. This is a part of the Prague Castle visit. It is a complex within the Prague castle and you will stumble upon this when you come.

Czech Palace/Prague. Do not miss this palace and it's incredible collection of 10,000 priceless items! Take tram #22 to top of Cast;e Hill and then walk down so you don't have to climb. Lunch is delightful at Palace.
Must see. Excellent visit, with lots of interesting pieces to look at. We went to a lunchtime concert which was very good. Cafe does great cakes.

Something you must see when in Prague.. This place is a must visit when in Prague. It's a museum in the palace grounds. It has original symphony manuscripts by Beethoven and some original music of Mozart.! That alone is woth the price of admission. It also has a nice cafe where you can sit on a terrace overlooking Pargue.

Excellent. One of the best things we did in Prague! This palace is an art museum now, containing the Lobkowicz family's private collections, and the audio tour, which is included with price of admission, is extremely interesting and well done. I really enjoyed my visit, and would especially recommend it for a rainy day.
Walking shoes. Get the tram up to the castle & walk down through the wine vineyard stop rest & enjoy Glass of wine & the great view

Not to be missed. The palace is lovely, but the value here are the unbelievable collections of items the family has on display. Original works by Mozart and Beethoven are inches away from your fingertips! Instruments made 600 years ago on display, guns and weapons that are works of art fill 2 rooms. The audio guide is excellent! and it is narrated by the current owner/heir who artfully discusses his family's history as well as Czech history.A quick but thorough review of Czech history and perspectives all the way through to current time in about and hour and a half--well worth it!
lobkowicz palace. Very interesting small palace. there were also some musical performances given during our tour. Lovely very small coffee shop on premises.
Loved it!. This place was wonderful. They have terrific events and it is just beautiful to see the rooms. A very lovely visit.
Don't Miss. An absolute must see. the collection spans several centuries, and the Audio guide, narrated by family members, was excellent. One of the highlights of our trip.

Inside you can find paintings by Brueghel, Canaletto, Bellotto, Cranach, Rubens, Veronese, etc.. The oldest and largest privately owned art collection in the Czech Republic, The Lobkowicz Collections draws its significance from its comprehensive nature, which reflects the cultural, social, political and economic life of Central Europe for over seven centuries. With the passage of the restitution laws in the early 1990s, it became possible for the Lobkowicz family to reassemble most of The Collections, making them available to the public in a family context after more than 50 years.In this wonderful place you can find some world-famous paintings by Brueghel, Canaletto, Bellotto, Cranach, Rubens, Veronese and many others, medieval and Renaissance works of art, ceramics spanning five centuries and exceptional arms and armor.

Jewel of Prague. It was part of an exclusive dinner event for our group at the castle. Must say - it was experience of a lifetime. everything unique, everything special.... the food, the live music, the view, the hospitality, the care and to top it all - the prince himself explaining the history. A must visit for anyone interested in history!

Check out the "dog room!". The family did a wonderful job restoring and displaying artwork that had been neglected for years and years. The Lobkowicz family has been a hugely influential family in Czech history and it was interesting to learn about them.

Great place to see the history of Czech Republic. One of the things I liked the most about the tour is that you get headphones and you can listen to explanations (In English) about everything you see in the palace. If you love history you will like this place.

Owned by the same family for 4 centuries (minus Nazi and Communist appropriation). So cool. I wanted to write a thank you note to this family for opening up their palace to others. Better than most museum exhibits that I've ever seen.

A gem not to be missed . If you are a fan of music, art, military weapons or just castle life, Lobkowicz collection is going to please you. Great story of noble family who reclaimed their possessions confiscated first by the Nazis then by communists. William Lobkowicz, very personable man with a Boston accent who owns some of the most valuable musical scores in the world i.e. Orchestration of Handel Messiah in Mozart own hand.

Fascinating tour for music lovers. Fascinating tour. If you are a music lover, be sure to include the concert as part of your tour. It was well worth the cost of admission. View of the city from the cafe terrace isn't bad either!

Very Interesting!. We combined our trip to the Palace Museum with a lunchtime concert. There was a trio of high class musicians on piano, flute and viola plating light classical pieces...excellent.The Museum is a must see... the audio guide, which are normally boring in trying to give you too much information, was covered by the present encumbent and owner, who has an engaging voice and clearly loves to share his beautiful treasures with the public. There are many wonderful paintings and documents which he weaves into his story of this famous family's lives and loves over seven centuries; their connection and sponsorship of the great Beethoven is a revelation in itself.....Even if you are tired by the time you reach this end of the Castle complex, please do not miss this part.Highly recommended

The highlight of my trip to Prague. I really liked this part of Prague. We did the castle the day before and came back because of what I read about it. They had one of the best audio tours I have ever listened to, and I have listened to a lot of them between personal travel and conducting field trips over the years. I think one thing that made it nice was that the Count narrated it and it was like he was showing you around his house. The original music scores were amazing as well as the paintings and stories about the family. At the end we had lunch in the cafe and it was very nice and certainly not overpriced.

Majestic Castle and Palace. On the advice of the hotel concierge we caught the No 22 tram to the Castle then worked our through all the glorious scenery on offer and worked our way back down to the bottom we found this a really good way to take on board all the grandeur this fantastic area had to offer can highly recommend this approach
Stunning private collection. The Lobkowicz palace was outstanding – you would love it and the audio commentary is narrated by the prince and his family.

a collection with a purpose. an unique collection of objects of art reflecting both history of country abd one of the oldest families in the country. The collection has a purpose and is not a random set of objects. The best way to spend a rainy day idea to visit it if a rainy day caught you in Prague

Beautiful place with amazing history. I purchased the museum tour with audio guide and Midday classical concert. It was great! I was hanging out solo since my husband was in class and this was such a nice day for me. The concert is an hour and I highly recommend it, if that is your thing of course. The palace has such a great and impressive history, the whole country itself does. I walked around Prague castle and enjoyed the beautiful views of the city before heading to my concert, it was an amazing experience.

Amazing treasures!. We visited this palace as part of a Viking tour. I am unsure what this tour costs. We liked the audio tour feature. I found the museum treasures to be extremely interesting and the family story just as fascinating. Since we had already been to Vienna and the Schonbrunn Palace, this was an expansion of the story. Our tour included a goulash lunch in the palace. A nice touch, but I'm, again, not sure what that costs and it certainly is not a "must" when visiting this palace.
really cool palace. there are objects in this museum that no one else has, and that are worth gawking at. the audio tour is free and is excellent.
Worth the walk up the hill. We didn't do a tour but just walking around the castle and its gardens is well worth the walk up the hill. Like the rest of Prague you feel you have gone back in time.
When in Prague, Lobkowicz Palace is well worth the visit.. Worth going to for the history and feel of life long ago. Interesting story of the family and its fortunes over the years.

Wonderful find. Went to Prague Castle and found this gem of a museum. The story of the museum and the family is interesting in and of itself but in addition there are many rare and beautiful things to see. We felt it was the high point of our visit to Prague Castle.

Must do for history buffs.. Was truly amazing, although didn't have enough time to appreciate all the beautiful rooms and listen to all the information provided. If you go, allow 1/2 a day to fully appreciate the Palace. Good shopping.

Beautiful palace and gardens. This is a beautiful palace full of interesting and unusual artefacts. There are a number of beautifully decorated rooms with wall and ceiling paintings. Outside there is a lovely garden with manicured lawns and great views over the city. Well worth a visit.
Very interesting museum.. This was a great museum detailing one family's time during WW1 and WW2. It was really interesting and provided a real human element to the history of the time period.
Great if you have time. With so many wonderful places in Prague to see, this is not a high priority. Does have some nice views which make the walk there worth it

Concert in private hall of Palace was superb. Lunch with Viking Group in Palace, Concert: Beethoven,Mozart,
Bach and Private showing of Palace Art museum. Excellent
way to spent the afternoon within the Castle grounds in Prague

Beautiful and interesting. A wonderful experience for all! The museum experience is made especially personal, because members of the current Lobkowicz family narrate the audio guide. It is truly a beautiful palace and the room with the scores of the Beethoven symphonies and music instruments made a real impression! Recommended for all who visit Prague Castle.

Spectacular view from the terrace cafe, excellent food and service. Had a relaxing lunch on the terrace overlooking Prague. Was one of the highlights of our trip. We were exhausted after the Disney-like experience of touring the castle and cathedral with throngs of tourists. We just wanted a place to rest and have lunch and were surprised that we stumbled upon such a beautiful and elegant property. Prices were very reasonable for the location and the food was excellent.

A palace with history. We visited this palace on a tour organized by Viking River Cruises.we arrived at the palace and were invited to have lunch in the princes dinning room.This room is large and can sit up to 40 to 60 people.It was very nice set up and the food that was served was delicious,wine or beer was served with the lunch.The beer was made in the princes brewery and it was very tasty.After lunch we had listened to a wonderfully quartet of musicians who played Mozart etc.The princes music room hat a nice acoustic and the decorations are beautiful.We were aloud to step on the balcony and hat a breathtaking view of Prague and the surrounding Area.A tour to the palace with historic paintings,weapon collection,beautiful golden crosses and so much more ended this tour.A disappointment the prince did not show up to greet us,which would be the highlight of the tour.
Explore Then Relax.. First do the palace which is impressive and then make sure you enjoy the gardens (park) with its splendid vistas.

Lots of nooks to explore. There were a number of nooks to explore. The main feature, the cathedral was full of tourists, but you could fine a number of spots free of crowds to explore. Worth the time.

Spectacular Private Collection. While walking along Jirska street from St George Square to the eastern gate of the Pague castle, i came across this wonderful palace which is the only privately owned building in the Prague Castle complex.A renaissance building with rich architectonic decorative work in early Boroque style,it is home to the highly acclaimed artistic collections,midday classic concerts, museum shop & an excellent cafe & bar .Its most splendid room is the famous Banquet hall with mythological frescoes from the 17th century which is used only for exhibitions & concerts.Don`t forget to take the free Audio guide in 8 languages with the narration by the members of Labkowicz family & the chief Curator of the place.The art collections are exhibited in many beautifully appointed galleries in many rooms.These paintings include the works of Velasquez,Brughel the elder & many other famous ones.There is also an impressive display of Royal portraits,rare decorative arts about 500 years old,musical instruments & original scores of Beethoven,Mozart & Haydn.There are other elegant avenues for private functions.In the cafe standing in the balcony you can have a lovely view of Prague.

Extremely well done. We decided to go after listening to Rick Steves' podcast interview with William Lobkowicz (available on Rick's Audio Europe app). The museum is the perfect size for feeling like you got what you paid for but still leaving wishing you could see more. Absolutely immaculately displayed collection and the included audio guide was great (moves you through the collection at just the right pace). Next time we're back in Prague we're definitely going to visit the palace outside of the city to see more of the collection.

Wonderful Tour with Audio by Lobkowitz Family. We really enjoyed this self guided tour. The family history was so interesting and the audio tour was excellent. Definitely worth going. We ate first in the little café in the courtyard.

Big palace, don't miss. The palace is really beautiful, guided tours are good as well, there's a café with terrace from where you can see fantastic sights. If you would like, you also can go on a concert there.

Wonderful museum, concert, and cafe. We purchased a combined ticket, including the museum and the afternoon concert. We enjoyed both very much. The audio guide that describes the items in the collection of the Lobkowicz family is very well done and helps you to appreciate the art even more. The classical concert lasted an hour and was just delightful. The pianist, flautist, and violinist were all top notch musicians. The drawing room where the concert was held was very elegant. We also enjoyed a delicious lunch on the outside terrace of the cafe. All in all, it was a delightful afternoon.

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful!. We really enjoyed the half-day we spent in the Lobkowicz Palace area. We had a terrific guide who provided great insight into everything we saw. There is also a great view of Prague and the surrounding area.

Seek This Out, It is Spectacular. This will not be a part of the tour tickets to the other attractions in the Castle but it is far superior to any of the other venues you will visit. There are two floors of decorated rooms and exhibits and a not to be missed small chapel. Attached to it is a café with wonderful food and their own Lobkowicz beer. Do not miss this gem!

Best tour of a family run palace!. The palace is lovely, the family narrates the tour and makes it more appealing with their personal history.The cafe is also so lovely- food was wonderful, nice location.

The Mozart and Beethoven works were the highlight. This is a beautiful palace with quite a history-- the audio guide is nice to listen to as it is curated by the family. The tour starts off with a brief background on the prominent family members and then takes you through the entire palace. The collection includes paintings, ceramic ware, arms and music. The most interesting part of the collection I felt was in the Music section -- with the autographed manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart and the connection of Beethoven to the Lobkowicz family.
Wonderful buildings. You could spend hours here, there is so much history and beautiful works of art and architecture. Take a tour or just please your self. A must see.
Great Rail Journeys - Beijing to London. The whole castle & it's buildings are well worth visiting. There is a ticket you can buy that gets you into all of the sites. Well worth it.

A bit of history. What a joy. Beautifully laid out. Stayed for the lunchtime concert in one of the reception rooms - delightful. Learnt a lot about the history of the family and how they restored twice-stolen art. All fascinating, in the Castle grounds. Worth a visit

Leave plenty of time for this. We had booked a lunch-time concert and only had time for a one hour look around the palace. The audio tour is excellent, one of the best that I've ever used. With only one hour, we were really rushed but the paintings and artifacts were just amazing and the history of the place very interesting.

My favourite museum from Prague. This museum wasn't in our plans, we sort of stumbled upon it, and it turn out to be quite lovely. We especially liked the audio-guide presentation recorded by the prince Lobkowicz himself, which brought a unique nuance to the whole experience. Amongst the highlights of the art collecions were Pieter Brueghel the Elder and original scores and manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart. Also, the view from the palace is amazing!
Can be skipped. We did a one day casle and it was great. This one, while nice from outside and in the pictures... nothing too special and we did not spend too much time on the exhibits.
Amazing view from their terrasse. This is a beautiful castle which offers amazing historical exhibitions.I have had the pleasure to come as a tourist and as a guest for some of their events

Mozart wrote music and played here! Lobkowicz Palace.... Wow.....Do NOT miss this Palace! I had never heard of this historical site nor known of the generational philanthropy to the musical talents of Mozart and others. A beautiful collection of family paintings and a story of survival and productivity. You must ask for a special tour to see Mozart's original hand written musical scores and the families amazing collection of weaponry. An 8 ft long powder rifle...amongst other unusual pieces.

A hidden ta. An interesting museum with some wonderful works of art by Canaletto and .Breughel. This musical family also has scores of Mozart, Beethoven and Corelli as well as early lutes, crumhorns and cor Angolans. Follow this with a visit to their cafe with its panoramic views over the city.
Interesting. Most things inaccessible. Alot of refurbishment being undertaken at the time. Again, really only another photographic opportunity for lovers of the lens!!

A museum with a very interesting story. This museum has quite a few interesting artifacts. But, the highlight of the museum is the audio tour. The owner of the palace and artifacts, along with some of his family members narrate the story of their family and their collection. It is a great story. Don't visit the palace without listening to the audio tour (which is included in the admission).
Palace Tour. Really enjoyed our tour of the palace. Audio guided tour is very interesting/ Many interesting paintings and antiques. Well worth the time to walk around.

Really not worth it.. Lobkowicz is a small privately owned portion of the Prague castle. I was with a group that had a lunch, a short duration concert and some time in the museum. The lunch was very slowly served and mediocre. The concert was very good, but also very brief. The museum can be done in 20 minutes and is the story of a wealthy family who got their land back after the Nazis and the Communists. There are far better ways to spend your time and money within a few meters of the front door.

Worth a visit. This is right in the grounds of Prague Castle, so it's convenient to visit it on the same day. The audio guide is wonderfully done, with interesting narration by the Prince and his family members, and even the choice of music. It was fascinating to learn about the story of the family and see the highlights of their incredible collection. The most notable items in the different rooms are clearly indicated, so that you can pick just those that interest you. I was happy to see our 2 teenagers and 8-year-old walking around at their own pace and listening intently to the explanations.

The audio guide is the best ever. We came here on a recommendation from our Sandemans free city tour guide Kate and she was spot on. The highlight of this palace is the involving and intimate audio guide with a narration by the royal family that leaves one with goosebumps on many occasions. It was amongst the many highlights of our trip to Prague.

This audio tour was the highlight of our trip.. The audio tour of this place was a trip through the history of four generations of this family's fortunes. Created with care, attention to detail and a lovely balance between the historical details of the rooms and their contents, and how they relate to the family members past and present made this tour feel like a personal gift to everyone who has ever wandered the hallways of the palace.

Please don't overlook this delightful gem !. We wandered up to the Prague Castle and explored its treasures but somehow "missed" the entrance to the Lobkowicz Palace. Determined to enjoy this marvel, we returned to the Hradcany (Castle) district via the Wallenstein Palace/Gardens and it was certainly worth the effort. Unbelievable story (worthy of a Hollywood movie !) and a beautiful, fascinating chateau and museum. The personal audio tour is very moving and informative. A must see !

One of the Many Highlights. We were very lucky to have dinner here one evening...it was part of our tour and a highlight of our stay. The owner's wife spoke to our group over dessert and coffee about the history of the castle and how it once again became part of her husband's family. Another highlight of our visit was to view their art collection, some of it very famous, e.g. a Cannoletti.

Unexpectedly lovely!. This tour was an optional excursion of our Viking River Cruise. and what fun! Lunch and a private concert before the tour.
