Who know the Lobkowicz family was a patron of both Mozart and Beethoven? The audio guide is narrated by a family member who lives in the United States, so was completely understandable. The collection of old musical instruments is lovely. Understandably, we couldn't take pictures, but the small book about the Lobkowicz collections has perfectly adequate pictures. Gift shop has more interesting items that a lot of others.

Not to Be Missed. A truly exquisite collection of paintings, weapons, pottery, musical instruments and more, portraying the remrakable story of the Lobkowicz dynasty, intertwined with the history of Prague, Bohemia and Europe. The audio guide is probably the best I have ever encountered. And there is a good coffee shop for a nice lunch after the tour. Whatever you do in Pargue, make a couple of hours free for this fantastic museum.

Don't miss this beautiful palace. Fabulous, breathtaking and the Lobkowicz family is amazing! Had a private Tauck tour dinner here and it was fantastic! Great music, beautifully, well-kept surroundings. Don't miss this experience if in Prague!
Best of all the palaces. Twice stolen from the Lobkovich family and twice recovered. Only palace still privately owned. Has the most to see of all the palaces we visited.

Gardens are worth the visit. The gardens are enough of a reason to visit this palace. the views are spectacular. Although there are many people here, you will still find a nice place to relax and soak in the atmosphere.
Lunchtime concert. We visited a lunchtime concert at this palace and enjoyed beautiful pieces on violin, flute and piano. Not to be missed if you love music.

Moving, do not miss. The Lobkowicz family history is riveting and was told to us by the Prince himself. It is a fascinating story, believable only because it's true. The devotion to music is displayed in the music room. Here you will see the original 5th symphony in Beethoven's hand. Unbelievable. And, Handel's Messiah arranged by Mozart. Music lovers, if you are in Prague, don't miss this.

A must see!. Had heard about this through a Rick Steve's interview with the Prince! Took a little time to find it in the castle complex but so glad we did! Got there just in time for the 1:00PM concert which was superb! The rest of the palace was so full of interesting items that we spent all afternoon there! From the Canelettos to the Brughel, the Mozart and Beethoven scores, and all the family memorabilia - just so intriguing. Highly recommend this!

A hidden treasure!. This was an amazing and unexpected treat. The palace is part of the castle complex sitting above Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace has a heart-stopping view of the city but, more importantly, a fascinating history. It was built by the family in the 1500s, and run (along with several other palaces in the Bohemian area) by the Lobkowicz family until it was taken by the Nazis. It was given back after the war, but then taken again by the Communists. It is now back in the hands of the family along with a historical treasure trove of musical manuscripts (Beethoven's 5th in his own hand, Handel's Messiah also in his own hand), priceless artwork, ceramics, musical instruments, and on and on. Definitely a don't-miss place while in Prague. Probably difficult for people with difficulty walking -- lots of cobblestones and stairs, and probably no elevator.
Go visit . Seriously this is a hidden gem - no crowds some great history and original works of Mozart and Beethoven. Make sure you try the cafe too

Two Canelettos and some Beethoven. The audio tour is quite fine, narrated as it is by a family member. The real catches at this museum (in the old family palace in the Castle Quarter) are the two 'London' Canelettos, and the fact that you can come nose-to-page with Beethoven first editions and Mozart's own handwriting. The exhibition rooms are grouped by subject and type of painting or drawing. The rooms are smaller, and have no place to sit and take the works in, which for me was a flaw.

Thoroughly Recommend. We just loved the display in this Palace; nice mix of the story of the Lobkowicz family, story of Prague / Czech Republic, connections with Beethoven, guns/amoury, protection of the Czech heritage. The building itself is worth seeing.

Hidden Gem. In quiet corner of Prague Castle ( near an exit ) we chose the Combo ticket ( $690 Czech or $38 Australian each ) which included Museum with Audio guide ( oldest & largest Private Art collection in Central Europe ) plus one hour midday classic music concert plus 10% off cafe. With two floors of Family History, Paintings, musical instruments, Armory, ceramics and original compositions by Mozart, Beethoven & Haydn. Not crowded. Cafe has views overlooking Prague ( good & reasonably priced, with $6 AUD Coffee & cake special )

Don't miss this museum, it is wonderful . We visited Prague castle and were quite tired after a long day and gave this museum a miss. Two days later I looked on Trip Advisor for our last day in Prague to see if we missed anything and found the reviews on the Lobkowicz Palace. It is excellent and has family history for hundreds and hundreds of years with original paintings, manuscripts and a wonderful story by the current family members. The audio guide is a must even if you skip through some of the information. The best way to get here is tram number 22, go to the Prague castle stop and walk down to the museum. Tickets on the trams are cheap and it saves a heap of walking.
Beautiful!!!!!!. This property is still owned by the Lobkowicz family. The art collection is wonderful and the collection of Beethoven is priceless. If you get to Prague this is a must see.
Best thing we did in Prague. An incredibly rich collection of art - excellent audio guide by Lobokowicz family members - a sense of living history. A must for music lovers!

A hidden treasure of art and music. I did not even know that this Palace existed. I was walking around Prague Castle and I was looking for some place to buy a cold drink. I walked into the lobby and saw a short description of Lobkowicz Palace. I could hear music coming from a room upstairs. A concert was taking place. The short summary of the Palace told of the Lobkowowicz Family and their trials and tribulations as they fought to keep the many treasures of the Palace through the war years and even through the cold war years. The treasures include handwritten manuscripts by both Mozart and Beethoven. That alone was enough to get me to purchase a ticket and enter. The audio guide has descriptions of the treasures and the history of the palace all given by Lobkowicz Family members, adding a personal touch to the experience. There was another concert about to begin as I was leaving.

Lots of stuff. Nice collection. WE mostly went to watch the bethoven stuff. I tohught it woild be paced, but we were two of the few visitors. Everyone gets a audio guide, witch is quite handy. The guides are te owners, relatives of the previous residents, so youdon't learn anything fo how they came into all the posessions, just who and when. It's still a nice museum, and the 7 th. prince changed music history. So go have a look/listen.

Great history- take the audio tour!!. I'll say it again- take the audio tour! A tour of this palace becomes a tour of the history of the entire region, as seen through the experiences of one very wealthy family. The story is gripping, and the way they actually give personality to all the people in the stuffy old portraits will change the way you see such portraits forever.

Best European museum tour ever!!. As a frequent traveler to Europe and a visitor of a multitude of museums, this one truly stands out. Not only does it have some incredible original pieces by Velasquez and Bruegel, but also original manuscripts by Mozart and Beethoven. The audio tour is included in the price of the ticket and makes this tour incredibly rich and real. The story of the palace from its Imperial rise to greatness, as well as twice downward spiral and final resurrection to today is told in the words of the family that bears it's name. This unique, personal narrative is unlike any other museum that I have ever experienced and makes the history relevant and palpable. There is a shorter tour and a longer, 75 minute tour, that I wished had gone on for longer. There is also a nice restaurant in the back of the museum which overlooks the city scape. There is a 10% discount at the restaurant if you buy A ticket for the museum. This is truly a do not miss stop on any tour of Prague!!

One of the best but most u proclaimed museums ever. The palace details an amazing personal story of a Czech family with immense wealth but caught up in war Amazing articles with a huge surprise in music collection One of the best museums ever

Mid-day concerts, good terrace cafe and museum with guided audio tour. We went here to attend a mid-day concert and stayed to see the museum and have a meal at their terrace cafe. If you are a classical music lover then this is definitely one destination you must visit.

Amazing!!!. The Lobkowicz Palace is defenetly a must for history and art lovers. You can only buy a ticket with the audio guide included, but it's worth all the money. Hearing Mr. W. Lobkovicz's voice as he personaly tells the story of his family and all the collection pieces... gave me the chills. Wonderful collection of art, porcelain, musical instruments, etc. I would recomend giving it a good few hours 2-3 hours and after, serve a good cup of coffe and enjoy the atmosphere from teh Palace! All in all the this is my best memory from Prague! :)

Amazing collection within Prague Castle. This palace was recommended by our contact at the Prague Convention & Visitors Bureau. Buying tickets on line is easy and affordable (discounted for combination 1PM concert and palace; also senior rates). We had to change the date ticketed and they handled this quickly and pleasantly. The collection of the current owner, William Lobkowicz (no longer titled 'Prince') is amazing! The audio guide is included and worth listening to as it tells the story of this powerful, cultural family and how they came to collect such rarities as original music scores by Beethoven and Mozart. Seeing these showcased was more inspiring than I'd ever imagine. GO..and reserve the 'gold' seats for the daily concert- 3 instruments, mostly known music, and the gold seats are the first 2 rows and much more comfortable, padded seats. Also, the cafe is lovely and you must find the chocolate kiosk and pray they still are serving the melted chocolate cup. Heaven on a boiling hot day!

AMAZING. I toured all around Europe and this had to be my favorite museum. Such a rich collection with beautiful pieces! 100% recommend eating at the restaurant attached (order the Lobkowicz beer!!) and then go check out the museum. It was fascinating, entertaining, fun, and I learned a lot! Enjoy!
Private Tour with Viking Cruises . We had Abe excellent tour, lunch and concert arranged by Viking Tours. Do not miss it if you do the Prague Extension. Decent food, great concert and good guides.

lobkowicz Palace. Lobkowicz Palace is open for tours. You can buy your entrance ticket and take the bus, or you can walk up the hill and enter with your ticket. The walls are covered with pictures and tapestries. Except for tables most furniture lines the walls. Lots of sitting rooms, few bathrooms.
Amazing Castle. The castle is more of a city than a castle with many buildings in a cluster and including the cathedral. Well worth a visit. There is a great view of the city from the palace.

The real Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace is a must for history, art, and dining. We there as part of an excellent Viking Danube River cruise and had luncheon, string trio, and guided tour of the art and music galleries. Excellent little gift shop and great guides. A wonderful experience.
Lobkowicz - Prague at you feet.... Wonderfull place with amazing panorama... I just wait to come back in Lobkowicz Palace. 10 minutes to the Bridge.

Beautiful palace and informative tour. I missed this palace on my first trip to Prague a few years ago but very glad I fit it in on this trip! It was great to hear the commentary from the actual descendants of the Lobkowicz family and hear their stories. The midday concert was also a treat to hear and much less expensive than some of the evening concerts offered in Prague.

A view on ages past. A group of us on a Viking tour opted to pay extra to visit Lobkowicz Palace. It was a great way to rest after having walked through the rest of Prague Castle. First we had lunch, prepared by the staff: Salad, Goulash and cheesecake-very good. We were then treated to a concert in one of the palace rooms, after visiting a balcony that had wonderful views of the city. We then toured the palace and viewed the rooms, the painting collections, collections of musical instruments and original musical scores. Wonderful visit!
Wow . Wow, was this a great museum! I'll add more later when I'm on a real computer and have more time. Good audio guide.

Don't Overlook this Palace, in the shadows of the Prague Castle. We were looking for another historical site to visit during our final days in Prague and saw other trip advisors giving the Lobkowicz Palace good reviews so decided to see for ourselves. With the audio guides as our learning tools, we really got a lot out of the exhibit, the palace and family history, and general history of the region. The descendants of the family, in the current generation, were the voice of the audio guide which made it all the more interesting and special. I do recommend it for all this and because there are fewer people with this location tagged to visit, plus indoors on either a hot or rainy day. We also went to the musical concert as an add on, which was very pleasant.

Make sure you set aside a few hours for this. The audio tour was great; narrated by the owners of the palace which makes it all the more unique. So interesting to see all the paintings of ancestors, their stories, even letters written hundreds of years ago! Highlight is the music room, with original scores written in the hand of beethoven and mozart. Also enjoyed the concert very much then topped it off with a beer and lunch at the café in the palace which was also good.

Worth a visit. Enjoyed the visit to the castle. It is quite lovely. The art/ weaponry collection is quite amazing. The Lobkowicz heir was quite loquacious and asking/begging for money in a way that I thought was a bit over the top and inelegant for an educated very privileged individual from Massachusetts.

Picture postcard. Wow the history of this building is amazing ,and the whole building i found amazing ,it was busy but the staff smiles all around very friendly ,a really nice cafe i enjoyed it plenty to see and do ,i really like the architecture of the building

Beethoven Slept Here. So glad that we added Lobkowicz Palace onto our trip to Prague! What an interesting history this place has, including the fact that the palace was lost to the Lobkowicz family twice in the 20th-century, once when the Nazis invaded Czechoslavakia and a second time to the state during the Soviet era.Today, the privately-owned palace is opened to tourists. In addition to an excellent audio tour of 22 rooms of displays, there is also an hour-long concert (ours was a violin and piano concert) as part of the ticket. The Lobkowicz family were patrons of Beethoven and Mozart so you will see original compositions on display as well as wonderful collections of objets, art, and the decorative arts. Not to be missed are the Velaquez, Canalettos and Brueghels owned by the family.We finished our tour with an excellent light lunch in the palace's cafe, on a terrace overlooking Prague. The setting alone is exceptional.

Worthwhile and Interesting....So Many Choices....Don't Miss!. The audio tour was exceptional, a mixture of history complemented with modern day family perspective. If you are in a hurry, they highlight "do not miss items". Not only paintings but artifacts and extensive blue/white china collection. The staff was very friendly and their cafe has the best view. The warm breeze, music and meal was the perfect ending following the tour!

Great views.. This place is located within the grounds of Prague castle.It has a cafe with terrace and the views are simply magnificent.If we had time would have loved to have a meal and a drink here.
Private Palace. Enjoyed the time there. Great paintings and has a coffe shop and souvenir shop at the entrance. Great to spend some time in. Bought some great little dishes made in Praha.

If you love the arts, you must visit Lobkowicz Palace!. We came across this by chance on our walk up to the castle. After wandering around the grounds of the castle and deciding that it was too crowded, we wandered back down the pathway to visit Lobkowicz Palace as we wanted to see the 2 Canaletto paintings of London (where we're from) and were amazed at our find -not just these paintings but just about everything we saw inside, including original manuscripts of Beethoven and so many musical instruments. The audio guide was just brilliant too, giving a family history right up to the present.

A hidden treasure in the Prague Castle area. As we finished touring the Golden Lane and were on the way to exit the castle area rain began and to take shelter we saw the Lobkowicz Palace. The audio device guided tour was a bit expensive but consistent with the rest of the Castle attractions and much better than the long walk in the rain so we began the tour not knowing what to expect. The audio guide was quite good filling in the history of the families and their journey through Czech history. There is a fair amount of stairs to cover the multiple floors of the exhibits. Very nice collections of family portraits, other paintings, weapons and armor and period decor. Worth seeing.

Palace Tour. We took a tour of the Palace today and were pleasantly surprised by the intertwining of history and amazing treasures in the Palace (e.g., Beethoven's original manuscripts and his close relationship with the Lobkowicz family). It was an especially memorable event as a member of the family, William Lobkowicz, made a personal appearance to our tour group to speak about historical events and the future of the family's efforts to collect and restore lost family treasures and present them to the public. The audio tour was outstanding.

Great Insight into Czech History. The tour of Lobkowicz Palace is quite an eye opener as history unfolds before you. The paintings, firearms, and other artifacts tell a story that draws you in. If you have the time, take in the 1 hour concert which is relaxing and well worth it.

Great family history and aritfacts. The museum was a little on the pricey side but consistent with the prices of other attractions. It does come with an audio tour guide which was great. It gave a lot of history about the family and the artifacts there. They have some great music items for those interested in mozart.

Intriquing Story, Fabulous Displays. Enjoyed almost solitary time in this private castle viewing stunning collections with the assistance of a lovely audio-guide narrated by the actual family members. Highly recommend it. Other reviewers speak eloquently of various special collections, some the kind that give you the good kind of goose bumps. I was quite taken by a room of restored bird pictures that featured real bird feathers. Wished we had attended the afternoon musical concert that took place while we visited. The small gift shop yielded some nice, value-priced tokens to take home to grandchildren.

Impressive Private Collection & Setting. After touring the castle and Cathedral, upon exiting, there is a private palace that has some wonderful paintings. The palace is privately owned and a separate charge is necessary, but worth it. The audio tour is by one of the heirs of the original owners, and he is rightly proud of the steps taken by the family to preserve the family heritage. Highlights from the Museum include works by masters such as Canaletto, Brueghel the Elder, Cranach, and Velázquez, a display of family and royal portraits, & displays of historical tableware & firearms. A big draw for me were the original scores and manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart, including Beethoven’s 4th and 5th symphonies and Mozart’s re-orchestration of Handel’s Messiah. Afterwards, you can get a lunch at the Palace overlooking the city with a scenic view.

Quite a Story. After a long history under the Hapsburgd, the palace was lost twice -once to the Germans in WWII and then when the Soviets took over. It's amazing to see what a collection of art and artifacts the family was able to recover.

Living History. As an amateur violinist I had often noted Beethoven's dedications of major works to Lobkowicz so a visit here was a top priority. I found that Lobkowicz had provided Beethoven with a life-long stipend, allowing Beethoven's precious gifts to operate unhindered by the need to earn a daily crust. Other beneficiaries were Mozart, Haydn and even Gluck, son of one of Lobkowicz's foresters.The Lobkowicz family's connections with the arts are many. This tour is a real education and the government's restoration to them of their land and assets has been justified by their careful stewardship of them for the benefit of posterity. I was only sorry that there were no tickets left for the concert on that day.Strongly recommended to anyone who is interested in music, art or architecture.

History comes to life. There is something special about learning history from someone who can give you their first-hand experiences. Touring the Lobkowicz Palace is like having a conversation with a royal family, tracking through their ancestry and their fortunes under successive regimes. The audio guide, narrated by Lobkowicz family members themselves, who moved back to Prague from the USA, takes you through a fabulous building and its interesting collections. Worth a visit!

Should be on the top 10 list. The history behind the Lobkowicz Family and their remarkable return to Prague is what prompted us to visit this fantastic museum. The fact that their lands and collections were lost and returned twice due to first the Nazis and then the Communists and the tenacity of the family to work to restore their family history could be a movie. Highly recommend.

A great collection of art and artifacts. The Lobkowicz Palace, though located on the extremely touristy castle hill, is easy to miss because it is separate from the other, more popular, tours of the cathedral and Hapsburg Palace. It is definitely worth the time to check it out, and, because it is easy to miss, it has the added advantage of being much less busy than the neighboring attractions. The audio tour guide is included in the ticket price and, in the English version at least, is done by the current head of the family. The art and artifacts included all have Lobkowicz family connections which makes the collection coherent.Musical performances (separate fee) are also offered at the Palace.One word of advice is to skip the cafe in the Palace as it seemed extremely overpriced and not really special.

Ho hum.. While the Palace is steeped in history and there are some fine paintings and historical pieces, i found it a bit boring. You can't take photos either. Still, it does give a bit of history about the family and its origins.
A hidden gem!. An extremely worthwhile visit to a very special home. Hard to imagine that this is a private home and collection. We had only 2 hrs, but we could have stayed 4.

The best attraction in Prague ..... ..... an amazing museum tour with the audio narrated by the Lobkowicz family. The family portraits and original scores by Mozart and others and other family objects definitely made the history of the area come alive. The concert in the family's music room was most enjoyable.

Do Not Miss This Historical Family Palace. This is not a typical Royal family palace. This place has collections and histories that are unlike many others! The Lobkowicz family is truly fascinating and still have living members! The history and charm of this Palace is truly amazing.

A Fascinating History. The important aspect of the Lobkowitz Palace lies in its history - a palace that was taken from the family, together with its art collection, during World War II, retained by the communists during the period of communist occupation and finally returned to the family following the "velvet war", when communism was defeated. It's well worth a visit, especially to see the original Beethoven manuscripts and the art and delft collections.

Unmissable, this collection really is spectacular. Make sure you leave ample time to enjoy the full extent of this experience. The Lobkowicz Collection is truly amazing. From Mozart's amendments to manuscripts, family history, bird paintings and weapons, this collection is full of important European history. For once, I would also recommend listening to the audio that is included as part of the admission fee (275 Kč). The commentary is provided by members of the family and gives you a real insight into the significance of the collection, their pride in their family history and the struggles they have undergone to preserve it. If you only do one thing in Prague, this should be it.

Interesting Place To Visit. We went on a tour and found the story of the family interesting, and the various rooms full of paintings and artifacts of a bygone era. The music room was particularly impressive.

Lobkowicz Palace Treasures. Try to make some extra time to really explore this Palace not only for its treasures but its interesting Lobkowicz family history. Arrange tickets for the daytime concert - you won't be disappointed a very special opportunity.

Highlight of our trip to Prague!. This is a true gem and overshadows the castle itself. The role the ancestors of the family who own this museum played in providing patronage to the emerging talent of Mozart was clearly pivotal. To stand in front of Mozart's handwritten orchestral manuscript was truly moving along with the Caneletto's and Velaquez paintings. The audio tour provided with the ticket price as others have said is incredibly good. If you only have a limited time period in the castle precinct make this a priority - you won't regret it.

Excellent Audio Tour. We liked that the audio tour was included in the ticket price. Also, it was a well done audio guide. We spent about 1.5 hours in the Palace. There were some interesting pieces. If you are in the area, the cafe has a nice outdoor balcony (food is okay).

Family jewel. Fantastic family history from the Nazis to the Communists. This family has survived and has amazing artifacts in their palace including original Beethoven manuscripts. A fine collection of musical instruments and guns. A family member does the narration on the audio guide which is excellent.

Concert and art gallery. We attended the midday(at 1pm) classic concert, not being much into classic music, it was excellent. 13 pieces of music by different composers, played either on flute, piano or violin, or all of them, several pieces you will recognise. A good taster experience. Then looked around the gallery/museum afterwards, so much to see.

Awesome. I happened on this place by chance and went in more to get away from the maddening crowds in the castle.It was the best money (about 12 euro I think) that I have spent in a long time for admission to a musuem. It is an almost perfect collection - I dare you to find something that wont fascinate you here - and is beautifully curated. It gives you firstly a sense of the history of Bohemia and secondly a fascinating glimpse of the landed gentry of Europe. This is the home of an immensely cultured family and even things that would not normally interest me eg the delft collection and the guns, were of such quality that it is just amazing that it is all still intact.The highlight has to be the music room with the original manuscripts by Mozart and Beethoven but an outstanding Breughel is worth the admission alone. The audio tour (which comes with the admission) is excellent and helpfully highlights the best pieces so that if you are short of time you could do this in little more than an hour - but please allow a little more time to savour some of the most awe inspiring things you may ever see.

Wonderful Experience - Great Story, Great Lunch and Great Views. We visited the Palace in early May, 2015. Our tour included lunch and a brief chamber concert. We thoroughly enjoyed the entire experience. After the sun-soaked starkness and heat of the interior courtyards of Prague Castle, entering the Lobkowicz Palace is a refreshing change. Our lunch of Czech-style goulash with dumplings was excellent and the dessert of homemade cheesecake with wild berry sauce was really yummy. It was a nice way to begin our visit. The art and objects on display make up one of the finest private collections that we have seen. Of particular meaning to us was seeing the score of Handel's Messiah annotated by Mozart for his re-orchestration of the work - Year 1789. The family story is also fascinating and is brought to life by the narration by the youngest members of the Lobkowicz family. The recorded tour is extremely well done and it was nice to be able to move through the rooms at our own speed. Views from the terrace are, of course, beautiful. If one visits Prague Castle, besides St. Vitus Cathedral, a visit to the Lobkowicz Palace is worth the time. Don't miss it!

A must see. One of most interesting places on Castle Hill.. When we were in Prague in the past never went to this Palace, but decided to visit this time. Wish we had seen it earlier. With the larger Castle you really don't get the sense of how it was furnished or lived in. The opposite is true with Lobkowicz Palace. The audio guide is one of the best we have ever experienced. The bird room and dog room were phenomenal. Staff was very friendly.

good place to get a feel of Prague of the recent past. Prague generally is a great place to visit; who knew. We were on a Rick Steves Eastern European tour and it was a great experience. We went to this palace and had lunch and took in the concert. His families story of Communist taking his property and getting it back after freedom from the Communist is like a movie story.
Views of Prague. Full of history and great views over Prague. Views of Prague are some of the best from the walls of the palace

Not super English friendly. We were visiting a friend and he was translating for us a lot. We visited this palace within an hour of getting off the plane! Maybe the staff did not like us? They were not friendly at all and pre-lectured our friend about translating for us! The collections were lovely, its a very well kept palace. Worth a look if you have a lot of time to spend in the area but not a MUST see in my book.

Great Museum / Coffee with view. Great collection of paintings. The family enjoyed the tour whilst I was enjoying a cappuccino on the terrace in the coffee shop on the ground floor of the Palace from where you have a fantastic view over Prague. We stopped in the Gift Shop on the way out and bought some genuine Czech souvenirs.I should recommend to visit for anyone.

Touch of Noble family. Graet exhibition of family story of one of most important noble family of Bohemian kingnom. Audio guide is accompanying you throught exposition witn voice of prince Lobkowitz, you can see collections of family as well as beautifull pallace rooms.Beautifull wiew of Prague is a free bonus during refreshement on pallace terracce. You shouldnt mis it!
Lovely Lunch Spot. Ideally situated in Palace ground. Lovely simple lunch after visiting this amazing palace. Had the lunch special which was great value and very enjoyable
Beautiful.. We loved our entry into the classical music recital and lunch on the terrace with awesome views of the city. A must do attraction.

The history of the family is amazing.. The family played a major role in mid-European life for many centuries and collected a wonderful assortment of pieces and art. Lost and recovered their holding twice in the 20th century. The voice narrative is very well done, by current family members, making the continuity of the family very meaningful.

Concert in the concert room. We bought a combimed ticket to a concert (piano, viola and flute trio) and to the palace itself. The concert was absolutely excellent, and the concert room it was in was very impressive. There is a lot of art in the palace, the Canaletto London pictures being particularly impressive (particularly the one which is less well known). However there are whole walls of family portraits, of variable quality, and to me, quite little interest. The audio tour was annoying, lots about the family, and a grating sense of entitlement regarding the properties which were restored to the family by Vaclav Havel.
Very fine. This museum was elegant, interesting, had great variety of various artifacts. Splendid display of Beethoven and other composers personally annotated musical scores.

A Must See in Prague!!. This was our first visit to Prague and the tour of the Lobkowicz Palace was a highlight of not only our visit to Prague but our entire European trip. It seemed there were wonderful surprises around every corner: our lunch, the classical concert, meeting and talking with William Lobkowicz, and finally seeing the incredible treasures in the palace museum. I may never visit Prague again, but if I do, I will definitely find myself touring this magnificent building again.

Great Palace that is not marketed enough. Wonderful tour here that wasn't marketed by our Guide. We went on our own steam and found it really informative. The fact that family give the audio tour is fantastic too - makes it seem so real! Loved the Caneleto paintings!

A palace with a very interesting history. The Lobkowicz family tree has three major trunks and members include Phillip II of Spain. Many of the relatives portraits dating back to the 1600's are presented in two rooms of family history. Part of the palace has been opened to the public by the family and includes a china room, firearms collection, the dog's room, bird room, and the music room. We enjoyed a wonderful lunch in the cafe on the premises outside on the balcony with a good view. We returned to the music room in the afternoon for a concert by a pianist, flutist, and violinist. It was like being transported back in time to hear Bach, Handel, and others played just as they intended with no microphones, and superb acoustics.

Great art work. Some rooms were closed on the day we were there for a 'private function'. Overall I thought the materials on show were average although the portraits and other art works were very interesting.

Definate for classical buffs. I booked the combination ticket and went to the lunchtime classical concert. Well worth it. The three players were exceptional individually and as a group. An hour of pure bliss.

Don't miss this little gem. It is, essentially, a family museum, reconstituted after the communist government fell. It is a wonderful collection of paintings, music and other art. The free audio guide is narrated by the family member in charge of managing the museum and it's collection, and it's great. Definitely make time for a few hours on your way back from visiting the castle.

A lovely if small museum and palace. We had a private evening tour of Lobkowicz Palace and then dinner on their balcony overlooking the city. It was all magical. This is a private collection of the Lobkowicz family and includes some personal portraits of their forebears as well as a fascinating music room with a collection of instruments and some personally annotated scores by Mozart etc The restaurant is a much better than average museum eatery and if you get a seat on the balcony you will have a breathtaking view of Prague.

An unexpected addition to our visit to the castle area. We thought we'd finished looking at the various attractions of the Prague castle, when we noticed that there were some Canalettos on display at the Lobkowicz Palace. Indeed there were, and there was also a Breugel - but the real story was that of the Lobkowicz family, patrons of Mozart and Beethoven. The family suffered during both the second world war and under the Communist government of Czechoslovakia; quite a story.

A hidden gem just a few feet from Prague Castle. Do not miss this. It has treasures galore and doesn't seem to be mobbed like other venues. You will see one of a kind exhibits and a free, terrific audio guide is included.

Lobkowicz Palace. I just got back from a quick weekend in Prague, and visited the Lobkowicz Palace for the first time. It was the highlight of Prague Castle. If you have time, I'd definitely suggest going. When my traveling companion suggested it, I was quite skeptical. I didn't really want to visit another palace, but I went along with it and I am very glad I did. It is a family's art collection. It is primarily paintings, but there are other things as well. The original manuscripts from Mozart and Beethoven were incredible to see. What really made the visit worthwhile was the way that the stories around the collection are told. The family narrates the audio guide, which makes for a far more personal experience than at a typical art museum. The stories they share are fascinating. They also explain how the collection was confiscated, and a bit of what it took to get it back. Very, very worthwhile stop. It's also a good way to escape the crowds at Prague Castle :)
Mid-day concert worthwhile. Attended the 1 pm concert. Great recognizable classical music very professional, wonderful ambience.
Apple Strudell and coffee. With magnificent views of the city from the balcony who couldn't enjoy coffee and cake. We had beautiful weather which was an added bonus

Lobkowicz Palace. We visited Prague Castle today but the museum we wanted to visit was closed on Mondays, how fortunate. Yesterday we took a tour of Prague with Beat Tour and stopped at the Lobkowicz Palace for a comfort break. We returned today and I have to say it has been the highlight of the visit. For the price of your entry you get an audio guide narrated by the owner of the Palace, William Lobkowicz. I think I said OMG at least once in every room. The paintings and music manuscripts are stunning. How wonderful to have a history like this. We finished up by having lunch in the Lobkowicz Cafe and one of the tastiest chicken Caesar salads I have had in a long time. This gem is well worth a visit.

Must see in Prague. We dined. Enjoyed a delightful private concert. Tour was magnificent. My favorite was were the original manuscripts of WA Mozart and Beethoven. The armory was very impressive as well. We thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to tour the Palace. There is no photography permitted.

family history direct from the family. A wonderful collection of art and rare objects beautifully displayed and explained with the best audio tour I have ever taken. Don't miss the London Canalettos they are magnifeicent

Highlight of Prague. The story of the Lobkowicz family is the story of the Czech Republic. One of the oldest and wealthiest families in the country, their family history is intertwined with the history of the Czechs. Their Palace is actually located within the confines of Prague Castle, the only privately owned property there. It contains the artworks and treasures that the family has collected over the centuries. The family has lost and regained its proper twice, first under the Germans in WWII, and a second time under the communists after WWII. The were able to regain the property after the liberation of the Czech Republic in the 1990s, but as the family had relocated to the United States, they decided to open their properties and collections to the public. Of particular interest is the fact that the English narration on the audio tour was done by William Lobkowicz which gives the tour of the collection a very intimate feel, such as when he refers to his grandfather, or his aunt obtaining something in the collection. And what a collection it is. On display are original manuscripts of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Ludwig van Beethoven compositions. The most valuable item is probably the manuscript of Beethoven´s Opus 55, Symphony No. 3 in E-flat major (Eroica), composed in 1803/04. Beethoven had originally conceived of dedicating the symphony to Napoleon Bonaparte, but instead dedicated the symphony to Prince Joseph Franz Maximilian Lobkowicz. This Lobkowicz ancestor was also dedicatee of some other great works, including Joseph Haydn's "Lobkowitz" quartets (Opus 77), and Beethoven's 5th and 6th symphonies, as well as his Opus 18 string quartets. It is amazing to think that this family had a hand in the creation of some of the greatest musical works everwritten. There is also a daily midday concert on the premises for an extra charge, but is well worth attending. It consists of a flautist, viola player and a pianist who were all quite talented, and is an hour of enertaining music played in a beautiful drawing room. A combination ticket for the place and the concert gives a discount on admission.Last, but not least, there is a very reasonably priced cafe on the premises where we had a very nice lunch after we toured the collections. Highly recommended.

An interesting place with an interesting history and priceless pieces.. The family was able to reclaim their collections after Nazi and Communist confiscations. The highlight for me were the hand annotated and autographed Beethoeven scores. Palace also has a nice restaurant with great views and also does daily concerts.

A true Gem in Prague!. During my 2-week visit with my daughter and her husband (who live in Prague) they recommended that I visit the Lobkowicz Palace, located on the grounds of the Prague Castle. I was overwhelmed by the top-notch audio tour; amazing collections; the family history; gift shop (always a favorite stop on any tour for me) and the friendly staff. I told my daughter and her hubby how great my day at the palace was and the next day, attending a pottery market at another of the family's castles, we met William Lobkowitz (yes, the person who runs the "family business") and his wife. How cool that I was able to tell them both how much I enjoyed the palace and the cafe, which has a nice selection of food and offers breathtaking views of Prague. Highly recommend spending time at the the palace!

great Family History on this Palace. This is the Palace you should paid to see and save your money by not seeing the castle. The Lobkowicz Palace has so much to see, plus they don't charge you a deposit on their audio like Prague Castle does. The cafe in which this family took to restore their history and this Palace is amazing. Also has a great cafe with beautiful views of the city.

Superb - amazing history and connection to music. Now this is some attraction and one that totally exceeded my expectations. The museum itself is a delight with excellent audio commentary available as part of the ticket. Take time to soak it up. The connection of the Lobkowicz family to musical greats like Mozart and Beethoven is a fascinating part of their family history. We also took in the one hour concert which is extra and needs to be booked well in advance. This was magnificent - piano, viola and flute.The is also a good cafe. Try to get a table on the outside deck overlooking the city for a superb panorama

Simply Superb in all categories!!. Oh my goodness: don't miss it. We spent a good share of the day there going through the collections (paintings, ceramics, arms and armor, musical scores) with the included audio device, having a lovely lunch on the balcony of the restaurant, attended the concert, shopped for a few treasures in the gift shop. We tour on a bit of a budget and this entire experience didn't tax our budget over much. I can't praise it highly enough - when we return to Prague, we will definitely return to the Lobkowicz Palace. This day will live in our memories.
Lovely. We went to the palace for a music performance and loved the beautiful setting. It is at the fat end if the castle complex, so give yourself plenty of time to get there.

Underrated and somehow undiscovered by many tourists eve though it is right in the castle. The Lobkowicz collection is an absolutely enthralling place to visit. An audio headset tour narrated by William Lobkowicz himself takes you through the palace and makes the family history, paintings, armoury and treasure come alive.
The paintings alone are magnificent with Canalettos and Breugels. An original Mozart manuscript in there to view.

Amazing. Our Tauck Tour group brought us to the Lobkowicz Palace. We met a descendent of the Lobkowicz family. He told us the history of the Palace and then we toured the Palace.Beautiful art work, gun collection, were the original musical scores by Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven. Just amazing that this collection even exists. Very impressive.The audio device brought the people, music and era alive.

Art, History, good food, a concert, & meeting a Prince. What is not to like! A visit to this palace includes a world class art & historical artifact collection, excellent local fare in the dining room, beautiful music, a fortunate visit by the Prince, & you support the continued reclamation & restoration of treasures stolen by the Nazis.

Best museum in Prague. We visited the Lobkowicz Palace by chance whilst visiting the Castle.It is definitely not to be missed. The audio tour is narrated by the Lobkowicz family and you feel as though you are hearing the true and astonishing story of how they lost everything twice, to the Nazis and then the Communists and then they got most if not all of it back in the 1990s after the Velvet Revolution.There are so many things to see and stories to be heard, including an original manuscript of Beethoven's 5th and his 3rd symphony and Mozarts orchestration of Handels Messiah.A truly outstanding experience, and definitely the highlight of our visit to Prague.

Amazing slice of Czech history!. We visited this attraction on the recommendation of our local tour guide. In Prague's sea of touristy traps, this is an absolute gem. The self-guided audio tour tells the amazing story of a family that lost and regained their fortune from both the Nazi's and the Communist government. The museum collection includes original scores from Beethoven and Mozart, incredible art, and an unbelievable collection of weaponry. Be sure to buy the combination ticket which includes a midday chamber concert performance! The admission includes a 10 % discount for the adjoining Palace Cafe, which offers an affordable option to enjoy a light lunch.

amazing place to visit. As you walk toward this place it looks massive and grand but nothing prepares you for how big it is, be prepared for a lt of walking, but it's worth it the view from on top of the wall overlooking the city is nothing short of breathtaking. Once you get in to the place the grandeur of the place is something to behold. Be prepared for a lot of people, I would recommend going early in the morning to avoid the crowds.

Worth every penny!. We spent at least half a rainy day wandering round the palace with our audioguides, learing about the family, their fortunes and misfortunes. Entrance to the caste was included when we bought tickets for the lunch concert. A piano, flute and viola in a room where the acoustics were perfect.
A mellow hour. We spent a mellow, honeyed hour listening to the classical concert which is performed daily at the palace at 1-2pm. Superb!!

It's worth the experience!. We had the pleasure of having a private tour with Viking River Cruises. The whole experience was magical, up to meeting Prince Lobkowicz. Learning about the family's history and then viewing some of the art pieces, just tied it all together. The private concert they had for us was absolutely perfect. If you enjoy photography the panoramic view from the terrace is one of the best in Prague.

Worth visiting for music and art lovers. I think this is the only private palace on the grounds of the Prague Castle. There is an interesting art collection with interesting comments on the tour tape. The Lobkowicz family were patrons of Gluck, Haydn and Beethoven, and the museum contains original manuscripts of these composers. We also enjoyed the food in the restaurant, which has a great view over Prague from the balcony.

The Palace you never heard about. Your trip to Prague will not be complete without a visit to this palace. We had the privilege of hearing William Lobkowicz speak of the effort to make this beautiful place available to public view. The family lost in he palace twice: once to be he nazis and once to the communists.

WELL WORTH IT.. The Lobkowicz Palace is right at the bottom end of the Prague Castle complex. It is also one of those places that seems to be ignored by the followers of the colourful umbrellas and giant flowers - the tour groups! You can therefore enjoy the visit without too many crowds. For me the museum is excellent and made all the more interesting and personal by the fact that the narrator on the audio guide was William Lobkowicz himself. The family story is a powerful and moving one and I for one am delighted to see the property back in the hands of the original owners after the decades of turmoil in the last century. The fact that the family is prepared to put all these items on show for the public to see in a museum, to me, speaks volumes about them. Not everyone is prepared to do that. There is a wide variety of exhibits to enjoy - paintings, weapons and other artefacts. If you are interested in the history of music there is some fascinating material. I entirely agree with the "Hidden Gem" description. It isn't cheap, but then very few things in life are. It was well worth the money for us and I certainly don't mind paying for the upkeep of the kind of treasures that the museum houses. There is also a good little café.All in all, a great visit and another "must" if you are off to Prague.
Amazing. Indeed amazing place to see...Having the atmosphere which you feel the old times...Country culture harmonized there and, came out of the world for the people to see and, feel...

A hidden gem. We hadn't planned to visit the Lobkowicz Palace on our trip to Prague. By chance we picked up a brochure at our hotel.The midday concerts attracted us. The concert was great but there was so much more A great audio tour narrated by one of the descendants..Portraits of family members and contemporary greats. The portion of the museum that really knocked our socks off was the music room. We learned that the the Lobkowiicz's provided an unconditional stipend to Beethoven and some of his works were dedicated to them.And if this was not enough, original scores by Beethoven and Mozart.We also had a delightfl lunnch in their cafe which has outdoor seating with a great view of Prague from the Palace complex

A must see. A definite highlight of our trip to Prague. We got there shortly after it opened at 10:00 am. We had the place to ourselves. Most tourists walk right past. The audio guide was outstanding in narrartating the history of the Lobkowicz family. The 16th century palace is a private musuem which includes paintings, weapons, armore, some furniture, music memorabilia. Tram 22 will get you there. Worth the admission price of 275 CZK. Going back it's about a 10 minute walk to the Old Town Center.

Midday classical concert. We booked this on a whim and were so glad we did. We are not big classical music aficionados but this one hour concert was such a lovely mixture of pieces that we were familiar with, performed in such a lovely setting. We rounded off our visit with a light lunch on the balcony of the palace terrace cafe. Great food and service, gorgeous views over the city.

One of the best audio tours we ever took. I could not get the history straight about Prague but after taking the tour of this incredible museum/palace, I was able to put everything into perspective. I am so happy we visited the Lobkowicz Palace. A "jewel."

Elegant Museum with a Personal Touch. Our family loved the Latest blow it Palace and art collection. The tour was memorable in large part due to personal narration of the collection by family members who helped recover the pieces after the Communist era. The restaurant also served the best soups and deserts of our visit. This was perhaps our favorite spot during a week of touring Prague.
I really liked this place.. We thought this was a marvelous palace. The family's connection to Beethoven was fascinating. The audio guide was excellent.

True palace. This is what you expect a palace to look like. It was without a doubt one of the most interesting and beautiful places in Prague. The audio tour was easy to follow and made the history come alive. We had a wonderful lunch and an fantastic concert by a string trio. A great day.
Another great place to visit in Prague Castle. A lovely building and worth visiting if you are visiting the Castle . They also do lunch time concerts the Terrace Cafe has great views.

truly amazing Palace and Wonderful setting. It is huge palace. Thats it!!
We can go at length speaking about its architecture and artwork done in place. I am still amateur, still learning what art meant to Europeans.
Even if you have little knowledge, you would not stop admiring the beauty :)

Not well publicised but worth visiting!. This Palace is located almost at the end of the Prague Castle area/grounds. It is the private art collection and furnishings of the Lobkowicz family - you get audio provided as part of the ticket - ticket can be bought on line in advance but it certainly wasn't busy and no real difference in price. As a lot of the castle buildings do not have a lot of furnishings to see per se - this was really quite interesting and would recommend it.

Most enjoyable visit to Lolbkowicz Palace. This was without question, a major highlight during our recent trip to Prague. A very genuine," from the heart" audio tour given by William Lobkowicz as well as his wife ,father and mother about the beautiful contents of the collection that includes original manuscripts of such composers as Mozart and Beethoven , magnificent art works and ceramics. This is a must visit when in Prague and a most memorable experience. The gift shop has some very beautiful items to purchase at reasonable prices too.

Brueghel !!!!!. OK, I admit : I'm Flemish. Perhaps that influences my judgment. I liked the whole museum and the story (stories) behind it. I enjoyed seeing the manuscript of Beethoven's Fifth symphony (among others).But ...The Green Michelin Guides use the expression : "Vaut le voyage" (worth while the travel). Peter Brueghel the Elder's "The Haymaking" on its own "vaut le voyage". And I'm prepared to stand on anybody's coffee-table with my flemish shoes on and say that again ! Go there and watch it. Feel the summer. Laugh. Enjoy.

Fascinating. Went to this palace by chance,as the castle had too many tourists around,and a long queue to get in.Very interesting family home over the centuries.Audio was included in the price of the ticket.Also lovely little cafe with very good food and reasonably priced.

a MUST see in Prague. Incredible family history, amazing art, military armor, and a music collection featuring original scores by Beethoven and more. You'll feel extremely emotional walking through some of the rooms of the palace as you learn and see some of the great history of Prague and through such an important family in the history of the city. Often shadowed by the Prague Castle, tourists make the mistake of walking right past it. I highly recommend putting this on your list. Really great. Good for anyone to visit.
Nothing special physically. The palace is not like your usual palace. It's not massive. I did enjoy the history side of it though.
Family history that was a new experience. really enjoyed seeing the artwork and did not know anything about the family beforehand. The cafe was really good.

Nice piece of history. Visiting the palace and viewing its art collection gave me the sense of history of Bohemia.
However listening the music in the palace was not a good choice and worth the price. It was a potpourri of some of the well know classical music pieces.

Staff is accomodating and 1 pm concert is worth going to. This is a private family museum which contains the works of famous musicians like Mozart, Beethoven, etc. The staff is friendly, and place is beautiful, the gift shop has unique treasures, and the wifi music cafe is worth stopping to grab a light snack. Tucked in the heart of the castle, you need to buy the ticket once you're inside the castle. TIP: They give you a discount for their portion of the tour and the full castle tour if you buy the ticket here rather than at the FRONT of the castle information. You can enter the castle without a ticket and head to Lobkowicz Palace inside (stay on the castle grounds and you will end up here when you reach almost to the end). Worth attending, esp. if you are a muscian like myself.

beautiful. this is stunning. its the old part of prague and as you descend down from the palace the streets are stunning with stories to tell. the old street where people lived is now a musuem. the paths and roads are all cobbled so dont wear heels. to imagine that people used to live there and some still do all i can say is they are very lucky. when i was there i saw the changing of the guard which was great.
Amazing collection. An interesting collection - made outstanding and visit-worthy by the audio guide and the story behind it. Worth it!
Beautiful with great history. We had the privilege of learning the story and history of the Lobkowicz Palace and the entire family... well worth it.

Interesting and cultural. We enjoyed visiting the museum and liked the audio tour in English. Lots to see from this important Czech family.We then enjoyed a Classical concert at lunchtime with piano, flute and viola ...very good , wonderful live music.

Incredible music. Loved the tour of the palace which provided a great history of both the Lobkowicz family and palace. It was interesting to learn of the family and understand how the history of the Czech Republic shaped the palace into what we see today. The mid afternoon concert is a true treat as well. Nothing will beat being inside the beautiful palace listening to world class music played by such skilled musicians!

Very interesting. Very interesting tour with accompanied audio guide. Family had to flee during the war and how they went about to reclaim all their holdings. The English audio guide really enhanced the tour and is given by the current owner explaining the family history and guiding you through the various rooms of the palace. Well worth a visit.

Not to miss. A must if in Prague. History just drips everywhere and is astounding. Don't miss lunch at the Palace Cafe and browse the Palace Museum Shop. It is hard to believe there is so much to see and enjoy in one place. Beautiful Old master paintings.

Go for lunch enjoy the view. Part of the palace complex we sat on the verandah with heaters and blankets!, yes we were warm!,Had a loveley lunch and used the clean and free toiletsThere are concerts held here and it would be loveley to hear one if you are there at the right time

A surprise delight in Prague Castle. After walking through Prague Castle from the top to the lower end, we came across this intriguing palace built into the walls. The family's story as told at the entrance, sounded fascinating and the palace contains many wonderful artworks such as Canalettos and a Brueghel so we decided to go round it. The first room, full of family protraits at first seemed uninteresting until we listened to the included audio guide, spoken by the current Prince Lobkowicz. He led us through the amazing tale of his family's history from the 16th century to today, bringing the various family members to life and culminating in how they had lost everything not once but twice, first to the Nazis and then in the early 50's to the communists and how they had eventually recovered nearly all of their numerous Castles and Palaces and the priceless collections of art and furniture.The palace feels very much a home inspite of the grandeur; the staff were friendly and there were touches like an account of the family dogs over the centuries. It is very manageable even after a day of walking round Prague and we felt that we had been somewhere extremely special, personal and much loved yet important in Czech and European history

Great chance to see Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts!. Loved this little palace within the larger castle complex! For music lovers there is a rare chance to see some precious manuscripts written by Mozart and Beethoven as well as one of the seasons paintings by Bruegel (the remain four are in Vienna and one is missing) .The cafe is excellent with marvellous views from the balcony. This little palace is a gem and often overlooked by visitors possibly because there is an extra entrance fee payable. Well worth it in my opinion.

Midafternoon musical respite. We booked our afternoon concert through our hotel and paid with a voucher. The music was quite lovely and featured a violin, flute and piano playing many of the famous Renaissance era classics. After the show we made a quick stop in the cafe for some drinks and then back out to the city. We did not tour the museum part but the cafe and concert were lovely.

Best event of our stay in Prague. We took a tour of the Lobkowicz collections after spending the morning on a Viking Cruise Prague city walking tour. The tour ended up at the Castle, cathedral, and President's building, where we were picked up by a Viking Tour of the Lobkowicz Palace, the only privately owned property at the Castle. No one should miss seeing this, the highlight of our tour of Prague; we spent some time walking through the private art collection that was stolen by the Nazis and held captive by the communists until 1989. The Lobkowicz family has been reconstructing the collection since then. Family members narrated the audio tour that explained the art, the history, and the current state of the collection. A short concert of classical selections by a pianist, violinist, and cellist followed the art exhibit, a real touch of elegance. More to come-- we were wined and dined in a lovely room in the palace, and after lunch, Mr. Lobkowicz came in to visit with us and answer questions. From Boston, he was informal, informative, and totally charming. Evidently, he came to visit our group because we were the first Viking tour group of the season.If you are visiting Prague, this is a do-not-miss stop. If you are on a Viking tour, GO!

Don't miss this in Prague Castle. Highlight of whole Prague Castle experience, the guided audio tour is very enjoyable and even includes paintings of the family dogs. The afternoon concert was good, but can be skipped if you are short on time.

Americans Claimed and Own This Palace, How Cool Is That?. While traveling with my aunt we had a chance to do the Palace Tour with Viking Cruises. The tour included an amazing lunch in one of the ballrooms which had an amazing view of Prague. The treasures this family was able to claim back after the war is astounding. Mr. Lobkowicz was able to come and speak with our group during lunch and hearing the story of his family and how they were able to get the Palace back is truly a great historical story. Being American is was very interesting to hear how they were able to come back to Prague and claim their property and all the hard work it took. The audio tour is very informative and easy to follow. The tour itself will take you an hour or two if you want to listen to everything. They have a "fast track" path to follow if you just want to "cliff notes" version of the museum. They gave us a concert of classical music which was awesome as well!

an amazing insight in the possessions of this wealthy family. Yes, there are many portrets of the many members of the Lobkowicz family. But, more interesting, also beautiful paintings by e.g. Breughel and Canaletto. And really amazing and moving: the original score of the 5 th symphony of Beethoven, dedicated to a member of the family. There are photo's of the famous conductor Kurt Masur, browsing through the pages, to find the personal remarks of Beethoven in the margin. And; like the other art musea in Prague ; You'll be one of only a few visitors.

Eye opening tour of a huge art collection. this tour was brilliant and recommendable, the ticket in clouded an audio tour which was narrated by the current head of the Lobkowicz family, giving a personal and informative touch to the whole experience. I especially enjoyed the contributions to classical music made by the ancestors.

Spectacular Palace, Museum, Luncheon, and Concert. After admiring the outside of the Palace and the surrounding area, we went into the Palace for a luncheon. This consisted of rolls, salad, spinach lasagna for us, and cheesecake, all of which were quite decent. After this, we went to a small room for a short concert of classical music played by a trio (piano, cello, violin). The classical music included pieces by Mozart, Bartok, etc. After the concert, we went through a museum of paintings, dishes, guns, and much more, accumulated by the Lobkowicz family. On the tour, we had a recorded guide to identify and amplify what we were looking at.

Very enjoyable experience. The Lobkowiczs have hit upon an absolutely wonderful formula for a museum-going experience, which seriously deserves to be emulated (and should to be a required experienced for many a museum curator). Because everything in the collection is presented within the larger story of the Lobkowicz family, which is superbly scripted and told on the audiophones (without any of the affectation, pretension, or indulgent/excessive details that characterize too many audiophone experiences), the pieces in the collection are given true meaning. I normally walk through a museum room full of paintings of 15th-century nobility because there is no way to appreciate them--'if you've seen one, you've seen them all.' Yet, here I ended up spending more than half an hour in the first room because the Lobkowicz's stories of who they were (masterfully combined with touches like a personal letter between a wife and husband and details of what happened to a garnet ring in one painting) were engaging and interesting. I spent almost two hours, listening to all the audiophone recordings and studying the collection presented in just a few rooms on two floors. Wafting through the rooms was the live classical music of the midday concert that sounded delightful and, like everything so tastefully presented here, also was so much more real than what is usually served up in a museum-going experience meant to be cultured. In particular, so much of our museum-going experiences these days are structured around a particular curator's theory, interests, or passion (which ultimately decontextualizes the objects and renders them as merely objects of curiosity and ultimately unreal) that having a collection set in its historically authentic story was wonderful. Here you can appreciate things with the Lobkowiczs who are authentically sharing a history as if you were their personal guest.
Don't miss!!. This private residence offers tours and a luncheon with specialties of the house like their own aperitif, to be savored while having the best view of the city from a gorgeous balcony.

Take in some culture. We went to a lunchtime concert at the Lobkowicz Palace. These take place daily at 1pm, last about an hour and are popular classics played by very talented musicians. Add a bit of class to your visit!!!
Lovely orchestra show. We enjoyed the midday orchestra show there....make sure you arrive well on time as it is a long walk from the entrance of the main palace. But well worth it!
amazing. loved this place warm feeling great atmosphere found it purely by walking past looking for another bar and the view is stunning overlooking the water

A hidden jewel in a jewel of a city!. This was a wonderful museum with beautiful artwork and a fascinating story of the family who owned, lost and then regained their ancestral home. The audio headsets are a must as the family story is told by family members! Don't miss this treasure!!

A MUST See museum. The hidden treasure of Prague!. We were recommended this museum and are so glad that we went. The whole museum is well presented with a free audio guide included (use it as you learn so much!).Key things to see are Beethoven's 5th... the original score. The Bruegel landscape and a couple of Canaletto scenes of London...The cafe is good and you get a discount if you buy your museum tickets first!

Surprise gem. We only visited the Lobkowicz Palace because it came with our afternoon concern tickets, but we were so glad we did! The audio tour, by a modern-day member of the family, was interesting and informative, and the collection told us a lot about Prague history and noble families. There are some amazing artifacts, including a Beethoven score dedicated to one of the family members, among other impressive memorabilia. Even if you skip over some bits, there's plenty to enjoy.

Art museum. I wanted to take some photos of Prague at Night from the castle and had to kill some time before it was dark enough. I decided to go to this museum. I took the audioguide and when up, you begin with painted portraits, then porcelaine services, religious artefacts, weapons, music, painted animals and some kind of conference room/chapel. Everything is perfectly preserved, they have done an exceptional work with that. The audioguide explains the relations between the family and some of those piece of art, gives you some historical details... The obvious gems are the manuscripts from known composers but I also loved the last room that I felt had something special. Photos are prohibited. Definitely a really good private collection that survived the war. If you like paintings you will probably enjoy it and learn a thing or two about Prague at the same time.

Lobkowicz Palace. Don't miss this gem; it's the best museum in Prague... Breathtaking paintings by Breugel and Canaletto; original manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart... WONDERFUL audio tour narrated by William and Sandra Lobkowicz about the dazzling collection of paintings, furniture, china, and armaments housed in what was the family's Palace...Finish a wonderful hour or two by having a casual lunch in the cafe with spectacular, panoramic views of Prague.
Music. Every day at 13 a chamber orchestra, very good! We heard a combo of traditional, very well performed with a great ambiance

Interesting private perspective. i didn't know too much about the history of Prague before we visited for a tour and concert. It was very interesting to get such an insight into the way in which the Lobkowicz treasures are being recompiled and restored after decades of being lost to the Nazis and Communists. Particularly liked the original manuscripts and first edition Beethoven and Haydn scores. Gems.

Very modest. The paintings collection is really modest - mainly portraits of the Lobkowitz ancestors by second hand painters from the XVII-XVIII -th centuries. Only two paintings worth seeing - a Breugel and a Canaletto - definitely not worth the trouble. The whole collection consists of self-important bearded fat aristocrats dressed in black, painted by second-hand painters.

Private collections can be the best!. I thought it would be all portraits, but the ancestors were great travellers and collectors, so there is porcelain, weaponry across the centuries, 2 Canalletos, a Cranach the Elder (Renaissance) and the 4th Breughel - Haymaking. What an unexpected pleasure.

it needs atleast 4-5 hrs, plan accordingly. it is a must see when in prague. very scenic and gives one of the most amazing view of the city. palace is too big and there are lots to see inside. reach early to make best out of the ticket you spend to see them all. do not exchange money at western union. they are very expensive. other shop all around the street converts at a very good rate and without any charges.

Awesome all the way. I've visited Lobkowicz palace twice now, and just wow! There is so much decadence everywhere it's such a huge complex with beautiful statues and the view of Prague from the hill is stunning.

Lovely and you can eat here too!. The cafe on the ground floor has spectacular views over Prague. Food is lovely and reasonable, free wifi off those who care. Sit outside on the terrace if you can for the view - in Feb you get a blanket and sign under burners so you won't be cold!

Interesting if you want family history. I wasn't sure what to expect from this palace which is part of Prague Castle. For 275 CZK you are given an audio guide in your preferred language, which will give you insights at the numbered locations. There are over 30 recordings, but they are almost all historical information about the family, their weddings, love of dogs, how they lost and regained the palace. Most of the tour is paintings of family members, though there is an entire room dedicated to paintings of family dogs. I didn't find most of that interesting, because I have no stake in the family. They do have two rooms filled with old weapons, and probably the most interesting room to me was the music room which had a story about how one of the princes of the castle had Mozart stay there and write an opera and another story about having Beethoven on retainer so he could just write whatever music he wanted.The tour comes with a very small savings in the gift shop, and 10% off in the cafe, which is why I went into the cafe. This turned out to be the best part of the morning for me. The cafe has a terrace seating area which, in the early morning in February, was a quiet and peaceful way to prepare for the day. Their apple strudel is the best I've had in Prague. Next time I am up near the castle I will definitely stop back into the cafe, which can be accessed without the tour through another entrance.I didn't mind the tour, but I wouldn't do it again, and I didn't listen to the entire series of recordings.

Audio Tour. At around £8 per person I thought this was great value. A well laid out museum/exhibition you are left to explore with your audio tour guide, however there are people dotted around to offer more in depth explanations should you wish. thoroughly enjoyed my visit as part of the trip to Prague Castle. This also gave an insight into the recent history of both nazi and soviet influence on the region.

Amazing private family collection. Probably the most professional and polished private collection I've visited, this gem of a museum houses some truly amazing items.As if seeing an original score of Handel's Messiah hand annotated BY MOZART (!!!) was not enough (I wept a little...) they have two really important large Canalettos of River Thames scenes.Those items alone justified the admission price as far as I'm concerned.Also the included audio guide is brilliant. Narrated by family members, it is informative, amusing and really easy to enjoy.The only criticism is that the audio gives the impression you can look at some old letters that are under a covered case. The case even has little handles to lift the cover. When we did, a very rude young woman leapt forward very aggressively. Exactly the same happened with two other couples while we were still in the gallery. They should change the audio, or add a clear sign, and/or train the room attendant to be more pleasant in her approach.Other than that... Marvellous museum. I loved it.

Unexpectedly wonderful tour. This was money very well spent! We both spent much more time than we anticipated wondering slowly around this house listening to the audio guides. The family have a fascinating history and the fact that they tell it makes it all the more wonderful. We were lucky enough that it was very quiet while we walked round so we almost had it to ourselves. There are some real crackers within the tour too, such as original manuscripts of Mozart's work. We also listened to the classical music session. This was enjoyable but we probably wouldn't include it again.
Great cafe, great view!. We were only able to visit the palace cafe, which was very nice with good local beer and food. It also offers seating outside with a great view of Prague.

Wedding Reception NYE 2014. We were fortunate enough to celebrate my son and daughter in laws wedding at Lobkowicz Palace. The setting was simply beautiful, the food, wine and service was excellent AND they during the evening Management offered a tour of the private art gallery - which was certainly worth seeing. Thank you for an amazing night
Amazing views of Prague from the cafe. Seat outside on the terasse and enjoy the view in absolute peace. Great way to spend an hour studying where to go to next!

Exceptional. A gem that is a "must see" for everyone. The palace is beautiful, the family story fascinating, and one of the greatest gifts is the music room with the finest instruments and Beethoven original scores including the Eroica
A "Must" Visit!. True life story of a remarkable family, whose members impacted past and present European history, and for whom America also plays an important role.
classical music concert in palace. You can buy classical music concert tickets here and have a unique experience listening this music in historical palace
Very nice visit. One of secret treasures of Prague. If you spend more days in Prague, put it on your list.you will not regret.

Beethoven's manuscripts and more treasures. The Lobkowicz Palace is located at the northeast end of the Prague Castle and has one of the most impressive collections in Europe. The Lobkowicz Collections display family treasures from more than four centuries, including the Canaletto painting of Lord Mayor’s Day, Beethoven’s manuscripts of the 3rd, 5th, and 6th Symphonies, armor, and more.
For more, and photographs, visit http://www.jenniferlynking.com/2015/02/03/6-places-see-prague/
Just went to the shop and toilets!. Just went to the shop and toilets! Both excellent and got some of the atmosphere of the building. Friendly staff. Crowds of young groups going in.

Week in Prague. We just couldn't get enough of walking about this place. Take time to go down each nook and cranny. The views from the top are stunning and a must. Overlooking the whole palace from above was really great and managed to take some really good photos. The changing of the guard and all of the other touristy things are a must.

Beautiful Palace with so much history. The Lobkowicz Palace is filled with so much history and the tour is very reasonably priced with the audio guide. What made it even more interesting was the audio guide was in English by one of the Lobkowicz family members! The palace is filled with rooms that are themed. The room my cousin and I found most interesting was the Beethoven room because my cousin is a music teacher. Seeing the actual works of Mozart and Beethoven brought tears to her eyes.
