There is also a daily concert at 1:00 p.m. Unfortunately, we were too late but could hear the music through the doors and it was beautiful. This is definitely a must-see when you visit Prague. I learned so much from the tour that I now want to get a book to read more about the family.

One Family's History. If you are a lover of history and culture Lobkowicz Palace is an incredible collection with provenance. Located at the Prague Castle complex nearer to the old castle steps, complete with terrace views of the Vltava River, bridges and the beautiful spires and rooftops of Prague, both sides. It is both an interesting and engrossing family respective of roots forced to take flight. Visited this site as a guest of Viking Cruise as an added excursion. To that end, it was maybe less cost effective, but it was an all inclusive private luncheon, concert and tour with other guests and we very much enjoyed the whole experience. The audio tour of the rooms and exhibits was thorough and informative as the members of the Lobkowicz family discussed their deep rooted connections to Prague throughout many centuries. The art and artifacts are the family's personal collections lost and then reassembled with great effort. Quite an accomplishment. The palace interior details are beautiful although photography opportunities were limited.A visit to Lobkowicz Palace is recommended, especially if you have a few days to devote to the Prague Castle complex. It will certainly take that long get from one end to the other and absorb the richness of the past. Again, as this was only a portion of our trip to Central Europe, by choosing to visit this site we did not feel compelled to visit other larger museums or palaces with similar offerings.

Great Museum learnt a lot of Czech history.. A beautiful museum, with a good English audio guide. I learnt a lot of Czech history great paintings, collections of arms musical instruments and art. The entrance fee was very reasonable and the café and shop ace. The guides are also very helpful learnt a lot too about handball, WW2 and Communist rule too.

A palace to discover. Me and my wife have been there for a chamber concert at new year eve. It was fashinating concert and concert hall. Before and after concert, we had seen around abit. There are museums inside and other facilities. We would like to spend more time there to discover more about it. Next time in prag, palace will be one of our target.

Lobkowicz Palace at Prague Castle is great !!!. There is one of the best museums in Prague. Very helpful staff. To see the museum you can use audioguides available in several languages. Its is good to have more time available. Nice caffee, very nice museum shop. I like to come back.

A couple of interesting hours in the dry. An audio tour given in many languages including English. Follows the Lobkowicz family through the war and ending with the family moving back from The States to reclaim their many art treasures, paintings and land.Some beautiful paintings and China on display with a good commentary.A classical concert is also available on most days.Very good value and a most pleasant experience.

Beautiful palace. Lobkowitz palace is part of Prague castle Hradčany. It is one of the important pieces of Prague history. This luxurious palace houses a magnificent collection of arms, pictures, musical scores, instruments and much more. Entrance fee is not too expensive and is worth every cent. I strongly recommend this place !

Amazing to compare aristocracies between Britain & Czech Rep.. At first I thought this place was going to be a bit pricey considering you're looking around a house with a few pictures in it, but I was very much mistaken. We paid a bit extra to stay for the midday concert - worth the money and put a nice finish to the end of the tour (we started in the morning). It's a great story of this families history and their struggle to preserve some fantastic pieces of art and heritage. The tour (at least the English one) is told by the family themselves, seeing as most of them spent more time in England than at their natural home. Apparently it's not unusual either to bump into one of the family while wondering around. There are some great exhibits, and was amazed to learn this about the ties they have to some of the great composers. We stopped for lunch before the concert at the in-house restaurant, tasty simple food that you get a lot of! I think in total it was approx. £17 for the tour and concert, it took us around 4 hours to do everything and was well worth it!! A must see!!

A gem, with concerts included.. This is well worth a tour if you are in the castle district. The self-guided audio tour provides an easy and fascinating insight into the history of the Lobkowicz family. We started our tour, broke off to go to the concert, then resumed, and completed our wanderings through the palace. With an indoor/outdoor café, this is a great place to spend time, especially if you are visiting on a cold winter's day.

Great family story with a wonderful collection. I stumbled upon this museum accidentally and was a little skeptical to go in at first, but I am so glad I visited. I got the audioguide, but was also lucky to stumble of a group tour led by one of the children of Prince William Lobkowicz!The family's story was fascinating, and the collection was wonderful. I especially loved the music collection and the wonderful artwork. Definitely worth a visit, and I would go back again on my next trip to Prague.

A PALACE REBORN. Prague is an exhausting place to visit as its streets and squares are littered with the Baroque palaces of the departed aristocracy. Overfacing even for the diehard architecture-buff. Most of these mansions are now deserted or in institutional use, but the one shining example of a resurgent palace is the Lobkowicz Palace. At the rear of Prague castle, there lies a treasure trove of world stature. Visited by only a few of those passing its vast door, this mansion displays some of the recovered possessions of this once vast land-owning family. That these pieces have been restituted is extraordinary in itself, but the way that they are displayed and the way the audio-guide takes you round in a familiar and personal manner is a tribute to, not just, technology, but to the imagination of the owners. Prince Lobkowicz (now ostentatiously "Mr"Lobkowicz) describes his inheritance, maiolica, portraits, silver, jewels, musical instruments and scores, as if he were at your side. Particularly moving is to stand in front to the "Eroica" symphony's original score with the music playing in your ear. Finally as the feet begin to give out and the eyes glaze over you come to the final bare room where hang two vast and magnificent paintings of London's river by Antonio Canaletto. Spectacular! Outside tourists of all nationalities troop past glued to there i-phones oblivious of all that is within.
lovely concert. We attended the afternoon concert. Violin, Flute and piano. They played short classical selections ending with a Christmas Carol medley.

Wonderful Collection and outstanding family story...both inspirational. It was great to see the rich and amazing Collection where audioguide of the Lobkowicz family created very authentic atmosphere and shared with us the unique and interesting story of the family. It is worth to visit for all generations. It is more than just a museum.

Such an interesting story!. The Lobkowiczs' have such an interesting and unique story. The english audio guide does a great job explaining the absurdity of their family history. Make sure to get an audioguide -- the palace would not be the same without it!
Wonderful private collection of art and artefacts. This is not covered by the tickets to the Castle complex but is well worth a visit. Get the audioguide.

A gem. My friend and I were delighted with our tour of this palace. The audio-guides are excellent and narrated by a member of the Lobkowicz family. The treasures in the museum are stunning, including a Velazquez painting, two Cannalettos and manuscripts of Mozart, Beethoven and Hayden. Fantastic.

Excellent. Stumbled upon this while wandering through Prague Castle. Very glad I did. The collection is fantastic and priceless - including manuscripts by Beethoven and a score in Mozart's handwriting. There is a famous landscape by Pieter Bruegel the Elder (the Haymakers,) and two paintings of London by Canaletto. There's plenty of portraits owned by the family and some other artefacts (including a suit of armor worn by a family member in the Thirty Years War.)What makes the visit truly memorable is the commentary by the current head of the family, William Lobkowicz. He narrates the tour like a good friend, introducing new members of the family where appropriate. One of the better audio guides I've used.
Lunch at Lobkowicz Palace. Very well prepared luncheon in impressive surroundings. The Lobkowicz family offers a tour of their home/palace as part of the luncheon experience.
wonderful art and history. I loved the family narrated tour and the art that was salvaged from the past and offered to the public for viewing and enjoyment.

Well-organised and informative family collection. This is a very well-organised museum about the history of the Lobkowicz family and their art/weapon/porcellain/music collections. Through the example of one important Czech noble family, you can get a deeper understanding of Czech (and European) history over the last few hundred centuries in different regards (culture, music, customs, connection with Austria/Spain etc.). Every visitor is equipped with an audio guide (different languages available) which comprises all the essential information. I really enjoyed the audio tour and the fact that someone was telling the history of the family and the artworks like in a conversation - partly the family members themselves are telling the story. It's an easy way of learning about and understanding history. The exhibition is laid out on two floors of which the upper floor contains the more meaningful exhibits, so calculate more time for it. We spent about an hour upstairs, listening to all the numbers in the audio tour. The lower floor takes less time, about 30 mins. For visitors who have less time the important numbers are marked in red, so they can skip all the other numbers. Note that on their website they offer discounted combo packages.Overall we really enjoyed our visit and would absolutely recommend it. However, there is still room for improvement. One of the most striking pieces in the exhibition are original works by Mozart and Beethoven. For us, these were by far the most significant exhibits and we wondered why two big rooms are dedicated to weapons and just one small room to music, even though the family plaid such a significant role in developing some of the most famous compositions. E.g. we would have liked to have a look inside the scores of the Eroica written by Beethoven instead of seeing just the cover. Also, the history of the centuries before the 20th is told in detail which is very interested and gives great insights into the European history and the role of the nobility. But very little information is given about the 20th century family history, about the flight of the family, their life in exile and their return, their life today and how they manage to maintain all the property that was restituted to them. We would have been interested in hearing more about this more recent history. Finally, one needs to bear in mind that the history is told by the family, so I don't know how objectively it is told. If there are other versions to it, you won't hear about them in this exhibition. A midday concert is offered from 1-2pm which we attended. We didn't regret it. Three chamber musicians play popular pieces by Beethoven, Mozart, Smetana and others. It's a nice way to let everything sink in, relax and enjoy. We had lunch at the Palace Café after and were happy with that, too (see separate review).

What a lovely palace. This is a great way to spend an hour and to get away from the maddening crowds at the castle. If you buy the combo ticket you get to see the exquisite museum and enjoy the delightful concert. I was amazed that the small but beautiful concert hall was only half full when the castle was so crowded you could hardly move. The palace/ concert is the best deal in town. The ticket was about $25 US and it included a 10% discount at the lovely cafe. Be sure to go outside and see the breathtaking views. The music room is fascinating. It is hard to believe the museum is a family' s private collection.

See original work my Beethoven and Mozart. I didn't realize how connected Prague was with Vienna and classical music. Visit this museum and listen to all the audio guide you have time for and learn more about this interesting fact and about the Lobkowicz Palace. Image growing up as a prince in another country, becoming a real estate agent, being able to reclaim your thrown at the age of 31, moving back to your home country, learning your home language and then sorting and claiming centuries of your families valuables. That's what this fascinating museum is about.
Wery interesting. Interesting exibitits and historic presentation of the family.Recomend to combine with the mid-day concert.

Phenomenal Palace!. We thoroughly enjoyed visiting this place. It's just amazing to view all the centuries of family history in this privately owned palace and to know the current generation is still involved in running it. Stunningly beautiful.

Do not miss this!!!. We had a surprisingly awesome visit! We didn't really know what to expect, but truly loved it. It is a very well done museum that offers spectacular history of Prague and this family! The family has an amazing collection of artwork, dishes, and music. The armory was pretty neat, too! This is well worth the time and money! We also enjoyed getting dessert and coffee at the cafe! Be sure to make time for a visit!

Great story. This palace is easily visited after the main Prague Castle as it is next door. As palaces go, it is very lacking in furniture, I presume the nazi's pinched all the original, and the communists didn't buy any new furniture, so you are left with a large palace with empty rooms but lots of paintings - I can see why the nazi's left a lot of these apart from the Canaletto views of London which are beautiful.Despite these issues, I was entranced by the story told on audio guide by the current family which made the exhibits much more interesting and personal. The dog Room, for instance, has some ordinary pictures of dogs but when you hear bout them from their owners it makes the paintings come alive.There are some interesting musical exhibits, including items used by Beethoven himself. It took us about an hour and a half to stroll around here and we were glad we did, but make sure you get an audio tour.

Must see in Prague. This is a truly wonderful castle museum with an overview of the Lobkowicz family during the past centuries. Many of the displays are of rare manuscripts and personal possessions, all of which give insight into the daily lives of one of the royal families. I wish I had allowed more time to spend in the museum. Cafe and gift shop are small but among the best to be experienced in Prague. I would highly recommend to any traveler to Czech Republic. There are also concerts which I did not allow time for, but wish I had.

Manageable Castle. Nice palace with an amazing story: the family fled both the Nazis and the Communists only to reclaim part of their holdings in 1991. The family Lobkowicz has a storied history, and a painting for almost every ancestor. Would also recommend paying for the 1:00 concert of Prague's greatest classical hits.

Nice historic story about Prague. Interesting visit, with a really good audio tour.Some nice historic facts about Prague and the Lobkowicz family.Had some really nice artifacts; like some writings from Mozart and Bach.

A Wonderful Surprise!. A friend recommended a visit and I am do glad that he did. This museum is in the Palace grounds and was home to a prominent Czech family who fled the Nazi invasion and settled in America. They reclaimed their heritage after the Velvet Revolution in 1989 and have restored four of their twelve residences.The audio tour is included in the price of admission and is wonderfully narrated by William and his father Martin.If you see only the two Canaletto's they would be worth the ticket price; but you would miss so much more. The highlight for me was the Music Room, which contains a Chopin score that is edited in Mozart's own hand and Beethoven's Eroica score. Goosebumps. Stop by the cafe for wonderful coffee and pastries and a spectacular view of the city from the terrace.

Beautiful palace. Amazing story of a local very rich family. The palace has absolutely an amazing collection. Highly recommend a guided tour or the audio tour to understand the history of it. We also did the afternoon concert, which was disappointing. Tourist standards. The piano player in our opinion hammering too much on the piano, the violinist made too many mistakes. Only the flute was of a better quality. Lunch was nice in a very busy cafe.
Unexpected pleasure. we had a wonderful and interesting time touring the Lobkowicz Palace. The only thing better is the Lobkowicz beer!

Wonderful palace. This palace is very big and beautiful. The collection of the Lobkowicz family is rich and amazing. I especially loved how Maximilian Lobkowicz explained everything through the audio-guide. It felt very emotional and lovely. The paintings, silverware, guns, other artifacts etc. are beautiful. If you have time, enjoy the everyday classical music concert at 1 p.m. There is a book shop in the palace and a restaurant.
Worth of visit. Located just in the area of Prague castle, with easy access. You are equipped by audio guide and can enjoy the sighseeing by yourself. No need to hurry.

Who knew people like this still existed?. So, the big feature here is really the Lobkowicz family, which goes back a long, long way. They had extensive land holdings and a fabulous art collection, which they lost twice (once to the Nazis, and then again to the Communists). However, after the Velvet Revolution, the Czech government passed legislation for restitution of private property, and the Lobkowicz family, by then in the United States, got it all back. William Lobkowicz, the current heir, narrates (most of) the included audio guide, and the effect is pretty electrifying, as he relates Czech and family history in terms of two floors of objets d'art, including some amazing things like original Beethoven, Hayden, and Mozart scores (Beethoven dedicated 7 of his works to the contemporary Lobkowicz, including Symphonies 3, 5, and 6), paintings by Rubens, Brueghel, and Canaletto, Croll (who painted the family's 13 castles).I don't know quite how I feel about this kind of art in private hands, but the fact that the Czechs gave it back says a lot about their country, and the chance to hear the story from this scion of an ancient noble family was lesson in history there are few opportunities to get. I don't really see Elizabeth II narrating an audio guide, do you?
Great Museum. Fabulous museum and super restaurant with great views of the city. Food good and not expensive. A really great pkace to relax after a visit to the Cathedral and/or the Castle.

Gem of arts and music, hiding in plain sight. Located in the Prague castle complex, but entry is separate from the Castle multi-site ticket. Nearby steps lead directly downhill to the tram stop. The building has several elements of interest:(1) Cafe with soup, salad, sandwich, coffee, cake is very good quality and reasonably priced.(2) Music Room is venue for one-hour classical music concerts. Includes a varied program of favorites, performed by professional, symphony musicians of very good quality.(3) Palace collections on display, with audioguide in multiple languages. These museum-quality exhibits cover the gamut from framed etchings to antique porcelain to musical instruments dating from Mozart's time. Lobkowicz was the richest family in Bohemia and the exhibits give insight into the history of this prominent noble family. One was a patron of Beethoven, and some of Beethoven's original handwritten scores are on display. Altogether, highly recommended. Concert plus museum available on combination ticket online.

Lovely private collection. Great variety of exhibits - paintings, porcelain, armoury and best of all (for me anyway), original manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart - amazing. Very good café with delicious hot chocolate!

Audioguide makes the visit!. My husband and I read the book City of Dark Magic that had to do with the Lobkowitz family before we came to Prague. We enjoyed the museum thoroughly. There are a lot of portraits of the family that might seem boring at first, but the audioguide brings them to life with tidbits of history narrated by members of the family. The firearms room and the music room are especially spectacular. You might not want to do this if you only have 1-2 days in Prague, because the city is filled with so many wonderful things, but if you have more time, DEFINITELY check this out.

Some of the items on display gave me chills..... Lobkowicz Palace is a sleeper of a destination. I knew nothing of it and went because it was included in our trip and it seemed more appealing than simply wandering around. But I left with great appreciation for the Lobkowicz family. Their display of firearms is simply spectacular. And their music room includes manuscripts by Mozart and Beethoven and those literally sent chills up my spine. Well worth the modest fee to visit!

Spectacular!. Our tour of the Lobkowicz Palace was the best thing we did during our trip to Prague. Do not miss this opportunity to step back in time. The audio guide was informative and moving and the overall collection is beyond words. The entire experience (including the cafe) is wonderful. Highly recommend!!!

Entrance ticket a little pricey. Much less crowded than the rest of Prague Castle, rooms are open around a courtyard on 2 upper floors. One floor is set up like an art gallery with the room's original decoration removed, the other floor still has the wall decoration and in some rooms, a little furniture. The audioguide is included and is entertaining with a lot of history of the family. The sales pitch to go to their country estate to see more is annoying and repeats in several rooms.

Good Time. Had a good time. Went there on a river trip. Most of us were around seventy years old. The people on staff there really made an effort to see that we enjoyed ourselves. They even listened to our feedback.

Special, special, special. Musical archive/manuscripts, too.. The art collection is magnificent, and the audio guide, narrated by 2 generations of the Lobkowicz family, is extremely well done and makes your visit feel very personal. The story is remarkable, and these are treasures of paintings that are of world-class quality (i.e. "Haymaking" by Brueghel the Elder). The Music Archive is astonishing, and some of the instruments, and manuscripts on display, are fantastic. (Beethoven's own hand on the original scores for his 4th & 5th symphonies, and Mozart’s re-orchestration of Handel’s Messiah.)The beef goulash at the cafe was very good, and very reasonable.

Lobkowicz Palace tour and dinner. this is an amazing private collection lost twice in both wars and recollected. the dinner and music was also good and the personal appearance o a Lobkowicz family member to greet and meet us.

Really nice. The palace was returned to the original family in the 1990s. They have done a great job of putting every back the way it was before the communists stole it from the family. You hear the story of the family and their treasures. Very well done. The restaurant is good also and very reasonable

Its more than a museum, it's history unfolding. For some reason we missed it first time we visited Prague, so in our 2nd visit we just had to come. The Palace is located within the boundaries of the Prague castle. From outside it is somewhat modest, as we almost missed it, but inside it's part of a castle, a family estate of the Lobkowicz family. Audio tour is must in order to learn the history of this palace and the people who owned it - and lost it a few times throughout history.Beyond that, I found the art displayed interesting (mostly portraits as I recall), as the story in the audio tour relates to the portraits that are shown.During winter the place was populated "right" - not too many people wandered around, but it wasn't empty either.Open every day from 10:00 to 18:00, regular ticket is 275 CZK, but you can pay 10% less by buying tickets online.Art and modern history fans alike are going to enjoy this place.

A must see!!!. Located within the walls of Prague Castle, is this beautifully restored palace. Take the self guided audio walking tour and learn the history as you move room to room. We also met the Prince, who has painstakingly restored the palace to its pre-Nazi and communist splendor.
Lunchtime concert. Lovely setting, great music,special memories are created there. followed up by museum visit. Informative and interesting. Thoroughly enjoyed

Very special and unique palace. The palace itself with all of its surroundings is pretty big! We visited the family collection through the museum, which was astonishing. We also walked all over the palace, but the inside cathedral stole my heart! Unfortunately the Royal Gardens were closed between November and March.

Best attraction at Prague Castle. Though the Lobkowicz Palace is situated in the Prague Castle, it requires a separate ticket for entry (which includes an hour long audioguide tour). But it is definitely worth it because the audioguide was extremely informative, using the works of art to explain Europe's history as well as Prague's history through the story of the Lobkowicz family. And the audioguide is narrated by a current member of the Lobkowicz family, so it was quite personal! I learnt so much more as compared to the audioguide from the Prague Castle. Would definitely recommend this place to people who enjoy art and history.

Pleasant afternoon concert. After strolling across the Charles bridge and going up to the Prague castle, we had very pleasant and relaxing visit at the Lobkowicz Palace. Seeing and hearing about the amazing art and antiques collection and the story about how the family amassed such a fortune and lost it to WWII and then to the communists was interesting. Then we sat in on an hour long concert of classical music that was a relaxing and pleasant cap to the afternoon.

Don't miss this wonderful place!. Having read about the Lobkowicz Palace in the Rick Steve book, and as an avid museum goer, I was very interested in visiting this site, plus I had also read that the cafe there was the best place to have lunch while in the Palace area. One tip I learned too late: if you plan to tour the palace, buy your ticket first and THEN have lunch in the cafe, as they give a 10% discount both in the cafe and in the gift shop, which I didn't get to take advantage of .The included audio guide really makes the palace come alive- as it is narrated by the current Prince Lobkowicz, who actually was raised in the US and is trying to keep the various Lobkowicz inheritances (palaces and the like) not only afloat but actively engaging with the larger audience. He succeeds magnificently, in our opinion. This spot, very near the palace, was one of the highlights of our four day visit to Prague. I encourage you to visit!

Highest Recommendation. We can not recommend more highly the Lobkowicz Palace and Collections for the wonder and the beauty they contain and not least of all the family story of loss and recovery. We also recommend attending the hour-long musical concert and lunch at the cafe. Don't miss it.Ron & Carol--Menlo Park, CA
Beautiful palace and museum. What a beautiful palace and interesting family collection. The history of the building and family is worthy of a trip.

Definitely worth a visit. I really enjoyed my visit in this palace. I was looking on my TripAdvisor app to find something different for my sightseeing, and this palace caught my attention. I really appreciated the museum in itself (a lot of paintings but also a music room, arms & armor, etc.), but what touched me the most was the Lobkowicz family's story.Take a look at the website of the Palace, you'll understand what I mean: http://www.lobkowicz.cz/en/It was a really nice place to visit and I can just recommend you to go there.

Worth A Visit. We visited this palace and did the audio tour. It was far more interesting than we expected. The story of the family who owned the property, then lost it, then recovered it again (and again) was intriguing. There is a nice collection of artwork and antiquities - some of which have ties to some very famous people. It was well laid out and not very crowded - a nice change from the rest of the tourist areas.

Beautiful Place. This extraordinary palace has, after all the dislocations of the second half of the 20th Century, come back into the hands of this once powerful Lobkowicz family. They have fixed it up beautifully as a museum of the history of the family, which interests with kings, emperors and composers. The taped tour is as good as I have ever heard; the narrators include the present head of the family, who grew up ih the Boston area and so has an American accent. Don't miss this slice of history!

A pleasant surprise. After over two weeks of organized tours throughout eastern Europe, I was ready to head back to my hotel room and watch reruns of Gilligan's Island. It'd already signed up for the Lobkowicz Palace tour, however, so I figured what-the-heck. And now I'm glad I did! I'm not a huge art history buff and when I saw rooms filled with portraits of people I didn't know, I groaned internally, However, the way the tour was organized, with excellent narration by William Lobkowicz and nice accompanying music, I left very impressed and certainly with a much better appreciation of European history. Each room has a different theme, ranging from some of the earliest porcelain dinner settings used in Europe, to original musical scores of Mozart and Beethoven. I especially enjoyed the armory room and the impressive collection of musical instruments. We were treated to a very nice lunch and a wonderful chamber orchestra concert (by members of the National Symphony no less!) as part of our tour. It was an afternoon well spent.
Phenomenal Palace!. My wife and I spent about a half day visiting the Palace and could have spent more. There is so much history here it is hard to take it all in. It is a must see in Prague!

Must see! . One of our favorites in Prague! I can say we aren't huge museum/art type buffs, but this palace was phenomenal. The audio guides are free with entry price and are incredibly well done. They are narrated by the Lobkowitz family members and really grasp the highlights of the collection. They were so entertaining and I was so interested in each and every piece they decided to speak on. Very unique pieces in the palace, every thing from paintings, China, weaponry, musical instruments, and even "feather art." Very well put together, and highly recommended.

Wonderful place to visit. If you are visitng the Prague Castle, plan to spend a few fascinating hours at the Lobkowicz Palace. The midday classical concert, which takes place in one of the rooms in which the family historically hosted concerts, was truly magnificent and uplifting, and well worth planning around. The castle, which is now a museum chronicling the family's history, was very interesting, and was tastefully interwoven with magnificent art works, music collections and armaments. Seeing Beethoven's original handwritten scores for the third, fourth and fifth symphonies, dedicated to eh family which acted as his patron, was very special. If you have time for only one attraction in the Prague Castle, I would highly recommend that you choose Lobkowicz Castle.

excellent place to visit. Situated in the Prague Castle complex. You can listen to a lunchtime classical concert and visit the museum on a combined ticket; 575 koruna.The collections are superb and include Canaletto's painting of London on Lord Mayor's day, original Beethoven manuscripts and hunting rifles to name but a few.

Nice concert. We went to the afternoon concert. The music was lovely and the ambiance of the concert hall is great. It is the perfect thing to do if you are visiting the castle complex and need a break.

Unbelievable collections. If you only have a few days, or hours as I had in Prague, Lobkowicz Palace is a must see. The walking-audio guide gives you a great sample of the history of the region. While the palace has a great collection of art, porcelain, and weaponry, as a music lover, their music room is one of the coolest places I've ever been. On display they have original scores from Beethoven and Mozart as well as a great assortment of classical instruments dating well beyond the time of those two composers. Each staff person I encountered was incredibly nice and knowledgable of the collections. The views from the windows offer a great view of the city and the cafe wasn't half bad either!

History in one family and what a family!. Stop by on your way from Prague Castle. Worth the admission to hear (on included audio tour) the current members of the Lobkowvicz family narrate their history. They were the strong and powerful art patrons (both of Mozart and Beethoven and have original, hand annotated musical scores to prove it) and were literally Czech/Bohemian royalty. Lost their art to the Nazis and then the Communists. Now it's back and everyone can see it. We were fascinated at how it survived both confiscations.

Lobkowicz Knows Tourism. If you get the audioguide, you instantly learn why this palace and tour are so much better than other sites in Prague - it's run by Americans. Expect the standard excellent American tour experience with complete information, friendly staff, a clean space, and displays that are not reproductions. It was so good we took a train ride to see Lobkowicz-owned Nelahozeves Castle as well.

Excellent - a must see. Rich in history and architecture absolute stunning. Views of Prague from Castel Hill absolute breath taking and all the staff was knowledgeable and friendly. Read up about the history before visiting so it will make the experience even more special.

visiting options. For those who want to see the impressive art collection without the guided tour of the residence or family history presentation, it's possible to visit the museum alone. There appeared to be two entrances, one to the restaurant, which was much larger and busier, and another a bit further on, which had a entrance desk for museum tickets. This entrance also leads to the very pleasant little coffee shop (not the big restaurant), which has a small outdoor terrace with the same stunning view of the city as the larger venue. We were the only customers in this smaller cafe when we were there and had the terrace to ourselves.
A must visit. This is a wonderful museum, with many paintings and artifacts.The narration is done by different members of the Lobkowicz family and is extremely interesting.

Definitely worth a visit. Adjacent to Prague castle, this venue is worth a visit. Its history is very intersting, the premises were restored recently and the lunch concert a pleasant oasis of peace in this very busy and crowded castle area.

Superb. My girlfriend and I stumbled into this gem of a palace/museum on Castle Hill. The story told, of a family which rose to the highest reaches of power and luxury, lost it all, regained it briefly, lost it all again and now, after the Czechs threw out the Communists regained some of it again, is riveting. The story is told beautifully and then topped off, if one chooses -- as we did -- with an early afternoon concert of Mozart, Chopin and more. A highlight of our trip.

A treasure in Prague. What a wonderful family to share their palace and treasures with everyone. The lunch was delicious and served in a beautiful palace room with extensive views of the city. With a personal visit and introduction by the Prince. The self guided tour and headsets were excellent. The trio that entertained with works of Mozart, Beethoven and others was outstanding. A must for all visiting Prague.

Worth a visit to this historical family palace.. The Lobkowicz family history is brought to life in this beautifully preserved palace. The story is told by family members as you listen through the earphones to the long history of the family property. The history includes the loss and restitution of the property twice through WWII and the communist takeover. The paintings and family heirlooms are worth viewing for their historical significance to include original musical compositions by famous European composers. We also had a delicious lunch at the palace.

Great views of Prague. Visited at the end of a river cruise with our tour director, lovely coffee and apple streudel, enjoyed it so much we visited again on our own, very clean and cosy, blankets provided for outside seating but warm and sunny when we visited, would definitely recommend the coffee and streudel special 160 crown each, nice clean toilets, lovely building and great views of Prague from the terrace
History and More.... The Lobkowicz history is fascinating. Enjoyed the concert as well as a lovely lunch in the castle. Do recommend the castle as a place to visit while in Prague.

Excellent way to spend a couple hours of enjoyment. Great museum ( and I am not a museum person) there is a great view of Prague from the area of the museum but what makes this so special is that it is one family's personal collection and the narrator of the tour is actually a person from that family. Everything from art painting to old weapons to old "things". Really interesting. I suprisiingly loved it. Well worth the entrance fee. If I had to reccommend 3 things to do in Prague this would be one.

Lots and Lots Going On!!!!. Outstanding art gallery, fascinating family history, delicious café, lovely concert - all at the Lobkowicz Palace. Not to be overlooked with so many other sights close by. Not crowded - an overlooked and under visited location with much to recommend it. The concert was beautiful is a lovely room in the palace at one in the afternoon. The Lobkowicz's contributions and support of music is truly an inspired and unknown part of history. Get the audio guide to the museum to learn the full story of the family's role in so much of Czech history.

Music, art and good food. Music, art and good food encompasses the gifts Prague presents its many visitors. A beautiful venue for these treats is the Lobkowicz Palace, where we heard a lovely concert of music of Mozart, Bach, Beethoven and Dvorak. Their art gallery has beautiful masterpieces, and their cafe has a beautiful view of the city and good food. A real treat!

Beethoven and Mozart Manuscripts. We went specifically to see the early copies of works like Beethoven's Eroica and it's really exciting to see these if you're a musician. The family story is interesting too, and the way the family lost and regained their inheritance is so educational. The audio guide by members of the family is definitely more interesting than your average audio guide. Your ticket gets you a discount at the cafe and gift shop. Sadly we went to the cafe first! Not that we minded - the cafe is good, with the family beer and on a beautiful day, we sat out on the terrace with wonderful views over Prague.

Lobkowicz Palace--not to be missed!. Almost not able to do this tour, but soooo glad that we did! A remarkable family history as benefactors of music and art--wonderful collections of paintings, portraits, fine porcelain, and original musical manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart. This family truly made it possible for these artists and musicians to produce their masterpieces! The Lobkowicz heir and owner spoke to our group about the Nazi takeover and later, the family's efforts to reclaim the palace and property--no small feat. Their mission to make it available to the public is admirable since the cost of maintaining and repairing the palace and grounds is enormous. Please consider taking this tour as the proceeds help support this beautiful treasure!

Don't be shocked if this place claims that the sun rises because of the Lobkowicz family. If you really want to learn all about some family that was/is great in every way and married all the right people, ran away with all their riches whenever trouble arrived just to reclaim all their property after trouble went away(unlike most of their fellow Czechs), then feel free to use your time as you like. If you think England's royals are full of themselves, just wait until you get a load of this place. I myself was relieved when the baby had a fit and I had an excuse to beat it out of there early. My poor wife felt the exact same way but had to suffer through the entire museum with our 7 year old (because strangely enough, the 7 year old actually enjoyed parts of it).With all the other great historical attractions in the area (that actually show a bit of Prague’s history), I see no reason why this place would be on the “to do” list. I regret going the first time and I certainly wouldn't return.

Beautiful family story. Fantastic family treasure, including original partitions of Beethoven masterpieces and one of the most beautiful Bruegel painting.Taking the audio-guide is a must. The owner of the collection tell the impressive story of his family and how his collection finally survive the 20th century.

the biggest castle complex in Europe. The Prague Castle complex is very large, with several palaces, churches, and administration offices. It is also said the the soldiers guarding the entrance to the castle are the most photographed men in the Czech Republic.We went on a guided tour of the this complex (the best way to learn about it), and found it very interesting. definitely worthwhile.

Lobkowicz Palace Prague. This is a must see when in Prague. The Palace is the only privately owned palace in the complex and has one of the finest art collections, arms collection and rare music collections in all of Europe. A great story of the Lobkowicz family over the last few hundred years, and most interesting is their escape from the Nazi's in WWII, then coming back to the Czeck Republic to lay claim to their family history and collections. I highly recommend visiting this treasure.

A Glimpse into Musical History . We took this tour as part of the Viking Danube river cruise. While pricey, it gave us an appreciation for benefactors of the arts through time. Kudos to the family for trying to maintain and restore art through the modern era.The views from the palace are awesome. You can find grander palaces or homes elsewhere. You have to take the family's journey as part of the whole history of the European continent.

A most enjoyable personal survey of 400 years of Czech history and culture.. With the narration of American educated William Lobkowicz guiding the viewer through the rooms of the palace we encounter the portraits of the major movers and shakers of the country, the dishes, furniture, weapons, and music through the centuries. Original scores of Beethoven and Mozart supported by the family are highlights as are original paintings by Velazquez, Brueghel, and Cranach. One can end the fascinating tour with a concert in the palace or a family owned beer on the terrace overlooking the city. One of the top visits in the city.

A great Czech family. We signed for a tour of the palace as part of our Cities of Light river cruise with Viking. Our tour included a delightful lunch, as well as a tour of the castle and the museum. We strongly recommend this tour and have nothing but the highest praise for the staff of the palace. I will echo the same positive comments that have been made here previously by others. We were particularly impressed with the history of the family, as well as the treasures found in the museum. There so many beautiful places to visit in Prague, and in the short time we had, we missed seeing many. However we are so glad that we did not miss this one.
Worth the time. Beautiful place to visit and I highly recommend the Lobowicz museum tour which is really well done and quite remarkable.

Art, music and food. I bought tickets to visit the Palace and attend the concert as a treat for my parents, during a short break in Prague. The Palace is well worth a long visit, and holds an excellent collection of art (especially portraits charting the history of the family), porcelain/ceramic, and - the highlight for music lovers - some impressive music memorabilia. Not many families can boast an ancestor who was a patron of Beethoven, and you can hear the pride in the voice of William Lobkowicz who is your (audio)guide throughout the visit. We bought an all-inclusive museum + concert ticket, which also included a discount at the museum cafe'. Unfortunately the weather was a bit too cold on the day to enjoy our lunch on the terrace (which has a great view of Prague), however this was the best meal we had in Prague! I was only disappointed by the lunchtime concert, which is a collection of short pieces for (or arranged for) piano and/or viola. Unfortunately on the day the pianist (although obviously very talented) seemed to be in a hurry to get through the programme and played every piece too fast and too loud - at the expense of the quality of the performance (and at times of the quantity of the notes!). I had expected a higher standard, and was sadly disappointed.

Highlight of my Prague Visit. Our tour included a visit to Lobkowicz and as a professional musician I was totally blown away by the collection. Imagine seeing the original manuscripts of Beethoven symphonies! Our tour included a private concert and - lucky for us - a talk by the actual OWNER of the museum, an American. It was very inspiring to see how these priceless artifacts were rescued from both the Nazis and from the communists. Please go and see this - you will not be disappointed.
Most important siteseeing we did in CR. This was a riveting opportunity to partake in a slice of european history. Beautifully presented. Audio guide a must.

Among the Highlights of our Trip. A real gem, the Lobkowicz Palace is a don't miss when in Prague. Situated in the gigantic Hapsburg Castle, the Palace had been lovingly and carefully restored under the keen eyes of William and Alexandra Lobkowicz and provides a fascinating glimpse into the long legacy of this illustrious Czech family. It's a beautiful place and its impressive story is told with the aid of a superior audio guide narrated by none other than William Lobkowicz, who with Alexandra and their 3 children returned to Prague from the US in the 90's to help guide the restoration. Included in our Viking tour was a delicious luncheon in one of the Palace's palatial rooms and a lovely string ensemble concert. You won't regret your visit which, among other things, celebrates the importance of family.

A Gem! Do not miss!. Thanks to Vaclev Havel and the Restitution Laws of the 1990's, the collection that goes back 700 years is now back in private hands.The palace is privately owned and located in the Prague Castle Complex. This privately owned art collection is the oldest and largest in the Czech Republic, is open to the public and should not be missed.Paintings by Brueghel, Canaletto, Belloto, Cranach, Rubens and many others! Musical scores by Mozart are on display as well as instruments.The one hour audio guide that is included in the price of admission includes music and is narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family and Curator.At 1 pm each day there is a classical music concert.Take in the views, stop in the Cafe, and take advantage of the very clean, free bathrooms.DO NOT MISS THIS GEM!!!!!!

Save time for this. Save an hour or so for this oasis at the end of a day spent wandering around the Prague Castle area. Impressive family art collection over the centuries, now reunited after depradations of the Nazis and the communists. Helpful audio guide included in the price of the entry ticket. Delightful cafe/restaurant with wide views over the town. Spotless (free) toilets.

Magnificent. It is a great find. The audio really made the visit, telling about the family, how they reacquired much of their incredible wealth after WWII and after the fall of the Iron Curtain.We enjoyed the holdings and also enjoyed the 60 minute concert with a piano and a viola.
Beautiful gardens. A must see if you are visiting the old town. Gardens and scenery is just impeccable. Definitely recommended..

Great slice of history. We had an opportunity to visit the Lobkowicz Palace recently and loved it. Our tour had lunch, some great views of the city, a chance to look at some to the artifacts (including some Mozart original manuscripts) and best of all a small chamber concert. Definitely worth the trip.
Midday Classic Concert. Daily at 1.30 there is no better way of resting for an hour than by listening to the "Pearls of Czech and World Classical Music". Superb musicians.

Great museum commentary, not as good in music performance, good food and service. Overall a must do visit. Performance can definitely improve as piano player's style just about can break you eardrums in a couple of pieces. Also don't expect an orchestra as there are only two musicians. This seems to be an area for improvement.
A definite tour!. This Palace was beautiful. The view from the area overlooking Prague was fabulous! So much to see and take in. The history is so interesting!

A Good Tour but Not worth the Price. This tour was promoted as an add on tour from Viking. The palace is a fascinating collection of Czech history and of the Lobkowicz family and it's amazing it was able to be retrieved after WWII. However, at 100 Euros apiece (including lunch which was OK but nothing special), it was a bit on the pricey side and we found out that the musical quartet who performed for us can be viewed virtually everyday. The brochure also gave the distinct impression Prince Lobkowicz himself would stop by to say hello when that's not the case as all - he merely narrates the prerecorded audio tour. It's an interesting bit of history but you can probably set the tour up by yourself and save some $$.

Don't miss it.!. The biggest castle in the world i think.Very well renovated.Amazing buildings with great architecture.The view from the castle is breathtaking. It's like being in a movie.It's a town inside a town.The also have two coffee shops where you can have a coffee or a beer break.You will see.Come here and you will feel the atmosphere.

Step back in time. A real treasure. One of the most beautiful and informative places we visited Couple visit with a lunch on the terrace and a reictal for a great, relatively uncrowded experience. Go early during the week by tram and plan to spend some time.

Absolutely amazing - don't miss it!. The Lobkowicz family lost their possessions twice in the 20th century - once courtesy of the Nazis, and once courtesy of the Soviets - and they have gotten virtually everything back, twice. It's an amazing story in itself - but the story of this family and their fascinating ancestors will keep you engaged as you walk through the palace and marvel at the wonderful collections. Take the audio tour! It's really well done, as is the entire presentation of the collection. Highlights include original manuscripts by Mozart and Beethoven (and the amazing story of the Lobkowicz connection with Beethoven in particular), the Brueghel painting, and the Canalettos - but the many family portraits from across the centuries, and the decorative arts displayed are all of great quality and interest. This is a must-see in Prague!
palace worth a visit. very historic especially for music lovers because of the families relationship with Beetoven. Also a great view of the city from the viewing point outside the entrance

Lobkowicz Palace Overwhelming History. Spend some time at this fine palace but be prepared for crowdsand some walking. Very close to the wonderful St. Vitus Cathedral.Stroll through the gallery and absorb all the history involving theLobkowicz family. Enjoy and remember!

The best thing I saw. I have to rate the Lobkowicz Palace as the best thing I did in Czech Republic. Their collection of art and weaponry is superb. My favorite room in the palace was the music room. To see the original manuscripts of Mozart's rendition of Handel's Messiah and Beethoven's 5th symphony in person was a one of a kind experience. For those of you who don't know Beethoven's 5th symphony was dedicated to Joseph Franz Maximilian Lobkowicz and the original manuscript with his notes is in the palace!! Go onto the Lobkowicz website and book the museum tour and the concert at 1:00PM. It is worth every penny. Here is the website: http://www.lobkowicz.cz/en/Lobkowicz-Palace-9.htm

An amazing experience. To be invited in to their castle and be "shown around" by William Lobkowicz himself (via my headset) was very moving. He tells his family's story of having lost the family lands twice (Nazis and Communists) and reclaimed them twice. The collection is well exhibited.Have lunch in the cafe and then attend the concert at 1 PM.It is all quite an experience!
Palace tour. On palace tour. Had local beer, goulash, dessert (cheese cake) and an aperitif. All felt like authentic Czech food

Interesting museum collection; mediocre classical performance. We attended the 1 hour afternoon concert, buying the Lobkowicz Museum pass as a package. The concert was advertised as a trio, yet no flute, just piano and violin. The violinist was very skilled yet played in only about half the songs. The pianist played all the notes correctly yet reminded me of a piano teacher, lacking finesse to create a variety of moods. The piano also seemed a bit out of tune. The self guided tour of the museum (with audio-guide) was interesting. The family's fascination with their dogs (paintings/sculpture) and financial support of famous composers was a great back story of the palace. Enjoyed a quiet visit at one of the more obscure buildings on Castle Hill. Also consider eating at the cafe - good simple food.

Musical treat highly recommended!. Everyday at 1:00 p.m. a concert is held at the lobkowicz palace. When we went it was a piano and viola concert which we enjoyed tremendously. The musicians played very well but the experience was very special in that it really helped to imagine what it must have been like a hundred years ago to enjoy music, when not in a huge concert hall or on the streets, but in homes or palaces of people who had family members who could play an instrument or two. It was very different from the concerts in the chapels, churches, and the other bigger venues in Prague. Highly recommended! We unfortunately did not have the time to also see the museum, but for only Czk100 more, there is a ticket that also includes the entrance to the museum and the audio guide.

Privately owned castle. Has lots of pantings, but not really any furniture. It is good to have the audio guide as a family member tells you the signifigance of the pain tings. I was intrigued by the bird pictures using real feathers

Must visit this castle. Small, very well ordered, interesting history we would never have known. Definitely use the free audio unit that gives information about the most important stops in each room. We spent and hour and a-half and could have spent more time. Tip: you get a 10% discount ticket with museum entry, for use in the cafe. Food is delicious, service is excellent - all food and drinks came at the same time - and the proprietary lager is the best pivo I've had in Praha.

Enjoyable afternoon. Growing up in Prague I knew the story of the Lobkowicz family. They lost their fortunes twice, first to the Nazis, then to the communists. We have taken a break in their terrace cafe when visiting the castle area on our previous visits to Prague, but never took the time to visit the museum. It rained that day and it was a perfect timing since a classical music concert was starting at 1PM. With just enough time to buy a combo ticket ( museum and concert) we were ready to sit down and relax in the beautiful surroundings. The pianist and violinist were accomplished musicians and couple of times I was moved to tears. We then walked through the museum rooms and displays, stopping at what interested us most. You can spend as much time as you want, and I was surprised, that it was not crowded. I took off one star for the following reasons:The line for tickets was painfully slow (people not having correct change, trying to decide what kind of ticket to buy and only one person handling the register.) We worried that we will miss the beginning of the concert. The tickets we bought hurriedly were not the most expensive ones. The first two rows with chairs covered in white slipcovers were the priciest. We bought the rows behind the first two- the so called blue chairs. Wrong decision! The "blue" chairs were crammed together- small - highly uncomfortable chairs (no padding), that one would find in the street cafes. I was hoping to be comfortable for an hour and found myself fidgeting and with a hurting back afterwards. Even just the appearance of these chairs in the beautiful room of a palace seemed out of place. I understand that the more chairs you fit in, the more money you make. But no matter how you look at it, these chairs did not fit the beautiful surroundings.One more thing: The ticket price is very affordable to tourists like us, but I have been told, that the czech people , especially the generation that lived under the communist regime, may not be able to afford to see the beautiful palace and the concert. And one more thing: A very small bottle of mineral water at the cafe is 90 crowns- about $4.50. The most I ever paid for water! We enjoyed the coffee and cheesecake and above all the beautiful view from the terrace. The palace is relatively easy to find, If you are leaving the castle area. It is located just below the slight hill that leads to Zlata Ulicka. The entrance to the palace will be on your right if you are going down the hill towards the city center.

An eclectic bonanza. Prague Castle is a bit of an anomaly. Lovely grounds and beautiful buildings but not much interior content. This is all rectified if you explore the Lobkowicz palace on the grounds of the castle.It is a lovely building, but the contents of the collection are fantastic. The art, porcelain and weaponry ( if you like that) are truly wonderful. The music collection to me was the highlight. Original manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart with fascinating descriptions of the Lobkovicz influence in the creation of these masterpieces. Unbelievable stuff!!! Take the time to hear a lovely classical concert every day at 1:00 in one of the music room of the palace. An addtional plus is the food and drink offered in their cafe- some of the best food in the castle area. The Lobkovicz Palace should not be missed, especially if you are a music lover!

Not quite as good as Buckingham Palace, but worth seeing!. In 1971 the Duke of Bedford Published "How to Run a Stately Home". It was the story of how, facing bankruptcy because of taxes, the Duke set about turning his family home into a cultural attraction as well as a tourist attraction. And a money-maker. The Lobkowicz family is demonstrating how, confronted with the challenge of unbelievable and unexpected circumstances, they have responded. Clearly they had the brains and assets to respond well in a situation that some might describe as making lemonade after being handed lemons.Lobkowicz Palace is a good museum with a collection that has something for almost anyone, from weapons to paintings to china, and what makes it really interesting and unusual is how the family tells their story. It's a story that isn't all that unusual anywhere in Europe. The museum is professionally curated and well presented. I wanted to see it specifically because of its two Canalettos, and more importantly it's Brueghel, which is one of five in a series. The others can only be seen in Vienna and New York. I can now brag that I have seen all five!It's pretty clear that despite the pretty steep admission price, that the museum is not necessarily a money-making proposition. It is likely that the special events (weddings, banquets, meetings) are. And the only criticism I have is that money was solicited to use the restroom. A somewhat better attraction is Benesov Palace, which is an easy thirty minute train ride from Prague. There you can see the private spaces of the Archduke Franz Ferdinand, whose assassination brought about World War I. The bullet that killed his wife is on display (whether that's in good taste is for you to decide.)

Breathtaking collection. The brief descriptions of this amazing museum don't begin to do it justice. The collection of art is marvelous, the palace itself is stunning, and the contributions made by this family to the arts over the centuries are beyond measure. Standing in front of manuscripts written and edited by Mozart, Beethoven, and Haydn left me breathless and almost in tears. Thank you to this family for sharing their wonders with the world.

Art Collection and Afternoon Classical Concert. The art collection here is fabulous, mostly consisting of family portraiture. They also have 'Haymaking' by Pieter Bruegel. We attended the 1:00pm classical concert held in the concert hall of the palace. The interior was a lovely backdrop, especially the painted ceilings. The concert lasted 1 hour, with 2 musicians (1 pianist and one violist).

don't miss this. the name Lobkowicz may not be well known to many people, but this family was extremely influential in European history. This palace is in the Prague Castle complex, and shouldn't be missed. There is a large assortment of historical items that tell the story of the family and a lot of European history, and what is most remarkable is that the family lost almost all of these items twice- once at the hands of the Nazis, and again with the Communists. It is because of the hard work of the present members of the family that all of the items were recovered, and are now available for the world to see and appreciate. Not to be missed.

Top notch museum. Really enjoyed the visit to the Lobkowicz palace. In fact, it's the only museum I went to in the Prague Castle area because on the paper it appeared like the best one. I wasn't disappointed - great, various collections (you don't get bored - there are paintings, firearms, music instruments, porcelain... but in limited quantities, only the best items are on display), a perfect audioguide (which is included in the ticket price) and great views from the café terrace. Do yourself a favor and learn about the noble family of Lobkowicz. I wish I could go to their other museum near Prague...

It's good to be a noble family. The Palace, we were told, is the only private residence situated in the famous Prague Castle. Because the owner are royalty they have family portraits going back into the middle ages. One of the old counts was the patron allowing Beethoven to freely compose.

Best Palace artifacts in the Castle area. Don't miss this palace as you wonder through what seems like endless castle buildings at the top of the hill. The art collection is one of the best remaining artifacts that you will see in Prague. Paintings, household artifacts, and extensive gun collections are among the highlights along with the music room and original scores. Cafe is wonderful and relaxing--gift shop is one of the museum bests that I visited in Prague. There is also a chocolate stand outside the gates of the entrance if you need a little treat. Great family history and completely enjoyable.

Well organized museum. A nice experience to learn the histories of this family and this place. Very well organized, especially the audio guide, it is great. You can go for the concert for an additional fee, we went for it and it was enjoyable, but the visit is still complete without it. Recommeneded when you are in Prague.

What a fabulous family!. This gorgeous museum in a castle tells an awesome family story, and if you get the audio (do it!) you will get the intimacy of the family telling its own history, with details of family life going back many centuries. Feels like a novel. Among too many highlights to mention are the instruments and original scores, with scribbles and corrections in their own hand, of Eroica, handel's Messiah, and others. And the classical concert! wow! And a serene break from the crowds everywhere. problems? Finding it! the place when Prague Castle staff offer little help, even at the "information" kiosk.

Worth the visit. The collection is beautiful and you can learn a lot about the Czech history. You should take your time, for me it took about one and a half hour to see everything. Some parts are touching.

Did you see Monuments Men?. This is real life movie material! It was very cool to walk through this palace and view the exhibits, especially in the music room, having recently seen the above mentioned movie. The personal art collection, and the original music scores were fascinating. So much of history is contained in this private museum. I recommend getting the audio guide and doing just the "red" stops, and it will not take a lot of time but will leave a lasting impression. Loved it!

A hidden gem. This is a hidden jewel at the bottom of the castle district. I wouldn't have known about it if a friend hadn't told me about it. There are original Beethoven manuscripts with changes in his own hand.I was able to find it only because as I asked a castle policeman, who didn't speak much English, I was aided by a lovely Czech couple who had been residents of Australia for decades, who were able and nice enough to translate.

Much better than expected. I had some difficulty to visit other places in Prague castle, due to unfriendly people who word there. However the Palace was much better than expected. I have been there to find the Brugle work, but had a good time all over the place in the palace thanks to the audio guide. The explanation was very fruitful and well designed.Due to the time limitation, I could not visit the cafe and I miss to ve there again soon.
Gershwin Concert. lovely temple, decent price, good musicians! nice way to spend an hour in Prague! Got the tickets from our hotel. benches are a little hard, but it's only an hour!

Learning about the Lobkowicz Palace. Through a private tour booked along with our Viking Danube River Cruise, we thoroughly enjoyed the audio presentation that walked us through the highlights of this beautiful palace. It was the best addition to our river cruise.

Wonderful cafe, wait to be seated on the balcony. We loved the food and the view from this cafe. We did not go into the palace, just ate at the cafe. The Salad Nicoise was superb. Service was excellent, the view devine.

Well maintained, great staff. We toured with a guided group and had paid for a lunch, a liqueur on a terrace, a string trio concert and access to the special collections. There were a lot of stairs, but the staff operated a three=person elevator to assist those who needed it. We enjoyed our visit and would recommend it, though perhaps not for young children.

Viking River Cruise/ Tour of Lobkowicz Palace. This special tour of Lobkowicz Palace is a memory I shall never forget. After a delicious lunch in one of the spacious and beautifully decorated rooms of the palace, our Viking Tour Group were escorted to a balcony overlooking Prague and given an after lunch aperitif. That was followed by a special concert of music with a trio, pianist, cello, and violin, and then a tour of the collections of the Lobkowicz family which included sheet music written by Mozart. The accompanying audio for the tour was narrated by a member of the family and highlighted the more important pieces in the collection. All in all it was a special experience and do not miss this tour if you travel with Viking to Prague.

Leave Lots Of Time. This place goes on forever. There is many parts to the palace so allow a lot of time. Look out for the midday classical concerts, they are well worth the effort and never have we heard classical music in a more appropriate setting.
OUTSTANDING AUDIO TOUR. If you admire organization, you'll admire this tour. Not the most important palace around, but one of the most interesting as related by the real life private owners.

One of the most interesting tours anywhere!. A must do while in Prague. The audio tour of this palace will make you feel like you are a personal friend of the Lobkowicz family. You will view amazing treasures collected over centuries by this amazing family. Allow time for lunch or dessert at the cafe, lovely view and delicious menu choices.

Viking Palace and Dinner Tour. We toured the Palace with Viking and enjoyed the private dinner. The palace is an amazing structure with a wonderful history. As always, pictures never do it justice. We toured the museum and exhibits and learned about the Lobkowicz family history. Truly interesting! We came away grateful to the Lobkowicz family for their continued support of the arts. It is hard to imagine how much of the worlds great music would have never been created without them.

Upgrade to the private tour worth every crown!. We enjoyed a private tour of the Lobkowicz Palace -- including lunch and a classical concert -- and thoroughly enjoyed the time spent in this magnificent complex. In addition to the above, access to one of the most intriguing art collections delivered the experience of a lifetime: original scores from Mozart and Beethoven!

Start at the gardens. Very beautiful and amazing structure. We took the metro to malostranska then tram 22 up the hill so all the walking we did was downhill. Pictures do not do the palace and its grounds justice. Also you get a great view of Oldtown from high ground.

Palace and Concert Tour. Visited the Palace and enjoyed the exhibits. of special note was the Handel scores annotated by Mozart, in his own hand ,for the reintroduction of the Messiah. WOW! thats some impressive sheet music!
Really enjoyed the accompanying concert. Wonderful performances by piano and violin. Stirring music delightfully executed in a wonderful European Palace.
Really worthwhile and very affordable.

Wonderful. Attended a private lunch, 30 min. concert and a "meet the owner" who is an American. You'd expect them to be millionaires but they aren't and have sunk their life savings into restoring the family properties (and getting back artwork) - all confiscated first by the Nazi's then Communists. They are doing it for the Czech people and the world "making culture relevant". Kudos to them. Beautiful palace - breathtaking views.

Amazing art and a great story - use the included audio tour!. I had never heard of the Lobkowicz family prior to visiting this museum, but their story is fascinating and their impact on art and music significant. This is a must see site in Prague - the collection is impressive, as is the mansion and it's setting, but the audio tour that is narrated by the family is what really made the experience special. They include the audio tour with admission - definitely take them up on the offer - even my 9 year old son loved it.

Such History (and Beer). The castle has one of the finest art collections in Prague. The restaurant has one of the finest views in Prague (From the balcony). If you are on the castle grounds, this is a must stop for lunch or dinner (Or just drinks). The staff is excellent and the view to die for. The food is good and the memories immeasurable.

My favorite place in Prague (so far). The story of this family and its impact on art and culture is unbelievable. The palace and its priceless contents was lost to the Nazis and then the Soviets. Incredibly, the family has recovered them again. The collection includes original scores and manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart, including Beethoven’s 4th and 5th symphonies and Mozart’s re-orchestration of Handel’s Messiah. The 3rd Symphony, Eroica, was dedicated by Beethoven to the 7th Prince Lobkowicz. Lunch in the Palace Café is delightful, with marvelous views of Prague.

Our favourite historical site in Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace is found in the Prague Castle complex but isn't included in the general Palace ticket as it is a private museum, this seemed to deter people from visiting as we had the palace pretty much to ourselves on a Saturday afternoon.It is well worth paying the extra to visit this palace though as you get an audio guide included in the price (dictated by the owner William Lobkowicz) it gives the tour a personal feel & even has a highlights-route if you're in a hurry.Don't miss - Musical scores annotated by Mozart , Beethoven & Haydn and paintings from Cranach, Canaletto & Brueghel the Elder.

A fairy tale story. While in Prague a visit to the Lobkowicz Family Palace is to discover a most fascinating story about the loss and recovery of a family legacy linked directly to our modern day. You will see a fabulous collection of art and valuable possessions that are linked to the history of Europe since the 1600's. We attended a delightful chamber music concert at mid-day in the palace. My favourite discovery besides the overall story of the family, was the music rooms where there are musical scores written in both Beethoven and Mozart's own hand.

Don't miss this castle tour!. This is one of the best things we did in Prague! The castle is beautifully maintained, the collection is incredible and very diverse - including paintings, artifacts, silver, china, musical instruments and guns, to name a few! The story is quite remarkable and the audio tour is well-done. The admission price was reasonable for the amount that you got to see and learn about. The Lobkowicz Palace is now being run by the grandson, William, and his wife, Alexandra (formerly from Boston, MA in the US), and they have a terrific gift shop too!

A castle and fortune lost and found TWICE!. Our tour included a narrated castle tour, dinner overlooking the city of Prague and a concert featuring Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Dvorak. A pleasant surprise was a visit by the current prince and resident of the castle, William, during dinner. The castle and its 'contents were lost twice, once during the Nazi occupation and then again during the Soviet era. Both times most of the art and historical treasures were recovered. The castle currently pays its' way with tours and dinners.This is a remarkable place, made doubly special by the fact the owner fled to America after the Soviets took over in 1948 carrying nothing with him. He raised his family in the US until 1989 and returned with the clothes on his back.I am grateful to the family of Lobkowicz for preserving this wonderful piece of history for the ages!

Fabulous place- only privately owned property at the Prague Castle. We attended a wonderful classical music concert in the palace featuring a piano and viola which we loved. This was our favorite museum in Prague. The museum gives you free audio guide which is narrated by the Lobowitz family. It is so personal and so interesting that 3 hours flew by (and I am not a avid museum tourer). NOT TO BE MISSED IF YOU ARE AT THE PRAGUE CASTLE.

Beautiful place with a great view of the city. The audio tour did a good job of providing overview of the Lubkowicz family and their possessions. The Palace is located at the top of hill, so that you will get a nice view of the city.

Must See!. Fabulous collection, also open Mondays when other galleries are closed. Must have lunch or dinner at the Lobkowicz Palace Cafe, upstairs for the best views over Prague. Sunset was beautiful!

Amazing Art Collection. This collection is truly amazing. One of the coolest things they have is original Beethoven and Mozart music compositions with hand written notes on them. The family that owns this palace had 13 palaces that were confiscated by the Nazis, they got them back and then they were confiscated by the Russians, then they got them back again. They have an amazing art collection with a lot of masters represented.

Downton Abbey of Prague - free audio tour is not to be missed!. There are few palaces left in the world that one can actually imagine as someone's home, but in the Lobkowicz Palace a visitor can actually imagine a family calling it - home. In fact, remarkably, it is THE only private residence of the Prague Castle complex and as such is worthy of at least a stroll through, but go ages take an audio tour and you are likely to see the palace in an entirely new light. The audio guide is free!!! The star of the visit is, of course, the art collection of the Lobkowicz family, comprised of many family portraits. In most museums it is easy to forget that much of art used to be portraits of well-off patrons and of religious significance, a visit to this museum palace and particularly the audio tour brings this into focus, as one strolls through the rooms enjoying the lively narrative about the portraitures and many both interesting and typical objects belonging to the family. The Palace is relatively compact, so a tour is relatively quick and definitely gives one a glimpse of life that is long gone, although the story of reacquiring long nationalized possessions gives it some contemporary significance.As I was traveling with my teenage son, we follow a rule of eating only "local" food while on vacations… The terrace restaurant was the only exception on this trip. Since the Lobkowicz family, before returning to The Czech Republic to reclaim their confiscated possessions, grew up and lived in the US, my son was thrilled to order a good ol' american cheeseburger with french fries. And that's exactly what he got, and loved it. My lunch was equally well executed albeit a bit more middle european - a chicken schnitzel. The lunch on the terrace is lovely and a great place to take a break from all that walking.Overall, the Lobkowicz Palace is a truly unique experience and is an integral part of seeing ALL of the Prague Castle treasures.
Portraits and personal family collections. Rather dry displays of the family's collections of art, porcelain, musical instruments, etc. highlight was the music room.
A must see!. Visited the complex twice and enjoyed it immensely. The history of the restoration of the palace was fascinating and well worth the visit.

Expensive. The tour of this facility included a lunch and a concert. The Palace is quite nice and the audio tour is well done. However, we felt that we did not receive value for the money spent. While in a beautiful room, we felt the lunch was just okay. The concert was nice, but most of the selection of music was not well-known. The view from the rooms is spectacular, but not reason enough to justify the cost for a few hours.

Great Food. After climbing the steps to the Palace we were in need of a drink. The food menu was so good we decided to stay for lunch. This was a great rest stop and very reasonable for a 'tourist attraction'

MUST SEE. Definitely go for it.
