Very impressive compound spotted with many attractions and hidden gems.The golden Lane at the far end was a truly unique experience not to be missed.Of course, choose carefully your season and avoid the crowds if you can.the restaurant terrace lunch supplied us with a breezy and tasty break.

Skip it. I had this down as one of the places that I wanted to go and see. I arrived after one so I was unable to catch the classical concert. With your payment you also get an audio guide. The palace has two stories for you to explore. The collection is nice, but the information was uninteresting to me. I suppose this is because I am not from Eastern Europe. Perhaps I would have enjoyed it more if I was from the country. I found myself skipping the first floors items and wanting to leave. For it to be so highly ranked on tripadvisor it should have been much more I interesting. Definitely a fail for me.

A Private Palace on Castle Hill. This private palace, the only one found within the Castle Hill Complex, contains a very fine art collection and there is a very interesting history about the travails of the owner of the Place during World War Two and during the Communist era. The history is explained to you during the visit.
Stunning!. This place is amazing. It is like something from a picture book. Amazing views of Prague city from the Palace grounds. A definite must see if in Prague

Lobkowicz Palace. Prague is a feast on the eyes. Just magnificent.We really enjoyed every aspect of our visit. The Castle, the old town, the food and Mandarin hotel. Lobkowicz Palace was the highlight of our visit to the Prague Castle. The Palace has a great collection of paintings, arms, musical instruments and scores. The tour audio is terrific and brings to life the history of the family and the place. Not to miss!
Do Not Miss It!. The audio tour is a MUST!!!!!!! The Palace and the art therein is such a gift. Fantastic way to spend a couple of hours if you are at the Castle.
Worth seeing. Nice interiors, rich and various collections displayed. Takes about 3 hours to walk through all the halls, really worth seeing. Audio guide is provided.
Very nice. We had the privilege of having a private dinner at this castle. They have a small collection of art as well.

A reclaimed treasure. This is a very large palace which was reclaimed by the American branch of the family in recent years after Pragues occupation during the war years and after. It has been lovingly and painstakingly restored mainly thanks to the American wife of the current owner..The art collection is vast as there are many rooms in the palace filled with all kinds of treasures within its themed rooms. The palace is situated in the castle area of Prague, where there are many wonderful things to see. We found that we needed two days to explore all that the area has to offer. Don't miss the adjoining restaurant - have a drink and a snack or a meal on the lovely veranda at the back which has stunning views.

Arts, antiques and music! . I was not expecting to go here. After visiting the Golden Lane following a long day the the Prague castle, we were on our way back home down the hill when we passed by here. I'm not big on European history, but I am very much interested in museums and galleries. Having set food inside I knew the experience wasn't going to be like any other galleries I've been in. From the beginning you are presented with an ad music tour narrated by William Lobkowicz and various family members. The paintings are remarkably well preserved along many exhibits that I was surprised to see on display. There were paintings made of feathers, guns of various nature and manuscripts of original works from beethoven and Mozart. Overall, I was amazed and despite the short time spent in the museum, it was certainly a treat and we'll worth the price of admission. As a student, an audio tour and entrance fee was 200 czk, a bit pricey but really worth the value!

Wow what a legacy. pretty crazy when you think of how long this family has held this home and then lost it twice once to the Nazis and then to the Soviets only to make it a museum for the public. A testament to ones love of art and culture.

A good place in town. This touristic restaurant, in the heart of Prague Castle, is not a tourist trap. They serve a good gulasch and a vegetarian burger (which is not easy to find in town!) and you can enjoy a nice view over Mala Strana.

Average. Visited on 24 June.
Nice but too focused on the family as opposed to the history of Prague itself which is far richer.

Amazing Palace. Really liked th palace, even though the weather was not ok.
The only thing I didn't like, was our tour guide, is this guide from the canarian islands, from the green T-Shirt tours, Francisco. He is not a good tour guide, at all.

Best museum I have been to, ever.. Truly an amazing museum. There were no crowds, no long waits and the items on display were amazing. It's great knowing that the items you are looking at are all connected in a way. They all belonged to the same family for generations and were stolen by the Nazis and then again by the Communists. Eventually returned to their original owners they are now on display. The audio guide was one of the best and each room tells a different story. The highlights are Beethoven and Mozart's original scores and all of this in a beautiful building. A must visit!

Beautiful. This is just the most beautiful building in Prague. It is like a very regal lady sitting on her throne viewing the country below. The view is breath taking and even with all the people it is a very serene place to visit

Very interesting palace. This is a great place to learn more about the Lobkowicz family, a prominent Bohemian family. When we were there, an entire floor of the Palace was closed due to a private event. We paid the regular entrance fee but we were given a voucher to use in the gift store to compensate. The Palace has some nice exhibits which include some paintings, original manuscripts and musical scores, and arms and armors. The audio tour was interesting and informative. The Palace has a cafe with a lovely terrace where you can have lunch. Buy your Palace tour ticket before you eat there and you'll get 10% off your restaurant bill (something we missed because we ate at the cafe first).

Enchanting Palace. What made our visit to the Castle even more special was a classical music concert performed in the beautifully decorated 17th-century baroque concert hall.The intimate performance gave us greats from Bach and Vivaldi,Mozart and Beethoven, and Czech composers, Dvořák and Smetana. Incredibly moving.

Enjoyable afternoon. I'll admit that after visiting Europe for several years I occasionally develop ABC (another bloody castle) syndrome, but I made it a point to visit Lobkowicz Palace based on the reviews on tripadvisor. It was a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon. The attraction is not just the castle itself, but the audiotour of the history of the family, which dates back several hundred years, and their recent successful attempt to reclaim the castle after it was appropriated by the Nazis and then the Communists. The audio tour is provided by family members, who have that rare ability of being able to tell a story that is both succinct and interesting. I had lunch at the cafe, which was a welcome escape from the general craziness of the Prague Castle complex. A very worthwhile experience.
Hidden Gem. Story of how American William Lobkowicz reclaimed his family's 12 castles and belongings after the Velvet Revolution.

Very remarkable story behind re-privitazation. After having been confiscated by the government, the Lobkowicz family was able to get the palace back. The owner had fled the country and settled in America. Mr. Lobkowicz gave his American retirement money to his son to work on reclaiming the property. He was successful. We heard the son tell the story while eating lunch inside the palace. Please go inside should you get the chance.
Unbelievable view. And a very interesting story told. Get the little self guided tour headset and take your time. Well worth checking out.
Perfect wedding spot!. We were invited to the palace for a friend's wedding, it's a gorgeous place, with great views of the city. lucky are the couples who get to use it as their wedding venue :)

Unique Perspective. The back story of this building and collection is fascinating, especially since the audio tour is given by the actual family who owned/lost/regained/lost/regained their possessions. I am so glad that these priceless artifacts are back in the free world's hands, after being held hostage by the Nazis and the Communist Regime. Seeing the original scores of Mozart and Beethoven symphonies in the artists' own hands gave me chills!
Great art, interesting history. It's worth taking one's time and listening to everything the audioguide has to say. The connections with various composeres are amazing.

Interesting Art Collection. This was an interesting visit to this small private palace museum in the Prague Castle. The art work is Czech and so I wasn't really familiar with any of the artists, but the audio tour was well done and it gave some history of the palace. Plan to spend about two hours there. There is a very nice café in the Lobkowicz Palace for lunch, make sure to ask for a table on the terrace that over looks the city and has a great view.

Fantastic, well maintained museum.. We unexpectedly ran across this palace as part of our Prague overview tour. I was grabbed by the poster outside advertising that they have original Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts on display. It got my attention so much that we decided to drop off from our original lackluster overview tour, just so that we can spend time to visit the Lobkowicz Palace. That turned to be the best decision we have made during our visit to Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace is amazing! The audio guide was narrated by the current living Prince Lobkowicz. Prince Lobkowicz returned to Czech Republic from the United States to take back ownership of the Palace. All the displays were well maintained and his narration was personal and informative. Finally, seeing the original manuscript of the Beethoven 3rd Symphony at the Palace was the highlight of my Prague visit.

An unexpected gem. Having strolled through Prague Castle I stumbled upon the Lobkowicz by chance and decided to visit. It was a superb experience that encompassed music, history and art. Wonderful place.

Impressive. Did everything. Took the audio tour which was great. Ate in the cafe which was good. Stayed for a concert. Even the gift shop was nice. Seeing the original Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts made the hair stand up on the back of my neck. Wow!

One palace only. We only made time to go into one palace and this was it. We choose it to hear a selection of light classical music at 1 pm and then take the audio tour of the palace. The music was well judged, excellently performed, and in a small room. The museum included original manuscripts by Mozart and others! The audio is by members of the current family who tell some of their own experiences in assembling and presenting the artifacts. That added to the sense of occasion.

wonderful visit. We bought the combo ticket which included a lovely midday concert. We booked online before our visit which all worked well. The audio tour is excellent -nicely done, not boring, interesting stories. A really lovely afternoon which I would highly recommend

A surprise treat. I wasn't expecting much from this family home, but the positive reviews convinced me to go. I'm so glad I did! The art work collection is nice, but there aren't too many standouts. The most amazing part of the collection is for music lovers. Past members of the Lobkowicz family were patrons of Mozart and Beethoven, and they have kept some of the artifacts from that time. Seeing things written in Beethoven and Mozart's own hand was quite moving.The personal story of William and his family, as they narrate, was also touching. I was happy that my ticket money will go towards helping the family maintain and continue to restore this lovely piece of history. The ticket price was reasonable, and comes with a free audio guide.

Hidden gem for music lovers!. This estate is a success story of the repatriation laws of the 1990s. The original family has returned and opens their estate for the enjoyment of all. My personal highlight was the audio tour of their collections. Family history, famous painters, guns and antique armorments, and the coolest musical instrument room, featuring a number of original scores by famous composers. Mozart's reorchestration of has Handel's Halleluia Chorus, Beethoven's Eroica Symphony. Family also has a nonprofit organization to catalog and preserve this treasure.

Unexpected treasures. We thought we would go to one of the many concerts in Prague, and this one was at a time that suited us. Plus we could get a ticket that included a tour of the Palace. We didn't really know what to expect. Firstly, the concert was really lovely. Jan Srámek on viola and Sylvie Jazkova on piano were professional, accomplished musicians. They played some solos and duets, some familiar (the eternal Moldau by Smetana, but in a piano rather than orchestral rendition; Für Elise, but in a duet for piano and viola) and unfamiliar (a sonata for viola and piano by Henri Eccles). One hour of lovely music. Then came the tour of the Palace, including an audio by the current head of the family and some other family members. We were amazed at the wealth of the collection, including manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart, paintings by Brueghel and Velasquez and Canaletto and much more. The bird pictures, made from feathers of those birds, were intriguing and beautiful. Others may sneer at the portraits of the family pets, but as fellow pug-owners we were enchanted. The display of armour and weaponry was fantastic. I also loved the many portraits of women BY a woman - so very unusual. The account of the history of the collection, its confiscation by the Nazis and then the Communists, followed by the restitution, was a poignant reminder of the convulsions this country has seen in the last century. Overall, not to be missed.

Serene and calm. The palace is a magical place to visit. It oozes with history and take lots of photos as it is so beautiful and splendid. The Royal Guards keep watch in their sentry boxes just as ours do in Britain.

Great mixture and high standard of exhibits. A really good mix of stuff, we went particularly to see the musical scores (slightly underwhelming really) but the Canalettos are superb. A good audio tour gives plenty of information as you walk around and gives a lot of insight into the exhibits. Highly recommended

A definite must-see in Prague. If you go to Prague and don't see the Lobkowicz Palace, you are really missing out. Not only does this special exhibition display the fascinating story of one Czech family, but it also chronicles Czech culture from past to present. Definitely use the audio guide to enhance your tour, and if you have time have lunch in the cafe and attend the daily 1pm classical concerts offered by the palace. It is well worth the trip!

Amazing history, art, and cultural experience: stay for lunch!. I've been to Prague on several occasions and have no idea why my local hosts never included this on the tour stops. To be honest, it may be my favorite museum in the entire city. The collection of paintings, ceramics, weapons, musical instruments (and scores), is among the best in Europe. The audio tour is definitely worth it, and for anyone who is a music buff, they have original Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts.The historical narrative of the Lobkowicz family is also fascinating, especially against the backdrop of Nazi and Communist totalitarian regimes and persecution.Our group was able to reserve a lunch in some of the palace rooms. The food was excellent, service terrific, and it was an incredible capstone to our day. The palace staff were accommodating on so many levels. This is a MUST do.

Fascinating story of one Czech family. This private family collection/museum works perfectly well especially thanks to possibility to see it together with perfect audioguide, listening to very own words and very own voice of last member of this great |Czech aristocratic family, William Lobkowicz, who is telling you fascinating story of his dynasty during last centuries. And of course - Bruegel's Hay harvest!!

A "Must-see" in Prague. If you get to Prague, the Lobkowicz Palace brings the experience of past and present into perspective. See collections that have survived the Nazi's and the Communists to become a treasure to a nation and the world.

What a great visit, with audio tour narrated by the current head of the family. Just do this. It's not far from the Prague Castle and even more enjoyable than the castle. There are many beautifully decorated rooms where you can study paintings of members of the family going back centuries. Treasures on display include beautiful furniture and carved boxes, plus the piece de resistance, Millet's "Haymaking", one of his five existing paintings of peasant seasonal activities (3 are in Vienna and the fourth at the Met in New York.) There are lovely paintings by an artist hired by the family to depict their various castles and holdings, and a "bird room" the walls of which are covered by carefully-restored pictures of birds made from bird feathers. The story of how the family lost its property while under German control in WWII, getting it back in 1945 only to lose it again in 1948 when the Communists took over, is poignant. Also visit the nice gift shop, where you can buy a woven wall hanging if the "Haymaking" scene, and eat on the balcony of the palace cafe, where you'll pay $5 for a 20-ounce Fanta but the view is astonishing.

One of the best museums you'll ever visit. This is a great experience from start to finish. The audio guides are superbly executed, and bring the Lobkowicz family history to life, including the encounters with Mozart and Beethoven. To see original autograph scores of Beethoven symphonies is awe-inspiring stuff, and I didn't realise till I came here that, after Beethoven scrapped his dedication of the Eroica to Napoleon, he rededicated it to the then Count Lobkowicz. The two London Canalettos are superb. The story told by the current Lobkowiczs is a heartening tale of culture recovered from barbarism. Simply one of the best museums I've ever been to.

Wonderful!!!!. Lobkowicz Palace was part of our Prague visit and what a delight it was! It is beautifully maintained and a history buff's delight. A wonderful lunch was included with the tour and we had the opportunity to meet the Prince!!! Yay!:D

Wow what a visit. My daughter and I visited Lobkowitz Palace in June of this year and were beyond impressed with the entire presentation. This is hands down a must do in Prague. The physical scene - the palace, the art, the armor, the rooms - are impressive, but it is the story as told on the audio guide by Lobkowitz family members that makes this site so special. This is a great example of how compelling a personal story can make lessons in history and art. As you move through the rooms listening to the audio guide you fall into the family's story as you might fall into a good movie or book. We gobbled up every last piece and both felt that this was easily the best site in the castle quarter to take in. The Lobkowitz family members who tell you their story hit just the right tone of acknowledging that they are members of a gloriously wealthy and noble family while also remaining quite human and humble about their history. You come away thinking you might like to meet these nice people over a beer to thank them for sharing.

A Treat for Music and Art Lovers. Beethovan was a family friend and the originals of some of his famous works are on view together with some nice art pieces from masters like Canaletto.Again an early start, they open at 10.00, is recommended as you can enjoy most of the 34 points of interest alone when you get there early. The audio guide is included in the entrance fee and is narrated by the head of the present Lobkowicz household. It brings you through the family history in a very interesting way and you are left very happy that the family managed to get back its possessions that were confiscated under Communist rule.A most enjoyable experience.

Fabulous visit. Visited with 3 teenagers and they all became involved with the display.Staff were helpful and the Palace was very easy to navigate. The audio system is one of the best we have used.We spent around 1.5 hours fully engaged in the display. When I left I wanted to find out more about this interesting and influential family.
Culture. A must , even if you are not interested in history. can be done in 40 min if you are in a hurry. Do it early in the morning.

Lunch, Beer, Concert, and a great Tour Too!. We spent part of our morning at the Lobkowicz Place, watched the changing of the guard and took in the views of Prague as well as walked through many of the open buildings. In the afternoon we had a wonderful personal experience that began with lunch of Beef Goulash, a fine but small salad of tossed greens and a nice cold beer said to have been brewed on the place grounds since the 1400's. Following lunch we had an excellent cheese cake with fresh berries and preserved berries that my Wife said was fantastic. I don't do much dairy so I said I would trade her for her glass of schnapps that we were given as we began or tour of the galleries and rooms of the most recently used parts of the Place. As part of the tour we had a very nice session with three musicians from the Prague Orchestra who played five pieces of classical music for us. A very memorable and unexpected treat for us. The galleries were very interesting and the audio tour provided with entrance was very useful and added to the experience, we could have easily spent another few hours wandering if we had the time.

Well organised venue. Fascinating tour with lots of variety. Audio information system free with entrance tickets. Enjoyed a lunchtime concert after the tour, performed by excellent musicians. There is also a nice cafe with terrace where we enjoyed a pleasant lunch.

Beautiful historic artifacts at the foot of Prague Castle. William Lobkowicz (an American) returned to live in the Czech Republic in the early 1990s when the newly-independent country made it possible for the heirs of former residents to reclaim their property. In William's case it was some of the nation's crown jewels, the Lobkowicz's being one of Bohemia's oldest families, with palaces to spare. William and his family have done a fabulous job of restoration and a portion of the goodies are on display in the family palace within the Prague Castle complex. There is a separate admission charge, a lovely cafe and a wonderful concert every day at 13:00. Definitely worth a visit for the paintings alone.
Very interesting. A fascinating museum with some stunning displays. Worth a visit - you can buy a ticket at the entrance.

Preserved history. The culture and history of Prague are on display at this Palace. It overlooks the valley below and offers a wonderful presentation of the history of those who inhabited this palace prior. You can walk down the hill through the old town, get a flavor of the customs of past and present. The locals are very friendly and welcoming, especially when you enter their shops filled with souvenirs of present and past history.

if you have only thing to do in town ! THE MUST. Through the amazing because unexpected-rare-diverse Lobkowicz Collections, it is the History of the country that is then discovered or depth, vividly. Don’t miss the concert !
Additionally the staff is very - very friendly which makes the visit unforgettable !

Not to be missed. Get the audio tour, it was fantastic. There are works of art here that are extraordinary and most people probably don't visit this museum. They really miss out. The audio tour tells about the Lobkowicz family using the works of art as background. The family has a history that goes back hundreds of years and continues today. Fascinating tour!

Don't miss this. We did not have the time to see the Lobkowicz Palace on our last trip to Prague. Glad we got there this time! Beautiful. Excellent collection of original musical manuscripts from Mozart and others--we were totally amazed! Wonderful collections of art and ceramics. Commentary done by family members. Good to know that Americans are helping the foundation to do more restoration of the collection. I will contact the foundation because our company does work for non profits in the US and my husband is of Czech descent.

Fascinating Family History. Narrated by a personable story of an enormously wealthy and powerful family's cultural history. I enjoyed the recipe for white rose petals ("cut the rose as usual . . ."). If you can catch a concert there, you are very lucky.

Don't miss Beethoven memorabilia. The Prince of Lobkowicz gave Beethoven a yearly, unencumbered, stipend which freed him to compose what he wanted. The Prince's reward was the dedication of three of Beethoven's symphonies.

Read "City of Dark Magic". On the grounds of Prague Castle it houses the collection of the Lobkowicz family. Use the Audio Guide (free with entry fee) despite it being hard to get around the American accent of the current Duke who is the narrator.I strongly recommend a trashy novel that takes place there - "City of Dark Magic" by Magnus Flyte. Made me appreciate my visit more.

Lovely music!. We purchased tickets to the midday concert and it was well worth the price! We thoroughly enjoyed the hour-long piano and viola performance of classical favorites. The ticket also included a discount for the palace cafe, which has a fantastic view of the city from the terrace. We did not have time to do the museum tour, but we will definitely do it if we visit again.

Amazing Art Collection. We had the privledge of having dinner here as well as the opportunity to view the art collection. This is truly a unique location in the Castle District, with wonderful views of the river and the Old Town. The art collection conveys the family history of the occupants of the palace, and the lifestyle of the old nobility. Not to be missed!

Very worthwhile. Tour was self guided, which I liked,,,,spend as much time as needed in different rooms. Great collection of firearms, art and musical instruments. Well done and well managed. Would recommend.

Intimate museum with few visitors and great cafe. The audio tour comes with the admission price and the managing Lobkowicz family member does the audio tour. The result is an intimate and very information experience. It takes just an hour or two to see the whole collection. Do visit the cafe with the views overlooking the Prague and with its own brewed Czech beer. The whole experience is a great antidote to the chaos of the Prague Castle.

Our favorite experience in Prague. This is a must see museum. The Lobkowicz family personally takes you on a tour via their audio guide. Everything in the museum, comes to life because the family shares their personal journey through some very difficult times in history. While in the castle, you feel at home. Very few museums have such a personal touch.

Spectacular private family art museum. Do not skip the family art museum in the palace. Beethoven's 5th original score in his hand, arms, and one of 4 van Bruegel seasonal paintings are just a few of the treasures here. Well worth the entry fee to live one family's history through their collection, as told by a family member in the audio tour..be sure to use it.

My visit to the Lobkowicz Palace in May 2014. My name is Isabel and I am a Flight Attendant with Qantas Airways Limited based in Australia. In May 2014 I took my mother on a visit to the Lobkowicz Palace in mid May 2014 whilst holidaying in Prague, Czech Republic. What I had to show mum was amazing which begins with going through a tour of the very valuable Lobkowicz collection which was quite unique and pleasing but with ease to the eye not only for myself but to my mother who has a great love for her classical composers. Although I had visited the palace in November 2007, the information I soaked in last time from the tour was priceless. I couldn't wait to show mum what was inside the Music Room which have the beautiful original compositions of Beethoven, Handel and Mozart (to name a few) and how they came about.May I say that it marked a special day for my mother in which she will never forget...It was one of the highlights of our visit.I came on a holiday to Prague this time with my mother so that I could show her the absolute richness in history and culture one city (Prague) possesses and the impressive architecture that surrounds the city and historical buildings, plus never forgetting the delicious food and beverage it has to offer...I highly recommend it.

Best experience in Prague. Visited as part of an optional tour organised by Viking Cruises. Was not inexpensive at around 100 Euros but was well worth it due to the fantastic quality of the offering. A tasty lunch was included, although drinks were extra. We were offered an after lunch drink with which to enjoy the great views of Prague's iconic buildings and bridges. This was followed by a short concert of classical music consisting of five pieces performed by a trio of excellent musicians. The tour was concluded by a self guided tour of the museum and gallery of the palace of about an hour. The exhibits are too numerous to mention here but was worth it for just the music room with compositions annotated by Mozart and also the room with the Canaletto paintings. Well worth investing in a visit. You won't be disappointed.

Great history lesson. We almost missed this gem of a palace/museum but thoroughly enjoyed our visit. The family history was told through portraits and the very interesting audio guide done by current family members. Music lovers will appreciate seeing original Beethoven and Mozart scores as well as antique instruments. We paid extra to attend a piano/cello concert and was disappointed with the quality of the music. We were also surprised that the food in the cafe was mediocre and found $5.50 for a medium size water outrageous (ask for tap water.)
The best coffee in Prague.... .... on a sunny balcony with wide views over the city. Attentive and courteous service on both our visits. But cheap it isn't!

Grand and luxurious... A must see.The Palace has been the residence of one of the oldest and mostaffluent and influential families.The taste in art is impeccable and spans manycenturies.Surprisingly everything survived the communist regime without been plundered.Exquisite oil paintings,architecture,interiors,musical memorabilia and furnishings.A great touch is the audio guide by family members making the visita lot more personal and warmer.Great coffee and sweets at the cafe.

OK Museum. There is an audio guide in English describing the past family members in portraits by unknown artists. Current family members narrate the audio guide. While I do understand the family's desire to preserve a part of Czech history/culture it makes one wonder how they acquired all the wealth they are reclaiming. In addition, 5 rooms were closed on the day of our visit for a special function. We were not told we would not have access to the entire collection and when inquired at the ticket desk we were told to come back the next day. I hope Mr. Lobkowicz reads the reviews.

Big Surprise. This was not on our original plan for Prague. But we were up at the Castle and had time on our hands. What great luck we thought to visit Lobkowicz Palace. The audioguide in English is a must -- you hear from the familty members... not only about the history of the palace, the art collected there, but also how the newly democratic Czech government restored the property seized by the communists. And they love dogs! Great stuff! It only requires an hour or two... plus the cafe next to the palace is terrific!
Hidden Treasure. We took the audio guide personal tour. SO WORTH IT!!! We saw many musical treasures and heard the story of the Lobkowicz family. This was a highlight of our trip.

Deserves the Raves. We almost missed this gem, one of the highlights of out three week tour through Vienna, Prague Ceski Krumlov, Salzburg, Rome and Vienna. I can only second the rave reviews by a number of other reviewers. Unlike some of the old-fashioned family palaces in Rome, where pictures are hung traditional style from ceiling to floor, here the hanging is to modern taste, as in a museum. The audio guide is excellent, tying together family history and the art on display. For anyone interested in music, the Mozart and Beethoven scores are priceless. Since the Prague castle and its sites is more than OK but much less interesting than the Vienna castle complex, a trip to Prague without visiting the Lobkowicz Palace would be a real mistake. And the family/dynastic history you'll be exposed to here will make -- for instance -- the Cescki Krumlov palace that much more "historically" accessible and understandable. Wish we had had the time to try the cafe. This palace is on the route for river cruises, it appears. Enjoy.
Must not be Missed. One of the highlights of our visit to Prague. Excellent audio guide and exhibits without being overfacing. The cafe is of good quality and not expensive too.

Beautiful treasures worth a visit. The visit to the castle included lunch and a visit to see the many paintings, writings and other treasures. The family history was fascinating and openly shared. Some of the paintings are quite interesting. Of great fascination to me was the connection to music. We saw original notes from Mozart and Beethoven, original notes from Mozart on the original Handel's Messiah composition. Amazing treasures that are so appreciated.

Very interesting history. Loved the story of the palace as told by the current family members. Thrilled to see the original manuscript for the Messiah adapted by Mozart....also enjoyed the Canalettos on display at the end of the exhibition. Worth getting tickets for the piano and violin recital. Lots of popular classics. All in all a very pleasurable experience only spoilt for us by not being informed on booking that one floor was out of commission due to a private event. We felt we should have been told. However still an interesting morning if you enjoy putting places in their context in history.

An unexpected jewel. We almost didn't go into the Lobkowicz Palace, which is just down Golden Lane behind St Vitus Cathedral - but decided to take a look almost on a whim, and were so very pleased that we did. The family was once among the richest in Europe, but had their possessions seized not once but twice (first by the Germans, and then again by the Soviets); after the fall of the USSR they had the chance to apply to the Czech Government for restitution of their property, and did so successfully in the 1990s - but with the property came the responsibility to restore and preserve it, and the programme to do so is ongoing. This story in itself (as told in the audioguide by the current owner, William Lobkowicz) is interesting enough to make a visit worthwhile - and there are some marvellous paintings, including a Breughel and 2 Canalettos - but the room which for us turned this tour into an emotional and unforgettable experience is the music room. There you can learn about the 7th Prince Lobkowicz - one of the most influential art patrons of his time - and see original scores for pieces produced under his patronage, including Beethoven symphonies and Mozart's reworking of Handel's Messiah. There are regular lunchtime concerts at the Palace - we didn't go, but had the pleasure of hearing much of the music anyway as we took our tour. We didn't go into the cafe, but it looks nice and has been well reviewed by other people. Highly recommended.

Interesting palace. Didn't do this on my last rip as I balked a the price but this time I didn't pay for viewing the castle grounds and instead paid to see this exhibition, I enjoyed the rooms, architecture as well as the exhibits, Not a necessity but definitely good value

A good meal, nice concert / art display and a fantastic view. We attended the Lobkowicz Palace as part of a Viking Cruise Package. We had a good meal, although I was surprised to find that Czech goulash is not the same thing as Hungarian goulash. After the meal we had some time on the terrace from which the view was fantastic. This was followed by a nice concert and an English language audio tour of the art collection. This tour included the history of the Lobkowicz Family and Palace.One word of warning - as with all sights featuring fantastic views, the weather is the critical factor in the experience.

Fantastic!. Definitely go through the audioguide from start to finish (don't skip to the red numbers only), the tour is so informative and interesting. Apart from the delicious food this was the highlight of Prague for me. The pieces are well organised and not so voluminous as to overwhelm you. The best part was seeing original manuscripts from Beethoven and Mozart. Amazing!

Fabulous, the only description necessary. The art collections are just fantastic. Spanning many generations of history. They also have a great collection of musical instruments and what I consider to be a great gun collection. Well worth allocating several hours of time.

Creme de la creme of museums in Prague. Hope every museum curator in Prague has visited this museum! We paid a visit on the last day of our trip and this became one of the top 3! Do not listen what the Lonely Planet says (push audioguide button only in case of red numbers) - everything is worth to listen!

Great and so informative. Spent several hours here. There is so much history here and audio commentary really brings the palace's past importance to life. Probably one of the highlights of our Prague visit. The courtyard cafe is great and there are lovely sweeping views over the river and the city. All the staff were so professional and very helpful and friendly. The one hour lunchtime concert is well worth attending.

Beautiful museum which has lots of love put in to it.. One of the best museums I have visited with the most incredible artefacts. The Canelletos are amazing as are other paintings in the collection but to see Beethoven's manuscripts was totally mind-blowing even though we knew they were there. The guide done by the family was very moving as well as very informative. At the end I just wished we had more time to go to one of their other palaces outside Prague. We also went to the concert which was good I was not that impressed with the pianist but the Viola player was superb.

Hidden gem: a family shares its love affair with the country, best audio-guide ever!. Until I visited the Lobkowicz Palace, I was mostly disappointed with Prague Castle. The Old Royal Palace was closed for renovations. The Royal Treasury was outrageously priced. The gardens were either closed or just lacking in any blooms given the early season. The Golden Lane was a commercial travesty. Fortunately, right next door to the Golden Lane was the hidden gem of the entire Prague Castle complex: the Lobkowicz Palace. It's a true family business - the only difference is that it's a former royal family. The greeting and instructions I received as I paid my admission were so warm and genuine, as if being invited into someone's home. They even apologized in advance for "darker-than-usual" lighting in the Beethoven room, and gave a 50 Kc credit at the gift shop as an apology (no minimum purchase required).The key component of the tour is the audioguide that is included in the admission price. English-speakers are in for a treat, as the narration is done by the American-born heir William Lobkowicz who returned to the Czech Republic in the 90s to reclaim the property his family had to abandon to escape Communist occupation. As you tour the museum, William recounts his family history as a multi-faceted love story: love between the various ruling couples, love between family and country. Many members of the Lobkowicz family played prominent roles in Czech history. Were they the key players? No, but their presence is interspersed throughout the country's and city's history, and after you leave the museum, you will start to put the pieces together and place this family within the overall historical context.I took the "express" tour using the audio guide for only the highlighted exhibits. This took about an hour. Highlights included the Bruegel masterpiece "Haymaking" and the original scores by Beethoven and Handel written in their own hand! Towards the end of the tour I added a few non-highlighted exhibits, especially all those narrated by other members of the Lobkowicz family. The pride they express for their family and their country is inspiring.When I return to Prague, I will come back to the Lobkowicz Palace and take the complete audioguide-driven tour, and have lunch at what's supposed to be an excellent café. I only wish I had the chance to meet William (who is reported to scoop ice cream at the café on some days) and congratulate him on establishing such a wonderful museum.The only slight disappointment is that there was no way to photograph the breathtaking balcony view.The tour ends in the gift shop, where I used that coupon to buy a few nice souvenirs. I wish that gift shop were located closer to the city, as I had wanted to return to it because it had such a good selection of tasteful items at reasonable prices.All in all, this was my favourite museum in Prague. I recommend that you consider spending an hour or two here to wait out line-ups to the cathedral. You will not be disappointed.

Lobkowicz a Huge Success thanks to guide Zuzana. My wife and I had a wonderful day at the palace that included a very tasty lunch, the tour of the family history and art collection, the midday classical concert, and sampling Becherovka on the balcony with the a view!! Zuzana, our enthusiastic and informative tour guide did a spectacular job of hosting our group. Definitely ask for her when you take the tour. We would recommend having lunch after the concert, not before. Soothing classical music in a warm concert hall after dining and a savory shot of Becherovka - a Czech liqueur made of herbs and spices, litterally Becher Bitter - made for a sudden onset of nappy time. Definitely do this while in Prague.

Surprise. We are retired music teachers and already knew of the connection of Prince Lobkowicz, composers and artists. Discovering that the museum contained hand written manuscripts by Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven, as well as old instruments and great paintings, made this stop one of the top highlights of our trip.

A real gem with a personal touch. This museum was recommended to us by the tour guide on our walking tour. The Lobkowicz family displayed portraits, pottery, valuables, musical instruments, manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart....and the walk through the museum was accompanied by the audioguide that was recorded by members of the family. The little cafe at this place was quaint and it was nice to sit outside on the terrace. Highly recommend.

Huge castle. Worth Visiting. Amazing buildings and gardens. Lots to see and do. Various tours but you need at least half a day to do each.The castle and gardens are beautifully restored and maintained. Go to the castle by no 22 tram which stops outside. The afternoon is less busy than the mornings. You will walk miles on cobbled streets. Comfortable shoes are a must in Prague
Love this place!. This is an unforgettable experience. Wonderful staff, the history of one family, don't overlook Lobkowicz Palace!
Lobkowicz Palace. This was a wonderful museum filled with history and artwork from an important family in Pague's history. I really enjoyed it. Worth the price.

Superb collection in a building with an amzing view. This palace could easily be overlooked as you leave Prague Castle, but is a must see. The family history, and the related paintings, are worth the trip alone. But the highlight is the art and music collection. The Canaletto paintings of views of the Thames, a wonderful Breughel and Beethoven and Mozart annotated scores are world class. We found the audio guide that comes with the entrance ticket to be very helpful. To judge from the lunchtime concert on the day we were there, the live music (which is expensive) is not worth the money. At the end of the tour there is a good restaurant which, while not the cheapest, offers a small range of well cooked dishes.

A must-see in Prague!. This was one of our favorite memories of Prague! If you are looking to see some of the castle, this is the spot. An awesome story, a beautiful place, and lots of history. I definitely wouldn't listen to every single number on the audio guide as you would be there forever, but the highlighted ones are plenty and it is an awesome Prague experience! We were a group of 6 college kids and were not bored at all - highly recommended for everyone!

Best part of the Castle. Stumbled across this by accident having come into the castle complex the back entrance. As the queues for the other castle buildings were extremely long, this one was nearly empty and with the free audio guide, helped to capture the story of the Lobkowicz family and their exile, The most amazing artefact was Beethoven's 5th symphony manuscript! This made every other building in the castle pale in comparison. Do this if nothing else in that area.

Awesome place if you love classical music. Loved this place within Prague Castle. They have some great paintings and art, but the highlight is the classical music room. Just amazing to look at Beethoven's original, hand written, manuscript from his third, fourth, and fifth symphonies. They also have a hand written Mozart adaptation of Handal's Messiah. Very cool pieces to see.

What an audio guide tour should be. A well-laid out exhibit with an audio guide tour that enhances the experience. All of the people on the guide are personally connected with the tour and you feel more interested because of it. Not encumbered by oversharing or overdosing you on history or information, the tour was well worth the time it takes to view both floors. The staff is also incredibly friendly and helpful. Highly recommended.
Made interesting by the stories. I am not a big fan of museums but I liked this because the stories told in the audio tour made it interesting.

History in art. You will find the gallery with the audiotour very interesting through a historic view!Learned things about Beethoven and Mozart that I had no idea and also how connected the royalty in Europe was during many years.

A very pleasant surprise. This palace is understated, free of crowds and provides an excellent audio-guide. As you tour the museum, the commentary takes you through the past few hundred years of the ruling elite. We would also highly recommend the cafe for lunch - the food is good and the views from the terrace are superb.

medina??. if youve been to malta and to the city of medina then youll imagine what this is like!its lovely and well worth the climb(but I understand you can get on a tram that runs along the top then walk down)we felt fit so walked up and down!!

Historic Prague. Wonderful audio tapes taking you through the history of the Lobowicz family with great paintings and other artefacts. The highlight was the classical concert in the music hall. Well worth the joint visit to Palace and concert followed by lunch in the palace cafe overlooking central Prague - a great way to spend a few hours in Prague.

Eclectic collection. This museum houses an eclectic collection of paintings, ceramic and decorative arts, armor, and musical instruments and scores. The audio guide is useful in explaining the Lobkowicz family history, items in the museum, and how the family acquired, then twice lost, and finally re-acquired their collection. My primary purpose for visiting the museum was to see the autographs of music scores. I would have liked the music collection better if I could have seen a page with music notation from the scores rather than the cover pages. One could view the cover page of Beethoven's Eroica, but the visit would have been more rewarding if I could have seen the first page with music notation in Beethoven's own handwriting (which could have been possibly supplemented with a facsimile of the cover page). Still, the museum is worth a visit for the paintings.
Wow. The history behind this place is unbelievable!! The family owned place has an excellent tour. MUST see while in Prague.
Unbelievable story. Music, history, and great atmosphere. The museum has a collection of musical items and art that is magnificant. Enjoy a concert and lunch while you are there.

A Treat for Classical Music Connoisseurs. Music lovers will adore the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague thanks to its owner who had the courage and wherewithal to undertake restoration work. The place is located in the sprawling Prague Castle complex situated on the Hradčany Hill. The palace guided tour in English is a tour all music lovers should take. The palace also houses a restaurant. Music lovers will be thrilled to learn that Ludwig van Beethoven and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart compositions in their original manuscripts are displayed at the Palace. The piece de resistance of the palace is Beethoven´s Opus 55, Symphony No. 3 in E-flat major (Eroica) manuscript. One other display is sure to capture the imagination of the connoisseurs of art and that is the Pieter Bruegel the Elder’s painting of The Hay Harvest, a painting created in the year 1565. If you are lucky, you may be able to attend a classical music concert that may coincide with your visit.

Nice lunch and as always the view.... We enjoyed a break here after walking and shopping in Zlata Ulicka. Since we know the history of the Lobkowicz family, we did not take the tour. The fact that after the fall of the communism the family was able to get back what was rightfully theirs is of course fascinating. Having left the country years ago with my husband, I did not believe that this could happen in our life time! We walked around the small store and had a nice lunch on the terrace and a wonderful apple strudel for dessert. The terrace is not very big and we were glad to get a seat. They offer warm throws for when it gets colder. Took some beautiful photos from there. we will stop by on our next visit.

So glad we made the effort to see this wonder. Although this is separate to the 'Large' or 'Small' ticket you buy to see the wonders of the Palace complex, do go and see this magic place and listen to the family story. It's a jewel box of history, art and domestic collections seen in an uncrowded beautiful building. We could have stayed for far longer. There's also a wonderful cafe with balcony overlooking stunning views. Just go for delicious soup if nothing else!

Very nice!. This was a very nice visit. The castle gives a slight overview of the story of the Princes of Lobkowicz. The audio guide is necessary though. There I not much text to read in the exhibition. Nevertheless, the audio guide is great! We took t in English and the voice of the current Prince of Lobkowicz himself lead us through the exhibition. Classical music accompanied the stories. Personally, I would have liked even more information about the family story.

Excellent audio tour. We loved this tour. We were on the fence about doing it, since we thought it might be a bit boring, but I'm so glad we decided to do it. It was fascinating to learn the family history and stories behind the family heirlooms. It was a rare perspective. The audio guide is very well organized and informative, yet not boring at all. Would definitely recommend a visit to this palace.

Perfect!. After jostling with the other tourists to see around Prague Castle and St Vitus Cathedral we were lucky to find this oasis of calm to restore our flagging spirits. First delight was an enormous and delicious apple strudel in the cafe with a view over Prague. We then enjoyed the midday concert in the salon upstairs. A professional pianist and Viola player serenaded a disappointingly (for them, not us!) small audience which was the highlight of our trip for me. We then used the excellent audio guides to wander through the palace art galleries and were blown away by the music room which housed Beethoven's original manuscripts for his 4th and 5th symphonies as well as original manuscripts from Mozart and Haydn. Perfect!

Worth a wander around. Some cool buildings and historic feel, once you're up there, there is plenty to do and see. Definitely a half day to full day outing, depending on what you're into. It also provides a good view point over the city.

excellent cultural experience. Preferred this to the inside of Prague Castle...was very interesting. We ended up having delicious hot chocolate and strides in the cafe. Gift shop was too pricey for me.

A must for Beethoven fans. One the the Prince Lobkowiczes gave Beethoven a substantial yearly stipend so he could composer without money worries. In return, Beethoven dedicated many works to him including the 3rd (Eroica), 5th and 6th symphonies. There is another Lobkowicz palace in Nelahozeves which is even more beautiful and interesting.

Excellent tour & afternoon concert. Very informative audio tour showcasing exquisite artwork and family history of the palace. I highly recommend the tour and the afternoon concert located in an elegant music room within the palace. It was an incredible way to spend the day. Highly recommend.

Stunning views and a blanket too. Stunning views from the terrace make this worth the high cost - although with exchange rates even high wasnt really very high. Ive paid more for much more inferior food in UK tourist attractions. They have outdoor heaters and provide you with a blanket too!

Don't Miss This. The Lobkowicz family has a long and very interesting history. The palace is lovely but the real attraction is the family museum which is a show place of antique paintings of family, firearms musical instruments and manuscripts of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven. Viking Cruises has a special deal, which includes lunch and a concert. Wonderful experience. The tickets go fast; so, don't hesitate to grab them, if available.

Restored palace. Well worth a visit with an audio guide included in the price narrated by Willliam Lobkowicz. The contents of the palace are interesting in themselves but so is the story of the restitution to the family of the palace and its treasures. Quite remarkable to be able to view the Breughel in a room with no one else whereas the other pictures in the Seasons series in Vienna and New York would be surrounded by other people.

Great view from the patio. We did not visit the Palace itself, but I highly recommend to have lunch or coffee and cake on the outside patio in the cafe, which offers a beautiful view onto the old roof tops and churches. Great place for a break in the busy sightseeing schedule of the palace.

A personal history. The museum was interesting. A very personal history which made it quite a unique experience. Liked the art and music memorabilia. Takes about an hour or so and you can drop into cafe for a bite after.

Love the history. This city seems very safe and everyone is friendly. One treat for us was the tour with Viking River Cruise which included: a private tour of the Lobkowicz Palace with a sit-down lunch (Mixed green salad, Czech goulash with dumplings, homemade cheesecake), private 5 song concert, self-guided tour with hand-held recorder, and we received an autographed book "The Lobkowicz Collections" signed by Alexandra and William Lobkowicz. This sprawling city has so many incredible sights and intriguing history. You will thoroughly enjoy it!
great costumer service. the staff in the museum shop was extremely kind, more than one would expect, and they had lovely souvenirs
Palace. We loved the Palace. Lunch was delicious and the chamber music beautiful. The museum was awesome. Seeing original manuscripts from the maestros was breath taking.

Nice, but not that special.... We went to this museum, it is nice, but certainly not worth 5 out of 5, I would say a 3 1/2 but as I can't give that I will give it an average. It is better than average, but it's not very good either!.There are a lot of paintings, all related to the family Lobkowicz and mostly painted by unknown painters. There are two exceptions, three nice paintings, one painted by Breugel and two paintings made in London and which shows London from one side of the river Thames. All the other stuff is nice, but not that special, unless you haven't seen anything from that period before.Still you won't feel cheated when entering this museum, it is worth the money, so do go and visit. Another positive thing is that it is not very crowded!.

Both a collection and a history. The Lobkowicz dynasty were princes and other high nobility in Bohemia (Prague and surrounding area) from the 14th Century until the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire at the end of World War One. As you can imagine, they had the opportunity to buy or commission all sorts of great works of art.Although the First Czechoslovak Republic abolished the nobility, the Lobkowicz were supporters of the democratic state, which meant they had to flee when Nazi Germany invaded in 1939. They had to flee again when the Communist Government confiscated their possessions in 1948. After the collapse of the Soviet bloc, they maneuvered successfully to regain their possessions. I guess that the offer to put so many of them on display and to open their palaces to the public were part of the negotiations.So now, we get to see how the Bohemian 0.00001% lived, their portraits, even the Beethoven score they commissioned and which is dedicated to the then-reigning Prince.The English audio guide is by the American-born heir to the Lobkowicz title and his explanation of the art tied to the family history is a must, even for those who generally skip such guides.Highly recommended.
Absolutely beautiful. We loved the passion for restoration of the treasures of the palace made accessible to the public. Great history lesson.

Only for those that are interested. When we bought the tickets for Prague Castle (the short visit option) we were never given the option to include this Palace. So when we stumbled across this Palace we were shocked when we had to pay extra for this and that there was actually an option to include this Palace in our tickets. Nevertheless to see Beethoven's 5th Symphony manuscript up close is well worth the price of admission alone!

What a beautiful palace.. It has a vineyard and concerts there in the catheral.That is truly a Palace. The grounds are enormous.At night it is breat taking as you walk the streets. Praghue is worth visiting! Make sure to have coffee at the FAMOUS Coffee house where all the writers and poets would go and there is a man playing the piano.
Beautiful!. Our tour was great! We had a very good lunch with other Viking travelers then enjoyed a beautiful concert. We also enjoyed seeing the changing of the guards.
Fascinating Story, Beautiful Museum. The beautiful art and antiques that the Lobkowicz family reclaimed is a fascinating story and time to learn about in the history of the world. Amazing!

A Special Place with a Long History. WE enjoyed a talk about the palace and its family while sipping prosecco, followed by a delightful dinner complete with a string quartet, followed by a tour of the palaces public rooms and ending in their delightful classy gift shop.

A Prague Favourite.... Our tour of this wonderful museum was an afternoon to remember. We so much enjoyed the individual rooms, the artwork, the manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart, the history of this family and the present day involvement they have. The wonderful story about how the family was able to recover this and other properties they had lost....it all makes for a very worthwhile visit. We had a pleasant light lunch in the cafeteria and enjoyed the musical concert very much...very civilized! Don't miss this!

Perfectly elegant 40 minutes. Intimate look at Lobkowicz family treasures in very user friendly 2 story layout of diverse themes. Portrait rooms, music room (amazing to see both Mozart and Beethoven actual works!), gun room, priceless Brueghel room, even a dog themed room. Audio included is a must do. Also have hour concerts, which we did not do here but seem to great to spend a civilized hour. Go.
over priced but unique experience. Visited early part of Nov. Palace beautiful but the meal was a rip. The concert was shorter then we were lead to expect

An almost private visit. Visiting the Lobkowicz Palace in the off-season is like having the palace to yourself to fantasize about what it must have been like to live there. Seeing the treasures was enlightening with the accompaniment of the family- narrated audio tour. Of course, mention must be made of the hot chocolate with whipped cream in the cafe (which we repeated on the next day).

Lobkowicz Palace. We found this Palace to be a very interesting attraction. The fact that the current Lobkowicz family members are involved with this location made it much more interesting than the usual palace tours. The audio narration tour was great and very interesting. The music collection was wonderful and to see the original manuscripts was amazing. The view of the city from this location was perfect and the lunch and private concert delightful. During my trip through the gift shop I met William Lobkowic who was very gracious and engaging. It really brought the Palace to life for me and to discuss some of the plans with the music manuscripts was fascinating. Great collections - highly recommend you include this in your visit to Prague!

Best palace to visit.. American who owns palace does audio guide, gave a great history of his royal family. We were overjoyed to see original manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart. Would have loved to take pictures or at least buy copies or postcards of these.

Very enjoyable afternoon. We had the opportunity to have lunch, a concert, and a tour of the museum at the Lobkowicz Palace. While any one of those activities would have made the visit worthwhile, the best takeaway for me was to learn about "restitution" following the fall of communism. It is a heartwarming story to learn. Seeing original hand-noted Beethoven scores was an unexpected experience. The collection of family history is more than impressive. The afternoon at Lobkowicz Palace was the highlight of our visit to Prague.

Highlight of trip!. If you want a truly memorable view of Czech and European history, be sure to visit the Lobkowicz Palace, which is located at the far eastern end of the Prague Castle complex, near the top of the Old Castle Steps. Terrific audio tour – very well done! We loved learning about historical events through the stories told by the Lobkowicz family members. Portraits spanning centuries, jewelry that is featured in some of those portraits; china and silver; a collection of firearms; musical instruments, musical scores annotated by Mozart; huge canvases by Brueghel, by Canaletto – remarkable and fascinating collections. All the more interesting since these treasures had been confiscated by the Nazis, then appropriated by the communists. Now many of these restituted, repatriated Lobkowicz treasures are assembled in permanent exhibitions at the Prague Lobkowicz Palace. We loved the concert at the Palace – selections from Dvorak, Beethoven, Pachebel. We loved the view of Prague from the café terrace. This visit to the Lobkowicz Palace was a highlight of our visit to Prague.

A remarkable story of persistence. Lobkowics Palace is one of the many historic palaces surrounding the Prague Castle. It is now again owned by the Lobkowics heirs who when communism fell took the opportunity to restaure their historic heritage and claim it back from the Czech State. The palace is beautifully restaured and the family has been able to recover many of the historic works of art. The Palace houses a nice coffee shop/restaurant. It is somewhat of the beaten track in terms of tourist visits, but certainly worth a visit.

Great Place to Visit. Interesting Palace, restored to its former owners following the Velvet Revolution. Contains two great Canaletto paintings of views of London and some original music notes written by Mozart and Beethoven. Highly recommended.

OK but not great. We walked to the palace on a very pleasant October afternoon. It is a museum of the Lobkowicz family art, gun, and music collections along with a very detailed history of family members. The highlight for me was seeing the actual manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart along with a collection of musical instruments. It was interesting but I would not recommend it if you have only a short time in Prague.

Who Knew?. The palace is in the Castle grounds and, after two visits, decided to give it a try. WOW, who knew. What an incredible family, and incredible power and wealth in their days. The audio tour was very done and kept my attention throughout. You here about many things, the number of palaces they had, etc, but when you see an original manuscript of Beethoven, and learn that he dedicated his most famous work (5th) to the Prince you begin to understand just how rich (in many ways) they were. Fascinating
horrible this place was annoying and dirty. dirty young helpers not knowing what their doing .,...at all......they need to be with their own city and crowd and leave the good stuff up to the experts

Fantastic cultural treasure in the heart of Prague. This is a wonderful family owned stately residence near Prague castle. It houses many works of art including two great paintings of London by Canaletto. The museum staff are especially friendly and speak perfect English. Private guided tours are also available.

Nice Palace - Mostly Ground Level. Unfortunately the Palace was closed for their national holiday - but we got to see the beautiful Cathedral, nice chapel, and the "Golden Street". The street was the neatest. It was for artisans who worked at the Palace, then became Jewelry shops. A dozen or so have been restored - but be aware that most "artisans" were short - very short. All the doorways are about 5 feet tall - if that. Most visitors got a good thunk in the forehead more than once. There are warning signs, but who pays attention to those.... Last apartment belonged to a photographer, and his movies are playing continuously.

Afternoon concert was lovely. We went for the concert which was performed by a professional pianist and viola player in a spectacular reception room of the palace. It was worth the money to upgrade to the front row seats to fully appreciate the pianists hands from 4m away and have the more comfortable chairs. We then enjoyed a lovely lunch at the cafe. We would have liked to visit the art gallery which looked amazing but when you're travelling with a teenager...But even he liked the concert too.

This is a really fun stop to see the palace. We attended a lunch/tour/concert as part of a Viking Cruise. The lunch and short concert were very nice, and a cocktail was served on the terrace which had a great view and made for great photos. It was nice to tour the palace with all the photos and displays and wonder what it is like to live in such a beautiful home. There is a restaurant on site, and tours for individual purchase. Worth the stop.

A beautiful palace and museum. The Lobkowicz Palace is part of the large-scale Hradcany complex of Cultural institutes. It's a city palace and, except the beauty of it being a palace, it also holds a museum of versatile fine art, that is owed by the Lobkowicz family, whom their property was confiscated over the past century's totalitarian regimes, and than brought back.It's no too big, so an hour is all you need for it. There's a charming courtyard with cafe. Notice that taking photos isn't allowed.

Not to be missed. Definitely don't miss visiting the Lobkowicz Palace, and if you are a musician it is absolutely a must see with the family's spectacular history of music patronage of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven. The Cafe with a terrace overlooking Prague serves uncomplicated, delicious fare - don't miss the Black Forest Cake - the best.

Very memorable. Visiting this outstanding private collection of the Lobkowicz family is a very memorable part of our tour in Prague. We spent more than 2 hours there exploring the collection from one room to another. 270kc admission fee includes an audio tour (available in 8 languages: Czech, English, German, French, Italian, Japanese, Russian and Spanish) of the palace which explains the history of the Lobkowicz family and details of European history too. Narration by the members of Lobkowicz family makes the experience very personal. It is very dramatic that the family lost everything twice. First taken away by the Nazis in 1939 second by the Communist regime in 1948. Finally regained ownership of their palace in 2002.In the museum an extensive art collection is on display including family and royal portraits; fine porcelain, ceramics and decorative arts; military and sporting rifles; musical instruments and original scores and manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart.

Best Audio Tour EVER. We visited the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague with our children 6, 8. 8 year old has autism and really doesn't handle museums well because they are too crowded. We decided to visit this attraction because of the excellent reviews and were not disappointed. Our visit was at around 10:30 am on a Friday morning. There were hardly any other visitors at all (this was in October). The audio guide was simply the best we ever heard. The narration was interesting and personal as it is narrated by the actual owners. The artwork is lovely. My favorite room was the instrument room that had a handwritten score of Mozart's instrumentation of Handel's Messiah, as well as hand edited scores of Beethoven's Symphony no 5 and the Eroica. The whole tour took us about an hour during which time the children never got bored and enjoyed going from number to number. Afterwards we had lunch at their cafeteria on a beautiful balcony overlooking Prague. The food was excellent. I highly recommend you visit this place.

Highly interesting museum in Prague. Having passed by this museum a number of times on my many visits to Prague, my daughter and I decided to go in and see what was hidden inside these walls. We were stunned to see original manuscripts by Beethoven, for some of his symphonies. Furthermore there is a collection of art which is really worth seeing.Evidently ancestors of the present Prince Lobkowitz were very wise to see and acknowledge Beethoven's unsurpassed genius, enabling him financial independence.Highly recommended.Also very friendly staff!

Gorgeous. Our tour group had our farewell dinner in their ballroom....the crystal chandeliers were magnificent, the wait staff was outstanding....we felt like royalty. We got to tour the family artifacts which were wonderful. We even listened to the "Prince" tell us about his family castle!! Wonderful!
Beautiful museum. The audio is splendid! Gorgeous art and a fascinating history as told by a family member. Some of the finest art anywhere. This locale reflects much of the Czech Republic's past.

Highlight of our Prague Week. We took in the 1pm concert combo ticket on our first day in Prague. Excellent musical talent and the audio tour with narration by family members was educational and personal. After a week sightseeing, our daughter said Lokowicz Palace was her favorite experience.

Great visit to Lobkowicz Palace. Fabulous collection of classical music memorabilia. The family were patrons to Beethoven, Mozart and others. Original music scores in Mozart's hand and Mozart's hand written notes on Handel' Messiah. Period musical instruments. Plus great art accompanied by family history on audio. Charming mid day classical concert and our first taste of goulash. The highlight was when the Prince came to speck to us (apparently a rare occurrence). Born in Boston, what a genuine and down to earth guy. Definitely don't miss when visiting the Prague Castle area.

Lobkowicz Palace. It was interesting to learn of the history of the family and this is done by a commentary on headphones. A lot of the paintings were of moderate quality but their importance was in recording family history. The Canalettos were outstanding though. If you like earthenware and guns there is plenty to see. The cafe is expensive.

Don't miss this!. The palace is on the grounds of Prague Castle, but requires a separate admission, which includes the audio guide. It's well worth it! The story of the Lobkowicz family begins in the 15th century and is fascinating all the way, including their surprising return to Prague from the US in the 1990's. The family have been patrons and supporters of the arts, and the collection includes gorgeous paintings and decorative arts, plus original manuscripts from Mozart and Beethoven. The audio guide is done by family members and enhances one's enjoyment of this exquisite building.

Fascinating!. This tour is extremely well done with the audio guide narrated by members of the family. The story is fascinating and the treasures on display are incredible, both for their historical and artistic value, as well as the fact that they are still all intact in spite of the turbulent changes of possession through Naziism and Communism. To hear the story of this family is a genealogist's dream, but an amazing story for all. If you are in Prague, it is a must do!

Excellent concert & museum. On our last day in Prague we decided to visit the Lobkowicz Palace. So glad we did! The early afternoon concert was wonderful. The concert hall is stunning, small and intimate.The musicians (piano and viola) were very accomplished and played a wonderful mix of classical pieces. It was a unique experience. Following the concert we spent hours in the museum. Fascinating collection and family history enhanced by the excellent audiotour.
Amazing. What a surprise to discover this private collection inside a palace on the castle hill. Best of all was the audio tour narrated by a family member; it made it feel so personal!

A must visit in Prague. We happened to walk by the Lobkowicz Palace while strolling at Prague Castle and decided to go inside. What a lucky happenstance! It turned out to be our favorite place to visit. The story of the palace is amazing and the Lobkowicz family does a great job of interweaving their family story/history together with the art, furniture, and historical items together (the audioguide is narrated by the current heirs).We enjoyed our tour so much that we went back the next day to attend an outstanding piano and violin concert at the Palace. The pianist and violinist were simply amazing....excellent choice of music and arrangements too.

You really don't want to miss this..... This was by far one of the most interesting highlights of my visit to the Prague, and it surprises me how many people seem to pass it by. While crowds were swarming in other areas of the Prague Castle grounds, I was able to tour the Palace on a weekday morning with just a few other visitors. The audio tour is excellent, and the Lobkowicz family's story and historical connection to Prague and to music is fascinating. I spent a considerable amount of time alone in the music room viewing the original Beethoven manuscripts in the family's collection -- which would be a major attraction if they were exhibited in any of the more famous museums around the world. I also attended the lunch time concert and took advantage of the discount offered for lunch in the Palace cafe -- both of which were a nice retreat from the hustle and bustle of the long list of tourist sites in Prague. If you have a few hours, this is well worth a visit.

Absolute must!. We went to the lunch time concert in the palace which is just spectacular! We then had lunch in the cafe on the terrace overlooking Prague followed by the 1 hour audio tour of the Lobkowicz Palace. Highly recommend all three!!!

Family Pride. A most glorious example of family heritage I have ever sene. Be sure and take the audio tour as the son of the family narrates and makes it very personal. what a fantastic display of the family and their history. I can't wait to return.

Don't miss!. We did a 3 day extension to our Danube cruise and stayed in Prague for 3 days. One of the highlights was the walking tour of the Jewish sections of the city, the Charles Bridge and then a trip up to the Castle to see St Vitus Cathedral followed by lunch and concert at Lobkowicz Palace.The Palace contains priceless treasures including original Beethoven manuscripts - music lovers take note - this is a very special part of the tour. There was a very nice post lunch concert given by a quartet of talented musicians and then we had some free time to explore the Palace. Highly recommended.

Incredible - don't miss it.. This was all I wanted to see in Prague and I wasn't disappointed. It was the highlight of my trip. We only had one day and arrived late so raced up to the castle and found the Lobkowicz Palace. The audioguide (which is a must and spoken by a member of the Lobkowicz family) personally immerses you in the world of this family and their fantastic collection. It is wonderful to feel like a fly on the wall of their personal lives and how it translated to their art collection. Plus original manuscripts of Mozart and Beethoven! A truly wonderful experience.
Gem of a collection. Very interesting and beautiful collection. Loved the Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts. The audio guide narrated by Lobkowicz family members is surprisingly entertaining.

A personal perspective on history. This museum traces the history of the Lobkowicz family over about 500 years. They were princes with high offices in the Hapsburg government so were in the center of political events. They were also patrons of the arts. The museum is in their former palace, at the edge of the castle complex. The museum's artifacts include family portraits that identify the roles of the individuals in history, musical manuscripts (Beethoven, Handel as reorchestrated by Mozart), musical instruments, firearms and armour, artwork including a Brueghel painting and two Canalettos, as well as dinner service, paintings of the family's dogs, and more. William Lobkowicz narrates an audio tour in English (other languages are available) in a pleasant, unpretentious, and informative voice. What makes this museum unique is that it personalizes history through the experiences of a family. Most museums focus on history OR art OR houses, but this one embraces the full experiences of living and helps one put the facts of history together. I especially liked a picture of Princess Polyxena showing the survivors of the second Prague "defenestration." She may have hidden them in her ample skirts! A humanizing touch was to hear William's father tell of riding his bicycle in the long halls of another grand family palace.
