The family lost all of these treasures first to the Nazis and then to the Communists, but when they got them back in the 1990s, they decided to share them with the world. What a gift to us. The admission fee is reasonable (about $10 US dollars in 2013, including the audio tour--the concert would add a little more). Combining this visit with other experiences: (So much travel info focuses on one site but not on how to piece things together; the combination that follows worked in terms of locations and variety for a full day.)My husband and I had a great (though ambitious) day beginning by walking from Josefov across Manesuv Bridge (one north of Charles Bridge, near the Rudolfinum hall), then up a couple of blocks to a walking path to the castle. Lobkowicz Palace is the first place in the castle complex entering from the east (Jirska Street). After our museum visit (about 1.5 hours), we enjoyed lunch at the Palace cafe (great views of the city as well as good food). Then we walked through the castle grounds and descended from the other side to walk to St Nicholas Church, an amazing example of the Baroque, took a little detour to the small church on Karmelitsca Street that houses the Infant Jesus of Prague (a gift of the Lobkowicz family), then to the Kafka Museum (quite different), then across the Charles Bridge. Lots of steps and a full day, but each thing we saw was amazing, and walking gave us a feel of the city. (We had spent time in the castle and St. Vitus Cathedral the previous day and didn't pause there.)

Beautiful and historically interesting. Well, the family certainly have been able to regain many of their treasures. Also try to attend a concert here - every day at 1pm. Fabulous cafe - wait till you see (and try) the black forest cake (add 10 kgs to you). Exceptional collection of firearms - and the musical chambers are wonderful - even Beethoven and Mozart annotated manuscripts.

Gem in the Hradcany Castle complex. Many people visit the Hradcany palace and miss this gem. The only privately-held portion of the castle complex, this palace has been home to the Lobkowicz family for hundreds of years. The stunning exhibit and and audio tour describes the history of the palace and it's family, and centers on the little-discussed period between 1938, the Second Wold War and the revolution in 1989 when the family lost it's land not just once, but twice. It is a sad but powerful story, and well worth the visit.

Gorgeous private palace. Spent the morning at the Lobkowicz Palace . This family treasure has been restored and maintained as an gem for visitors to Prague. Definitely purchase the multi pack with access to the palace, the concert at 13:00, the audio tour, and various discounts. Great cafe with amazing view over the city, great food , and efficient staff. In fact all of the staff - entry desk, shop , and cafe were all pleasant and helpful. The items in the collection were amazing especially the music room, the paintings and the china. My thanks to the Lobkowicz family for sharing their rich history and their continuing commitment to the Czech Republic at this palace and their other residences.

Wonderful attraction. We visited the palace, saw the museum, went to the 1pm concert and had a light lunch in the café. .Lobkowicz Palace is a great way to spend a few hours. The concert was enjoyable, the cafe surprisingly good and the museum really interesting. The history of this family is absolutely fascinating and you learn a great deal about the history of the city hearing their story.

Like Ali Baba's cavern. Very eclectic, and all the more fascinating, collections. We were especially moved by the music exhibit, with the Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts, and the stories about how the Lobkowicz supported those artists. The Canaletto room, too, deserves a lot of attention.The story of the Lobkowicz family alone, and how they saw those treasures confiscated, and then surrendered, over and over again, is worth the visit.Don't miss it!

Interesting collection. An audio guide takes you through the Lobkowicz collection. They have art, pottery, weapons, and some interesting musical items (including original scores from Beethoven and Mozart). It's an interesting way to hear a bit of the history of Prague.

If you do anything in Prague this is it. How many words to say this may have been our favourite attraction in Prague? Located near the lower entrance to the Prague Castle look for the signs directing you to the Toy Museum behind the cathedral, the entrance for this is directly across called "Lobkowicz Museum". You do not need to pay to walk through the castle grounds to get here although you will have to dodge the huge tour groups! The entry fee includes an audio tour (narrated by the Lobkowicz family themselves) which is an absolute must to tour this place. Fantastical family history including young brides, the Spanish, guns, Mozart, and Beethoven bringing you closer than most of us will ever get to true Royalty. We would tour here again. Recommend going here later in the day to avoid tours so you can sit and stare at all of the paintings

Must do. The Lobkowizc palace is located within the Prague Castle grounds but gets only a fraction of the crowds. However don't let that deter you if you want to see a good art collection and a fantastic music collection which includes original music sheets by Beethoven with hand written corrections! Amazing

escape the crowds and stare at Mozart's handwriting. The castle was swarming so we ducked into here. With the Senior discount, it was a deal, especially considering the fascinating English audio guide (included). For us, it was the best thing on castle hill.

don't miss this, though you'll be tempted to pass it by. get the audioguide, a sweet and fascinating accompaniment to some displays you'll not see elsewhere, including original music manuscripts of Mozart's and Beethoven's
Interesting tale to be heard. Away from the crowds in the castle take an audio device and enjoy the trip round and dont forget the cafe with great views back to old town

A prince of a place. What a treat our visit here was, part of our Tauck River Cruise. We enjoyed a fabulous dinner in the palace -omg, not my usual evening activity. Best of all, we had a wonderful talk by the Prince before the dinner telling us all about the history of this beautiful place and, more specifically, his personal story and that of his family. It was a night I will not soon forget.

Magnificent Palace Blending Family History, Music & Art. We were fortunate to have a private, behind the scenes tour of this exquisite palace as it is slowly being restored to its original beauty and displaying amazing family portraits, handwritten manuscripts of Handel's Messiah reworked by Mozart and several of Beethoven's symphonies. In addition, there is a huge Canaletto depicting the River Thames as well as Brueghel the elder's Haymaking, a stunning example of Dutch Renaissance art. We were part of a tour group that met a charming, articulate member of the present Lobkowicz family who has been working for two decades to restore and display the exquisite past of the only privately owned palace in the Prague Castle complex. A truly emotional and enjoyable experience.

Fascinating history lesson made personal. The museum is introduced with an audio guide narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family, making the history lessons much more "real". The museum has some real treasures - original copies of musical scores by Handel and Beethoven, beautiful paintings and art objects, and a fascinating personal story of the Lobkowicz family's loss and recovery. The restoration of the palace is nearly complete - a major undertaking.
worth a visit. it's not on all Must see lists as charles bridge & Prague castlebut his was certainly nioce to see with our guided tour

Charming. Set in the castle grounds this is a collection of pictures and artefacts belonging to the Lobkowicz family. Interesting history to be listened to as you walk around about the families fortunes & misfortunes. Rushed through it a bit as it was late in the day so probably didn't get the full value & the entrance fee is expensive. Wanted to come as read reviews a about the afternoon concerts which we missed. Did see the room in which they are held however, which was lovely & can imagine is a perfect setting to hear chamber music/quartets. Highly decorated panels and ceilings etc. Interesting place but expensive.

The history of Prague made accessible through the story of this amazing family. Brilliantly curated, the audio guide was simply wonderful. A lot of the Czech history I'd taken in from reading and other museums finally 'clicked' when it came in the form of the telling of this amazing family history. My only disappointment was the finsl two rooms were closed for renovation. The cafe is marvelous too. Great food and views. Thoroughly recommended.

great history. This is worth the price of admission (small) just to learn the history of the family and their quest to recapture their lost property and restore it in order to share with all people. Made me want to learn more about this long and consuming, not to mention EXPENSIVE, quest.

A gem of a museum. Go.. From the moment you enter this beautifully managed museum it is apparent that great care has been given to its design and curation. The audio narrative (do not skimp on this) by a scion of the family and his parents is superb and the objects on each floor are so artfully arranged you will be captivated. We were privileged to attend a wonderful viola and piano concert that was also first rate.

well worth a separate visit. The 'modern' Lobkowitz family, who run this, have set it up as one of the most interesting and worthwhile tourist things to do in Prague. When you get sick of the crowds around the Castle and the Old Town (and you probably will, no matter how good both are to see) - then it's worth the separate entrance fee to visit here. Beautiful restoration, and one of the best and most engaging audio guides ever - comes as part of the admission.

Charming. Lobkowicz Palace is a fascinating family heirloom which holds the history and the treasures of the Lobkowicz family whose history is tied up with the history of Prague. A fascinating visit, and while slightly on the pricer end, is quite worth it to see the art, the masterpieces and original copies of Bethoven's work. A few hours are necessary to truly appreciate all the history the house holds.

Nice to see. A very interesting place to visit full of history, do not miss it, which is in prague castle complex. Nice freschoes and architecture, staff willing to answer questions, and provide good information. In the courtyard one finds and nice coffee shop , which hass clean restrooms.
Wonderful setting. Had a great tour of the palace and a delightful lunch in the families private quarters. Fascinating history about the family. Were given a special chamber music concert also.

History brought to life. I can't recommend following the audio books enough. It really brings history to life.
I won't rehash the comments already here, but just add that seeing Mozart's own handwritten arrangement of Handel's Messiah, and Beethoven's 3rd, 4th & 5th (yes 5th!) in person is worth the price of admission alone for any music lover.

Our Favorite Museum. We went here on a recommendation of a friend who had been to Prague. This family museum was a highlight of our trip. The artifacts come to life as narrated by William Lobkowicz. He takes you though the history of his family dating back several hundred years. The music and art with his narration tells a wonderful story and brings life to what you will see. I highly recommended this !

Old world grandeur. We took a tour of this Palace and were amazed at the elegance and beauty of this palace. It is worth seeing if you have the time. We also enjoyed a lovely lunch at the palace and were treated to a piano and viola concert.

Fascinating Museum and Story. We were fortunate enough to be at Lobkowicz Palace on a night that William Lobkowicz himself could give us a lecture! This was an unexpected pleasure for us. As an art and music lover, I was looking forward to the experience, but hadn't really researched the backstory of the family or the place. The palace is lovely, the art treasures are very interesting, but the real reason to go is to hear about the history of the family and Mr. Lobkowicz's efforts to reclaim and restore the estate and collections after their confiscation by the Communist government. The story is available on the audio guide- the palace also has some excellent books in their gift shop. A must see!

Great museum!. I went to this museum in doubt. I had spent less money to see the whole castle therefore though that maybe the entry fee here was a bit expensive.Couldn't be more wrong. This is the museum to visit in Prague.Yes, the entire castle complex is interesting but it shows little in comparison with this one (except maybe the Picture Gallery in the Castle).You receive an audio guide that will explain the history of the family and the history of some important pieces. This place is amazing. You get to see really rare stuff like music manuscripts from Mozart and Beethoven (not even in Wien you see this because the originals are here).The audio guide is entirely from the point of view of the family (don't know if the voice in EN is really from the family but in CZ it is). Very interesting.

Museum With A Fascinating History. In preparation for our recent trip to Prague, we listened to an interesting Rick Steves free podcast in which he interviews William Lobkowicz about the history of his family and the creation of this palace museum (titled "American Nobleman in Prague"). It led us to visit the museum, and we really enjoyed it. The audio guide provided to every visitor, also narrated by William Lobkowicz and his family, gives a real personal touch to the exhibits. For example, in addition to portraits of many Lobkowicz ancestors, there are two wonderful paintings of 18th century London by Canaletto, that were acquired by a young Lobkowicz prince when he was there at that time. I was particularly fascinated by the story of the original musical scores for several Beethoven symphonies that had been dedicated by Beethoven to a Lobkowicz ancestor who was his patron. I found that these and similar histories brought to life many of the paintings and objects in a way that you do not find in most museums. The palace also has a very nice terrace cafe with a great view over the city. At 1:00 every day there is a musical concert, for a separate admission fee, that is held in one of the palace's halls.

History at it's best.. With only one day to spend in the city, we opted to take this tour. You are provided with an audio headset and are able to see the history of this family and the country. Well worth the time and money spent.

Fun visit. Liked this the most out of all the palace area grounds. The audioguide is included and really fills the experience. FYI you can buy a combined short trip for the other palace grounds and ticket for here at a lower price than buying them separately.

A castle with a point of view. Wonderful museum of family history. Well laid out with an absolutely masterful audio tour by the current Prince Lobkowicz.We were so impressed that we went to see another Lobkowicz palace about a half-hour train ride outside Prague.

Exclusive lunch in a unique setting. Attended an association lunch at the Palace. The environment is special - can not be compared with many other places; the history and the amazing view from the terrace while being served by white glowed waiters is surely special. The food was elegantly presented and taste was not far behind.

Top of my visit list. A thoughtful look into the Lobkowicz family over the centuries, narrated by the Prince himself you will get a look into the history of one of the powerful and rich families in the Czech Republic.
I loved the palace and every room in it. I am really glad I did not miss this one. 9/10 easily

Lobkowicz Palace - Meet the Prince for lunch. A wonderful visit for lunch. The prince has just returned from a wedding, but took the time to visit with us and tell the story of his family's exile to the US, and the efforts they've made to recover their heritage after the fall of the Berlin Wall and the USSR.

What a family story. Once upon a time....So their family story starts with hundreds of years of service to the Czech rulers and wealthy estates until 20th Century history tests their true metal. The art work, collections, the palace all bring life to what might have been just another group of portraits and large rooms.
A wonderful afternoon. Had a lovely lunch and "private" concert as part of a tour of Palace. A lovely place. Worth the extra cost

Traditional building at the heart of Prague. Traditional building at the Prague Castle complex. Very good condition inside building plunge yours into the historical atmosphere. Museum of Lobkowicz family. Interesting list of activities: Hradozamecka noc, Detske zamecke slavnosti, Vinobrani (young wine festival lake Bojole arive).
Reccomend for family and romantic visites.
You can buy ticket to palace online and save 10%
http://eshop.lobkowicz.cz/cs/vstupenky/

Just Spectacular!. The Palace and the surrounding area in Prague is a really amazing place to visit: you have the feeling of getting into a time machine! The palace is well maintained and reasonably signposted. Make sure that you visit this area in the morning when you are still fresh, there is a lot of walking involved! Be prepared for numerous pictures!

MUST SEE. Fantastic audioguide, this was one of two museums that we visited in Prague and felt like it was a perfect overview of history, art, life, etc. A must see in the Prague Castle area - hardly anyone there so it was great to escape the crowds a bit. Ate lunch outside on the terrace overlooking the city (defo get a table outside) which was a bit overpriced compared to the cheap deals that we found in the rest of the city, but we paid for the atmosphere and it still wasn't 'expensive' compared to home at all.

Worth the time. If you want a sense of the history of Prague and one of its noble famiies, this is a wonderful place to go. We saw the noon concert (piano and viola, both excellent musicians) and then took the audio tour. The tour was full of interesting information and sights, narrated by a member of the family. It's the best audio tour I've ever taken. If you are a music lover, you will delight to an original manuscript of Beethoven's 3rd, sponsored by a member of the Lobkowicz family and an arrangement of Handel's Messiah by Mozart. The building is beautiful and filled with beautiful objects. Make sure to have lunch at the cafe on the terrace. Affordable, with beautiful views over the city. You get a discount when you buy the tickets for the concert.
Palace. The place was full of history and very breathtaking, We attended a concert and luncheon which was wonderful
Beautiful. This palace is one of the most beautiful I have seen and its grounds are almost like a little village

Mostly Paintings. I was a little disappointed and glad I did it while I was already on the grounds of Prague Castle as opposed to doing it as a secondary tour the next day. $10 admission but lots of paintings, a gallery of weapons, another of musical instruments, and another of china. I had been expecting furnished rooms but the audio tour did a nice job of explaining each gallery.

Fascinating. We were travelling with the masses in August and found this gem. The Audio tour was fascinating, and we had the place to ourselves (bargain). Its a wonderful story, and well laid out. You are in for a treat. We went to the restaurant afterwards, the food and views were excellent.

Make sure you use the free audio guide!. The free audio guide narrated by various members of the Lobkowicz family is what makes this place so special as you get a moving personal account of the history of the palace, the Lobkowicz family and the collection of rare items (including original scores by Mozart and Beethoven and paintings by famous artists such as Pieter Bruegel the Elder and Canaletto) on display. The audio guide is very easy to use, features beautiful background music and the most important display items are highlighted so you can skip to the most interesting bits of the collection if you are short on time (however, I would recommend listening through all of it). I even saw William Lobkowicz himself on my way out!I visited in the second half of the afternoon and the palace was almost empty - great if you want to escape the crowds for a bit! The café is also a good place to stop for lunch or an afternoon meal and serves delicious food (you get 10% off with your ticket).
Excellent recital. Didn't actually go in the Palace itself but went to an hour long piano and viola recital which was excellent. The room it was held in was beautiful with ceiling paintings.
Exquisite palace and monestry. Exquisite palace. +- 200 steps to ascend, but beatiful views and exquisite monestry. Beautiful city views and well worth a visit.

What a great sunday. We started with the performance. The concert was really great! Then we had a tour of the Palace. What a fascinating history! Having several members of the family, explaining their history was really nice. It was outstanding to see original work from Beethoven and Mozart. We had lunch in the café (very good). Unfortunately it was raining so we did not have the possibility to be seated on the terrace. My only remark is the display of the numbers in each room. Sometimes it's not clearly indicated and not very obvious to find. Besides this, everything was perfect !

Most interesting thing to do at the Castle!. This private collection of paintings, original manuscripts of 4th and 5th Beethoven's symphonies, dishes and weapons drives you through Czech history , and with help of a perfect and intelligent audioguide, you learn the incredible history of family Lobkowitz, who run Czech power for centuries , received enormous properties on exchange of their contribute to the Empire, and then lost everything first by the Nazist and after by the Communist, and then got a great part back. We think it has been the most impressive and interesting we have done a the Castle. Even my daughter, 12 years old, has been really impressed.

what a great place. This was one of the best museums we've ever visited. The audio guide was so worthwhile. What a family; what an amazing history. There were Mozart scores because an ancestor was his patron. This is just one of the exhibits, there's so much more. The restaurant was delicious, on a terrace that overlooked the city. Even the gift shop had the most beautiful selection. I highly recommend this highlight of our trip.
Interesting. Nice palace to visit inside the Prague castle area. They also have a cafe with a view. Hear the owners describe life before and after communism.

A Hidden Gem. Our friends were running late and we wanted to escape the hoards of tourists in the area so we ducked inside. Amazing. What a collection! What a story! Once you see the original Beethoven, Haydn and Mozart manuscripts, you will never feel the same about classical music. DO NOT SKIP the audio guide. It was excellent - narrated by the grandson of the owner who fled Nazi oppression and died in exile.

We had dinner here.. This Lobkowicz Family had their properties returned to them in the 90's & are working to restore them. There is a very steep walk up to this palace & the cobblestones don't help. Once there,it is well worth looking around !

Beautiful palace filled with culture and history. We went to the afternoon classical music concert and also purchased the ticket to visit the museum with an audio guide. We learned about the journey this aristocratic family has been taking since the fall of communism, saw beautiful pieces of art, musical instruments, etc.

Impressive story and great audio guide.. To keep it short. I was impressed about the story and their collection. Also on the side note, it is always a pleasure when people can use their voice in a noble manner.Somebody said that take the audio guide, but they give it without asking and is included in the price, since at least i think that without the audio guide the experience would be missing 95% of it's charm.

Was hoping to tour a palace. I know that this said it was a museum but I was hoping to see more living quarters and not just empty rooms with a bunch of paintings. We had a lovely lunch that was very delicious - the only problem was there was no AC or enough fans and we were sweating pretty bad. My poor Grandma kept falling asleep during the musical performance because it was SO incredibly hot in the room. And she loves musical performances. I felt bad for the musicians. They were wonderful and it was a great performance. The views from the balcony of Prague were great as well. The museum was pretty good - Amazing to see original work from Beethoven, Haydn and Mozart. That was the highlight to me. It was hard to enjoy other parts because it was just so hot. I'm sure we would have taken more time to look at the exhibits if it was cooler. I'd go back if I had more time to learn more about Czech history - I think we were overloaded with facts and information and it was hard to keep it straight. Highlights again were lunch, musical performance, balcony view and Beethoven's 5th.
wow. beautiful elegant palace museum. The restaurant serves fabulous food. We ate outside on the veranda overlooking the Charles Bridge and the roof tops of the city. It was beautiful.

Must See. Nothing really makes it stand out from the other touristy attractions. It is not publicized as the Praha Castle, or the cathedrals and Sinagogues, but this castle has the most amazing collection outside a museum I have ever seen. The music collection is particularly impressive with very antique instruments and music sheets by beethoven and Mozart. The gun, armor suits and china collections are also very interesting.
Inspirational personal story. We stumbled upon this gem in our visit to Prague. Take the audio guide which relates a family story linked with historical events.

A real treat. We loved this. The museum is small but full of little gems and stepped in the history of Prague and the Lobkowicz family. Make sure you use the audio guide when going around the exhibits

Great personal story. The audio tour by William Lobkowicz makes this showing special. It is always more moving to have a personal connection with works of art and historical artifacts and William brings that in a personal relatable story. One of the highlights of our trip.

Make this one of your many stops. Beautiful place, interesting and a very perfect place to relax by watching and listening to their great violinist and pianist, try the cafe next to the museum and enjoy the galleries.
Best views. We had lunch at the restaurant at Lobkowicz Palace. The views from the terrace is the best from the castle unless you climb up the South tower of St Vitus. Food was also good.
Lovely art collection. Such a lovely art collection with a interesting story ot the Lobkowicz family. Nice restaurant in the yeard and nice concerts.

Very nice afternoon concert. We booked this separately from our River tour group because we didn't realize it would be offered by them as an optional tour. In the long run we were glad we did as the price to book the Palace/Museum/Concert on Lobkowicz website was far less than what the optional tour would have cost. We would recommend it !
A must. An absolute must when you visit Prague. The museum is fantastic with originals from Beethoven., a great collection of paintings and - if you like, old weapons.
Palace Tour with Lunch. Interesting tour, good lunch. Tour guide very helpful answering information about the Palace and the city of Prague. Worth the price and effort.

Beautiful view of Prague and great food!. My family and I stopped by here on our way up to see the huge gothic looking Cathedral. This place is a little bit hidden and to get to the restaurant, you have to enter an outside cafe area and go around. But this place is amazing!! The food here is delicious. They even have vegetarian options. I ordered the chicken Ceasar salad and my brother got the Veggie Burger and my cousin got the tuna melt. Everything was to die for.

Don't miss!. This is a privately owned family Palace in Prague Castle. I found it really cool how it is able to tell the history of the country through the story of a single prominent family. The audio tour was more interesting than they typically are and is by a family member. The palace has a nice collection of paintings, decorative objects (china), armor, musical instruments, and even original manuscripts by Bethoven! If you like historical house museums this is like doing one on a grand scale.

Extraordinary Collection. We found this a peaceful respite in Prague. Perhaps because it costs a bit more, it was not crowded on a hot day when Prag seemed jammed with tourists. The history of the family who own it is astonishing, as is the collection they offer to the public. The audio guide was excellent. It was perfect to arrive at 11, spend two hours in the galleries, and then sit down for an hour in the lovely small concert hall to hear the very pleasant selection of music performed by a very good pianist and violinist. Then, we went outside for our usual picnic lunch, and returned to finish the galleries. We found the room with musical instruments fascinating. Everyone on staff was helpful and friendly. We didn't go into the cafe attached to the museum, but another museum right next door has an espresso cafe with the best coffee we found in Prague.

Great museum. Really enjoyed this museum although a little pricey at 275 per adult. Very good narrator via a head set. Musical area the best. Amazing views across Prague. Missed the concert unfortunately, so head there for noon! Well worth a visit.

It's a Nice Muesum, not a must see though. This review (rating) is tough, because I really love to support museums and this one is a nice change of pace from the rest of the Castle district, but I gave it an average because of the Price. I am sorry, but $15 per person is a lot for the size and exhibits in the museum. To put it in perspective the short tour of the entire Castle District which included the Old Castle, Cathedral, Golden Lane, etc. only costs $13 The price did include an audio guide, and there were some nice portraits, as well as some hidden Gems (like a copy of Handel's messiah edited with composition notes by Mozart), but still I felt overcharged. Overall I would say- Go to this Museum if your time and Budget permit.
Beautiful piece of History. Get an earlier start to see the Palace and be the first if possible to avoid the crowds. It is a visual experience.

Personalized Tour. My family and I attended a Lobkowicz Palace concert (piano and viola) to enjoy Mozart, Dvorak, Beethoven and Smetana in a small setting. While the concert was enjoyable the audio tour of the Palace was delightful. A family descendent who emigrated from the US back to the Czech Republic narrates the tour and in doing so personalizes it and helps connect historic events and persons to the listener. Our daughter left with a desire to learn more about the Hapsburg family and their impact on the region. (This from someone who is not terribly interested in history!)

Not to be missed!!!. By far the no. 1 highlight of our (second) visit to Prague, this exquisite collection of paintings, musical instruments, old weapons, furniture, china and more, accompanied by informative audioguide with a personal touch, is an absolute must! Whether you are an art lover, history fan, music conoisseur or just fond of any aspect of European culture, a visit to this wonderful collection, tastefully displayed in its impressive original setting, is a treat you don't want to miss.

Don't skip it if you go to the Castle. Really interesting audio tour of an unbelievable family "home". ps the noon concert was mediocre, very light Czech classical selections played by a pianist who may have been too hot and she certainly played too loud and too fast (the violist was really very good).

Don't miss this gem. We almost missed this lovely Palace, owned by the Lobkowicz family, taken from them by the communist regime, and returned to them in the 1990s. The grandson Lobkowicz narrates the tour on the audio guide and the rooms and views are spectacular.

Definitely worth the visit. One of the best palaces visits in Prague. The free audio guide for this visit has one of the best commentaries of any visit in Prague. The current owners/descendants describe the history in a personally engaging way as well as being informative about various aspects of history. The staff are friendly (very unusual in Prague!!) and the cafe has excellent views over Prague & Charles bridge and food is very nice too. We didn't do the 1pm concert but heard it through the open windows and it sounded lovely. The shop has high quality items (also somewhat unusual in Prague tourist sites!!). The Palace is located close to the exit gate of the Prague castle (can be accessed from this entrance/exit without ticket to castle, etc)

Absolutely worth a visit. Sure, Old Town Square and the Prague Castle complex top the "can't miss" list in Prague. I would seriously consider adding Lobkowicz Palace to that list. It was my favorite Prague attraction.Classic music fans may recognized the Lobkowicz name as that of the patron of not only Beethoven, but also (at times) Mozart and Handel. On top of seeing original symphonic scores in Mozart's and Beethovens' own hands, the museum is an incredibly interesting look at the history of a Czech aristocratic family. The family had their possessions stripped away twice - once by the Nazis and once by the Communists - only to be returned to them two generations later. The museum is eclectic housing paintings, china, a variety of martial arms, musical instruments, and other accoutrements of Czech noble life. A free audio tour is included with admission, and is incredibly informative and at times quite funny.
Beautiful. Be sure to have lunch overlooking the rivers. Try the local wine, it's delicious. The little town square is cute too.

Fascinating way to learn some Czech history. We went in on impulse and were so glad we did. An amazing, diverse collection, with some impressive art, astonishing musical scores (Beethoven, e.g.), and a real glimpse into Czech history. The audio tour is really good. Highly recommended.

Under-recognized gem of a museum. Alot of tourists don't realize the fascinating story of the Lobkowicz family and their art collection and castles. There is a first rate free audio guide with the admission actually narrated by the present Lobkowicz in an entertaining manner covering the key art and ceramic collections in the museum. We highly recommend also attending the daily 1 pm music performance performed in a beautiful room in the museum. Its a one hour show of classical music and well worth it. Combine this museum with a visit to the cathedral and castle and you have a whole day of sightseeing!

Worth the visit!. We took the tour of Lobkowicz Palace and saw a classical music concert there. We would highly recommend seeing this as not only was the Lobkowicz Palace and museum very interesting but the audio tour was one of the best we’ve ever heard. It is narrated by a member of the Lobkowicz family and was very entertaining and interesting. I had never heard of this family or palace before but we were pleasantly surprised. We enjoyed seeing all the musical instruments and especially the seeing the music sheets signed by Beethoven. Well worth a visit!

A very nice Palace. There aren't many palace left in Europe. But since you are here, you must visit them. Firstly make sure you get the Tourist pass which you can buy from the tourist centre. It allows you to visit quite a lot of museum. The Palace is rather modern compared to a lot of other palace in Europe. There is a tour in spanish, italian and English. I joined the English one and they will tell you the history of the Palace.

Enlightening. How many non Czechs have ever even heard of this amazing family? The art, property, family history are all fantastic. Our group had a decent goulash lunch thru our self guided Viking tour and it can be done in anywhere from 45 minutes to two hours depending on how deeply you want to immerse yourself.

Learn some history. Even we found the entrance ticket expensive, it was well spent money. The audio guide is included and you get a 10% discount at the cafeteria. We learn about the history of the family and also the history of Prague and some operas. It was really interesting. The collections are also very nice.

Worth the steep admission. This place has a steep admission fee, but it's well worth it- it was easily one of the highlights of my stay in Prague. The artwork and artifacts are decent, but I enjoyed most the audio tour, narrated by William Lobkowicz, that runs through his family history and gives a personal touch to everything you see. It's fun, friendly, and very well done. It's got portraits, porcelain, original musical scores (and instruments), scenery paintings, watercolor-and-feather bird paintings, dog portraits, etc.The full audio tour is 90 minutes, but the "greatest hits" is less than 30, and of course you can stay and linger to look at things and read signs. I was in a rush and had to be out in less than 60 minutes, which was very doable (especially since 2 rooms were closed for a concert), but I would have loved to stay longer.

A "must" for visitors to Prague!. I have visited the Lobkowicz Palace more than once -- it merits a return visit if possible! The palace itself is elegant, the collections are amazing and the tour is very useful.

Nice surprise concert museum and cafe. Came here for the concert which was excellent included in the price was the audio tour of the museum. If you enjoy classical music and its history this is a little gem not only explaining the connections of the family to composers but what they had funded. A good selection of prague history without being to heavy. Finally finish off with a very reasonably priced and good quality meal at the terrace cafe with stunning views over prague.

Best we ever attended. This audio tour was the best we ever took. It gave a history of the city, told how everything was lost after WWII, regained, lost to the Communists, and finally regained. There were rooms for arms, dogs, original music manuscripts by Mozart, Beethoven, Handel etc. The narration was fantastic.

Not worth the entry fee. Quite ordinary for the fee. This is a private palace that mostly has portraits of the owners ancestors, and even their dogs! Only highlight are 2 music notes of beethoven and mozart. Overall - avoid.

Off the beaten path history of a Czech noble family. This palace is located within the Prague castle which requires a separate ticket. It was very interesting how the Lobkowicz family can trace their roots back to the 14th century. you learn about their history and how their artifacts got taken away twice! By the Nazis and the communists. They are still at work trying to restore many paintings. They were even patrons of Beethoven and Mozart!

A Gem of a Museum. We visited this museum on the recommendation of a friend who had just been to Prague. We are so glad we did! This museum is a must see! The Lobkowicz family has remarkably preserved so much histoy in this museum, now housed in one of their palaces. Not to be missed. Be sure to add it to your Prague Castle visit. We also enjoyed the concert. It is peformed daily and does require an addtional ticket...well worth it!

An Amazing Experience. This was our second trip to Prague, and both times we found the visit to the Lobkowicz Palace fascinating! I was worried that I had seen everything the first time, but the Chamber Music concert was new to me (check in advance to find out the timing--it is a unique experience to hear that music in the traditional setting of a private reception room). The art remains extraordinary--the highlight of the castle visit!

A Must See Museum in Prague. Have been really looking forward to visiting this place. We had a marvelous time visiting the Lobkowicz Palace! The history spans 700 years back, so everyone will find something interesting see, we in particular loved the Music Room and Beethoven manuscripts. Afterwards we enjoyed a very nice lunch in the courtyard. Will definitely come back next time we are in Prague.
Exelent. One of the most interesting exhibition places in Prague. I also enjoy the restaurant with the Lobkowicz delicious wine.
Take to tour and learn about it!. It is amazing how a place can look way much better if you take a tour with a great guide. I'd recommend it strongly to anyone that likes CR culture.

Interesting to specialist. The art collection is mediocre but for those who love music, the scores in Mozart's and Beethoven's handwriting (plus the dedications of Beethoven's 3rd and 5th symphonies to family members) is a memorable experience
Grand palace. Excellent display of a family's heritage throughout the use of artwork and story. A must see if you are going to Prague castle.

Some interesting pieces. Worthwhile visit if in the Castle area and you have seen most that has to offer there and you are looking for more to do. Yes it is he story of one family but arnt many museums or castles the same! Not as extensive as most but a few interesting pieces. A little self promoting in the audio tape. Approx $12 - 15 for entry including audio.
Bad. What a disappointment and waste of time and $20 US.This is a love story to their family and very boring!Don't waste your time

Disappointing Palace. I was very excited about visiting this palace, but in the end I was disappointed. The value was not good for the money. It was about $15 and I just don't think it was worth it based on the items on display. There are so many things to see in Prague, if limited on time, best to skip this one.Front desk woman was very friendly though.

Wonderful Palace, Museum and View of Prague. We visited this attraction as part of a Viking Cruise tour. We were provided lunch, talk and sell guided tour of the palace. All of these elements were very enjoyable, informative and enlightening. The view of Prague from their balcony was worth the price of this tour alone.

Another great carrot cake experience. The Lobkowitz palace is our favourite place in Prague. We take all our visitors there. First a walk through the museum which is not to be missed when you visit Prague and then a stop at the cafe on the balcony of the Palace overlooking Prague. The view is fantastic and the food fabulous. I had the soup and half a sandwich and stole a piece of my wife's carrot cake. To die for! Go, you won't regret it. Oh, then go for a walk down through the castle gardens. Very few tourists find this treat. Walk off a bit of the carrot cake :)

Fascinating Palace Museum. Beautiful views of the city of Prague, once you walk into the castle premises. The museum has great collections overall. Worthy of mention some original Beethoven and Mozart music scores. There is a restaurant inside the Palace, where they serve very tasty food and cold beer, however expensive. Perfect place for a break in busy Prague. They offer a guided visit that is very interested, I enjoyed it a lot. Really a very nice place to visit and priceless views of the city. Don't give it a miss!
Extraordinary. We stopped here on our second day in Prague, and then came back the following day. Beautiful collection and a very good commentary in English.
not too good. It('s one of the many historical buildings, Prague has about 100.000 of them. Don't botter about the artworks there.

Did the short tour. We did the short tour and that was enough. It got us into the places we wanted to see and the value was there. We had lunch at the cafe that is just on your right hand side when ou come out of golden lane. We sat on the patio and the view was great The food was very good, the goulash delicious. We also had the prosciutto panini and it was very good. We happened to be sitting at the table beside the owner of the palace and his family so that was a surprise.
We were inspired by the Lobkowicz Family history.. We enjoyed seeing the original manuscript for Beethoven's 5th symphony and Mozart's handwritten annotations on Handel's Messiah. We were in awe.

Nice privately owned castle.. We visited the Lobkowicz Palace on Tuesday, December 18th, 2012. It requires a separate ticket from the Prague Castle Tour. Definitely plan on having lunch here. Not only is having lunch here convenient because you don't have to leave the castle complex, it was delicious. We had the goulash and it was yummy. We also attended the classical music concert at 1 pm. The concert was so relaxing and a nice break in our day. The castle itself was a really cool experience. I especially enjoyed the gun room. The gift shop is also a worthy stop -- they have their own brand of those delicious Czech wafers.

A wealth of history. This palace contains a wealth of history and fascinating artworks and other historical items. Restored by the current descendants of the Lobcowitz family, the palace is beautiful and houses some truly interesting items. The highlight for us was the music section which included an original manuscript by the composer Beethoven as well as one by Mozart. The palace hosts classical music concerts every luncthime, where one can enjoy a musical presention for one hour. One can buy tickets at the Palace on the same day

Really poor. I don't get all the positive reviews about this place. You basically see a lot of portraits of rich people by (mostly) unknown artistis. Meanwhile, a family member narrating the audio guide is actually trying to make the visitor feel sorry for them, since they lost all their assets twice and got it back. There is almost no relevant information about Czech history.So now they are just a wealthy family which owns a lot of property around Prague and charges tourists a high price to see their "dog portraits" (I mean it, there are portraits of the family dogs. Really.)Yes, that is a real survival history, it is really hard to imagine how they are able to survive with only a couple of castles, some paintings and a "museum". I am glad I paid a high price for the entrance ticket, at least now they will be able to buy some food.I am giving two stars instead of one because of the original manuscripts by great composers. But, honestly, it will you take no more than 5 minutes to look at this. Not worth it.

Too much hype for too much money. This collection is ok but the price they charge is ridiculous and i think it is wise to just see the lobby and take some pictures.
You can get your money and times worth in so many other places in Prague.

Surprisingly good. This old palace right next to the castle has a great tour - use the audio guide to hear someone with an American accent describe the history of his family and see the exhibits. I loved seeing the original Beethoven scores - didn't realize this family supported him. Worth an hour to 2 hours to see this.

A must visit when in Prague. The Palace is Beautiful.
The view in entrance very nice.
There are short classical music show that is not bad.
I recommend this place for visit when you are in Prague.
A lovely visit. A fantastic museum, well worth a visit. You can relax on the terrace and enjoy a very nice lunch whilst enjoying spectacular views of the City.

interesting place to learn about czech history. museum of the lobkowicz family. There is a painting by Pieter Breughel the elderly, original notebooks by Von Beethoven, Haydn, Handel and Mozart, 2 paintings of London around 1750 by Canaletto, and a painting by Velazquez of the young girl that is promineent as well on his mot famous painting which is in the Prado now. There is a large collection of family portraits and 17th, 18th and 19th century guns, and of old music instruments. Interesting family history which is interwoven with Czech history. One of the more interesting museums in Prague.

Splendid restoration of a magnificent palace … a real treat!. What a surprise … we loved Lobkowicz Palace! In fact, we enjoyed our visit to Lobkowicz Palace more than any other venue within the castle complex with the exception of St. Vitus Cathedral.Built in the 16th century for the Pernstejn family & acquired & rebuilt (after a fire) in the 17th century by the Lobkowicz family, the excellent audio tour guides you through the fascinating history of the palace and the Lobkowicz family. After losing their properties to both the Nazis and the Communists, the palace was finally returned to the Lobkowicz family in 2002 & was lovingly restored. Don’t miss the magnificent frescoed hall & the 17th century chapel (dedicated to St. Wenceslas) as well as the collection of guns & rare musical instruments.Among the items I found most interesting in the Lobkowizc collection are two magnificent paintings of London by Canaletto, the Hay Harvest by Pieter Bruegel the Elder (one of only 5 remaining landscapes of the “months” cycle), the original manuscript of Beethoven’s Eroica Symphony (dedicated by Beethoven to Prince Franz Joseph Maximilian Lobkowicz) as well as manuscripts of Beethoven’s 4th & 5th symphonies, the original manuscript of Mozart’s re-orchestration of Handel’s Messiah, and the beautiful porcelain displays.The café offers gorgeous panoramic views overlooking Prague and afternoon concerts (held daily at 1:00 pm) are held in the magnificently restored Concert Hall.All in all, a winner!!Note: You do NOT have to purchase Prague Castle tickets to visit Lobkowicz Palace.You can purchase Palace concerts tickets (340 – 440 czk) at the following site:http://www.prague-castle-concert.cz/en/book-now/date-and-seats-selection/Location: Jiřská 3 - Located at the eastern gate of the Prague Castle complex.Tram 22 to Pražský hrad or Metro A to Malostranská & walk up the castle steps.Open: 10:00 am to 6:00 pmAdmission: Adults: 275 CZK /Seniors: 200 CZK (audio guide included in price of admission)Concert Admission: Dependent on seat selection, 340 – 440 czk. Book at the following site:http://www.prague-castle-concert.cz/en/book-now/date-and-seats-selection/Palace Website: http://www.lobkowicz.cz/en/Lobkowicz-Palace-9.htm

Pleasant surprise. We only went to Lobkowicz Palace because it was really rainy, but ended up enjoying the experience. I'm not generally a big fan of museums, but I liked this one because of the audiobook. The audiobook was narrated by William Lobkowicz which made it very personal and a lot more interesting than if it had been narrated by anyone else. We also saw William Lobkowicz outside the cafe!

Interesting - Don't Miss the Concert. Nice break from the turmoil of visiting tourist sites around the cathedral and the castle. Interesting family with a nice display of Czech heritage. Don't miss the concert in the small ballroom. We have a pianist and viol the day we were there - very nice. There is a pleasant cafe in the palace but it is expensive.
Amazing history. walk through with the audio tour. Amazing real history and we met the current (prince) though titles were abolished long ago.

A hidden gem.... I came upon this palace while researching for our trip to Prague and what a find! We did the obligatory tour of the castle and church and then went to the Lobkowicz Palace. We attended the noon recital followed by lunch and both were a welcome treat. It was fun seeing the palace and learning about the family. The audio was excellent and it was not at all crowded so we could take out time and enjoy the experience. I suspect it will become more popular as more people know about it...don't miss it!

Interesting family history shared in a great museum. The interesting audio guide in this historic palace is given in English by the owner of the museum. The contents of the museum are digestible. There are excellent views from the restaurant.

Dinner here with Tauck Tour. Great kickoff to our trip with Tauck on their terrific Blue Danube Riverboat Tour.
Wonderful introduction to the family's reclamation of their 700-year-old heritage following the Nazi and Communist eras.
Luncheon and celebrity encounter included!. 79 euro included an English speaking guide, lunch (beer/wine extra) and a meeting with a Lobkowicz heir. Totally recommended!

Family Insight. Lobkowicz Palace allows for an intimate look into Prague's history from the perspective of the gathering of wealth, its repeated loss and recovery as well as the remarkable influence this had on today's culture.

A great find. We went through the Lobkowicz mainly because the royal apartments in the castle were closed while we were there. We were so glad we did! The terrace in the coffee shop is one of the best places to enjoy an amazing view of Prague while enjoying some great coffee. The collection of art is amazing. The family's history, as told through the collection, is truly fascinating. Well worth the cost of admission.

time well spent. agree with positive reviews - what an interesting story learned when visiting this palace. Expansive family wealth, property taken, and family possessions/property reclaimed. Appreciated audio guide included in the price of admission (voices of curator, prince and his wife - information was clearly articulated). As stated in audio guide artwork is not gallery worthy due to years of exposure but many were still lovely, nonetheless. In addition to artwork - interesting collection of firearms, china, musical instruments, etc. Favorite tour offered among other Prague Castle structures. Enjoyed goulash lunch for two on the café terrace with wine and coffee. pleasant wait staff and what a view!

A Stunning Collection of a Dynasty of Collectors. We discovered the Lobkowicz quite by accident. The entrance is on the road descending from the Royal Palace. The Lobkowicz princes, all nobles loyal to the king of Bohemia, loved to travel, entertain, and collect treasures. Whether you are interested in weapons, musical instruments and manuscripts, art, china, tapestries, interior design, the Palace has it all. Where else could you see Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts in one room and three original Canelettos of London in the next room. There is also an excellent Cafe with great views of Prague at the end of your tour.

disappointing in view of all the publicity it gets.... The museum has a lot of family memorabilia (portraits etc. but also ceramics) and about 3 or 4 remarkable paintings by renowned artists (Cranach, Breughel etc.). I was a little disappointed because there is so much hype about this museum and not much inside. The museum doesn't compare, for example, with the Czartoryski in Cracow. The view from the Lobkowicz Cafe is NOT the best view of Prague, this is what your American guidebook will be telling you but please ignore.

Best part of the castle!. This place not only has an amazing story behind its restitution, but a fabulous cafe (delicious carrot cake!) and a beautiful piano/violin concert. Be sure to put this at the top of your list of things to do in Prague!

First time I enjoyed an audio tour. Normally I wouldn't go for an audio tour in a museum, but this time I really enjoyed it. The prince and his family are doing a great job telling the story of their family and providing an extra dimension to the things you see. Highly recommended (also has a great, slight expensive palace cafe).

Better than the Prague Castle. The audio tour by Mr. Lobkowicz made this museum so awesome. Even my daughter who isn't big on museums, found his stories and his way of speaking very interesting. To see how his family was instrumental in the life of Beethoven was a highlight of this tour.

An exciting afternoon concert.. I cannot comment on the Palace generally but we bought tickets for the daily concert of piano and violin, which was very enjoyable and well worth the effort of climbing up to the Castle. Between 20 to 30 people attended the concert, which was held in a very pleasant drawing room.We could have bought an inclusive ticket for the concert and to visit the palace but chose not to.

Skip Prague Castle, come here instead. Nestled in the Prague Castle complex is the private Lobkowicz Palace, owned and operated by the Lobkowicz family. I was particularly disappointed with Prague Castle, and would recommend the Lobkowicz Palace instead. (You don't need to pay admission to the Prague Castle to get to Lobkowicz Palace.)Rick Steves has a great interview with the Lobkowicz hier about what it is like to run a museum of what was once your family's home. Listen to it and then see it for yourself.

Not to be Missed when Visiting the Castle Area. As others have stated before the audioguide that is included with the tour is what really sets this attraction apart from a great museum to an excellent museum. Some of the highlights that I enjoyed seeing were the different guns in the armory to the marked up compositions from many famous composers.The only draw back was that for some reason they don't let you take photographs. Not sure why, but I was disappointed that I wasn't able to capture memories of this part of my trip.

So So Attraction. It's interesting to learn the history of this family and how they lost their property twice in history. The day we were there the museum closed early for a private event, and we were rushed through. The cafe was only mediocre though many gave it high reviews.

An Afternoon in an Amazing Palace. We toured the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague as part of an extension from our Viking River Cruise. What an amazing afternoon. We started with lunch in the palace, had a visit with William Lobkowicz, enjoyed a short classical concert, and toured the museum with a very helpful audio guide. What an array of priceless paintings and items including original scores by Mozart and Beethoven. I recommend this tour absolutely!!
Nothing much to see!. Very disappointed with this building, nothing much in it reminded me of a deserted hall. Best thing is the view from an outside balcony.

Great Castle Tour. Very interesting collection and really nice to see the restoration work done in the rooms for public viewing. The audio guide is also well done, interesting, and very informative about the family and the property.

Great audio guide. Nice museum inside the castle complex! Besides its main painting ( the little girl holding her dress) there are several other great art works. The audio guide was very very informative and gave a background to the entire castle complex and Prague!

Once in a lifetime experience. The Lobkowicz Palace is a must see in Prague. The story behind the families reclamation of their assets after the Velvet Revolution reads like a fiction novel but it's all true! The art work is beautiful but there are two treats that are even more spectacular. The cafe has the best view in Prague and the food is excellent and well priced. The service is fantastic and definitely try the Lobkowicz beer and wine. Following lunch we went to the concert in the palace which was so intimate, amazing and a one of a kind experience. After the concert we returned to the great cafe for dessert and drinks and were lucky enough to meet the charming and affable Mr Lobkowicz himself. The Lobkowicz is definitely number one on my list for sights and experiences in Prague , which is saying a lot because Prague is full of great places!

music lovers not to miss. In a beautiful castle setting is this amazing small museum with a unique sell displayed original full orchestra score of Beethoven's Eroica. If you go, you must take the audio tour. And, if you're lucky, you will meet Prince William Lobkowitz. A molst charming and gracious host. They also offer brief, but wonderful chamber concerts. The history of the Lobkowitz family is also very interesting.

Family Treasures Twice Recovered. We enjoyed an afternoon at The Lobkowitz Palace as an optional VIking River Cruise excursion. We enjoyed a delicious lunch of Czech Goulash in a private salon, followed by a brief chamber concert, extrememly well performed. We were then surprised to be greeted by Prince Lobkowitz himself, who explained to our group the history of his families palaces & treasures. The Music collection is breathtaking. Not just the gorgeous instruments, but the original score of Beethoven's Eroica, Mozarts rewriting of Handel's Messiah and more. The audio tour is very well done and narrated by Prince Lobkowitz. They have a full service cafe which looked inviting, and if our goulash was any indication, the food is quite good as well.
Amazing history. Must take the handout audio tour to listen to the family history which was very interesting which personalized all of the artwork on display. Highly recommend visiting this palace

Classical musicians: don't miss. Outstanding music room. I wasn't interested in any of the other rooms - only this one. It's the only reason I went to Prague. Original score of Beethoven's Eroica, 6th symphony and Opus 18 (I think) string quartets; Mozart's rewriting of Handel's Messiah. Gobsmacking stuff. I wished we could have donned white gloves and turned some pages. The commentary by the current Prague-residing Mr. Lobkowicz explaining the history of the family's link to Beethoven etc is brilliant. Don't miss it.One of my most favourite mornings in a month of travelling in Europe.
It was ok. Nice place but no WOW factor.Inexpensive & well looked after - liked this.Disliked lack of exhibits of interest.

An Evening I'll never forget.... Our company hosted a Private Gala for us one evening in this Palace. It was amazing! The view from the terrace definitely gave you the immediate feel of royalty. Champagne flowed, the food was wonderful and the service was complete with white gloves! A string quartet played and every room told a story! I can't imagine any better way for our company to show their appreciation for us (17 of us)! It was truly memorable!

Fascinating story - definitely worth a visit. I knew very little about Czech history, and this place was a fascinating insight. Plus the view from around the Prague Castle complex is spectacular. Free audio guide is a bonus :)

Lobkowicz Palace Museum. An excellent repository of art, porcelain, music, firearms, etc, collected over several hundred years. A must see for understanding the history of an area that long suffered under the Nazis and the Communists. William Lobkowicz is putting his family history back together for the benefit of the Czech people. This is where the Thirty Years War (over the Reformation) began in Prague. Have coffee on the terrace of the cafe overlooking Prague and the river.

Interesting Tales to Tell. The Lobkowicz' story of how they got their palace back after the velvet revolution is very interesting well told on the audio guide. There's a lot to see here and worth an hour or two - especially if it happens to be a cold and rainy day . . . ..

Beautiful and moving experience.. There are some wonderful works of art including a Breughel, but especially interesting is the history of the family which lost the palace during the Nazi or Communist era, but then regained it more recently.

Celebrated my birthday at this palace!!!. The story is amazing. The museum is very nicely layed out. The audio guide is very well done. And we were so lucky (our IWAP group - International Women of Prague) to get Prince William to come and tell us the story. He is such a gentle but proud presence for his family. I will definitely add this to my long list of places to take friends and family when they visit me in Prague.

AMAZING!!!!!. We had a GREAT experience here-- enjoyed a wonderful lunch at the cafe, afternoon concert in the palace, and tour of the museum. The staff was wonderful. I would recommend the cheeseburger and carrot cake. Also, the Lobkowicz white wine was delicious! this is a must see!

An amazing story. We had lunch at the palace as part of a Viking River cruise tour. The setting is amazing with views of Prague not to be missed. We had the honor of having William Lobkowicz come and tell us the amazing story of how the family regained possession of the palace and efforts to restore the palace. Seeing original manuscripts of Beethoven symphonies was beyond belief.

A Private public palace. Rarely does a family twice lose its lands and possessions through war and nationalization and have an opportunity to reclaim them. This happened to the Lobkowicz family. Forced to walk away to escape the Nazis, they got their holdings back after WWII only to lose them again to the Communists. When the iron curtain lifted they had a year to catalogue and establish title to what had been confiscated from them. Not only did they do this, but they also opened this palace and another to the public. The ongoing involvement of a princely family sharing their heritage with the public is a gift to the wider community that we appreciated. We enjoyed the audio guide, which was easy to operate, and were absorbed by the anecdotes told by family members. We had lunch at the palace cafe on its terrace overlooking the river after our visit.

Wonderful Experience. We were on a Danube Viking River Cruise and chose Lobkowicz Palace as an optional excursion. It was so enjoyable. We were served a private luncheon by palace staff, a short classical concert and then an audio tour of the fabulous artwork, music, instruments, weapons, etc. William Lobkowicz spoke to us after the concert to explain a bit more about what they are trying to do with these treasures. I don't know if what we did is open to the public but it was absolutely a first class experience.

High class concert around midday. We didn't visit the palace itself. We just went for the concert. Not particularly cheap at £15 per person, but the standard was very high, and was held in a lovely environment. Definitely worth doing.

Awesome. We had a more private experience/tour with Viking Cruise lines. The owners, William Lobkowicz, spoke to us as a group and it felt very comfortable and new even though I'm sure he's given this talk many times. We then had a concert which was just the right amount of time. We enjoyed the tour through the rooms. One of the highlights of our trip!
nice place with good view on Prague. take a coffee on the terrace of the Palace. When you have time enough, take part in a concert at 1.00 p.m.
nice place with good view on Prague. take a coffee on the terrace of the Palace. When you have time enough, take part in a concert at 1.00 p.m.

Boring audio tour - give it a miss. I paid for the audio tour of the palace. The person narrating was someone from the lobkowicz family who never lived at the palace. His voice was droning and there was no humour or any sort of excitement. If you like boring facts abut the history of the family and looking at paintings of the family then by all means do the tour.
THIS IS A MUST. It is a beautiful place, the story is fantastic and the tour very well thought out. Eat at their cafe too. It is very good not over priced.

The highlight of our Danube River Cruise and extension in Prague. I simply can't say enough about our excursion to Lobkowicz Palace on April 22nd. We were served a great lunch in a room which is breathtakingly beautiful, then had a private concert by a classical trio, and then got a talk from the Prince himself. The treasures contained in the Palace are mind-blowing. I just don't have enough superlatives to describe this experience adequately. If anyone ever gets an opportunity to visit Lobkowicz Palace, DO NOT MISS IT!!!!!!
Magnificent architecture.. The Palace is a must see on your visit, the surrounding buildings, cobbled courtyards and streets, the cleanliness and the sense of importance makes it very special.

The best attraction in the Castle District.... Not included in the Castle ticket due to being privately owned this museum / gallery is the highlight of the Castle District. Get the audio guide as it explains some facinating history of the family that lived in the Palace throughout many centuries.The Canaletto landscapes are spectacular and the rare manuscripts from Mozart and Beethoven are a privilege to behold.If you are going to visit the Castle include this great museum in your time there.

Excellent museum and fascinating audio guide. Don't miss this museum when you visit the Prague castle area. A very interesting collection -- paintings by Bruegel and Canaletto, manuscripts by Beethoven and many other wonderful things. The audio guide (English version) is narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family which gives it a very personal feel, as if you are being welcomed into their ancestral home. Cafe has good food and probably the best view from the castle district!

Don't miss the audio tour. Great little tour with a personal touch. Tells the story of the Lobkowicz family and their work to recover their stolen artwork. Also worth having lunch at the restaurant overlooking Prague.

Beethoven and the Lobkowicz Dynasty. We had a great experience visiting this palace, which included 60 minutes of popular classical music performed by accomplished musicians in the palace's intimate and ornate concert hall. The audio guide to the palace tour is beautifully done with a good balance of information about displays and a personal touch with stories about the family. The narration is provided by tmembers of the Lobkowitz family who are the present custodians of the treasures collected by the family over several centuries. The treasures include a collection of guns and crossbows, a fully intact Delft dinner service and, most remarkably, the original scores of some of Beethoven's most famous works. Recommended.

Worth the time to visit. This palace holds one of the largest and most valuable private art and music collections in the Republic. This includes the original manuscripts for Beethoven's 5th and 6th Symphonies. Also of interest is that at 1 pm most days there are classical music recitals of the highest quality by, inter alia, members of the Czech Philharmonic. Well woth the investment of time and money!!!
Interesting visit. Enjoyed the short tour of the museum and hearing about the family history. Did this after the visit to the castle and actually enjoyed it more.

Lobkowicz Palace Tour. We went on this tour while in Prague. It was just okay. The prince and family do not live in the palace anymore even though you are given the imression that they are sometimes there. There really wasn't a lot to see compared to other palaces in Europe. Don't think it was worth cost.

Fabulous!. The Lobkowicz Palace is so thoughtfully done. The displays are wonderful, the audio guide is delightful and the collection was a real treat to see! This destination is one of my favorite parts of the visit to Prague.

Agree with the crowd!. This is a fantastic museum, especially if English is your native language. The owner of the castle narrates the fantastic and very professional audio tour in his native English (his family fled the country so he was brought up in the US), and walks you through some really high quality pieces of art. It's nice and (relatively) uncrowded, reasonably priced, and overall one of the highlights of my trip to Prague!

Terrific. With the excellent english audio guide, a wonderful experience, and blessedly uncrowded in this very touristy city. Don't miss it. Very personalized museum experience of a family heritage regained after WWII and Communist era.

Interesting palace within Prague Castle. The Lobkowicz Palace is located inside Prague Castle. (The Lobkowitz family owned 13 palaces, all of which were confiscated by the Communist regime, and most of which were retuned after the Velvet Revolution. The family has collected art for centuries, and most of their collection is now in this palace. The collection includes major works by Velasquez, Cranach, and Brueghel. However excellent the paintings, there's an additional attraction. That's the amazing story of a wealthy and powerful family that has survived endless wars and conquests. Touring the palace is a way to see great art, and also learn about Czech history and the Czech ability to persevere.
Must see. A magnificent private collection and the best audio guide I've heard, related by members of the family.

Worth the trip. Basically it a museum of the Lobkowicz collection of art pieces but with the detail and interesting audio guide make the whole visit so much more fun. And not to mention they have some pretty interesting collection. Enjoy my trip there.

A wonderful collection!. After recommendation from a friend, my husband and I visited the palace and were wonderfully surprised and impressed. This was one of our favorite parts of the trip to Prague. Listen to the audio guide, even if just the main points, as it is very fascinating! I'm so glad the family was able to reclaim their possessions and is now able to share their wonderful collection with the world. This is one of the sites I believe everyone should visit.
Fascinating History. Incredible collection which tells a unique history of Prague and this aristocratic Lobkowicz Family.

A rare gem of Prague. This palace has a story like no others and treasures that will surely awe you. It has a gorgeous view of the city but the audio guide and rooms of displays will have you wishing there was more - absolutely do not miss this when you are in the Castle Quarter!!

Lobkowicz Palace. This was my favorite thing do to at Prague castle. The audio guide provides great historical information about the Lobkowicz family, the palace, and the artifacts contained in the palace. The family was connect with many great artists and musicians and helped to make their work possible. I would encourage anyone interested in history or music to visit Lobkowicz Palace.

Gives a Wonderful Overview of European History. The audio commentary provided such a wondeful history for the whole family to follow- my youngest listened to the "number 12" over and over- regarding the 9 year old married away to her uncle- yikes! Not too many artifacts to be seen- but those there are very important including the Infant Jesus- the healing one! The commentary was so easy to listen to- very interesting and no TMI unlike some- you know what I mean- if you've ever listened to the one at the Roman Forum!!!!!

Lobkowicz Palace is a gem. The exhibits were top notch and the English language audio guide was outstanding. The Cafe was excellent and reasonably priced. We highly recommend this site to all visitors to the Castle district.

Dont miss thos quiet museum. We were told by an ex-pat to be sure to stop in. One of the TripAdvisor reviews said the audio tour was great. It was! Both a quick leason in Czech history as well as a great family story. Couple that with the original Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts makes this a highlight.

Don't miss it just because it's not obvious beside the castle compound. It is one of my favorite displays in Prague. Very nicely organized and explained by the audioguide. Much more reasonable price comparing to Prague Castle. Interesting national history presented via a family history! U can't miss it!!!

What an amazing story!. The thing that made this gallery/museum outstanding was that the audio tour was narrated by the current head of the Lobkowicz family himself, making it a very personal account of their extraordinary history. The Beethoven orchestral manuscripts will make a classical music aficionado weep, and the Canalettos are just amazing paintings. Undoubtedly one of the highlights of our trip.

Best cafe view of Prague. We had lunch and afternoon hot chocolate and cake at the cafe in the palace and also visited the museum. Both the cafe and the museum were excellent. The cafe has a wonderful view of Prague and the food is very good and the service is prompt. The hot chocolate is particularly good, rich and strong like melted chocolate. The museum was also a nice surprise. An excellent collection with a great back story and a very informative audio guide. Well worth a visit. Plus they have free toilets in the basement!

Lovely afternoon concert.. We happened to arrive here just before the 13:00 concert. It was lovely.The girl at the desk was very helpful, and spoke English well.There is a head set with a recording which gives you information of the exhibits, which is included in the price.This Palace is not inculded in the ticket for the Castle Complex.The concert was about 1 hour, it was a violinist, and pianist - duets, and solo pieces. The best piece was Die Moldau by Smetana.The Lovkowicz Palace houses some original manuscripts of various composers, which we were interested in seeing.There is a bathroom - free.

Best place to visit in Prague. Whilst visiting Prague Castle we came across the Lobkowicz Palace and its amazing private collection of family photographs, fine art, paintings, furniture and arms all beautifully and carefully displayed in this small family Palace. We learned more about the history of Prague and the Cheque Republic here than any other museum and were mesmerised by the works of art which had survived wars, Nazi occupation and the Communist Regime. A real treat was attending a lunchtime concert in the family Grand Entertaining Room, a selection of classical music arranged for piano and viola, including Albinoni's Adagio, Beethoven, Smetana and Khachaturian. It was also our great pleasure to meet the charming owner, William Lobkowicz, who is often in the Palace promoting children's workshops and community events. Also has a lovely restaurant with amazing views from the terrace looking out over the whole of the city. Suitable for all the family. Oh and of course, the Beethoven and Mozart original manuscripts make your pulse race!

Great art collection and lunchtime concert. Most of it has been said by other reviewers, well worth the visit. Alternative to trek up numerous steps to castle precincts from town is a 22 tram to Prazky hrad aka Prague Castle main entrance. If you time it right, you can see the noon changing of the guard, and take in the 1 o'clock concert in the Palace. Don't normally bother with audio guides but worth it, as commentary by crrent owner, who we saw in the cafe which I thought was good value considering the location. Funny to see two such beautiful paintings of my home town (London) in this setting, but lots of musical, artistic and political connections.

Very Nice. Didn't heared on this place untill read in trip adviser.Worth the long walk and the time it takes, very interesting and inlightning about Prague history and its importance. Remindede alot places like Rome Museumes with the vast exhebition and many items

Touching and Impressive. This collection covers paintings, applied arts, weapons, china, silk, feather arts, mural, instruments. The audio guide is recorde by Mr. Lobkowicz himself, touching and personal.
Lobkowicz palace tells the history of country from the angle of a royal family; Its a touching story and a must-see for art lovers.

Best kept secret in Europe.. By far the best place to go in Prague. THE great Caneletto, family history tied up with that of the nation for 600 years and so many priceless treasures.
