Not just the manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart but the best gun collection in Europe. Even some of the chandeliers are special (perhaps the owners don't realise that). Script of the audio tour is excellent. Uncrowded and you can take your time in every room.

Simply superb. I came across the Lobkowicz Palace through Tripadvisor and booked for the lunchtime concert and tour online.We arrived early to take advantage of the 10% disount for the cafe and the view over Prague from the terrace, even with the discount the coffee and cake were still fairly expensive but the view more than made up for that.The concert was very enjoyable with a pianist and a violinist playing various works with a relation to the Palace.The highlight though was the tour with audioguide of the palace, the family history is quite exceptional and the part they played in much of the classical music we take for granted came as a total suprise to me, its not often I get to the end of a tour and am disappionted that it has finished, but I was with this one.A must do.

Excellent - Any Musician must go!. As a musician, this was a great experience because I wanted to see Beethoven and Mozart's original scores. Any musician or anyone with an appreciation of music should visit the palace if only to see this. The Lobkowicz family have an impressive history - The audioguide is helpful and informative. The staff are very helpful and patient and the view of the city in the Palace Cafe is stunning.

Feel like a Princess on Your Own Palace Terrace. This is still my most beautiful memory of Prague. After a wonderful day of visiting the large castle, I ducked into this Palace to avoid the crowd returning to the city. I discovered a wonderful cafe on a balcony overlooking the city. The view was spectacular, the food was delicious, and the setting was gorgeous. I felt like a princess in her palace. The museum is beautifully appointed, but even if you don't have time for that, stop and have a cup of coffee and enjoy the atmosphere provided here. The best place in Prague.

better than the castle. Very interesting history and well narrated audio guide by the owners. Take your time going through their family collection of paintings, personal items, ceramics, military rifles, original music scores from famous composers such as Beethoven and Mozart.All the items are very nicely preserved and displayed. The building is just gorgeous and inside it is even more stunning. Good on them for being able to get their belongings back TWICE!!! Very impressive story. The entrance fee is 275 Kr however you will receive discount if you purchased ticket to the Castle. There is daily concert at 1pm, tickets sold separately. We spent more time here than the castle area attractions combined. The audio guide did mention that they have more collections in another castle located about 30 minutes away from Prague. Unfortunately, we did not have the chance to visit.
Lobkowicz. We went here to look at the art collection and history. An interesting family and an impressive art collection in a beautiful building.

Stunning art and music : history of a 700 year family in Prague. Great location, wonderful views over the city. Not to be missed if exploring the castle and looking for a stunning family art collection, original music scores (Handel's Messiah), excellent audio guide.

An Absolute Gem - forget the castle!. On a particularly cold day in Prague we soon tired of the massing throngs in the castle area and then were surprised to see that access to the Golden Lane was not free (part of the group ticket and with so many tourists around we could not be bothered to buy). We then chanced upon the nearby Palace and were taken aback by the fantastic experience offered (550 Kc each including the excellent audio tour). The exhibits are outstanding and beautifully presented. The highlight for us were two Canaletto paintings of London. The cafe is also excellent and would be the ideal place to drink/dine in the castle area.

Wow-Impressive. This palace was one of the highlights of our visit to Prague. The exhibition was presented in a very personable, user friendly manner, and with the help of the audio guide our 10 year old really enjoyed it. The Lobkowicz family history is rich and impressive, especially with their past influences on European politics and the incredible patronage that the seventh prince provided to Beethoven. Who knew? We learned a lot. Because we already had the family pass to the Prague castle, the ticket was discounted to 400 Czech Crown for all of us, including audio guides. Memorable visit and worth the cost.

Well worth a visit. If you are going into the Prague Castle make sure you visit this Palace. From the welcoming staff to the audio tour everything about this place was well organised and so very interesting. The exhibits and descriptions brought the place alive and the very pleasant cafe, for which a discount comes with your entry ticket, has amazing views across Prague and down the river. I recommend this to anyone going to the Castle. The only downside is that you can get lost in the streets trying to find it!

Great Value. My husband convinced me to go to this, even though I wasn't very interested, and I was amazed. My 6 year old shared the audio tour with me, and we were blown away. The Lobkowicz family themselves narrate the tour, and it's told in a very thoughtful and personal way. I was blown away. I highly recommend it. Another interesting thing to note is that since I was taking my 6 year old, we had to cancel some of the tours that I originally planned for simply because he wasn't up for it. One of the tours I had to let go of was the Communism and Nuclear Bunker Tour, and I was kind of bummed because I really wanted him to learn about it. This tour at the Lobkowicz Palace, however, taught him so much about communism that I no longer felt bad for missing the other tour. It also made it more personal. I loved this audio tour.

Wonderful!. I read the book, "City of Dark Magic" by Magnus Flyte - its a fictional novel which features the Lobkowicz family and castle in the story. To then go and see all the things the author had described was so much fun. Any music and art lover should absolutely go tour this museum. Catch the daily concert at 1pm!
Great place. This is well worth a visit. It is a beautifully kept museum and the story told by the family is bought to love with the artefacts around the whole place. Very good.

Conference night. Was invited here for a conference gala night. Magnificent place. The architecture is terrific. It takes hours just to take a look at the exterior of the buildings. The inside is also terrific. If you have the opportunity visit the gallery section on the third floor. It includes the original works of Bethoven and Mozart. Magnificent place. The owners are very nice and friendly people.

Don't miss this museum!. Get a unique insight into the history of both one family (The Lobkowicz) and the city of Prague. This museum is well planned, instructive and appealling. Don't miss it when strolling around on the Prague Castle area!

Actually very intresting. I went to Lobkowicz Palace with my mother who likes going to museums of almost any kind. I am more of a skeptic and a lot more difficult to impress. This "museum" however, was very educational and at the same time entertaining. We did the whole audio-tour in English and got to listen to the heir of Lobkowicz family telling the story about the family through history and how he put the museum together. He and his wife happened to be at the Palace that day as well which was nice to see. I would recommend this trip to everyone above the age of sixteen.

Great Cafe. Be sure to have lunch at the cafe terrace after checking out all that the Prague Castle has to offer. It's a beautiful spot with great food and who wouldn't like to have lunch in a palace.

In my Prague top 5!. It is in the Palace complex toward the back. I wish I skipped the Golden Way and spent more time here. It is a self contained museum with an OUTSTANDING collection and a fabulous story. Family lost art in 16th c and got it back, then taken by the Nazis, then got it back in 1989 in an incredible story of reparation. The collection has exquisite and important paintings, china, relics and metalwork, musical instruments (they were patrons of the greats, Beethoven etc...) and more. One room has paintings of the families dogs and dog collars that look like they would fit around someone's waist! The audio guide is great and narrated by two generations of the family who tell lots of detail and share stories. While it looks small, I spent over an hour going through. There is a shop and a wonderful restaurant. The restaurant has incredible views down to New Town and Old Town across the river. Enjoy coffee and sit on the terrace!

One of the Top Five attractions in Prague. If you are visiting Prague for the first time, or just would like to know a little more history of the city and the royal family, the Lobkowicz Place is a must see? With so much to see in Prague, the Lobkowicz was a wonder escape from the mass of tourists in the castle area. In addition, if you are going to visit any museums in Prague, which there are tons, the Lobkowicz Place gives a great history of the city and the royal family. The audio tour was included in the admission, and was great, which the narrators are the surviving royal family members. Also, the tour is a great relief from the hot or cold weather.

Museum with concert included..... I didn't even know about the Lobkowicz Palace until I got on to Tripadvisor, but it was well worth the trip and 275 CZK. I would suggest going around 1 pm when the concert is scheduled, so that you can tour before and after. It is located at Prague Castle, so you can see both. Here is the good1. William Lobkowicz narrates most of the audiotour and lends a personal and professional job on telling the family history.... which is fascinating...you will learn how rich people really get rich.. and see a geanealogy that spans many years and many countries in Europe2. If you are a music lover there are music manuscripts by Hayden, Mozart and Beethoven, that were signed or written in the composers own handwriting. 3. If you are into military guns of yesteryear there is quite a collection. I know nothing about them, but many of them were beautifully decorated.4. They have a nice café there. They provide a 10% off coupon with entry. There is indoor and outdoor seating5. Free concert with admission. Performed in a hall where other musical greats have performed6. You need to go to use the Water Closet at the museum. There are pictures of William and his family with many dignitaries along the hall way toward the WC... Barbara Bush is in a lot of pictures there...funny7. You need to look out the windows to see the beautiful view of Old Town below. I took a picture out the window, it was that nice.

interesting Czeck family story. Lobkowicz Palace, located in Prague's castle complex, is a private museum, in which you can learn the story of this rich and influent Czeck family. The Lobkowicz sponsored Beethoven's work and lost and recovered their palaces and wealth twice, after the Nazis and the communist invasion. It is a very impressive story, told with an excellent audio guide. The palace also hosts concerts everyday, at lunch time.

Lobkowicz Palace. I took an independant trip to Lobkowicz as this was not included in my tour.I am glad to have experienced this fascinating palace the heritage of the Lobkowicz family which had been confiscated twice,once under Nazi occupation and secondly under Communist occupation.It was interesting to learn that the inheritors were American ( of course the male hier was of Czhec origin ) and that they moved back to the Czech Republic in 1989 after the fall of communism and the govt established a law that permitted his family only one year to reclaim the title to all thier estates and property collection! This was no mean task.They hired the best lawyer they could access and literally had to scout and identity hundreds of works of art ,ceramics and priceless collection from many places across the country within that short year ! Very impressive history and well explained with audio guide.I think private tours have to be booked.The gift shop was impressive with very good quality items and memorabalia.Well wirth the visit and very close to Prague Castle!

Excellent audio guide. The palace was extremely interesting, would definately recommend a visit. The audio guide that was provided and narrated by family members made the experience much more interesting, it gave you options of items you must see if on a limited timescale to a more in depth version, the audio guide gave a good story of the history of the palace through the generations.

Great interior at the Castle. When you tour the Castle, there is not much to see in terms of interiors. Lobkowicz Palace however is packed with equipment - I admired artworks from the family collection. From the palace you can get a fantastic view. I found the audio guide, provided by Mr Lobkowicz himself, very exciting. It is not just another art gallery, there is also this personal story of old noble family.

Beautiful and interesting. This was one of my favorite stops during my trip to Prague. The palace is beautiful and houses a wonderful collection of art and music history; not to mention an imprssive collection of antique weapons. There is a restaurant on the premises but was not open during my visit.
History. It was a great palace to visit and to find out more about the Lobkowicz family history. Highly recommended and the story is told (headphones) in an entertaining, easy to follow way.

Fascinating and worth a visit. I didn't plan to go to the Lobkowicz Palace when I visited the Prague Castle,but then I realised it hosts a collection of musical instruments and autograph manuscripts by many of the greatest composers of the 18th and early 19th centuries, including Beethoven and Mozart, which really interested me.I'm so glad I did!The Lobkowicz collection is the oldest and largest privately owned art collection in the Czech Republic, I really enjoyed seeing the artefacts and the audio tour, in particular paintings and the music archive.Before my trip to Prague I booked a couple of evening concerts, when I visited Lobkowicz Palace I realised that the palace hosts concerts as there was one taking place during my visit. Such a shame that I hadn't realised this sooner I think it'd be a wonderful experience enjoying a concert in this delightful setting. If you're interested in European History and history of art you'd be fascinated by this place, the admission is even higher than Prague Castle but personally think it's worth it.

Palace architectural unusual, museum interesting. The beauty of this palace is more outside than in, with ornately designed exterior walls. The museum in February of 2013 housed rare Beethoven and Mozart original manuscripts.

Beautiful palace with great music, food, and collections. My wife and I spent an afternoon at the Lobkowicz Palace. We started with a lovely one-hour concert followed by lunch at the cafe. We then went on to see the collections and learn about the history of the Lobkowicz family and Prague. The audiotape is a must. William Lobkowicz narrates with the help of his wife and his parents. You will learn the loss and recovery of the palace and the assets twice in the past century.

OK for the price. I went in and used an audio guide, it was okay, more about their family, but I guess thats what the building was used for so no surprises. The rooms inside were not decorated so very basic and just a few paintings and some collections inside...good to look around, audio guide is nice, its not amazing though and not a must if you are in prague for a day or two...

Great place to visit. This is a must for visitors. The palace is beautiful and it's history troubled. Particularly the German / Russian occupation of the castle during and after the 2nd world war. Amazing.
Fascinating. This was a highlight of our trip. A really fascinating museum and the audio was great.Cannot recommend this enough.

Highlight of Prague Visit. I often check out what places Tripadvisor reccomends when I am visiting a new city. I noticed Lobkowicz Palace and noted all the great reviews but pleasantly surprised when I went as it really was incredible. We weren't sure we wanted to spend too much time touring the palace but once we bought the tickets and started the audio tour we were hooked. The palace/museum is extremely well organized and easy to follow. The variety of artifacts and the history that surrounded them was fabulous. I was there in August of 2011.

Rather overrated. I am slightly surprised by the other reviews of this palace. It has two superb paintings of London by Canaletto and a truly first rate Breughal. The collection of old instruments and music scores is interesting but hardly spectacular. Otherwise the collection comprises mostly family portraits of fairly indifferent quality and the palace rooms are very sparingly furnished. There is a very nice cafe attached though.

Hidden gem.. My favorite museum in Prague.Not only because it's in the Castle area, but also because inside his magical rooms you can find real treasures hidden in every corner.From musical instruments, to first folio of Beethoven symphony, portraits of forgotten gentlemen as well as two marvelous Canaletto painted in London. Marvelous.The audio guide will be a nice complement of the tour.Daily concerts in the music room.Dog room with paintings of the lobkowicz ones.

Amazing Experience!!. I was lucky to travel here as part of a school singing trip in 2007. Prince Lobkowicz was a graduate of my high school, and was able to greet us and give us a tour of the castle!! If you're a music buff this place is for you. Original scores, ancient instruments and beautiful paintings of musicians abound. The grounds are elevated on a hill and provide a beautiful view of the city. The statues out front are a little weird, so make sure to take a photo :)

Audio Tour. Def get the audio tour. Without it you are just looking and interesting stuff, but there is no background story. It was fun and pretty. I would do it, but don't spend all day here. There is so much to do in Prague

The audio tour is definitely worth doing. The audio tour included in the price of the entrance ticket is definitely worth doing as it gives you an amazing background and history of the palace and the people that have used it.

Rather dissapointing. After a long walk up the hill there is not much to say about this place other than the fantastic views of the city. The palace is not that big and entry I thought was quite expensive,

Living History. Wonderful restored palace that was given back to the family in the 1990's after Czech Republic gained independence. The family had been living in New York and returned to restore this national treasure. Great way to see the history and progression of Prague through the decades of this families history, they also have a very nice cafe which has amazing views of the city with very reasonable prices. There are also musical events, concerts held.
National historic treasure!. We loved the restaurant with view of the city. Historic museum was well laid out - so many beautiful treasures to see and so much history that we didn't know about.
Great little museum. This museum is privately owned by the family which now lives in America. Very interesting and well worth the entrance fee.

Red Bus Tour Guide - The Best. We booked ourselves on the red bus tour that was for the Palace, the Jewish Quarter and the cruise. So worth it. The Palace itself was amazing the history, the feel of the place and our guide was fabulous. Loved the fact that a guard had a hut outside the Christmas Tree too! As if he was guarding just the tree and nothing else.

How the wealthy lived. It's a lovely, private palace on the grounds of the Prague Castle, owned by a family who had managed to reclaim their private property both after WWII and after the fall of Communism. Highlight is definitely the original scores of Mozart and Beethoven. Since it is not part of the Castle/Government property, the entrance fee to the castle doesn't include entrance to this particular palace, indicating that the money is going towards the upkeep of this private palace. It is a bit odd that they then ask their guests on the audio recording for help to restore this essentially private property. While it is a lovely historic landmark, as a tourist I found it rather offputting to be asked to help this obviously wealthy family refurbish one of their palaces. Kind of left this otherwise glorious building with a sour taste in my mouth.

An unforgettable evening. We were invited for a dinner at the Palace, as part of a congress group. The Palace is located at of the wings of the Prague Castle and was build in the beginning of the 16th centery, It has been reventially restored by the Lobkowicz Princely amily that has owned the Palace. Our host was Prince William zu Lobkowicz himself and I felt I was in a fairy tale. So many beautiful rooms and the dinner buffet was fantastic.

Not what I expected. I was expecting something similar and was somewhat disappointed that we were only on the exteriors of the building, however, the private string quartet concert and lunch we attended was fabulous.

Lobkowicz Palace. A gem. Wonderful to attend a private concert in one of the palace rooms. Everything beautifully restored (since the Velvet Revolution in 1989) and should be first on a list of things to do in Prague.

A bit overrated... After seeing the reviews we were very excited and made this our one museum to visit. Sadly the museum was a bit of a let down. The collection mainly consisted of poor portraits and the audioguide talks extensively about the family lines, as opposed to czech history. Highlights are original manuscripts by beethoven and a collection of handcrafted guns. Definitely not for the young traveller looking for an intro into czech history. There must be better museums out there..
Beautiful and fascinating. One of the highlights of our stay in Prague. You don't need a the general ticket for the castle area to access this palace, you only pay their entrance fee.
Amazing. It was a fascinating visit and well worth a day to view. Fascinating history and amazing art and artifacts

Fascinating place with an amazing history. I had heard the prince talking about his family history and return to the Czech Republic on a Rick Steves radio broadcast and it was fascinating. The Palace is just as interesting. The audio guide is outstanding and very informative and it is included with your admission. Do not pass it by. It will help you appreciate all that has been done to return this place to its former glory. This was one of our trip highlights for sure.We had lunch in the cafe which was fine. In our experience, food in the castle area is costly and uninspiring. We also attended a live concert with piano and viola. It was excellent. A hint for you if you do not want to climb extra flights of stairs: Pick up your audio guide before you go to the concert if you will visit the museum after the concert.

Fascinating History. This was a spur of the moment decision to visit this palace at Prague Castle. The audio tour was great and the prince and his family are easy to listen to. It is hard for "everyday folk" to understand their upbringing and privileges. Listening to Martin describe coming home after exile actually bought tears to my eyes (but I am a weepy person anyway). My mind was also reeling at the discussion of uncles marrying nieces, cousins marrying each other, etc.
Don't miss it!. The most amazing story and FREE audio! with your admission ticket. It's at the far end of the Palace, but a 1 hour concert and tour is worth the time.

Very Interesting. A small but very well set out museum. Very interesting and lovely to see a classical concert here. Being in the grounds of the castle there were many other interesting sites to see in the vacinity

A must for anyone appreciative of culture. Modest in comparison with many attractions in larger (but not necessarily grander) cities, and provides a sound collection of Central European works, well presented with suitable commentary for those wishing to know more about Czech history.

Lobkowicz - very interesting. I liked the self guided audio, informative and pleasant items on display, the history of the Palace and the family. I found this tour much more pleasant than of Prague Castle area as its much more relaxing. Didnt do the concert at the end of tour due to limited time but wished I did.. just think it would have been the perfect ending to the tour. Next time!

Average collection saved by excellent narrative. Lobkowicz Palace displays essentially the private collection of a rich and historic Czech family. Naturally, this isn't as grand as the great collections of the Louvre or the Art History Museum Vienna, but in my opinion the audio guide, which explains in enchanting detail the story of the Lobkowicz family, their connection to the collection on display, and their connection with the Czech Republic, makes this one of the best attractions to visit in Prague. At any rate, this must be rank amongst the top things to do in the Prague Castle area.

Intimate museum with family treasures in one of the most beautiful areas of Prague. The story of the Lobkowicz family is amazing. Having lost all of their possessions twice, to the Nazi's and the Communist regime, in 1992 they regained all their properties, I think partly because everything was well-documented. The current Lobkowicz family does an outstanding job bringing this history to life in the museum, the only building that is privately owned in Hradcany, the Prague castle. A wonderful part of the tour is the storytelling using the audio equipment. The story unfolds through the voice of the youngest Lobkowicz descendant, US born but moved with family back to Czech to undergo this incredible adventure. Three rooms stuck with me: the room with etchings - all by the same artist - of all the Lobkowicz palaces, the room with the pictures of birds using real feathers, and - being from Holland - the room with various dinner sets, including a Delft Blue one. Well done!

Excellent museum with an excellent audio guide. This museum is fantastic! Normally I get tired of seeing portraits of random people, especially royalty. This museum includes an audio guide with your ticket and because of its high quality it really brought the portraits to life! The museum chronicles the life of the Lobkowicz family and was knowledgeable and entertaining. There is even a musical score for the audio guide that really heightened the tension of the narrative! The room dedicated to music was amazing and my favorite of the rooms. Beethovens 4th and 5th Symphony were dedicated to one of their family members as well as Mozarts 'Messiah'. They have the original manuscripts which are amazing to see!The palace also offers nice views of the city. Their cafe is a bit pricey so we opted to go elsewhere but you can sit on the terrace and enjoy the views with your food. There are lots of trees which will block most of the view when in warmer months.

Amazing. My wife found this place by chance and we decided to go on a rainy day. We did not expect much as we have the impression that any hole in the wall in Prague need 5 things or more, that are somewhat related, to call itself a museum. However, we were amazed by not only the amazing collection of artifacts that the Lobkowicz family has put on display, but also their warm and fascinating story about it all that guided us through the mansion. Although we got to see amazing portraits, Mozart and Beethovens original scipts, grand collections and works of historical importants, these items seemed to merely serve the purpose of peripheral detailes that to the Lobkowicz. Instead, the exhibition took on a story about a family, their hardships and how they found back to their roots. This experience was as much impressive and beautiful as it was humbling.

Great palace to visit.. Worth paying the extra money when visiting the Castle area. Good audio guide to the exhibits.Some very interesting art works and other displays and a insight into the family history. If you use the Cafe afterwards you receive 10% discount on your purchase and get a great view over Prague.

Pleasant lunch and very nice museum. We went as part of a tour - the historic center ending with the Lobkowicz Palace, lunch and the museum. The lunch was fun, but the possible presence of the Count was oversold. Also, we were tired after a long morning tour, The group was entertained by an ensemble and given a tour of the museum. I wish we had gone to the Museum first rather than last. The exhibits were well done and the family history was pretty amazing.
Nicely done. While I am not a huge art fan I did enjoy this museum. You can spend an hour or so as I did and see a lot, or spend the day if you are a art nut.

Most interesting stop of our Prague trip...a must do.. The story of this palace and the family that owns it is narrated by the owners themselves on an audio tour that guides you through the magnificent rooms and exceptionally well designed exhibits of this palace. The ticket price includes the audio tour, and you learn about the family and some of the priceless heirlooms that have been in their family for centuries. I was captivated by the tour, and they have another castle outside of Prague that is also set up as a museum, and I hope to do that on my next trip.

Enjoyable afternoon at the palace. We very much enjoyed our visit. The audio narrated by the current Prince makes the place come alive and we enjoyed his obvious family pride and enthusiasm. Highly recommended if you are visiting Prague Castle.

Just Okay. My beau and I went to the midday concert and also visited the musuem. The highlights about the musuem are the original manuscripts of Beethoven and the concert was nice. Otherwise for us, listening to the audio about a wealthy family and view numerous portraits of the family left much to be desired. In our opinion, there are more interesting museums that deserve a visit prior to this one.

Excellent collection. Nicely curated.. At first I hesitated a bit because of the relatively expensive ticket fee. After paying a visit, I have to say that it is a must-go spot for all visitors to Prague castle area. The collection is excellent. Thanks to the wealthiness and generosity of the Lobkowicz family, we are able to see the true copy of manuscript of Beethoven and many other precious art work which documented important moments of history. The collection is nicely curated which draws your attention and interest easily. The audio guide strikes a good balance between information and length. P.S. The cafe there was nice too!

The story and exhibits are excellent. If it is #1 with Trip Advisor it has to be good right. I would say absolutely. The audioguide narrated by the Lobkowicz's as they tell their family history and the amazing story of how they lost all they owned and got it back from Nazis and Commies is fantastic. The palace and collections are outstanding.

Beautiful Place. We visited in December and even in the mist the views are lovely. We watched the changing of the guards, stopped for warm mulled wine and then toured the palace. I would highly recommend the audio, even if its not something you would normally do. It really brings the whole palace and all the paintings alive to hear them spoken about by a member of the family. Highly recommended!
Nice scenery, very enjoyable. Most of the place is very open in terms of access, so you can walk around easily and take outstanding pictures.

Magnificent view!. I took the stairs up the tower and almost gave up half way because it was tiring. Luckily I didn't because the view up there literally took my breathe away. Prague, you are really beautiful! This place is certainly worth going

Pleasantly surprising. Went here as it was recommended by TripAdvisor, and this website once again proved it's a great guide!
The audio-tour through the castle really adds another dimension to the visit.
Saw some great art and the castle itself is impressive. Also original works of Beethoven and Brueghel make the visit worthwhile.
Picture perfect. Don't take the stairs unless you are fit. Get the Tram to the top. Very beautiful and entertaining, the cafe is worth a visit.

Interesting history of the Lobkowicz family dynasty. Lots of interesting art and a beautiful location overlooking the historic city of Prague. Two fantastic Canoletti's showing London from an earlier period.

Unexpectedly interesting. I'm not one for museums or art but my 14 year old daughter wanted to visit after noticing it during our visit to the castle. I must admit I was pleasantly surprised. This may have been as a result of the interesting commentary and self paced viewing of the items but it's well worth a look.

Lobkowicz Palace Pleasure. My husband and I visited the palace following the Budapest - Nuremberg Vicking Riverboat Cruise and it was the best excersion of the trip. We were served lunch, heard a brief classical concert, and Prince William Lobkowicz happended to be in the palace and stopped by to speak to our group. That would have been enough, but we still had the tour, which was absolutely wonderful. I strongly recommend a palce visit when in Prague!!!

Great value. Amazing paintings - the two Canaletto are fantastic -, one of the first draft of the Eroica with Beethoven's handwritten corrections, the famous painting of Mozart. Low price. The audioguide by Lobkowitz himself is a nice touch.
rubbish. Not much more than some dusty memories of an old and fallen noble family from Eastern Europe. Few history for a lot of boasting.
Best palace to visit. Very informative audio guide, better than usual. Attended a short concert in the palace which was very good, but the chairs were a bit hard.
Recital at the Palace. A one hour recital that was well worth while. I'm not even in to classical music but the tunes were mostly classics that I knew and the musicians were brilliant

if you only do one museum in Prague. make it this one! Its a great collection of art from centuries of colecting by one aristocratic family and gives you a great view of what Bohemia meant in the 16th to 19th centuries.especially important for music lovers as the collection contains important mauscripts and great instrument collection.The audio guide is excellent as is the cafee and shop and if you are aroud at lunchtime you may have a special treat o a concert in the originl music room of the palace.
Somewhere diferent. A great museum, realted to the Lobkowicz family, but with much, much more. The music manuscripts are amazing. Very good place to visit when you are at the castle

A Personal Tour that Incorporates the Past with the Present. The most remarkable aspect of the tour through Lobkowicz Palace is how vividly it ties the past to the present. One can visit countless beautiful and interesting sites, but having Will Lobkowicz tell about his ancestors as if he knew them well, and relate their lives to those of his family today, makes this a most personal and memorable experience. My 11 year old son (full of energy and short on patience) listened intently through the entire tour and still comments on what he saw and learned. The weapons, extensive musical display, cheeseburger and guards outside the palace were most impressive to this tween. (His most frequent story while recounting our two weeks of European travel was telling friends how he had a cheeseburger for lunch on Thanksgiving--in a castle with a Prince!.) The Palace Cafe features Czech fare, salads (hard to come by in Prague) as well as . . . the cheeseburger, American style. The gift shop is also better than most.
Lobkowicz Palace. Plenty to see and do, but simply sitting in a cafe at the top of the mountain was enough for me - a breathtakingly beautiful city beneath, centuries of history preserved.

A Hidden Gem. My husband and I took the tour of the Lobkowicz Palace and we both thoroughly enjoyed it. The audio guide comes free with the tour and is narrated by the current Prince Lobkowicz who is incredibly engaging as he tells the fantastic history of his family. Listening to the audio tour alone would be worth the price of admission, but you also get to see some pieces in their stunning collection: beautiful art and china, impressive arms, and the part that brought tears to my eyes- musical scores handwritten by Mozart and Beethoven! A really amazing story and collection. Not to be missed!
Wonderful!. Such a beautiful and magical place. The audio tour was informative and really brought the place to life.

We were in tears. We happened upon this place while visiting the Prague Castle complex and it was one of the highlights of our stay. The immensely moving story of the Lobkowicz family - beautifully narrated into headphones - was alone worth the entrance fee, but the for us, the highlight was seeing Beethoven's original manuscripts of the 4th and 5th Symphonies. But, oh, the beautiful Bruegel, the bronze age sword... the collection is immense and wonderful. As photography is not allowed, do visit the Museum Shop for a souvenir.

Good!. We visited Lobkowicz Palace after we visited Prague Castle. The place has a good collection of paintings and articles. The highlights include the painting of "Infanta Margarita" and the figure of "Holy Infant of Prague". It is defnitely worth a visit!

Should not be missed!. This wonderful collection was the highlight of our trip to the city. The presentation of information through the self audio tour was interesting and just the right length. The information was told in such a way that you felt like you we're being told the details as part of being a guest in the home of the Lobkowicz family. The manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart were a stunning part of the tour.My husband and I agreed that we need to tell people about this gem! We only new of it through a friend and indeed their recommendation was a good one.We ate in the palace cafe, which was ok but not great. That really was of no consequence- the collection is incredible!

Interesting and impressive!. Its; a great site, that demonstrates power of aristocracy - in supporting artists, in colleation of real chedeuvres during hundreds of years...It;s full of prettiest things in the world.

Music and art. We arrived just in time for the 1pm violin concert, and enjoyed it very much. We followed that up with the audio tour of the art collection. It was one of the best parts of visiting the castle.
beautiful museum and art gallery.. Some great art (Breugal, Canaletto, Valasquez etc) and interesting collections. Not too big and a personal family collection. VERY NICE CAFE.

Dont miss. Wonderful, wonderful collection. The audio guide enhances the experience 100%, due to the clear and so very appreciative voice of the American born son Wm. Lobkowicz. To see Beethoven and mozart's original manuscripts brought tears to my eyes. The family history is fascinating, the place is beautiful quiet, untouristy, with a charming tucked away cafe with great views.

Interesting history about Lobkowich family. The Lobkowich family is clearly a prominent family in Europe and their collection is impressive. It tells you a lot about European history as well as stories about the family. Worth a visit

Wonderful Museum, tepid "concerto". Being on a city like Prague, is like visiting Salzburg or Venezia: you'll breath culture everywhere.I've never had before the opportunity to visit the Lobkowitz Palace, and this time I did.What a precious hidden gem! Not so easy for a person at my age to climb the steps or the ramp to get there, but once we did, we felt the prize was more than deserved. This private collection, very carefully curatored by members of the Lobkowitz family, offers visitors the opportunity to explore the history of Europe through the unique perspective of The Lobkowicz Collections and the Lobkowicz family. Set in 22 beautifully appointed galleries, this lovely Museum displays a selection of some of the finest pieces from the collections, including many of international significance. Ushered through the galleries by the museum's audio guide, which explains important facts of European history and the six-hundred-year history of the Lobkowiczes, including the dramatic story of how the family lost everything twice and got it back - twice, is narrated by two generations of Lobkowiczes and the Chief Curator himself.By 1:00 pm, we'd previously scheduled a so-called "Midday Classic Concert"......and there we go...It was not bad, not at all, but one pianist, sometimes accompanied by a violist, sometimes changing places as first or second instrument for the price of Cz440 (around $22 USA)sounded a little preposterous to me.Like a snack party, we were offered Bach and Vivaldi,Mozart and Beethoven, and Dvořák and Smetana, ending with a frightening arrangement of Khachatutian's Sabre Dance for piano and viola.Sounds grand, huh?Well, it isn't. Sadly, these masters of Baroque and early 19th century composers, have wrote their pieces under some conditions, hard to change and harder to be listened when brutally rearranged to fit a pair of instruments.Not bad, I repeat, but....strange. I had even thought, seriously, some musicians had not arrived in time. When the first of the duos started, I felt a little bit awkward, uncomfortable. The musicians did their best, each one in her category played skillfully. But the melancholy to realize they KNEW that those pieces were meant to be performed by at least a quartet, had lead me to a sentiment of pity. Yes, I was sorry for my colleagues performing GREAT pieces under so precarious circumstances. All right, it's all part of a plan- the music room, with its amazingly gracious stucco was meant to be a plus, but for those who are serious about music or play some instrument, be warned that the "Concert" is almost as sad as a "One Man Band". Boy...how expensive it could be to hire a cello, two violins, and a basso? It would sound lovely, fresh and happy, as the end of a wonderful visit should be.The poor musicians would certainly feel much more at ease, playing their score without having to break and suppress whole phrases and countermelodies the way they were forced to do, by mixing one voice with viola and piano, sounding like an aggressive discussion between two instruments, instead of the Estro Armonico every musician seeks.
Stunning palace!. I visited the palace for a fantastic party. And who does not wish it were their home - the palace changed hands and styles. The venue is worth a visit.
Don't miss this special gem. Art, history, music, culture, arms and armaments -- it's all here, even original scores and notations by Mozart and Beethoven

Excellent museum. Amazing collection of art and items of historical interest including original sheet music by Mozart and Beethoven. Wonderful collection of antique pistols as well. What made the collection so absorbing was the excellent audio guide, which is narrated by the surviving members of the Lobkowicz family. The entire collection is owned by the family, and the story of how they amassed, lost and recovered it gives the exhibition real context and character. You can see portraits painted hundreds of years ago, with the jewelry and furniture in the paintings shown alongside. Entrance is fair at 275 kcr, which includes the audio guide.Would definitely and unconditionally recommend.
Interesting. One of the largest in Europe although not particularly grand, it has lots of history that is interesting,.
Sensational palace. The audio is part of the entry ticket. A very worthwhile visit. The history is amazing. As part of the Castle district include it your days tour.

Highlight of our trip. I absolutely loved this collection. A complete must-do. The audio guide really enhances the experience as you listen to the stories of the family as well as the pieces you are looking at - a very personal, intimate insight into the family history. The music room is fabulous - original scores by Beethoven and Mozart - Amazing. The whole place was an oasis of calm and tranquility amongst the madness that is Prague Castle on a busy Saturday - probably because you pay extra to go in. Totally worth it. Also, really great cafe/restaurant attached with great service, good value delicious food. Highly recommended

Wow! Best museum in the city. We really enjoyed this museum/palace. It's small but well laid out with great audio to assist your visit. The story alone about the Lobkowicz family history up to the very present is amazing! The painting and artifacts will amaze most museum goers. I highly recommend the palace as well as have a beer and goulash in the cafe.

Fascinating palace full of family history and treasure.. Give yourself plenty of time to look around, use the included headphones. Lots of art works- you must see the 2 Canalleto Pictures of London and a Brueghel, fabulous!

A pleasant extra tour insde Prague Castle. Great place to visit while at Prague Castle Wonderful art, furniture, etc. Lobkowicz family is very interesting, having to win back their home from both the Nazi's and communists.
Worth going. It was quite fulfilling to see Beethoven's original manuscripts there among many other interesting items displayed.
Small but impressive. Looking at the unique china collection and especially imposing family portraits one will realize the importance of this clan to the Czech nobility
Very interesting if you take the audio tour!. Great audio tour! Very interesting family tree. Lots of art and "old things." Definitely not for children :)

A fascinating collection!. The Lobkowicz Palace was by far my favourite attraction in historic Prague. The collection contained some unexpected gems - such as original manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart - and the audio tour provided just the right amount of information to be interesting and not boring.The Palace was also a lot quieter than the nearby castle - we had the place nearly to ourselves - so we had some much-needed respite from the crowds!

The best in Prague. If you just go to one museum in Prague, make sure it's the Lobkowicz Palace. Don't miss the English language audio tour, in which members of the Lobkowicz family tell their story. The collection of art, furniture, music, porcelain is exceptional. They also have a really nice museum shop and a nice cafe/restaurant with a nice view. We take all our visitors here!

Impressive View. Tauck Tours included a dinner there replete with white gloved waiters and a three piece trio while we dined in the formal catering hall. Awesome adventure. We met prince Lobkowicz who spoke about the palace and how he's still trying to reclaim art that was taken from him during the war. He doesn't live there as he never wanted his kids growing up in a palace! His art collection and artifacts are open to the public too.

An amazing collection!. A beautiful family palace and an incredible collection of art and artifacts. See original compositions of Mozart, Beethoven and others who supported by this family. Delightful!
Must See. If you want to appreciate Czech history and culture, you have to visit this site. Incredibly impressive.
best museum in prague. Wonderful museum of Czech history as seen through the eyes of a famous Czech family.Two stunning Canalettos, a great Breughel and original scores by Mozart and Beethoven

Not to be missed. I wish we could have spent more time in the museum. Displays were all fascinating. The concert was one of the highlights of our 4 days in Prague. It was not crowded which added to our enjoyment. We had a brief stop in the cafe which was good.

Excellent.. An absolute must in Prague. Allow at least half a day here, and marvel at the Handel and Mozart hand-written musical scores. Old Master paintings, weaponry, china and a vast array of quality, fascinating objects. It's a marvel the collection survived both the Nazi and Communist regimes.
very interesting. Part of Prague Castle and displays all the Baroque spleandour you would expect. Also great views from the windows over the Vlatava river and central Prague.

A welcome rest and good food. This may not be a cheap stop but the food was delicious and the staff friendly and welcoming. Just what we needed on a snowy and cold day in October!! Make sure you do the tour of the Palace (extremely interesting) before eating to take advantage of the reduction on the price of your meal.

Magic. I'm not sure they do this all the time but we were treated to a private dining room and white glove service. All this with a balcony adjacent that looked out over Prague from atop the palace walls. Food and wine were superb.
Don't Miss!. A don't-miss in Prague. You get to know the family, see their fabulous collection, and learn a ton about the history of the country. Absolutely take the time to go in Prague!!
Fascinating family history. This was a great family owned/private collection of historical artifacts with one of the best audio tours ever!

Well-done tour !. As one unfamiliar with Czech history, I was very impressed by the organization of this tour - The personal touch of the audio guide & the arrangement of the displays presented a fine, interesting, understandable review of the history as it related to the Lobkowicz family. It was a thrill to see original scores by Mozart & Beethoven!!! After the tour,we enjoyed a pleasant lunch on the sunny patio overlooking Prague and then a concert in the palace. A wonderful day!

World Class Collections. Start with a view across the river to Charles Bridge and other sights. Get here as early as possible to minimize crowds. Decorative arts, paintings, you name it. Not to be missed.

Hearing the history from Mr. Lobkowicz made it really special. Our tour guide Eva Trkalova recommended that we tour the palace with the audio guide rather than with her and she was absoulutely correct. It is so amazing to hear the history of the family and how they lost all their property twice, once to the Nazis and then to the communists, and are now in the process of reclaiming it. The walk through the palace is very nice and the artifacts are wonderful to behold. The ticket includes 10% off at the cafe and if it is a nice day it is wonderful to sit on the balcony and enjoy the view over the city. The food was good and the Lobkowicz white wine was some of the best we had in the city.What makes this tour really special is hearing from the son, the father that fled to the United States to escape the Nazis, and the mother. We thouroughly enjoyed it.

Unique museum which probably has something for every museum lover's taste.. Why unique ? The excellent audio guide narrated by a Lobkowicz himself.How varied? Paintings, Portraits, mostly. Antique musical instruments. Original scores by Mozart and Beethoven. Arms, military and sporting weapons, some displaying fine artistry, Ceramics. Porcelain.What's missing? My wife would have liked to see more furniture; perhaps this did not survive Nazi and Communist confiscations or was not returned, as much of the displayed collection fortunately was.Where? In the Prague Castle complex, across from The Golden Lane and the Toy Museum.Our ticket to the Castle covered the cost of this museum. Regrets? Only that we did not have time to enjoy the midday classic concert or well reputed cafe here. But did browse the gift shop!
Lovely museum. Nice story that guides you through the museum. Exposition is built up in a logical way. good information on Czech history.

Outstanding (and necessary) audio guide. The audio guide is what sets this place apart. It's really well done. It's mostly narrated by the current resident, a Lobkowicz himself with the occasional narration from his family. Without the audio guide, it's just a bunch of family portraits, heirlooms, an impressive arms collection, and real written scores by Beethoven and Mozart. But the story is told so well, it really brings meaning and life to the things you see. (Tip: hold the forward/backward buttons to fad forward or rewind)The best part was the music room with a bunch of antique (but used) instruments and incredible original scores by Beethoven and Mozart. And I course the narration provides excellent information.Also impressive were the arms. There are 2 rooms filled with gorgeous guns, both ceremonial and military. Take a closer look to see the detail in the artistry.This place is just at the end of Prague Castle. You can buy a combo ticket and get a discount, although I think you should just do the free parts of Prague Castle. But if you insist on buying a ticket, get the combo ticket.

Interesting Story. Had a tour arranged through Viking Cruises that included lunch and a concert which was very nice. The story of how the palace was taken away from the family twice, first by the Nazis and then by the Communists and how the family recovered the property is very interesting.

Short but nice tour, gorgeous cafe. The cafe here is outstanding views overlooking Prague. We grabbed a beer and snack here before our tour, inexpensive and lovely. The tour was most enjoyable and told from a personal point of view.
Fantastic view of Prague. Try to snag a table on the balcony at the Lobkowicz Palace Cafe. You will feel like the Prince must have!

Go for the history. The story of this family is fascinating. The family portraits are interesting, but the bits of history make them great. Beethoven dedicated his Heroica to an ancestor and there is the score! We went to the musical interlude and enjoyed it, knowing that it was going to be only three musicians. (Duck around to the cafe and have some wonderful cake.)

Amazing story and collection. Be sure to pick up the one-hour audio guide free of charge with admission. I must admit, the tour was slightly boring in the beginning but then it became truly fascinating.The audio guide gives visitors the opportunity to hear the perspective of the Lobkowiz family and their history. You will hear stories about their artwork collections, family portraits, ceramics, porcelains, weaponry, and my favorite, musical scores.The musical instruments and original manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart are truly amazing. You will also fall in love with a copy of the Infant Jesus of Prague as it is on permanent display in the Lobkowicz Palace Museum. A truly wonderful experience.

Prague Highlight. Really enjoyed the tour and outstanding audio by very well spoken American member of the Lobkowicz family. We had the benefit of a lunch at the palace followed by a short concert by a local string trio. Highly recommend visiting this palace as part of historical Prague.
do not miss this one. Varied subjects extremely well presented. in the castle after a great back door walk. Audio guide was amazing even for the 'culture haters' in our group

A great surprise. Having been to a lot of museums lately I was not very excited to pay for another tour. But! This experience was very special with the personal narration from Lobkowicz himself. I recommend it to anyone. It's very overwhelming to think that a family acquired this fortune and has managed to retain it.

good bits but annoying. having read TA reviews i resolved to do this tour. i took the pricey admission charge on the chin and picked up my audio tour machine. i was led by the nose through the exhibition by his lordship's voice followed up by voices of various members of his family. truly impessive were: actual manuscripts of top composers; and 2 cannalettos. Unfortunately his lordship's smug tone got under my skin. Despite this i would have liked to see some more recent stuff in the exhibition and some evidence of what the current family is doing philanthropically. I mean no offence when i write that this would appeal more to north americans than brits......... this is probably why Lob's palace reached top billing in prague attraction reviews

Best audio guide. The art exhibits are greatly enlivened by the personal point-of-view of the audio tour by a member of the Lobkowitz family (who was born and raised in the USA and to whom the family estates were restored after the fall of communism).
Very Interesting. Great story, great art and history, and an excellent view of the city of Prague. This is worth spending some time to see and explore
Fascinating variety. Quite eclectic collection but if you like Beethoven to see the original performing parts of the 5th symphony was very special. A couple of fine Cannaletto's too

Make this top of your list. We didn't actually meet the prince, but thanks to the excellent audioguide narrated by him it felt as though we had. I absolutely floated around this fascinating place, listening to vivid descriptions of the amazing stories behind family treasures while Smetana's My Country played on the guide. It was the section about the Vlatava River, which you could see through the window. Since I've been home, I've been playing the CD and imagining myself back in the palace, looking at the portraits, the musical instruments and Canaletto paintings. Not to mention sitting on the cafe terrace looking at the view. A great experience all round.

Meet the boss. We took a tour of Lobkowicz Palace and met the real life prince. Turns out he is from Boston and his family had owned not only the Lobkowicz Palace but lots of real estate in the Czech Republic since the 1300's. After the fall of communism, he mounted a legal campaign, (costing millions), to recover his family property. He moved his immediate family to Prague and actually lives in this reclaimed palace. He narrates the tour, (via hand held listening device), and it is an intriguing history lessen along with some very valuable artifacts, (turns out Beethovan was supported by his family ancestors. Take the tour and if you are lucky, (or with the Tauck River Cruise), you might just get to meet the boss.

Concerts are great here. The music concert we went to here was great. Book it online and you get a better deal and can see the museum for free. Some fantastic performances though and well worth the money.

No words to describe such beautiful experience!!!. It's completely fair this place be one of the most recommended place to go in Prague. If you really enjoy history and antique stuff this is the greatest venue! Me and my boyfriend were  delighted with such preserved things. The audio tour is unique and kind of brings you to the old times. Is more than about the  Lobkowicz family, is about  the big part of Europe history! Definitely worth... At the moment is the best museum I've ever been.

The Beethoven Connection. This is a beautiful palace with interests for the historian and music lover. There was a small concert at 1PM and an excellent audio guide narrated by the current Prince. We were interested in the relationship of the 7th? prince who was an important patron of Beethoven in Vienna. A large collection of original scores and interesting instruments was the high point for us..

Fabulous experience!. We visited Lobkowicz Palace and enjoyed a delicious lunch, a half hour classical chamber music concert and then a tour of the wonderful museum, along with the audio guide which very interesting and is narrated by a member of the Lobkowicz family. It's a gorgeous and well run museum. Highly recommended!

Great Art Collection and Personal Stories.. As someone who enjoys history and has limited art knowledge I really enjoyed this.The audio tour really brought the paintings to life as you walked around and heard the family connections to each piece. Not only that you are hearing the story of portrait from the subject's actual descendant.The story of how Lobkowicz Palace and its collections was built up and then taken from the family twice and now reclaimed is interesting and moving.The art collection is impressive and vast.I was also deeply impressed by the music room which had actual music sheets from Beethoven for music he dedicated to Prince Lobkowicz. It really is very impressive to hear a piece of Mozart's re-writing of Handel's Messiah through the audio tour whilst looking at the actual music sheet with his handwriting on it.As a bonus for us, when we left one of the many rooms we actually bumped into Mr Lobkowicz himself, who narrates you through the tour. He was very nice and seemed genuinely pleased to meet us and hear how we enjoyed the palace.I really could not recommend a visit to this attraction any higher. It is hugely impressive and the audio tour will make it interesting for everyone, even those that do not particularly enjoy art or history museums.Also, when finished, go next door to the cafe and have a lovely Apple Strudel whilst enjoying a beautiful view of Prague.
A museum of a family. If you like a museum of a family history over hundred of years, this the place for you. I find it boring.

Lobkowicz Palace/Museum, Prague. Up on the Castle Walk is the Lobkowicz Palace. It's the home of the Lobkowicz family who have twice lost all their holdings (which are extensive to say the least) and gotten them back. This museum was wonderful and had an excellent audio tour. There are not only rooms of paintings of the family and by old masters, there are rooms with antique instruments and music...some of the original music written by Mozart and Beethoven, and rooms of ceramics. The audio tour gives a glimpse into this amazing, elite family

Worth a visit. A very interesting family story and the museum is narrated by a family member. The musical connections of the family and the exhibits are interesting and can be seen reasonably quickly without losing the narrative

Best Audio Guide and Great Exhibits. The English version of the audio guide is narrated by an American member of the Lobkowicz family and he interweaves the family's history (they lost and regained their properties and possessions twice - the Nazis and the Communists) with excellent descriptions of the items in the museum's collection. Well worth an hour or so before or after visiting the Prague Castle!

a different museum. the lobkowicz palace is a very personal and special place in prague. the english audio guide is very worthwhile and the museum itself a small but important collection in czech history

Great audio tour. I normally do not like art and artifact museums, but the audio guide was great because it was actually decendents of the Lobkowicz explaining the family history to go along with each painting/artifact
Amazing. Incredible, among the main atractions in Prague. Ideally do it with a guided tour to take most if it.

Don't Miss This!. We saved this for our last day and it was the perfect ending to our Prague visit. Book the combo that includes a recorded guided tour narrated by Lobkowicz himself, a concert of Czech-related music performed by a brilliant chamber group, and a discount at the cafe on a terrace with one of the best views of Prague available. The music room is amazing with original manuscripts of Beethoven's, Mozart's arrangement of Handel's "Messiah", and much, much more. My heart was in my throat hearing about this family's history and reclamation of their treasures. Not once, but twice! I will never forget this.

A must see in Prague. At the tail end {eastern end] of Prague Palace lies the Lobkowicz Palace, privately owned by the family and recently renovated with much of their astounding collection.....often referred to as 'the BEST private collection in Europe'.........sooooooo tastefully presented. DO NOT miss the daily chamber music concert at 13:00. [the program is about 45 minutes and perfect]..........take it in after a light lunch at their cafe.....also, excellent...... ....perfect respite after a morning at primary Prague Castle.

OK but nothing special. I added this tour to a Viking cruise and it was $90 and certainly not worth it. It included a bowl of goulasch, a small piece of cheesecake and a free beer or glass of wine. It also included a 20 minute classical concert and a self-guided tour of their gallery. It was very nice but certainly not worth $90!!

Amazing palace!. Make sure you buy the most expensive ticket where you can visit all the attractions of the palace. We chose the other option and regretted we couldnt see the actual palace inside :(.It is a very long walk to get to the palace, so be prepared with comfortable shoes and a bottle of water, or get a cab
Better than Prague Castle. There is a terrific collection of family furnishings, paintings and objects in several rooms to see. Free audio guide is included in the ticket price.

Must see when in Prague.. After traveling across Europe the Lobkowicz Palace is easily one of my favorite museums. The art and history of the Lobkowicz Palace is stunning. The best part of the Palace is the narration of your tour by the Lobkowicz family on audio headsets. Few museums that I have been to give such a personal account of the art and history standing before you in the Palace. Don't miss it!

lobkowicz palace. well worth seeing, prague its self is breath taking,a must see city.try to pick a season when it is less likely to rain, do not do the bus tours they do not stop and are closed (windows)

Wow, amazing palace!. Extremely well preserved palace, with gorgeous woodwork and furnishings. Great tour of the palace. We also ate dinner at the pavilion on the property, which is a magical setting for dinner.

Outstanding Museum in the Castle Complex. WE toured the museum, attended a concert and had lunch there. It was an elegant time and took almost all day and was a high-lite of our Prague visit. Would do it again on our next visit as my wife really raved about it to everyone we met along the way.

"A True Nobleman". Heard about this family on an archived Rick Steves podcast, but visited because our private guide told us to. She kept referring to the current Lobkowicz, William, as "a true nobleman." I highly recommend that you visit, the art is great, but the included audio guide takes you through Prague and world history in a way that sticks. The Lobkowicz story brings home the glories and struggles of Prague and the noble families of Europe. Also, the view from the tea room is spectacular, and the food is wonderful! Download the podcast and listen to it enroute to Praha!

Intriguing History and fine Museum. Very interesting palace with fine historical art and mementos of a Czech family who lost properties in WWII and during Communist period. Interesting peek into Czech historical aristocracy. Very worthwhile and good cafe.

Great Collection, Amazing View. Lobkowicz Palace is in the Prague Castle complex and is absolutely worth a visit. The price of admission includes an audio guide, narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family. The audio guide correlates with numbers on the different works of art, but certain items are highlighted as "must sees" which is incredibly helpful and keeps it interesting. With the audio guide, we had a chance to listen to Mozart while looking at the manuscript of the symphony in Mozart's own hand. AmazingAnother reason to visit is the view from the cafe. Rather than pay more money and deal with the lines and steps at St. Vitus, why not have a caffe latte and apple strudel at the cafe while overlooking the city of Prague. I've never looked out on a more breathtaking view.

Art and Czech History Revealed at the Palace. Our tour of this grand Palace included a wonderful Czech lunch, concert and audio tour of the Lobkowicz family's private art collection. It is here where you begin to understand the importance of the family dating back to the Holy Roman Empire. Their financial support of Beethoven, Handel and Mozart is revealed by the original manuscripts of these composers. Very enriching tour. Very well worth it! Then step outside and take some great photos of the city of Prague.

personal touch was fab. This was without a doubt one of, if not the finest, self guided tours of an art museum we have ever taken.Why? Because the narration was done by Mr. Lobkowicz , one felt he was showing with pride his family to us. we loved it;very personal touch
the palace. spent the whole day here watching the changing of the guard and seeing the other side of the river. if you have time find John Lenon Peace Wall. the art work is brilliant.

A nice reprieve from tourist central. We stopped here after the castle tour. There were maybe 3 other visitors so it was wonderful to be away from the crowds. The collections are amazing, really! The English audio tour was hosted by a member of the Lobkowicz family and was fantastic. The family history is so interesting.

Dinner with Tauck. The Prince gave a talk about the family misfortunes and restoration following WWII. The ambiance was great. My wife was impressed, as was I. Local wine excellent, especially the White wine. The group was made up of 98 persons. 4 piece orchestra was grappling with din from the boisterous crowd, who enjoyed themselves.

Well worth visiting. The Palace which is within the Castle grounds was excellent. If you buy a combined ticket that includes the 1pm concert then you will not be disappointed. Fabulous artifacts are hear including original Beethoven music scores in his own handwriting. The audio guide comes free of charge. The restaurant and cafe are very good here.
Wonderful Views of Prague. Have a coffee/cake or lunch on the terrace of this palace/museum. Very good views over Prague. We did not visit the museum itself so no comments.

A Gem in Prague. I've heard about this palace and it's history in a Rick Steves podcast. We went to Prague and visited the palace and we were pleasantly surprised...We bought the combo ticket that includes one hour concert and the palace with the audio guide. The concert was very nice and as lover of classical music I was very happy being in an intimate setting and not in a huge concert hall. Afterwards we toured the palace with the help of the audio guide which is one of best audio guides I ever encountered, very detail and with music transitions...the palace has a lot of objects the art and it's not huge that you get tired. We ended the tour in the cafe sitting in a balcony with a really good view of Prague and a very good black forest cake. It wasn't crowded as the rest of the castle district which was packed with people...a very nice break . It's also worth mentioning that the music concerts in Prague are way cheaper than the ones in Vienna...

Great Private Museum That Has Exhibits That Appeal to Diverse Interests. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed the two hours that we spent at this museum earlier this month.One is given an audioguide as part of the admission price and the English version is primarily narrated by William Lobkowicz(who grew up in the U.S.) with short commentaries by his wife and father. My wife and I both enjoyed this witty and personal touch in describing the exhibits.My wife and I have fairly different interests and we both found the varied holdings presented on the two floors of this well maintained and signed museum had great interest to both of us. If one only had 30 minutes to visit this museum and your main interests are painting and music one can visit the dozen "highlight stops" enumerated by the audioguide rather than going through the 30+ stops that constitute the entire tour.If one makes the effort to visit Prague Castle I think that visiting Lobkowicz Palace is a "no brainer"!

a nice little treasure tucked away in the main palace. the place is curated very well, and they present their collection in a very organized fashion. an audio guide is included with the admission price, and it is a refreshing break from the usual fact-heavy audio guides that are more typical. if anything, the audio guide makes the place stand out as it is narrated by a current generation Lobkowicz is an honest, genuine, "aw shucks" manner (they returned to Czech Republic from the US). definitely something that i would recommend.
very interesting. Boy, are these guys rich. An interesting display of a range of different things. Would have liked more art and less guns, but some of the guns were works of art.

As Good for Me as The D'Orsay in Paris. This may be for me as worthwhile a museum as the Museum D'Orsay in Paris which is my all time favorite. The tour begins with an audio guide narrated by the current Prince Lobkowicz  who along the way introduces his father and wife who take us through the many beautiful rooms of their palace loaded with family portraits and artifacts that describe 500+ years of their family's history and contributions to the arts.  They were patrons of many artists and the collection includes some of the original scores from Beethoven and Mozart right in front of our eyes. The acid test for enjoyment was that all of us were actually wanting more after traipsing through 3 floors for 2 hours listening to Prince Lobkowicz tell us of his wonderful family. We note that the Lobkowicz Cafe is listed as a wonderful place to have lunch and indeed it was eating in a courtyard in the middle of the courtyard, tres chic.

Fascinating history and collection.. The Lobkowicz Palace collection is well worth a visit if in Prague. It contains the story of one of Europe's most aristocratic families and it's place in history. It tells how the Lobkowicz family lost their priceless collection first to the Nazis, got it back and then lost it again during the post-war communist era, finally to regain it again upon the new dawn in Czechoslovakia heralded by the velvet revolution of 1989. There are priceless exhibits including paintings by Canaletto and manuscripts by composers such as Beethoven and Mozart. I would strongly recommend the audio guide (available in English) to gain a full appreciation of this amazing collection. Allow at least 2 hours to go round the entire exhibition.
Nice. The whole palace is nicely run. They have exhibitions, nice shop.But I go there to their cofee shop - just perfect, nice view, fine staff, good homemade beer.

great experience. great paintings, artistic objects, etc... but it is fascinating the story of the lobkowitcz family able to get back the castles and the collection after the nazists and the communists.

All around great visit. This was a wonderful museum. Not only was the collection itself really amazing, but the audio tour was incredibly informative and personal. So much great history with a very personal and fascinating story. The restaurant has one of the best views in the city, and the museum has some great things as well!

Fantastic museum. The collection is wonderful. Not too big and not too small. The narration by one of the living Lobkowicz was really neat. I wouldn't miss this site. There was the original scores to several Beethoven Symphonies as well as Handel's messiah

Best tourist activity in europe. this was a highlight of our entire european trip. the staff are unbelievable and the best people we encountered in Prague and europe. 10/10 for public relations/ going the extra mile. Would recommend the palace and concert as a must to any tourist. Top activity in europe.

One of its kind!. The museum of the Lobkowicz family treasures was really one of the highlights of our visit to Prague. Do take the audio guide (we took it in English but other languages are also available) which is anyway included in the admission fee. Don't forget to show your student card to get the discount even if you don't study in Czech Republic. We listened to every background information while wandering around the rooms and exhibits. The fact that you actually listen to Lobkowicz family members telling their story and background information as well as other historical figures' stories makes the tour even more enjoyable. Beethoven's original manuscripts of the 3rd, 5th and 6th symphonies are some of the noteable exhibits of the museum although I loved the whole collection of paintings, porcelain and ceramics too. The view from the museum windows is stunning therefore do have a look while wandering through the rooms.
Absolutely must visit. Your Praque trip won't be completed if you don't pay a visit in the largest palace in the world.I was there for a half day in this fascinating place.

Not to be missed. This palace is a gem: it used to be and is again one of the homes of the Lokowicz family, restored lovlingly and full of interesting and beautiful paintings and personal objets. We picked up the audio guide which is included in the price and this gave us a thorough history of the family as well as the history of the palace and an interesting overview of Czech history. There are some amazing musical scores, instruments and personal stories about world famous composers. My description doesn't do it justice, but we all thoroughly enjoyed our hour and a half here - including the teenager. Really not to be missed

Small collection of good baroque paintints. Family collection of baroque paintings and music manuscripts by various composers including Beethoven. The employees made us feel very welcome and appeared to enjoy sharing their collection with international tourists. The collection is housed in the family's palace at the edge of the Castle.
Well kept treasures!. This was quite a surprise. We appreciated the history of the generations of the family, who collected treasures and maintained them through the ages.

Family Heritage returned in Prague. As part of a tour group we toured the Lobkowicz Palace and had dinner there. It was an incredible exerience to hear the family's history of 700 years in the area and how they were able to come back to reclaim their belongings in 1990 after the Soviets left the Czech Republic. Their history as patrons of musicians and as art collectors was impressive. The palace has been lovingly restored by a young family with roots in Boston, Kentucky and Prague. The gift shop carries high quality merchandise at fair prices. Highly recommended for the historical and cultural value.

concert is only for tourists. This review is only for the daily concert. I felt the targeted audience was really tourists who don't know anything about classical music. It's a pity I didn't properly check the programme before buying the tickets, but as there are only 3 people playing, I thought they should have picked pieces that were actually written for a chamber orchestra, rather than try and replace a full orchestra with only 3 instruments.In particular, the violin was replaced by a viola, which really wasn't giving justice to the masterpieces they were playing, and also, the famous Paganini violin piece was played by the flute alone, and that was a disaster. Only the pianist was good.That being said, we thought the cafe served pretty good food, just skip the concert...
Very interesting. The collection is fascinating as is the family history told by family members on audio guide. Concerts are also high quality.

Fantastic city a must to go to. Great place, have coffee and cake at the cafe there, the apple strudle is to die for wear good walking shoes as most of the streets are cobble stones and can be very slippery if wet.

Beautiful, Great Cafe, Chamber Music Concerts.
