While visiting the Prague castle compound my friends and I had lunch on the terrace of the cafe which overlooks the gardens then proceeded to the chamber music concert directly following lunch. he lunch was adequately satisfying and the chamber music trio were member d the Prague Philharmonic.

Amazing!. They say that family history is important - but that takes on a whole new level when it's the Lobkowicz family.
Take the audio tour, take your time. And, I wont spoil it for you, but the music room is absolutely amazing!

Absolutely fascinating. My husband & I loved this museum, spent almost 2 hours immersed in the fascinating life of the Lobkowicz family & their amazing collection. A truly special place, one of our favourites in Prague, don't miss it!

Your trip to Prague is incomplete without visiting Lobokowicz Palace. The free audio guide tour is one of the best I have ever had. The Lobokowicz Palace gives you a great chance to know all about Bohemian noble families and their lifestyles. They also have original Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts and famous paintings that are shown in many documentaries. Highly recommended
amazing place with amazing story!. Must visit!! use audio guide to explore the story of Lobkovitz family. Really interesting and meaningful

A must see in Prague. Original Mozart and Beethoven manuscripts, a brilliant audio tour (included in the entrance fee), 2 original Canalettos, Infanta Margarita by Velazquez, plus more all without the crowds! So so good.

Incredible art collection. Original Beethoven and Mozart works---and other art amazing to have in a private collection. Good gift shop with some wonderful, inexpensive original watercolors. Fabulous views from private dining room.
Audio tour very interesting. We enjoyed listening to the personal stories and explanations given by a member of the Lobkowitz family on the audio tour

Interesting Collection. The story is interestingly told by family members via the audio guide, and the collection is well presented. We were there early afternoon and although we did not attend the concert it was pleasant to hear it as we wandered round, One tip if you are having lunch there, which was delicious, buy your entrance tickets first, as we found out after we had eaten and went to visit the palace there is a 10% discount voucher with the tickets

A lovely spot. Decided we had too may castles, palaces to see so were selective about our choice.We did a tour that included a concert and we had a delicious, well priced lunch on a balcony that had an incredible view - the tour included a 20% discount on lunch.. We rented the audio so we had a better understanding of what we were seeing.

Not to be missed in Prague!. This is probably the most outstanding thing I did in Prague. The castle is magnificently restored, the exhibitions brilliantly displayed and the audio is extremely good. The whole palace tells a story and the current family is involved and they did an extremely good job of it.Not to miss is the 1pm concert - really good.The restaurant in the palace offers really good food and coffee. It was so good the first time that I went back for more my second day in the castle.Thank you for a great experience and sharing your trials and tribulations with the rest of the world.

Like a fairy tale. Nobody lives as the Lobkowicz family has. You could spend a couple of weeks at the palace, roaming through the different buildings and gardens. Can you believe that this family had its own orchestra? They were patrons to great composers and house rare manuscripts as part of their vast collections. What fun it was to see how the Lobkowicz family lived over the centuries.
Museum telling a story. Contrary to most museums this museum not only exhibits great works of art, but also tells a family's history which has shaped the country throughout several centuries

Nice audio guide. Cafe sells expensive food. Tour is pretty interesting because of the audio guide, some bits were quite funny :) We loved the bit about the poor dog being made to smoke cigars. We took about 1 hour 30 mins to complete it.

Amazing! Zehr Gut!. I have been around the world and all of the reviews are correct - this is a must see! It was the most intimate personable tour I have ever been on! From our seven year old to the thirty/forty something year olds there was something for all! I had a few "eye rolls" when I purchased concert tickets but afterwards nothing but smiles! We capped it all off with an amazing lunch on the terrace! Don't miss this while in Prague! (note: the palace entrance is down Jirska street past the cathedral)

WOW!. LOVED this place! The history is amazing, the story of the family and the house itself is amazing and the riches held inside are unique and truly interesting. You won't find a museum like this in other cities and it's a MUST MUST see.

If You Only Visit One Museum ........ A great deal of the history of Prague and Czech in one building, brilliantly presented. Located in the Castle district, wonderful views from its windows, this has it all.

Fascinating Museum. We learned about the Lobkowicz Palace on tripadvisor and it was one of the highlights of Prague! It was great to learn about Czech history from a family's point of view. They had a huge collection of things. The audio was great since it was done by Mr. Lobkowicz who grew up in the US and easy to understand. We did the short tour of Prague Castle in the morning and this in the afternoon. It worked out perfectly! We would recommend this to anyone! It was interesting to learn of the ties to the Catholic church as well! We also liked going down the hallway to the bathroom had more recent pictures with presidents/dignitaries.
Very interesting place. Take the audio guide, and take your time. Lots of things to explore.
Wonderful. Wonderful tour... small & intimate. Enjoyed outside lunch on terrace
A great story. A great museum for people who don't like museums and a wonderful story.

Just great. Wonderful place, very nice indeed. We did the museum tour accompanied by classical performance that is in offer every day at the moment (always?) and it was great. We used our discount vouchers for lunch at the cafe with a wonderful view of the city.Just to see mozart's own hand on the reworking of messiah was excellent but there's lots of nice art including some truly seminal works by Bruegel.Lovely!

Someone should make a movie of the Lobkowicz family story - you can see it now. The compelling history of the Lobkowicz family history, intertwined with European history, is brought to life through the excellent audio tour of the Lobkowicz Palace and Museum. The tour is chronological to give us a sense of time and place but it comes alive due to the highly interesting human element to the story and through some of the Lobkowicz family members telling it themselves. Someone should make a movie about the family history, about how everything they had was confiscated, and then retrieved, twice! Go visit the palace and see this for yourselves. It is well worth the time. In June 2012, we visited the Palace and Museum and took the self-guided audio tour (our teenage girls were enthralled), attended the intimate chamber concert and had lunch on the café terrace overlooking Prague – one of the best views you’ll ever see. Be sure to make this a stop on your itinerary of Prague. The staff was so wonderful in assisting with our plans, making us feel welcome and providing information of other places to visit in Prague.
Intimate history. A family history that continues to this day. Great audio guide, the best exhibits being original sheet music from Mozart and Beethoven!
Don't Miss this Museum. Hard to find ,but don't miss it! Found this museum on this site and we were so happy we went there. Musicians will love the music section.

a must when in Prague. Went Lobkowicz by chance but was one of our highlights. Audio tour with family informative and interesting. Original scores by Beethoven and Mozart stunning, Canaloto's extaordinary.

not to be missed. Beautiful museum in a historic palace inside the castle of Prague. Plenty of artworks: paintings, two Canaletto's with views of London, drawings by Piranesi, historic weapons, Delft porcelaines and so on. But the most interesting part was the chance to hear the tale of the Lobkowicz family which was dispossed twice of its belongings to have them finally back in recent years. An audio guide is included in the ticket and it allows the visitor to hear many almost moving stories while looking at the stunning pieces collected in the palace. You need 1 hour and half to visit the museum but stopping only at the red spots would cut the time. Finally, some rooms and the cafe' have breathtaking views of Prague (and free WIFI) and you can get a beer from the Lobkowics brewery.

Excellent experience; fascinating story. This little gem has it all: a perfect location at the end of Prague castle; an amazing collection of art, musical instruments and stories and a fascinating history presented personally by members of the family through a carefully arranged audio tour. If you are already visiting the Castle, do not miss this experience.

Magnificent Display of Prague Family. Fascinating Narrative audio by living member of family that played leading role in Praha for five hundred years, patrons of arts, musicians Mozart and Beethoven and moany others. The rooms are wonderfully done to reveal the history of the family and Prague. The best venue in Prague
Fantastic story. What a fascinating story of the Lobkowicz family. Losing everything twice and then getting it back. The story of restoration and always fabulous to see a family's collection.

Well worth the visit. A quick gallop through history about this family. Very interesting and the audio guide was excellent.
There is also a concert in the Palace if you have time. If you haven't, you can still hear it as you walk round!
Wow, this is a cool place. Met a family member of the Lobkowicz family. He told his family story and then we went on a walking tour of the palace. Great story and a beautiful experience.

The art is not that great.. The only good painitng they have is a Canaletto. There is a painting "attributed" to Velazquez but in my opinion is not a Velazquez. I did like having coffee and cake in the balcony. It was rally good.

Unbelievable family museum: a Czech national treasure. Until a very few years ago, the Lobkowicz Palace in the Prague Castle grounds was apparently 'for history buffs only'. No more! This was the best attraction of our Prague visit. This family had been Czech princes for generations: clearly smart, politically astute, very rich, and tastefully acquisitive until fleeing the Nazis (the Lobkowicz of the time being vehemently opposed) and leaving everything. After having their lands and possesions returned after WWII, the Communist regime confiscated them all again. With the fall of that regime, they returned and the present Lobkowicz heir, who it seems had lived all his life in the US, brought his young family back to the palace and has transformed it into a non-profit world-class museum, with his own family narrative to accompany you (the audio-guide is a must). You move from a room of Canaletto's views of London to one of the 5 remaining parts of Brueghel's seasons, to Mozart's original score of his arrangement of Handel's Messiah, all within a perfect restoration of the living rooms for the palace. Amazing! You can buy a ticket for the Palace in combo with the Cathedral (also not to be missed), but it seemed to us that this was only advertised at the museum itself. We were so lucky our walking tour guide the previous day insisted it was the best thing at the castle. It is. Also has a lovely café where you can drink Lobkowicz beer (what else?), look down over the whole city, and enjoy a delicious lunch.They also have restored one of their palaces in the country to exhibit more of their stuff: a definite for our next Czech visit.

Must-Visit Prague Destination. Visited the Lobkowicz Palace on my visit to Prague in June 2012. Located just at the top of the old castle stairs inside the Prague Castle complex, Lobkowicz Palace is the ONLY private property in Prague Castle, and is owned and operated by Prince Lobkowicz whom we actually saw roaming the halls and greeting visitors while we were there. While the architecture and art collection in the palace were alone worth the trip, the Palace has the best view of Prague in the entire city. We had lunch on the terrace in their restaurant, which had both phenomenal views, and great food. it was even reasonably priced!

Pleasant little afternoon concert. They perform (at least in June 2012) every day at 1 pm. When we visited, the performance was of popular classical tunes by piano, flute, and violins. It was pleasant, nice richly painted room. They also have a restaurant with a terrace seating affording a very nice view of multiple red rooftops.

Best part of Prague Castle. Unexpected jewel of a site. Eat at their cafe, listen to the audio tour (in American English by the current heir of the family now living in Prague raised in America giving details and history in a most professional yet informal manner).
Superb Concert. I agree with other reviewers in that the lunch time concert is superb. Excellent musicians and a great selection of music.
Lobkowicz art and history are very interesting. great little museum that you can spend 2 hours in easily. There are also live concerts held here.
art work. loved the art work. had been to Prague but missed it before. was a good collection and very good guides to help you.

Don't miss the piano, flute and viola concert. Magnificient performance by professional musicians. Played 15 pieces by Handel, Bach, Vivaldi and others. A highlight of the day. Both cafes near by are good too.

Not to be missed!. We had explored the Castle quarter, and a local suggested we must visit the Lobkowicz Palace. We decided to go, and i strongly suggest you take the free audio tour, and try to go through all numbers if you can (about 1 hr). The history is fascinating, as the family had all their treasures plundered by the Nazi's, and recently have been restored. The rooms of the castle are so lovely, and their is a room with a manuscript of Mozart's handwriting, and Beethoven as well. Just amazing!

A delightful surprise. We came upon this museum by chance, but found it one of the more interesting ones in the Prague Castle complex: the family has a fascinating history, and the portraits, armory, and music collection all had real treasures. There is also a Breughel (one of the "seasons" sequence) and two fabulous paintings by Canaletto (views of London); all are in a far better, and more pristine, state than you find in most art galleries. The terrace cafe provides a stunning view of the city.

Well worth an hour or two. The palace is beautiful however what really stands out is the audio tour which is full of fascinating facts with different voices, you really get a feel for the family and its history.
the Palace. there were hundreds of tourists here. making it very difficult to get around to see it all. a beautiful place but was very happy to leave. quite expensive

a must visit site. Such an interesting place, learnt aboyut social history of Czeck... through this extraordinary family story. Excellent audio track to accompany visit and do have a coffee in the restaurant overlooking the city.

Fascinating place and family story. A palace within the confines of the Prague Castle, the audio tour tells the story of the Lobkowicz family, whose property was confiscated first by the Nazis, then by the Communists, but returned by the Czech Republic to the rightful owners. Fine art and artifacts.

Best value museum in Prague. Bruegel the Elder's "Hay Harvest" is housed here, and there is a room devoted to manuscripts and instruments of Mozart and Beethoven. The personal audio guide is a highlight because of the family history and it has an individualized appeal. A great value for your money if you are a history buff. It's full of historical anecdotal gems!

The perfect afternoon in Prague. The midday flute / viola / piano trio concert and museum combination ticket made for one of the most relaxing afternoons we spent in Prague. The only thing that could have made the concert more enjoyable would have been more comfortable seating. After the concert a delicious lunch was enjoyed while we took in views of the city from the outdoor patio of the museum's cafe. The museum was made all the more interesting by listening to William Lobkowicz on the audioguide, which was also included in the price of the combination ticket. His narration of the museum's treasures added a personal note that left me wanting to know more about the family's misfortunes during the Nazi and Communist regimes.
A must see.. The collection should not be missed. The music room with Beethovan's handwritten music is incredible. Great outdoor cafe for lunch (in the inner courtyard).
Wonderful concert. The trio (violin, flute, piano) played a wonderful selection of classical music in an elegant room in the palace.

Wonderful museum. Do not miss this museum on your tour of Prague castle. It is well worth the extra cost. The art collection and music history ( including original Beethoven mnauscripts) are beautifully presented

A palace without a throne (or much else). In reading the reviews, I thought I would find a home from 100 years ago, furnished and representive of the time and the status of the family. Instead, I found a very few pieces of furniture and lots of portraits, but nothing resembling a place where people once lived

Great Museum. This museum was by far my favorite in the castle complex. I would suggest not paying to go into any other buildings in the castle grounds and just pay for this one. The price of the ticket comes with an audio guide narrated by one of the family members so you get a personal story with the items you are looking at. I never listen to the audio guides, but this one kept my attention.

Real Gem. Don't miss this small museum. For one thing, the family history is fascinating. For another, there are a number of true art masterpieces in the collection. I think I loved most the musical instrument and manuscript collection. We saw the collection in about 90 minutes and then had a lovely break in the cafe within the Palace.

waste of time and money. Not worth to see if you are not specifically interested in that particular family. There are a couple of important paintings. The rest are things where you can find anywhere. Visit Kafka museum instead. At least it would help understanding old Prague and the master himself. Lobkowicz Palace does not deserve that much compliment.

Peace and Quiet away from the Crowds. We purchased a combine ticket for a lunchtime classical concert, 10% reduction in the restaurant and a ticket for the museum. It was a perfect location to relax away for the crowds of tourists that are i the castle complex. The 1 hour classical concert featuring a pianist, flutist and viola player was excellent and was followed by lunch in the open-air courtyard of the palace. The museum featuring the history of the Lobkowicz family (complete with audio guide) is also recommended

Nice venue for music; count your change at the ice cream stand. We took in a midday concert and then lunch at the palace and it was all fine. The terrace cafe has a nice view over Prague. The downside is the ice cream/gelato stand just inside. The very glib guy behind the glass has the patter down and gave my wife change for a 100 krona when she had given 200. When my wife caught that, he apologised but then gave her five 2's instead of the five 5's coins. She caught that also. Good for her. Beware.

What an amazing treat!. The Lobkowicz collection could have been the highlight of our trip. Each room holds one surprise after another. It is hard to determine which room as the best! There were very few visitors so we were able to take our time in each room without being jostled or rushed. Hearing the family members on the audio guide was an added bonus. We were advised to bypass the castle and go straight to the Lobkowicz Palace, and I am so glad we did. A must see for all visitors to Prague.

Entertaining, informative, very worthwhile. This exhibition sums up the best of Prague. The two hour audio guide was packed with great stories that span the diverse collection. Even our teen listened to the whole tour and recommends it. The comprehensive collection is very well organized from history through portraiture, armory, musical instruments, decorative arts, and more - something for everyone.
Long hike up to palace. Noon hour concert was average. Palace is beautiful. Restaurant looked OK but we only had tea.
history. History of generation of aristocrats - need 90 minutes top

Amazing display of art, weapons, and music!. Having not known about Lobkowicz Palace, we decided to take the tour, and very glad we did. There is an incredible display of portraits of the royal family leading up to the current Lobkowicz's, along with a chronological progression with audio commentary. The stories were well done, and interesting and the exhibit also includes an extensive collection of dishes, firearms (supposed to be the most extensive in Europe), musical instruments/sheet music (including some original scores written by Beethoven and Mozart). We enjoyed our visit so much, we spent all the time we planned on touring Prague Castle in Lobkowicz Palace - and had to come back to the castle to tour the rest on another day! Also HIGHLY recommend the Lobkowicz Palace Cafe - amazing view of Prague from the outdoor balcony tables and the food is excellent!
palace in chezh. chezh palace different in other palace in europe but very very beautiful with their background of sea so dont missed it

Narrated tour of the Palace. We listened to the English narration of the palace tour. This was spoken by the family itself, and engrossing. We spent more time in the Palace than we expected, and it was time very well spent.

One of the best galleries in Prague. The self guided audio tour provided a lot of personal history that linked directly to the people painted in the pictures and amazing manuscripts of famous composers that have been in this collection since they were created . This gallery has a few real art gems in Cannalettos and a wonderful Breughul too? Highly recommended!

art lovers should not miss it. This family massed an outstanding collection of fine art that is a must see. Excellent chamber music concerts each day in castle, lasting an hour. Reserve a ticket in advance.

Best attraction in Prague. Probably because this museum/gallery is privately owned, it has the best presentation of any institution we attended in Prague. Definitely worth seeking out. Far more interesting than the Prague Castle itself.
Wonderful experience. Interesting story about the family and how they got their palaces back...surprising collections.

A delightful gem for those who want culture. After the long climb up the steps into Prague Castle, our first port of call was the Lobowicz Palace. The building was old but inside was lightness and colour. We took a self-conducted audio tour. We could have added a midday concert but after looking at many flyers offering ‘classical concerts’ that were nothing more than extracts for tourists, I was getting a little suspicious about what the offering might have been. As it turned out we did not miss much as the Lobowicz collection is something quite astonishing. The first rooms are full of family portraits dating back to the late 16th century. The family made its mark by being high level civil servants at the court of the King of Bohemia and marrying well into the Spanish Hapsburgs. Over the centuries their wealth and prestige grew until 1939. Then the Nazis took over and sequestered the lot. After the war, the prince came back home, only to see his property disappear again after the Communist coup of 1949. He fled to the USA. Only after the fall of Communism and the passing of an Act of Restitution was the family able to recover what it had lost.In subsequent rooms there are wonderful collections of china, glass, weapons and dogs. It was in the music room that I was completely entranced. During the early 18th century the then Prince was a patron of Mozart. On display is the manuscript of Mozart’s orchestration of Handels’s Messiah in his own handwriting. Next to it are original scores of Beethoven’s 4th and 5th symphonies, again with the composer’s own notes thereon. I had already admired a Lucas Cranach the Elder painting and a Brueghel but I walked into the next room and there were two astonishing Canalettos, acquired when one of the Princes was dwelling in London at the same time as the artist was there. (mid 18th century) One is somewhat familiar with St Pauls dominating the river pageant of Lord Mayor’s Day. The viewpoint of other was Lambeth Palace with the old palace of Westminster in the centre and over to the left a large building about where Victoria station now stands with four slender towers at each corner. There was also a Piranesi Room with engravings of Rome of that artist. We went downstairs to the café had a very pleasant lunch in graceful surroundings. At £20 it was a bit pricey but we paid for the surroundings, I guess.
One of the best attractions in Prague. This unusual museum collection displays chattels from one royal family and comes with an audio guide narrated by a family member. History brought to life.

Lobkowicz Palace. The Lobkowicz Palace is beautiful as well as filled with remarkable history. The cafe has a fantastic menu and each of us had a delicious lunch. The Lobkowicz Family has a wealth of history displayed in the Palace. The audio tour is well done. The information that is given is very informative as well as filled with beautiful music in the background. You will be amazed and thrilled to see all of the Lobkowicz Family history and treasures.

Don't miss it!. Very special place to visit. Take the audiotour (included) and see everything in about 1-1,5 hrs. or do the quick tour with only the highlights. Very interesting story told by members of the Lobkowicz familie with beautiful music in the background. Be aware that in the early afternoon there is almost every day a concert in one of the rooms so it is not possible to visit 2 of the prettiest rooms. Or of course even better: visit the palace ánd the concert. It was not busy in the palace and you have a wonderful view of Prague from one of the rooms. We loved it and found it one of the highlights of our visit to Prague

Fascinating family palace. This palace is part of the Prague Castle complex, but since it is owned and run by a family rather than the state, it is far more interesting than most of the complex. Every day there is a concert at 1pm. The day we attended was the first day of a new program. For an hour, we listened to three very fine musicians play Czech music. We heard a piano, a viola and a flute in various combinations and solos. The room is not large, does not fill up, and the acoustics are good. The museum audio guide, included in the admission price, features a family member explaining highlights of the collections. Aside from interesting family portraits, there are some real treasures. The best piece is the glorious painting "Haymaking" by Pieter Bruegel the Elder. It alone is worth the price of admission, and since this museum is uncrowded it is possible to enjoy it in peace.mThere are also two wonderfully detailed and very large paintings of the Thames in London by Canaletto. The family's history is a window into the upheavals of this century. The current family members worked to regain their property after having lost it twice, once to the Nazis and again to the Communists. They are justifiably proud of their family history of supporting the arts, and of having kept their property in Czech lands at times when other aristocratic families took their treasures to safer countries like Austria or Germany. The cafe is very nice, and the cafe terrace has wonderful views over the city. I would visit this palace any time I went to Prague, whereas omce was enough for seeing the state-run parts of the castle complex.

Best museum in Prague. The best museum we visited in Prague. Great music manuscript collection of Beethoven and a Mozart. Good audio guide and no tourists! Place was almost empty. A rarity in the busy castle quarter.
beautiful. amazing place. well done museum. Use the audio tour.
History and theatre in one place. The changing of the guard was brilliant. A guard drew howls of laughter when he pulled a face.
Lobkowicz Palace. If you only have time to go into one of the beautiful buildings and palaces during a short stay in Prague, this should be the one.
Great History here. Don't miss this while touring the Prague Castle area. Amazing views.

Ever wanted to see how the super rich lived?. This small museum located within the Prague Castle complex was a complete surprise in the best possible way. The admission includes an audio guide narrated by the American branch of the Lobkowicz family - personal stories really make the collections come alive.Who hasn't wanted to go into a castle and see really rich people's awesome stuff? I have and this museum offers you the chance to do it. Family portraits, jewelry, porcelain and personal tokens are here - plus some world class art including a Velazquez and a Brueghel. Round it out with hand corrected music from Motzart and Beethoven and you have a greet small museum!The cafe serves up a hood luck with a beautiful view if you're hungry.
Incredible collection. Art, music, weaponry--it's all here. Tastefully displayed items relating to many aspects of life over the centuries of the Lobkowicz family's patronage. Well worth a visit.

A must see!. My husband and I visited the Lobkowicz Palace after reading the reviews on trip advisor and were not disappointed! The audio guide was really engaging and this visit was one of the few times I listened to the whole thing! We also went to the midday classical concert which I would also recommend.
Excellent tourist attraction. This was really interesting. I would certainly recommend you take the audio tour. Lots to see but the life story behind the exhibits was the main attraction.
Amazing Collection. A brilliant and varied collection of artifacts. Very modern and welcoming and for a music lover, the chance to view some original Beethoven manuscripts was unbelievable!
Magnificent works of art and exciting family history.. Very impressive museum and castle, and a learning experience (via audio tour) not to be missed of the history of such a regal family.

Uncrowded and fascinating. Went here on a cold rainy day and were almost the only visitors. Audio was excellent, and gave a personal family oriented story behind the museum. Some stunning exhibits e. g. Original scores from Beethoven etc. We also attended the 1pm concert which was great. No need to book the A chairs as the room is small. Highly recommended and not crowded.

Great audio guide and the collection is just remarkable!. I came here alone and was looking for a way to pass some time. You'll receive an audio tour right at the entrance and as you walk you'll feel as if you've stepped back in time. It's really well done and I enjoyed it a lot. If you are in a rush or impatient, just go to the red numbered audio segments, since they are the highlight of the tour. I particularly enjoyed the room with all the musical instruments and manuscripts of all the great composers! Afterwards, feel free to have a drink in the nearby cafe to soak in the marvelous view!
A poignant view into old and new Prague. This is a gem in Prague. I was only disappointed that they don't allow photography and haven't yet published a guide book.

The terrace view is the icing on the cake!. Not only is this private museum one of the best attractions in the castle area--just lose yourself in the superb audio tour, and you will emerge feeling like one of the family-- but it has a courtyard cafe and terrace restaurant which boasts a remarkable view of the city. Food is very tasty and well presented, and once you have recharged your batteries, visit their shop which sells many items exclusively produced for the Lobkowicz family.There is an hour long classical concert performed by professional musicians daily at 1pm too. We found this to be a lovely place and wish that we had come here before visiting the rest of the castle complex.

Very interesting and beautiful museum. Additional admission but within grounds of Prague Castle. Wonderful audio tour included in admission. By following history of one family I leaned so much about history of Czech Republic.

Take time out for music. My husband and I bought tickets for a one hour classical music concert last week. We left the crowds on the lane outside to listen to a beautiful trio of viola, flute and piano. In that one hour we were transported to another era.

Neat instrument display. There is one day a month that you can get in for free- I forget the day, but you can look this up. I had no expectations going into the Palace, but the museum is really different. The family had an amazing collection of musical instruments and were patrons to many famous musicians of the time. If you're interested in this type of thing, you might enjoy Lobkowicz Palace. The other displays are nice as well...:)
1pm concerts are best. don't overlook these concerts. they're held in a chamber room with about 75 seats. a delightful way to listen to some top quality classical music.

Nice Collection, good audio tour.. I quite liked this museum. It's quite small and yet has some very good portraits and quite a bit of variation. It is definitely worth a look. I particularly enjoyed the armoury and the small selection of religious artifacts, most especially a processionary cross with rock crystals that was extremely old. Frankly I did also like the audio commentary, I thought it was useful and added a little family colour. The dog portraits did not wow me though.
Excellent Break. Had a guide who showed and explained all history. Great

You'll hate yourself for going. The inside was room after room of portraits of the noble family. I was provided with an audio guide, narrative by William Lobkowich. It was an incredibly nauseating experience for me to listen to William Lobkowich brag about all the money that his family has. "Look at the portrait of my great grandfather. You can see the delicate silver woven in his robe. This is a sign of great wealth". Or "Look at the large emerald ring on my ancestors finger. On special occasions, my mother still wears that ring today". Or, "Its a proud thought for me to know that it was my great great grandfather who made it possible for Beethoven to write the 5th symphony". There was even a section in the museum on their pet dogs which Mr. Lobkowich mother emphasized were "portraits" in that you could tell which dog what which. Seeing that the Lobkowichs are so rich, why in the world am I paying to go inside their palace? I'm making them even wealthier.
Go visit!. The largest private art collection and a great story behind it.

Don't miss the restaurant. We didn't have time to visit the Palace itself - but had a beer and goulash in the delightful restaurant which has fantastic views over the river and Old Town. Try to get a table at the very front. On cold days, you are provided with a blanket to help keep warm while you enjoy the view - and a cold beer!
Interesting. More for story than the artifacts. Cafe was closed for a large party with guide when we visited, shame.

One museum definitely worth the visit. Small, intimate museum converted from a former royal residence. Very enjoyable. Highlights - Amazing gun collection, Beethoven's and Mozart's scores with their own hand notations.

Family ties to an ancient tourist site. It is easy to get swarmed into the masses visiting the Hradcany castle, St. Vitus, and the rest of the museums in Old Prague. Whether it's just for a lunch break or a tour of the best museum in Prague, you must visit the Lobkowicz Palace. The Palace is the ancestral home of the Lobkowicz family dating back to the Middle Ages. Ejected from these holdings, the family was welcomed back to restore the former glory, and make it into a commercial tourist attraction. They have succeeded! Even if it costs a bit more, you must take lunch (and enjoy a bottle of wine) at the veranda over looking the city. It you tour the museum the audio tour feels like the Prince is walking with you. I call this the most can't miss stop in Prague.
beautiful. Fabulous and mostly free to wander around, good coffee shopAs in all of Prague if you need the loo there is always a charge, so make good use when using cafes'

Great new exhibition. The story of the Lobkowicz family is fascinating and we had this palace recommended to us by a friend. The tour gives amazing insight into a special family and for me the highlights were certainly the original beethoven manuscripts and historical instruments - it's only a pity they're locked away in cabinets and not played more often! Can highly recommend this palace to others interested in the history of the Austro-Hungarian empire, culture and this incredibly powerful family.

Quirky collections and the best food at the castle. The first thing we noticed is the effort the entire staff went to share their enthusiasm and welcome us, to the point I would have thought it the beginning of a scam if I hadn't read previous reviews.Audioguides are included with admission.The comprehensive collections gave us an interesting lens on regional history.Our biggest relief was seeing the museum's facilities for families. They stored our stroller while we visited. The restaurant had a working high chair. Two bathrooms had change tables, and one was available for fathers to use (a real rarity here).

Well kept place with an interesting history and really enthusiastic staff.. The palace has a great story behind it. I was there with a colleague, because we were selecting a venue for a press event. The staff was very nice, they provided a private tour and we were amazed by the knowledge of the staff.The palace is I think the only one in the area of Prague castle, that is not owned by the state and the difference shows.You can enjoy simple meal or coffee after the tour.I strongly recomment to visit this place.
Worth a visit. I enjoyed the beautiful well-kept palace and its displays. It was also interesting to learn about the Lobkowicz family who opposed both the Nazis and the communists.
Great. This has beautiful architecture and well worth a visit

A travel to the past with a Nobel family. Somebody collected things. This somebody is a family and the mission lasted centuries. Every collector had a different choice and sometimes the period in history made the choosing. It is a very interesting place to visit.

the Lobkowicz Palace is the top attraction in Prague. We loved the Lobkowicz Palace so much that we visited every day of our five day vacation in Prague. On our first visit we toured with the audio tour. The story of the Lobkowicz family losing everything twice, once when the Nazis took over Prague and once when the Communists took power is amazing. It is the finest private art collection in Europe. There are wonderful afternoon concerts and the terrace restaurant is the best in Prague.

The Palace was a high point of our visit to Prague. This was one of the most interesting museums I have visited. It is very high quality, and just the right size. We signed up for a piano and violin concert which was held in one of the rooms and which was excellent. This Palace is a must-see.
So Cool!. This was a great place to visit! The staff was very helpful. This family has an awesome history. A highlight of our trip to Prague! I would love to see their summer/country residence.

Cooolllddd!!!. Of course you won't miss this visit, but be prepared for the cold if you are in Prague during the winter. It's almost unbearable, since there is absolutely no heater in any part of the Castle.
Lobkowicz Palace. When visiting the Castle of Prague, the Lobkowicz Palace is not to be missed as it really contains the entire and true history of Bohemia

Great story. Well done tour.. Decided last minute (and against the groans of our kids) to go through the Palace after visiting the Castle and St. Vitus Cathedral. Glad we did. Even the kids enjoyed it. Well done tour that doesn't last too long and tells an incredible story.This family has some amazing treasures. Not stuff they went out and bought, but stuff they accumulated and packed away, fully aware of their significance I'm sure. Ever seen actual manuscripts by Beethoven, Mozart, Bach.......? Now you can. Each has a great story attached. Don't doubt me. You better go.
interesting museum. use the headphones and the story of the lob family is told by one of the younger generation. Beautiful rooms and paintings to see aswell as crockery.

a pleasant (small) museum. There are some real treats in here, such as two Canaletto paintings. There is a comprehensive audio tour, a cafe and a shop and, if you like hearing how much this extremely rich and priviliged family have suffered and you want to look at dozens of paintings of their ancestors by 'painters after the style of ...' then you might find this a pleasant diversion (especially when it is too cold for other sightseeing in winter!)

What a treat!. I wasn't sure this was our thing but we had a great time. Not to miss and it helps that it's heated as the rest of the tour around the castle is not and I was freezing!! An amazing history of the Lobkowicz family. The guide via headphones made the whole experience complete. A must if you visit Prague.

... Overrated!. I'm really surprised at seeing all these extremely positive reviews here on Tripadvisor since I still laugh out loud each time something reminds me of our visit to the Lobkowicz Palace. First of all, the entrance fee was really, really expensive if compared to other (much better!) museums around the world: this is not the Louvre or the Uffizi, and the price immediately made me suspicious. We came here mainly to see the Infanta Margarita by Velasquez, and after a few minutes stroll through the rooms we quickly decided to skip almost everything else. Family portraits, pictures of the Lobkowicz ancestors' birds and dogs... who cares?!The audio commentary doesn't focus much on the pieces of art, it mainly talks about the family's history (how great their ancestors were, how much they suffered...) trying to move visitors to tears, which in my opinion was really irritating and completely inadequate. Someone else already pointed it out in previous reviews, which comforts me.This museum certainly offers things of interest (Velasquez, some Canalettos, Brueghel...etc), I'm not denying it, but all in all there's not enough here to justify the high entrance fee. It's a rip-off and having to listen to each tiny detail of the family's "glorious" history really made me feel even more cheated! NOT recommended!
Very nice. Mr. Lobkowitz' s grandson did a guide to guide you through a site so it is fun when he says "...and here my grandfather does this or that.."

Meaningful Museum experience. This was added to our "had to do" list after reading several wonderful reviews about the Lobkowicz Palace. The personal touch of the family members talking about their own history made it so meaningful and relevant. I was almost moved to tears as I looked upon a painting of one of the ancestral homes and listened to the father speak of remembering riding his bike down the hallways as a child.  This truely is one of the most interesting museums I have ever been in.

We nearly didn't do this tour but so glad we did!. Please do take this tour, the fact that it is the family guiding you round the palace by audio headphones makes this tour so fascinating and strangely intimate. Well worth the money.

Amazing exhibition, great presentation and excellent audio guides. I really loved this place, not only for its beautiful palatial interior, but mainly for the amazing collection of art and also great audio guides, where you can listen to the music as well and really feel a very personal touch as if the audio set was actually your personal guide. Excellent and very creative approach to presenting the exhibition. Also their cafe downstairs is great and offering some of the best cakes in town.

This was the highlight of our visit.. We really loved this place. The history is amazing and the commentary from members of the family make it feel very personal and poignant . The works of art are stunning, and for music lovers the collection of instruments and original scores unique!

An unexpected highlight. We stumbled across this museum by accident and were very impressed. A beautiful house with an interesting story and some amazing artifacts - most notably the original Beethoven & Mozart manuscripts.

Excellent add-on experience to Prague's Castle. Very interesting collections of an aristocratic Czech family which were confiscated by the communist regime and restated with their owners after the change to democracy. The daily concerto every afternoon is a pleasant experience.Don't miss the banqueting hall with mythological frescoes from the 17th century. Quite impressive indeed!
Fantastic!. We enjoyed the walk to and from the palace and seeing the changing of the guards.

What a hidden treasure!. The entry fee was pricey, 590 CZK per adult, 531 CZK for an 11yr old. It was 59 CZK to get an audio guide which was really helpful. There are some wonderful surprises waiting for you on this tour and some very interesting history, the 11 yr old loved it the most!

Absolutely breathtaking. Just returned from the visit and i have to highly recommend this place. The whole concept of audio guide, rooms and amazing view .. One of the most beautiful café in Prague (and I am local ;o). Great appreciation to the the excellent staff. Do not miss it when you are staying in Prague!
Well-kept secret. Really informative palace/ museum with unique insight into Czech history as narrated by a Lobkowicz heir.
Beautiful. The audio guide visit is very well put together. Discount at the shop

Pretty & Great Views!. We walked from the Old Town Square to the Palace which took us approx 30mins but it was a lovely walk across the bridge and up the steps, once you wrap up well from the cold. Palace and grounds are lovely and would recommend this attraction. Nice views out over Prague from the front of the palace and great pictures!
Exquisite building. Breathtakingly beautiful, clean and safe so much to see you end up walking with your face upturned constantly
just brilliant. the view is just amazing, though you have to walk quite a bit to actually reach the Palace, but still awesome to see

what a rare kind of exhibition. The Lobkowicz Palace blew me away. Rarely have I seen or visited a more personal exhibition and introduction to history. the Lobkowicz family had to run for exile before he Nazi's reached Prague and left behind everything they had, escaping to the US. follow the family through the centuries, see paintings, and hear real life comments on what happened in which rooms by all members of the family. touching, and something I will never forget. They also have a summer palace - I will return for that.

Nice. This is a Private museum of a family. It tells you the story of their desendent. It's always nice to see the insight of people's life, how they survive the war and all that. some interesting pieces to be seen inside if you like art.
Great collection. A must for any art and history lover!Also you will learn about the fate of one of the most important noble fasmilies in Czech lands.

An amazing glimpse into the rich cultural history through the exquisite Lobkowicz family Collections--amazing!. In the beautiful city of Prague, there are so many places to visit and so much history to indulge in ... but best of all, I believe, is the Lobkowicz Palace and Collections. Situated high above the Vltava River and Mala Strana, gazing out over the Charles Bridge, the Lobkowicz Collections are situated in the Lobkowicz Palace, inside the Prague Castle grounds. From historical portraits to an extensive collection of centuries of weapons, to famed landscape paintings to the astounding musical scores of Beethoven and Mozart -- the Collections are impeccably done and are beautifully narrated on the audio tour. Highly highly recommended. A must-see and must-tour while in Prague!

Great Concert & Museuem. Lovely setting on the hill. Great museum - audio guide really brought it to life - narrated by the family (not short of a bob or two I think). Great concert by a trio - just us and 6 other people. They played quite well known music plus some by Czech composers. Well worth a lunchtime & afternoon visit (loos cost 10CZH - no change given)

Very intersesting but could be better. Did enjoy going around here although felt a bit cheated by the guide (the carry around thing) in English its narrated by the Lobkowicz family who did keep banging on about helping them restore stuff and this did get to be rather irritating (? to Americanised for me). Also the only things they gave details of were the paintings! Lots of other just as if not more interesting things were not mentioned which I and my friend found very unsatisfactory. If they could stop the preaching and give more detail this could be a great place to visit.
What a Collection !!. Great Antiques - guns, swords, paintings and the way restored

Well Worth the Visit. We visited Lobkowicz Palace in September and found the museum tour to be a wonderful historical experience with amazing artifacts. We also attended the classical concert which was a terrific experience. I also recommend lunch in the cafe. Lobkowicz Palace is a hidden gem and should not be missed!
Must Visit. Well maintained and restored to it'e former glory days.
nice morning. Nice museum, very personal story that stays with you. The cafe was very pleasant with great views and the chamber music consert was delightful

Visit and you will understand why it is number 1. This smallish palace has exquisite collections. And the collections didn't come easy after the family had to repatriate all property and belongings lost first in WWII and then to the Communists! They persevered and what they share with the world is a very personal experience and history of their family and their country. Having family members narrate brings it home. The music collection is quite interesting with family connections to Beethoven, Mozart and more. We also enjoyed the afternoon concert and a late lunch in the small cafe. Do not miss this place! It is enlightening and entertaining.

Relaxing. I would recommend this to anyone with an interest in Classical music and History. I would also recommend it to those who might think these outside their interest. This place gives us an idea of the travails of some of the heretofore wealthy and how they have their burdens to carry. The simplicity of the experience is positive in that it enables the least informed of us to enjoy and introduces a view of life one might never think of. The presentation was easy to follow and was insightful.

wow. tha's all i can say. wow!!!. fist of all, this audioguide, included in the price, is worth the trip by itself.do you know the usual audioguides, full of crappy info, technical details and words in latin? this is the exact opposite. narrated by a member of the family, he gives a simple but captivating historical frame, followed by the meaning of each piece to his family. absolutely brilliant, with the right pauses, ... well. you have to ear it to believe it.second, there is no crowd. but, the best places in prague are strangely crowd-less... lidice is another example of that.third, the café-slash-restaurant is amazing. the best views of prague possible, not expensive and very decent food.fourth, and by far not the least. there are velasques there, it's truth, but original bethovan's, handwritten by the man itself, you'll find difficult to find somewhere else...go there... or you'll miss the best of prague....

Considering the history its remarkably complete. On a cold, foggy day in November I wandered into this warm haven not expecting to find these hidden treasures. I was given an audio guide (included in the ticket) and was guided around by the voices of the current Lobkowicz family. Each room has a theme and story to tell. keep your eyes out for the laminated descriptions of all the items in the room which are usually inconspicous in the corner. As I am still a young boy at heart I really enjoyed the antique weapons and armour room and was totally impressed in the music room to discover sheet music hand edited by Mozart and Bethoven! It was nice to discover that this family was the financial backing allowing some of these great musicans the time to create without worrying where their next meal was coming from.I didn't give full marks mainly for 2 reasons. The first was because I left with mixed emotions from the audio guide. I appreciated the personal touch and emotion the current family get accross in the guide however it's a delicate balance not to be disliked for being lucky or convince the listener the hardship the inheritance has cost and is costing. Similar to a friend winning the lottery and then complaining about the price of gas to fill his 8 cars and private plane. I think the guide would be better served with narration by the currator with little exerpts from the family to improve the experience.The other reason for not getting full marks is not entirely fair but it is what it is. I returned to London England a few days later and took my father to the Wallace Collection. This reminded me so much of the Lobkowicz Palace it was uncanny. Both wealthy familys who spent generations collecting wonderful things but the Wallace Collection was a level above and free. It set the benchmark and showed the differece between a 4 vs a 5.All this said and I am just glad there are people still out there who will devote themselves to collecting wonderful things, preserving history, and sharing them with the public.Please go as I'm sure your admission cost is going towards further restoration.

Must See. As someone with Czech heritage, this history packed tour was fantastic, the audio tour well done and gives you a wonderful insight into the Hapsburg days all the way through to now. I will go back again
not to be missed. it was breath taking and the veiw at night was also great

Lovely Soup & Lovely View. On such a cold night on the balcony of the palace the heater, blankets & hot soup were wonderful. The only thing to spoil it was the thought of the armed guard standing below in the chilling night temperatures.

Short on time & want a concise & great museum?. Well if you love history and perhaps are running short on time while at Prague Castle ---- a must see is Lobkowicz Palace. You will find here one of the best Audio Guided tours I have heard. The English version is narrated by William Prince Lobkowicz, his wife Sandra Princess Lobkowicz and his Mother. This story along with one of the most exciting and significant private art collections on public display in Europe, brings so much more depth and reality to what you see and experience in Prague. Truly, this is one museum that you should not miss.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED !!!!

Go here!. And use the English audio guide! It's narrated by William Lobkowicz (b. 1961), who grew up in the Boston area after his family left Prague when the Russians took over after WWII. He gives a very generous and personal guide to the exhibits. The story of his family pretty much encompasses the story of European nobility from the renaissance to the present. My wife and I were almost alone in the museum, even though there were the usual crowds outside in the Castle grounds. Rooms full of family portraits, some fine, some mediocre ((but with interesting histories). Some really nice landscapes and Pieter Bruegel the Elder's "Haymaking", worth a trip by itself. Also, Beethoven's original orchestral score for the Pastoral Symphony (I think). Beethoven dedicated the 3rd (Eroica), the 5th, and the 6th (Pastoral) symphonies to a Lobkowicz family member, Prince Joseph Franz Maximilian, a great patron of his. A great music manuscript and instrument collection. Also fine historical armaments. All in all, a great place to get away from crowds and soak up old European history.
Historic interest. A gread audio tour narrated by a member of the Lobkowicz family. Has a lovely patio restaurant with a panoramic view of Prague.

Truly a must. I don't think I can add much to what others have written already, but if you have the smallest shred of interest in history - this is a must. The collections are eye-popping, and the story told by the owner himself (the English version, he grew up in Boston), is nothing short of amazing. The visit was topped off with a small concert in the palace concert room. One of the decided highlights of our trip.

Truly a gem of a visit. It is probably the case that there are grander family manses to visit, but this one comes with a twentieth century story that is compelling, and most interesting, particularly as it is narrated by family members on the included audio tour. Be sure to see the original works by Beethoven, and try to understand the family tree.
Great views of city. Great views of the city compliment the palace. Plan on several hours to explore this sight.

Beethoven manuscripts!. The Lobkowicz family has a long history, including patronage of the arts, but what really blew my mind was seeing several original manuscripts of Beehoven's music because they were his patrons...

Wonderful gallery; good restaurant. Liked it all! Good artworks in a well-presented setting: given the history this is quite remarkable. Lunch was imaginative and also well presented, with friendly and helpful staff. Not cheap, but that wasn't expected. Good toilets!

Muesem. Best site in Prague
We loved the narration that came with the entrance fee.
Many of the articles in the Palace were beyond the expectations.
The history of the family was very interesting.

Highlight of my trip!. I saw many visitors rushing pass this place. I am thankful to the reviewers here - I would have missed the highlight of my trip had I not checked out the reviews here. The audio tour is fantastic, and I was enthralled by the original scores of Beethoven's 4th and 5th, not to mention the mess Mozart made on Handel's Messiah! The amount of work the family has put in is evident, and they have taken such great care to ensure visitors enjoy this experience. Sadly there were not many visitors when I was there, even though it was a Saturday. Please don't miss this!
Don't miss this. See Beethoven's original MSS. Sufficient reason to go there in itself but some lovely porcelain too. Very good value (especially for seniors) and a good cafe.

A magnificent collection !. This was the only true museum we went to in Prague and it was worth it! The audioguide is excellent being so personally narrated by the owner of the palace and its collections. What a story! What wealth ! The midday concert was only OK., but since we had bought the combo tickets, it gave us a chance to rest our feet. I would have liked to have seen more decorated living quarters from the time period, since this was a lived-in palace at one time, but that was not the goal here. Definitely would recommend a visit here !
Great. The audio guide made it very enjoyable. The family ended up in the US, and it was interesting to hear how the estate transfered.

Loved the Palace! Great tour by owner!. Amazing accomplishment to gather the art and collections of centuries again after the Nazis then Communists stole them. Loved seeing the music scores and instruments and hearing how the collections were restored. For us it was a highlight of our visit to the Castle.
Wonderful. Best laid-out museum I have been too. Fantastic audio guide. Don't miss it!

Fantastic museum, holds the attention very well. Even if you're not a huge fan of museums, the audio guide is well voiced and keeps things moving. They also have highlighted items which you can skip to if you want to get through quickly. There are some very amazing pieces of history which will surprise you. Definitely worth it. If you did it quickly you could get through in 20 minutes, 40 minutes at a normal pace.
Amazing exhibits. Fantastic exhibits including original Beethoven manuscripts. The audio guide was very interesting and helpful.

Excellent artifacts and great views of Prague. Visited this palace to see the artifacts - there is plenty in there including personalised manuscripts from Beethoven and various violins played by famous artists.The free audio guide was very helpful and transformed some of the more staid rooms by introducing interesting nuggets of informations

an incredible family history. The Lobkowicz Palace was suggested to me by my tour guide. It is an amazing account of the Lobkowicz Family from the mid-1400's. The family portraits are worth the visit themselves. I was particularly interested in the musical instrument collection, especially the baroque style trumpets. Something of interest to Beethoven lovers are the original manuscripts of his 3rd, 4th and 5th Symphonies. This venue is well worth the visit.
Great audio guide included and well presented art and artifacts. I liked the whole palace except the rather overpriced cafe for lunch. The audio guide was very good and explained many pieces.
great attraction with interesting history. the audiotour was excellent, also went to a chamber music concert there which I'd recommend
Interestng place. The audio tour is excellent giving you a real history and feel for the family.
Fabulous Museum. Great audio guide which tells the story of the Lobkowicz family, who fled the country and their struggles to get their art collection back.
very interesting. explains a bit of the cronology of the Prague history

Wonderful culmination to extended central Europe visit. We deferred our visit to the Lobkowicz Palace Museum to the last full day of our 16 day trip to Prague, Vienna and Slovenia because of time pressures. I am very glad we did. For us, this wonderful museum, with excellent audio tour, was the icing on the cake. We had recently experienced a review of Czech history at Cesky Krumlov. This prepared us for the extensive collection at this palace. This museum is artfully arranged, full of extremely high quality artifacts, and thoughtfully discussed by the son of the family who are the custodian's of these beautiful things on the audio tour. We were astonished to see several original scores in Beethoven's and Mozart's hands. the commitment to preservation of Czech culture is the paramount mission of this organization. Plus they brew and serve great beer at their in house cafe which, by the way, has a beautiful view of Prague. This was highlight of our trip

Don't miss this Palace!. Easily our favorite attraction on our recent (first) visit to Prague. The museum is full of interesting paintings, musical instruments and original music manuscripts (Beethoven's 5th Symphony, etc.), weapons, and other historical artifacts. The audio tour is extremely well-done and the museum wasn't nearly as crowded as other nearby castle attractions. I would highly recommend you visit the Lobkowicz Palace when you're in Prague!
Well preserved. Lovely to walk around, good views, supposed to be a good museum but did not get there.
Wonderful sight. It's proximity to the city, good to visit and then walk down the streets so narrow and steep. Just wonderful.
Must see. The quality of the exhibits and the audio tour which is included in price of admission is really good. The music manuscripts were particularly amazing.

Wonderful Experience! Don't skip it!. Visiting the Lobkowicz Palace is like visiting your rich friend who shows you his amazing collection of paintings, guns, ceramics, music collection and other valuables.The price of admission is $275 Kc / person and includes an audio tour, 10% coupon for food at their cafe and a $40 Kc coupon if you spend $300 or more Kc at their gift shop.If you have the time to manage it, you can go for a combination ticket of music and the museum for $590 Kc. Having had heard a concert at the Church of St. Nicholas by Old Town Square, I think I would have preferred listening to a concert here at this palace instead. Music in a church just echoes constantly and really, it sounds like musical diarrhea, although, my wife and many other listeners would probably disagree.Anyway, the palace offers a great collection of interesting things and the entire tour took us almost 3 hours, this is not including taking photos, as you're not allowed to. Every room is different and it's like tasting different foods as you tour. It's a fascinating look at what a wealthy family lived like back in the day.The audio tour is not bad, but if I were to say anything bad about this palace, this would be it. I would have preferred more information on the items on the display. I distinctly remember 2 rooms with a great assortment of weapons and armor but next to nothing on their origins. There must have been a hundred different rifles and handguns, some with exquisite artwork / etchings, but no information about them.There are musical scores or papers or notes that belonged to Beethoven that were briefly touched upon in the audio tour and one is left wanting more. Overall an excellent experience, it only needs a professional curator that can provide more to enrich the experience.

OVER RATED. I actually did not find it terrible, but felt it was important to bring attention to several observations. First of all, the reciept from the purchase of tickets for the palace had a statement asking to post a review on trip advisory. Since people tend to respond more if they perceive a positive experience, that is immediately likely to skew overall responses in a positive direction, and I think that can corrupt the usefulness of a site like this.Secondly, the palace is very interesting historically, but on a par with many other sites in this amazing city. There is no such thing as a definite number one in a historically rich destination like Prague. As for specifics, the fixed price lunch available with the ticket was OK, not great.As for the concert, it is total tourist fare. I am a lover of classical music, and I was disturbed by the brief edited versions of significant pieces performed. When I went to Prague 15 years ago, you would find small ensmbles performing complete and interesting works of music. Now these are being condensed to soundbites that give the illusion only of "serious music". Unfortunately, this is now prevalent all over the city. Fortunately, the great music festivals and symphonie orchestra persists.

A Snapshot of History in every room. We went to the lunchtime concert and also toured the palace with audioguides, before having a late lunch on the terrace overlooking the city.The concert was ok, lasts 1 hour. the viola player was the most enthusiastic-I wouldn't do this if you are a serious music buff though.Acoustics were good, and it was a pleasant enough hour.The museum is great-we spent 2 hours going around the palace.Every room has a focus, and my husband particulaly liked the amoury room, whilst I preferred the music room, which had original Beethoven scores,and was very informative about this period of musical history.We liked it because each room was different, and we could get a good overview of many things without spending the whole day inside.We also found out about the family's history, and how they came to regain their possessions after the Revolution. The audio guide is narrated by current members of the family.We then had lunch in the palace cafe, out on the terrace overlooking Prague, which was also very enjoyable.A great day, with plenty of variety-and not many people!

Find it - and go. Some of our maps had the wrong location. After scouring the area around the German embassy in vain, we went to the Prague castle complex, where the large display maps had the correct location. And it was as excellent as most reviewers claim - probably the best site we saw on our nine-day trip. There was a fee, but it was reasonable.

Highlight of our trip. The Palace is a great place to visit in the early morning. We walked up the hill and came through the back entrance and was greeted to a great view of the city as the sun was rising. We were really glad that we purchased the tickets early and were able to walk in and experiance an amazing trip through history. The museum is great with a large variety of items but we were taken aback by the handwritten manuscripts of Mozart and Beethoven. To be a visitor of a family that did so much for the advancement of classical music was an honor!The mid-day concert was very well done and an excellant end to a wonderful tour! This was the highlight of our trip to Prague and we hope that everyone will experiance this wonderful little museum.

Didn't get the raving reviews. This museum was expensive and boring. The audio was informative, but perhaps long-winded. There was not enough here to justify the price. The palace itself was beautiful, but I didn't really take it in because there was so much to listen to. As this place costs about the same as the short castle tour, which includes 4 sites, I couldn't recommend it.
A fascinating insight into Czech history. This is a story of the highs and lows of a family history

Fantastic!. The best museum visited during our seven country jaunt through Europe. Although many attractions say it, the Lobkowicz Palace really does make history come alive. To see how one family influenced history was just amazing.

Don't miss it, especially if you love history!. I thought it was very interesting, where else will you be able to set eyes on an actual music manuscript written in the hand of Mozart and Beethoven. I thought it was wonderful and very interesting, it is owned by the family Lobkowicz and you very much still feel the family presence and what it must have been like for them. Wonderful, wouldn’t have missed it even though we had to pay our tour guide an extra hour to tour the palace with us since guides are not allowed to give tours in the Palace, it is all done via audio tours. We didn’t want to have to go back on our own, and we were glad we did it this way. Lots to see, worth the time and extra ticket price of 275 CZK (about $16.30 USD) fascinating.

fascinating history of prague and incredible family story!!!. this is a city that is central to europe and the lobkowicz family continues to be central to prague. the history of the country and the lobowicz family are intimately intertwined. we thoroughly enjoyed the audio tour narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family. It brought the beautiful artwork to life hearing the stories behind each piece. Among other things, they were patrons to Betoven and encouraged him to make whatever music he wanted. During the 2nd World War,the family left Prague and all their possessions, but were rewarded for their patriotism 50 years later when the Czech Republic welcomed them back and returned their property. You and your family will love this Medieval gem of a city where you expect to see a jousting tournament around every corner and be sure not to miss the Lobkowicz Castle.

A key attraction within Prague castle complex. The Lobkowicz Palace is within the Prague castle complex and one of the key attractions. The palace is now a museum with a private collection of paintings, family portraits, musical instruments and other treasures from the Lobkowicz family. The audio tour was very informative and has a personal touch to it. Expect to spend at least 1.5hour in the museum.

Grossly overrated. This family's tale is not exactly a tragic one. I hope people understand that the Lobkowicz clan is of nobility/royalty who had -- and still have -- a tremendous amount of wealth. Compared to what most people went through during the Holocaust and Communism, this family fared extremely well. I hope no one is coming here thinking they are visiting the Anne Frank House.Overall, there are 4-5 paintings inside that are very nice (one of the Infanta Margarita by Velasquez, some Canalettos), but the palace itself is not exactly palatial and I was not moved by the family's story.It was 12 euros as of a few days ago, so I will be emailing Trip Advisor asking them to update the description (which currently says "free"). Also, the palace has signs in front advertising it, with one banner saying in big letters something like "Voted Best Site in Prague!" -- can you imagine the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay having something similar?

Music Lovers should stop by.... The best part of this mansion turned museum that sits next door to the Prague "White House" (so you will be walking right by it anyways) is the audio tour by the owner. The collection of paintings and armor are not so exceptional, but the narrative weave a story of the family for you. It is excellently designed so you can go through at three speeds - quick highlights, regular tour, and indepth commentary on any item when you wish it. The jewels here are hand annotated scores by Mozart and Beethoven (who were sponsored by the family) and instruments. The music collection was awe-inspiring. Plus, this exceptionally well-run place offers clean bathrooms, working AC, and a cafe with a sweeping view over Prague. oh- and there are concerts daily in the music room! A little jewel.

Great insight into one family's journey in the Czech Republic. We almost didn't go to the Lobkowicz Palace because of the price (I think it was about $30 for 2 adults, one teen, and one child) but we were very happy that we decided to go with the TripAdvisor reviews and go in. The Palace has a WONDERFUL audio tour included in the price of admission that is narrated by the American heir to the Lobkowicz family holdings. The audio tour gave us more insight into this family's experiences in the Czech Republic, flight to America, and return the Czech Republic, than any tour guide or tour book ever could have. It was genuinely inspiring to see how the Lobkowicz family has stewarded their inheritance and is working to preserve their history. The restaurant is also really good....real food, not tourist food.

A very diverse and interesting collection. This was my first visit to an art museum/collection of this type. It is really an impressive collection of items and I liked the way that the tour worked with the audio handsets, allowing you to go at your own pace and only learn about the items that interested you. A few things that I noticed differently from some of the other reviews. First, the tour was not free when I went but it is reasonably priced. Second, the audio commentary throughout the tour was mostly talking about the Lobkowicz family instead of the actual artwork/items. I am not sure if that is normal for these types of tours but it was something that I wasn't fond of. I was there to see the collection and hear about the pieces and not learn the entire history of the family that owns it. However, if you have a personal interest in the Lobkowicz history, then you will love this aspect of the audio commentary. Third, finding the Lobkowicz Palace is not easy. I was confident that printing out my trustworthy TripAdvisor printout of the place with the address and information would be a sure way to find the establishment. I was wrong. Most of the locals have no idea what you are referring to if you ask them where "Lobkowicz Palace" is located. The people who did offer their help in finding it usually (unintentionally) sent me in the wrong direction because no one refers to this place as "Lobkowicz Palace". I even stopped at a nice art shop near Prague castle (0.5km to the south) and the artist who spoke English couldn't tell me how to get there. Luckily, I ended up calling the Lobkowicz on the phone and the staff is very courteous and helpful. It really isn't difficult to find but just don't think that asking the locals will get you there.In the end, I still rate this attraction as very good because it is an interesting tour and even the history of the acquisition (and seizure and subsequent reacquisition) of the artwork is interesting

A Must See in Prague. I visited Lobkowicz Palace on a Sunday afternoon and I really enjoyed my time there.It has a very good collection of paintings and other family possessions.Hearing the story told by Lobkowicz family members made my visit even more interesting.

Don't miss any part of the Lobkowicz Palace. I spent the better part of a full day at the Lobkowicz Palace and consider it a must see (and hear) experience for visitors to Prague. The audio tour narrated by William Lobkowicz is fascinating, the midday concert delightful, the collections and rooms wonderful, the restaurant good with glorious views from the terrace, and the whole story of the families reclamation of their confiscated property very interesting.
Wow!. Fantastic museum. Loved listening to the audio tour! However, after seeing the original Handel's Messiah I lost interest in everything else. I highly recommend this museum.

The highlight of our trip. We visited the Lobkowicz Palace on a rainy Prague afternoon and had a really enjoyable time. We started with the concert (optional extra cost) and enjoyed the popular classical music played by the trio (violin, flute and piano). Then we had a late lunch on the terrace of the cafe - stunning views and great food (if a little expensive). Finally, we toured the Palace and, like many other reviewers, we have to say that the audio guide is brilliant and brings the exhibitions to life. After the crowds throughout other areas of the Castle complex, we appreciated the serenity and space within the Palace.

Excellent museum. Really interesting and well laid out museum. Very good collection of paintings, manuscripts (including original Mozart and Beethoven scores), and other family possessions. Excellent audio tour, with short version if you don't have so much time.

You must not miss this collection..... A bit hard to add anything original to the glowing reviews posted on Tripadvisor.Take the audio tour- my wife and I spent an inordinate time learning this family's story. What makes the audio tour so special is the family members themselves talking and personal recollections of a different era. I guess there could have been a lot of bitterness with all this family went through but this is not at all reflected in the tour.Towards the end of the tour don't miss the story of the two STUNNING Canaletto's- just amazing. Of course the Mozart and Beethoven pieces are a breathtaking part of history.This not the MET, the Louvre or Uffizi but I must say I enjoyed it immensely.

A Star Collection Made Personal by the Family's Story. Just on before you leave the Prague Castle on the way downhill and on the right is the Lobkowicz Palace, a small and very personal museum which highlights the history of the Lobkowicz family who were very influential in Czech history until the Communists took power.
