The family has since returned and oversees this collection of art. Definitely get the guided tour and listen to the story of the family history while viewing family portraits and other collections. The music room was the most impressive with original music by Beethoven and other luminaries of the music world. We saw the current Lobkowicz in the museum - presumably looking after the collection. Don't miss it.

don't miss this when you are in prague. i have a limited appetite for museums and art galleries but this gem in prague is definitely worth seeing. the story of how the lobowicz family had their property taken by both the nazi's and the communists is interwoven with some really fascinating artifacts( like guns , swords and other war stuff) and some artwork. the audiotour which is included keeps things moving.this is an attraction where an art starved wife could keep her husband happy since the whole thing can be done in an hour!! and then you can go for another awesome czech pilsener.

A wonderful museum, a perfect way to end a tour of the Prague Castle. This Palace is a small palace with a collection of paintings and musical instruments. If you visit, Google "William Lobkowicz," take a look at his picture, and then look for him at the palace. He is often there and he is such an interesting and charming man. He is a direct descendant of the Lobkowicz royal family and he seems genuinely passionate about the family's collection. He's from the US, so language is not a problem for English speaking tourists. A trip to the palace is lovely, but if you get 15 miutes to chat with William, it will become a visit you remember for a long time because he really makes the place come alive. I also recommend the audio tour. I am not always a fan of these, but this one is well done and is entertaining. The palace is inside the Prague Castle 'complex.' The Castle isn't one building, but rather a collection of buildings behind a fortress wall. If you visit the castle, you have a variety of options for admission, based on the number of buildings you wish to visit. I don't think that the Lobkowicz Palace is part of any of the Castle packages. Most, perhaps all, of the Castle admission packages include entry to the Golden Walk, which is a main street that goes past a variety of properties designed to show you what life was like in Prague a long, long time ago. Most of the shops are hokey, but there are a few gems, including the jail/prison. The Lobkowicz Palace is at the end of the Golden Walk. So if you get a Castle tour package that includes the Golden Walk, this will lead you right to Lobkowicz Palace, making it an ideal place to end your Castle tour. There is a one hour classical concert every day at 1 pm. I've attached a photo that shows the music performed. I recommend arriving at the Castle around 9:30- 10 am, touring on your own and ending around 12:15. This gives you time to have lunch at Lobkowicz Palace or another cafe, followed by the classical concert from 1- 2, which gives you plenty of time to rest your feet and refresh. After the concert, tour the palace for an hour or so, go back to your hotel for a nap, and then have a fabulous evening meal!

Not to be missed!. An incredible family history told amid a priceless collection. The music room display of Mozart's rearrangement of "The Messiah" in his own hand brought tears to my eyes. This review comes from their Terrace Cafe overlooking Beautiful Prague.Sue Cutler, Rancho Palos Verdes CA

Wow - most interestingly narrated museum tour I've ever taken. It's been a year since our visit, but we still remember the palace, the incredible paintings, the Beethoven room, and most of all, the amazing narrative of the intricate family history. Hearing the story told by Lobkowicz family members made the audio guide all the more interesting. We also met the current head of the family at the cafe, which is part of the palace. The family's deep involvement and care is evident throughout and makes it all a more personal experience. This was definitely our best experience in Prague!

Loved it!. I was not really liking Prague.... being cheated by cabbies, being surprised by the cover charges in restaurants, just generally thinking 'been there, done that, no need to return.' Seeing this collection and hearing the story of the family has made me feel completely differently about Prague and the Czech Republic. The portraits were fascinating. I am not a gun fan, but they were beautiful - pieces of art. And the music room, goose bumps. And I have a tin ear. But, the idea of what was created by the 7th Prince was amazing.So, go.

If you could only visit one place in Prague, this is it!. We were 8 adults and 1 child. There wasn't one person that was not touched by the family's personal audio presentation. Our grandson said Prague was the very best of five countries because of the Lobkowicz palace. Truly exceptional art and artifacts. Thank you Lobkowicz family for doing such a wonderful job and sharing your palace and story with us.

Beautiful and engaging. Like what was said - the audio guide is the highlight with personal stories told by the last few living members. In some rooms where there are too many displays to discuss, a returnable log is present with a short brief description of the items. It is amazing the story of one family and it makes you wonder what is the story behind that of your own. I would rank this before the prague castle and on par with St nicholas church in the lesser quarters.

A good way to learn about the history and rulers of Bohemia. With interesting paintings and manuscripts from the likes of Mozart and Beethoven, this is an interesting attraction. The best part about it is the audio guide narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family describing the history of the family and their place among the rulers of Eastern Europe. There is a concert at 1pm (nice, and not too long) and combination tickets can be bought in advance online for a discount.

A unique & personal into the finest collection and palace in Prague. The Lobkowicz family's personally narrated audioguide tour of the Palace's collection will reveal not only stunning works of art by Breughel, Canaletto and Velazquez but also give you a real insight into the impact of the Velvet Revolution and the huge efforts made subsequently by the Lobkowicz family to put their art collection back together after the overthrow of the Soviet era,The tour also tells how the Lobkowicz family patronised some of Europe's greatest composers thus allowing them the time and space to compose some of the best known and loved pieces of classical music, it also reveals the family's love of dogs and other personal and historical family anecdotes.And last but not least the views of Prague from the formal rooms and terrace are the very best in the city.

History becomes alive. For having lost their possessions 2 times, the Lobkowicz family has reassembled a wonderful collection of family treasures from the centuries past. Some items were a complete surprise to me! The audio tour was spoken by the Lobkowicz family members, making you feel welcomed, as if speaking to you as their personal guest. A must see for everyone visiting Prague.

Who would ever have thought that an audio tour could be so moving. Wow - I've been to a lot of museums, this is the only one that has ever had me on the edge of tears (seriously - don't wear mascara!). The audio tour is given by the grandson of the prince who lost his property to the Nazis and then to the communists, it's really personal and truly moving. The other remarkable thing about this museum is how empty it is (that really adds to the intimate feel) - I visited right after the concert when you'd expect it to be at its most busy, it wasn't overcrowded even then, and by the time I got to the end it was completely empty (other visitors must have rushed through).The combined concert and museum ticket (audio tour included) was the equivalent of about $30, remarkable value. I did enjoy the concert (I can't say how objectively good it was though, I don't know anything about classical music), but if your time in Prague is very limited, just see the museum, which takes at least a couple of hours to see properly.There's a nice cafe and a small gift shop which sells replicas of some of the family's jewelry, that's such a good idea, I wish it was bigger so I could pick up even more unique stuff whilst supporting a wonderful organization! You get a discount at both the cafe and the shop if you have a ticket.This was one of the highlights of my trip to Europe - I love TripAdvisor so much, I probably wouldn't have found this place without TA!

excellent. With its friendly staff , it is definitely the best museum in Prague. It is such a splendid museum where you can see the most unique manuscripts and paintings as well as the interesting history of the Lobkowicz family. Very close to the cathedral and a must visit museum in Prague.

Lobkowicz Palace is a Must-See in Prague. The palace is set at the lower end of the castle grounds and it was easy to find. Along with St. Vitus Cathedral, it was the highlight of the Castle district attractions for me. My daughter and I bought the combo ticket for the Lobkowicz Palace and the Short Tour of the Castle attractions.This palace contains the private collection of the Lobkowicz family (mainly art, but also armory/porcelain/music etc.). The free audio tour is narrated by various family members who do an excellent job of bringing the rooms and what you are observing to life. The family’s patronage of Beethoven and Mozart and the original music scores signed by these famous composers gave me goose-bumps, as I listened to those particular snippets of music on my audio-guide.I would definitely recommend a visit to the Lobkowicz Palace if you are going to visit the Castle area in Prague.

Beautiful - amazing family story. This is a beautiful palace with priceless collections. But the most interesting and unique thing about this palace (as there are so many palaces in this part of the world) is the Lobkowicz family story and how it relates to the palace. Often these sites are impersonal, but the Lobkowicz family and their story make it very tangible. I'll leave it to them to tell it, though!

Lobkowicz Palace was beautiful and educational. I learned so much about the Czeck Republic's history at the Lobkowicz Palace! The audio guide was actually really helpful and provided interesting and relevant information. The Nazis and Communists stole everything from the Lobkowicz family, and they got it all back twice! My personal favorite part of the palace museum was the music room. This family has been associated with many famous composers including Gluck, Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven. Beethoven dedicated his Fifth Symphony to the Lobkowicz family! The Lobkowicz Palace is rich with important culture and history. It is a must see in Prague!

a must see. Located at the castle area in Prague, this palace is a treasure to see. Family history is intertwined with the European history and is told by prince Lobkowicz himself in an audio tour. Portraits become alive and classical music carries one forward through the magnificent rooms. Wonderful!
well worth the visit. Very interesting and unique. I especially liked the audio guide.I highly recommend the visit.

Greatest story not heard of!. The Lobkowicz Palace is a beautiful place with so much history. The story of the family's history is absolutely trilling. The collection on display will captivate any audience; from the regal portraits to the breath-taking views of the city, the Lobkowicz Palace is a must see while in Prague.

Interesting summary of czech history. just before entering the castle area, from the river side, you find this palace.
the interest is not really in paintings or furniture or rooms, but mainly in the history, that you easily follow with the audioguide they provide, of this family whIch mirrors the history of Czech republic.

The Fairytale that is the Lobkowicz Palace. The regal beauty of the palace is only matched by the kindness and personability of the owners, the Lobkowics family. My study abroad group had the immense pleasure of talking to the always busy Prince William Lobkowicz or Mr. Lobkowics as he is called in Prague (who did away with titles in past years). The many paintings and exhibits are truly surreal and the classical music concert we got to enjoy was nothing short of spectacular. Theirs is a rich history with many hard times as well as grand times had by their many clearly laid out ancestors. I espicially liked the artillery room but the whole history of the family shown through their extensive artwork is an awesome sight to see. The family does many non-profit benefits, and their entire palace would surely be free if they were not the sole responsible party responsible for the upkeep of their many properties which is very expensive (50,000 a year just to maintain one stucco ceiling in the concert hall). I definetly recommend this to any tourist traveling near it is a great story with many cool exhibits to see for any age.

A gem in the centre of the crown that is Prague. When visiting the amazing buildings that make up the Prague castle, ensure that you stop and enter the Lobkowicz Palace.The Palace is architecturally magnificent, but what makes this visit so momentous is the story behind the Lobkowicz family that dates back for centuries. William Lobkowicz and his family are responsible for the audio tour that takes you from room to room in the palace. They explain the history and patronage that the family under took over time that culminates in the visitor being able to view original Mozart, Haydn and Beethoven manuscripts, study in detail Rubens, Canelletto and other masterpieces and many more exquisite artefacts.The recent history of the family at the turn of the 20th century through to current times explains the conviscation of their property and lands only to be finally restituted after the end of the cold war and the Czech Velvet Revolution in 1989.Although I live in Prague,I never fail to enjoy a trip to the Palace with friends and family that visit. For me it is the highlight of any tourist trip to Prague - enjoy!
History made come alive!. Great museum! Audio guide creates most of the experience make sure to get it.

Felt Cheated. We visited the Lobkowicz Palace on April 30, 2011 (Sat). We wanted to experience the entire Palace and the concert (realizing that we were going to be there on a Saturday afternoon and it could be busy) so we decided to go through the official site and book everything ahead of time so that we would be assured of seats at the concert and so that we wouldn't have to stand in line waiting to buy tickets. With our ticket confirmation number and print out of the credit card transaction in hand we left for Prague. When we arrived at the Palace we noted (as expected) that things were quite crowded. Mistakenly, we got into a short line to receive headphones and when it was our turn and I showed our reservation to the clerk she explained that I would have to stand in line at the cashier's desk. So we got into line at the cashier's desk and waited. When it was our turn I showed our reservation number for the combination package (concert and palace). This clerk said that "Yes, you have purchased a combination package, but I cannot help you. You need to walk back out to the front of the palace to the entrance where you will find a desk where a clerk has your combination tickets and then come back here to my desk with those tickets. IMAGINE HOW MUCH TIME WE'D WASTED BY NOW STANDING IN LINE BUT THIS WAS JUST THE BEGINNING!Next, we went back out to the front of the palace and found the desk (across from a man selling ice cream). BUT NO ONE WAS AT THE DESK! Behind the desk there was a window with two security people and we wondered if we should ask them if they knew anything about the tickets. Finally a woman comes out from a door behind us (next to the ice cream stand) and we explain that we have purchased a combination package. I show her the print out of the reservation number and the transaction and it takes her some time to understand (as if she is doing this for the very first time in her life). Finally she says "Yes I think you have a combination package let me get your envelope." So she finds our reservation on her information sheet and hands us our combination tickets. "Please go inside the palace and first show your entrance tickets to the cashier." WE HAVE ALREADY STOOD IN TWO LINES AND THEN WALKED BACK OUT TO THE ENTRANCE AND WILL NOW HAVE TO STAND IN THESE SAME TWO LINES ALL OVER AGAIN BUT THAT'S NOT ALL!!When we finally get our real tickets and our headphones we are told that we will only be able to see half of the palace because today there is a special event. So, the bottom half of the palace is closed to the public. "Then please refund half of the price of our tickets," I said. "I'm sorry we cannot do that because you have purchased a combination package, " she tells us. "Then can we come back tomorrow to see the other half then?" I ask. "No, because your ticket is a discount ticket," she tells us.MORAL OF THE STORY: "DO NOT BUY THE COMBINATION PACKAGE. IT IS MORE TROUBLE THAN ITS WORTH AND YOU MAY GET RIPPED OFF LIKE WE DID."

Tour & concert combined. We decided to visit Lobkowicz Palace after seing the high ratings on Tripadvisor. We got a combined ticket for enterance, audio guide (definitely a must) and a concert. The audio guide has been prepared perfectly. Overall this was a pleasant experience and you learn a lot about Check history. If you're a music lover, you'll be very excited to see original scores by Mozart and Beethoven. We spent more than 2 hours there and would even stay more and try their cafe if we had some more time.
must see. great history and listen to entire audio tour good info. dont miss cafe, sit on the open porch and have the apple studel it is the best !! my dad and I went back 3 times for it..

Amazing. So much too see. My wife and I took the abbreviated audio tour and skipped along due to time. I wish I could have heard it all. An amazing tour that is very well done. The items in the collection area amazing. If you don't get chills looking at Beethoven and Mozart's handwritten works, I have nothing for ya.

Great experience. I thoroughly enjoyed my time at this museum. The staff were very friendly, despite me being utterly confused. I entered at a time when a large Italian tour group arrived and I was mistakenly given an Italian audio guide and ushered upstairs without buying a ticket. I recognized the mistake and went back down to get a ticket and everyone was very friendly and forgiving of the situation. The museum itself was a wonderful exhibit of the art and artifact collection of the Lobkowicz family and the fact that the audio guide is so personal to the family is just great. I really enjoyed myself here.

Amazing Family (Hi)Story. We went to the Lobkowicz Palace firstly for the Concert ... but at the end, the combination of Concert + Museum visit was quite appealing in terms of program and opportunity to see the whole building, which has per itself, wonderful facades.The Concert was more than worthed : piano, violin and transversal flute enchanted the room and made us travel back in time. The Museum was not only a unique opportunity to enrich our culture about Prague and the Lobkowicz Collection, but also to get acquainted to an amazing life story of the Lobkowicz Family.I strongly suggest all Prague Visitants to have this experience!
Nice Stop in Prague Castle Visit. Very interesting family history, varied collection of art and artifacts, and nice views. We thoroughly enjoyed the well-authored audio tour.

Excellent choice. I had read up on place to visit on Tripadvisor before leaving for Prague. L.P. was brilliant, really informative and very interesting. The Audio tour is a brilliant idea and it was a very respectable cost to get in to the Palace.

A very lovely place!. I decided to go see the Lobkowicz Palace with a couple of friends when we were at the Castle. From what I read here on Trip Advisor, I had pretty high expectations of this museum. Let me tell you, I was not disappointed. At all. The collection was outstanding!The ticket cost me 200 Czech crowns and a high quality audio was included in the price. The staff was very nice and helpful.I highly recommend visiting this place! :-)

If you do one thing in Prague take the audio tour. We had a great lunch on the patio overlooking the city then did the audio tour with our boys (8 and 11). We all loved it. I was surprised at how much the boys enjoyed it. They are both high energy...

My favourite place in Prague!!!. On my second visite to Prague, it was the first place to check on. Museum is nice. Actually, first time to see the short movie in the end of the tour, I cryed. Don't know why. They have a good collection, and there is a feeling, that they all: the owners and the stuff love and care for the place. But my favourite place is the Lobkowicz Cafe, not Palace. From the gallery you have a view of historical part of the city. You can see Charles Bridge, National Theatre, St. Nickolas and many other buildings. I usually order hot wine, it's not glintvein, there is no spices in it, but it's the best drink on a raini cold Thursday!

Wonderful find. We wanted to go to the lunch time concert, then found we could buy a joint ticket for that and the museum. We were so glad that we did! The concert was good but the museum was wonderful. We looked round most of it before the concert then the remainder, including a second look in the amazing music room, afterwards. To begin with the commentary seemed like a rather over- the- top family history but it gradually came to life and we realised just how important this dynasty had been in Prague's history, and what wonderful treasures they had owned. The Cannalettos and the Breughel would alone deserve a visit and I would recommend it to anyone. We also had a bowl of soup in the restaurant and did not find it at all over priced, unlike a previous reviewer. The view was great from the terrace,but mainly because in winter there were no leaves on the trees!

No wonder this is attraction #1 in Prague. This was the most captivating and memorable audio tour I've taken. The story comes alive and you're not just looking at portraits of people from so many years ago, but know the connection between each of them. Museum is arranged perfectly, narration is so interesting that you don't want to miss a single number on the list. Loved the armory, music and bird rooms. Do not leave Prague before visiting!

Lobkowicz Palace - Jewel in the Crown. Whether you already plan a trip to Prague Castle or just want to see a magnificent piece of Czech history, do not miss the Lobkowicz Palace. Set at the lower end of the castle grounds it was easy to find (even worth the trip up the castle stairs, on its own). The palace tour is one of the best audio tours in the city, well narrated and self paced. You can see and hear the dedication the Lobkowicz family has put in to restoring this beautiful, historic site. Unfortunately we missed the concert, however, I definitely plan to visit the palace again. I can only imagine the restaurant view in the spring. I can hardly wait.

Excellent. I followed the recommendation to see this museum because of Trip Advisor. Excellent choice. The Lobkowicz family had so much influence in Prague. It is a separate entrance fee from Prague Castle but includes audio with is worth it. We followed with a nice lunch at the cafe in the museum as well. The history of this family tied into the Loreto when we visited there the next day. There are daily concerts in a hall within the Lobkowicz Palace that last an hour. We chose not to do the concert which was an excellent choice. While everyone was listening to the music, we were one of three couples touring the museum yet we could hear the beautiful music while walking around the museum. Concert was at 1 PM. When concert gets out the cafe fills up and it is not large so we headed to the cafe just prior to the concert ending. Cost of lunch at cafe very reasonable. Tables on outdoor deck have nice view and they provide blankets for chillier days.

Lobkowicz Palace is simply a MUST. I walked through the Lobkowicz Palace in the Prague Castle, listening to the recording from the owner. The recording and the palace were jam packed with history and interesting information. The entire collection is the private collection of the Lobkowicz family, which makes the visit even more personal....not to mention, you will walk through the palace with the voices of the Lobkowicz family in your ear. This was just absolutely fantastic and you cannot miss it!

Don't miss this corner of Prague Castle!. When you go to Prague Castle, be sure to head down the hill to Lobkowicz Palace. The palace is within the castle complex, but still privately owned by the Lobkowicz family. The palace requires a separate admission, but is well worth the price. It is a most surprising and eclectic museum, with treasures I didn't even know existed, like two original Canalettos. If you’re tired, and you don’t quite recall anything in Venice looking like that, the signs gently in form you that they’re views of London. Canaletto’s London period was certainly new information for at least one of us.Rarest of all are two manuscripts in the music room, amongst a rather impressive collection of instruments – the first is an original hand-written Mozart score for his rewrite of Handel’s Messiah. Neither of us realized that Mozart had done such a thing, and we haven’t yet found a recording. but it The work was commissioned by the Lobkowicz family because baroque music was quickly going out of favor and they wanted Handel’s work punched up a bit for audiences of Mozart’s time. The second treasure is the first edition of Beethoven's 4th & 5th symphonies, with Beethoven's original annotations. There are undoubtedly other treasures among the collection of manuscripts, but these were the most astounding to us. No, you can’t touch the manuscripts.If bird art or dog art is your thing, go downstairs. There’s something for pretty much any museum-lover in this place.Lobkowicz Palace offers a daily concert of Czech classical music. Admission to the concert includes admission to the museum, with the best audio guide I have ever encountered. Good-quality headphones are provided, rather than ear buds or just a stick you have to hold to your ear. Also included is a discount coupon for the palace cafe. Even if you don't visit the museum, the cafe is a good choice for lunch. I tried the lunch special of goulash followed by cheesecake. My husband ordered a rather unusual ham and brie sandwich, served with potato chips and coleslaw. Everything was good, and the cafe was quiet and smoke-free.

A Little Gem with a Great Audio Tour. The audio tour narrated by the owner of the palace gives a fresh, intimate view of the life his family led in this place. Moreover, if you like classical music, being able to gaze on the actual manuscripts Beethoven wrote and Mozarts edits of Handel are a real treat.

Beware - cafe outragously expensive!. The museum is undoubtedly lovely but entrance is expensive (but you can save money by taking a Castle ticket for a discount) compared to equivalent museums around the world. And the cafe is gob-smackingly expensive for what it is - 95k for very small and luke warm latte or small beer? Come on guys, that is so over the top - I felt ripped off - the view was not even that good!

a must see - even if you only have 1 or 2 days in Prague. This palace houses the private collection of the Lobkowicz family (mainly art , but also armory/porcelain/music etc. The free audio tour is expertly narrated by various family members. Their very personal approach really brings the collection to life and will quickly enthuse even the most luke-warm museum visitor. The family's involvement in the lives of Beethoven and Mozart, and the associated museum exhibits are especially remarkable. Don't miss the restaurant, provided you can get a seat out on the terrace, with spectacular city views . The Palace is located just inside the lower grounds of the Prague Castle and even if you listen to all the audio stops will only take an hour or so.

My favorite Prague attraction - a must see!. When asked about my week in Prague, this is the first thing I tell everyone about - it was my favorite memory of an overall amazing trip! I'm not usually fond of audio tours in museums, but this one was really different. The stories told by members of the Lobkowicz family really made the art come alive. I'm often one to practice "speed tourism" and breeze through exhibits, but at this museum, I savored every story. I did like that they had a "short version" to mark those key don't miss pieces for those short on time, but it is well worth it to listen to all of the narrations. The fact that the audio tour is included in the admission price is a bonus. And the view of the city from the Cafe downstairs is amazing. If you are pressed for time at the Castle, see the St. Vitus Cathedral and the Lobkowicz, and then see the other sites if you still have time. I just wish I wish I would have had some more time in the Czech Republic to see the Lobkowicz castle in the country. I guess that just gives me a good excuse to return.

A definite "must see". The story of the Lobkowicz family is a fascinating one and hearing the history narrated by family members is an amazing experience. The palace houses an impressive art collection as well as original Mozart orchestral manuscripts. Since it is a self-guided tour you can take as long as you like studying the collection. Lunch is available at the palace restaurant and if you are lucky enough to get a table on the balcony you can dine with fabulous views of the city.

Definite stop!. We highly recommend the Lobkowicz Palace as a top priority in Prague, even if you only have a couple days to see all the sights there. In addition to enjoying the first-class art collection and audio tape, we had the wonderful opportunity to spontaneously meet William Lobkowicz who happened to be in the hallway at the entrance where many contemporary family photos are shown. He is enthusiastic and personable, just as he is on the narrative on the tape. Before we toured the palace, we had lunch in the Terrace Cafe. The food and atmosphere are excellent, and it is a great place to revive after the exhaustive crowds in the castle.
Great!. Took about an hour, but was well worth it. Some great history and items to see.

Wonderful experience. Lokowitz Palace was a true high light of our Prague Castle experience. Their support of such musical geniuses as Gluck, Mozart, Handel, Beethoven (paid him a stipend his whole life) and Haydn was remarkable. I highly recommend the Audio recording - not something I usually do but in this case it was short. to the point, interesting, and full of invaluable information. If you can allow the time, don't miss this Palace. We had 45 minutes - and those minutes have left an indelible mark on our memories.

Lobkowicz Palace - A must-see in Prague!. What a charming palace, much more interesting than the castle itself! It's located on the right hand side, towards the exist of the Prague Castle, so beware not to miss it. Highly recommended for its treasures, atmosphere and Hollywood-style stories narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family themselves! One tip: don't forget to show at the entrance the Prague Castle tickets so that you can get a discount (CZK75/pers.)!

Not to be Missed!. The Lobkowicz Palace is not to be missed, not only for the attractiveness of its displays, but also for the romance and charm of the story of its recovery and resurrection by the Lobkowicz family. The idea that a Boston real estate agent can return to his family's homeland and revocer the family's past and heritage and then create a museum-- for museum the palace undoubtedly is-- is almost pure Hollywood. Throw in his grandmother overhearing two Nazi officers on the train discussing the planned German takeover of the remaining independent, rump part of Czechoslovakia left free after Munich and getting the family out of the country as the Germans march in and their return after the war only to flee again when the Communists took over the country in 1948, and it is truly a fairy tale. The coup de grace is when you meet Mr. Lobkowicz (they do not allow titles in the modern Czech Republic). He is a very approachable and down to earth person. We also enjoyed a stimulating conversation with the Asst. Curator who turns out to have been born in Kansas.However, the true value of the experience lies in the exhibits. I will not try to recount all that is there-- there is too mnuch for that. Suffice it to say that, even if nothing else was there, the Brueghel painting ("Summer" in the seasons series), the musical manuscript with the emendations in Mozart's own hand, the original handwritten Beethoven symphonic manuscript and the most amazing early gunpowder arms collection would be a "cannot miss it" by themselves. All in all, this place is a gem and well worth the stop. By the way, the entrtance price includes portable audio recorders in a number of different languages with explanations of the faimily's history, the provenance of the objects you are viewing and other matters.Jules Moskowitz, Prairie Village, KS, USAWe visited in July 2010

Unexpectedly rich and moving. For all students of history through painting, drawing, ceramics, and especially music this is a dramatic and beautiful family history in one place and one palace. A Prague highlight.

The unexpected highlight of our visit to Prague. We entered Prague Castle from the back gate (farthest from the Cathedral) and wandered into the Lobkowicz Palace almost accidentally. So glad we did! This museum tells the story of a family whose heritage and history mirror that of their country. The art, music manuscripts, porcelain, weapons, and other objects are interesting in themselves, but as part of the Lobkowicz family's story, they are fascinating. I usually NEVER use audio guides, but here it is an essential part of the experience to hear William Lobkowicz and others speak of the meaning of the objects for the family's and Czech history. As an example, as you stand before a portrait of a female ancestor from the early 1600's, William describes how his mother still wears a ring shown in the painting. There's a concert of Czech classical music daily at 1pm, and a terrace cafe has excellent food and fabulous views. We just loved everything about this place.

Don't Miss This. Prague Castle is on all of the tour highlight lists but the real gem of this site is often missed. Right next to the lower gate, where most people exit the castle complex, is the best museum in Prague. Lobkowicz Palace is the family home of an old noble family who lost it all in World War II and again under the Communists. With the Velvet Revolution in the 90s, the family (who were now living in America) sought restitution. The audio tour narrated by the family members is a wonderfully told story. But it is the selected items from their restored collections that shine. For music lovers, it is a thrill to see the original manuscripts of Beethoven and Mozart (especially his orchestration of Handel's Messiah). Art lovers will thrill to Breughtel's Haymaker - yes, the one that is in all the art history books. It's wonderfully restored and beautifully displayed. There is just enough of each type of treasure to satisy the enthusiast but not too much to bore the average tourist. If you're in Prague, do not miss the Lobkowicz Palace.

This museum makes Prague history come alive...you will feel it!. What a joy it was seeing the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague yesterday. Along with the church, its the most worthwhile thing to see in the Prague Castle, if not all of Prague. Hearing the voice of William Lobkowicz, the real live decedent from the USA, on the audio guide made it very personal and touching. He describes the paintings and history of his family and their collections including original scores written by Beethoven's own hand, (the Lobkowicz family was his patron). Hearing their personal story of the Nazi then Communist takeovers and their eventual return in 1989, makes this a beautiful educational experience and story: A testament to the artistic sensitivities, the strength and fortitude of the the Lobkowicz family and the Czech people. The palace itself is an Architectural gem (and the cafe is a great place to have a beer). Even our 13 year old son and 15 year old daughter were moved by it. The Palace makes history come alive.

Prague's Lobkowicz Palace - a must for culture and history. Prague's Lobkowicz Palace has one of the world's greatest private art collections, original manuscripts by Beethoven, Mozart and others, antique musical instruments and more. But most of all it is the history of a family that for centuries was one of the greatest patrons of musicians and artists in Europe. This fascinating but little known slice of Central European history is sensitively organized (and the excellent audio guide narrated) by current members of the family. It should be part of anyone's visit to Prague.

Worthwhile paying extra to visit. Great historical story and amazing what one family has done to preserve their heritage. Highly recommend this attraction - particularly for the incredible music scores.

This is the jewel of Prague castle that should not be missed.. This is a wonderful palace situated at far end of Prague castle that has been the residence of an important family in Czech history for roughly 500 years. The family was the patron of Beethoven and Hayden as well as playing an important political role in Czech history. Some members of the family also collected extraordinary paintings, that are simply breathtaking. This is all beautifully explained in a wonderful audio tour that is narrated by the American heir of the family. Their country home about 45 minutes outside of Prague by train, is equally worthwhile. Together, the 2 places, the city home and country palace provide a unique and wonderful introduction to Czech history and culture that should not be missed. This is the very best of the attractions at the castle.

A serene haven on Prague's busy Castle Hill.. We had many great experiences in Prague. The best was the Lobkowicz Palace on Castle Hill. Don’t miss this beautifully run museum, which is not included in the Prague Castle ticket package. Contemporary members of the Lobkowicz family provide the highly personal and informative recorded narrative that informs the palace tour (allow at least one hour for the tour.) Their grandfather abandoned hundreds of years of princely possessions when he fled the Nazis and later the communists, settling in the United States. For the past twenty years, his children and grandchildren have worked with the Czech government to reclaim their patrimony and to share it elegantly with visitors. Their story is moving and their holdings are remarkable. Our experience was heightened by a one hour musical performance in an elegant salon (separate ticket required), a great, very American cheeseburger in the terrace restaurant with a postcard view of Prague below and the well-curated museum shop.

Fascinating Palce, well presented.. We viisted the Lobkowicz Palace on June 2 , and were delighted with the experience. The Audio is narrated in American English by William Lobkowicz who was born and raised in the US after the family fled the Nazis first, then Communism after WWll. His personal comments about the portraits, family heirlooms and amazing connection to Beethoven and Dvorak made the visit come alive ,

The unexpected highlight of Prague. Take time to go to the truly stellar Princely Collection at the Lobkowicz Palace while you're at Prague Castle. It's completely worth the diversion. It was excellent- original Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts which gave me chills, terrific art, and a wonderful story to accompany it all. And lunch in the cafe was a dream: delicious food, divine dessert, and a view to die for.

What a Treat!. Thank you to the Lobkowicz family for sharing with everyone the story of thier family's history. This was truely the hightlight of our recent trip to Prague. We especially enjoyed the narration by the family telling the story of each room and the incredible items they have restored and place for everyone to see. Bob and Chrisytne Olson

Fascinating look at Bohemian history through one family's story. If you do one museum in the Hradcany complex, make it this one. Every object carefully selected for its contribution to the story of the Lobkowicz family, who narrate the exellent audio tour guide. My children enjoyed it too (aged 10 & 13) which is quite a feat. Highlight for me was the score and parts of Beethoven's 5th & his opus 18 string quartets. Worth every penny.

If you do nothing else in Prague-this is your destination. A true hidden gem! The Lobkowicz family does an amazing job audio guiding you through their Palace, filled with Art, music and beautifully decorated rooms. They tell you the stories about their family members, and how they lost their fortune twice. If you are a music lover, the Price was the patron for Beethoven, and the 5th symphony was dedicated to him. Skip Prague castle- this is your destination. The best tour of our trip! I wish we had stayed for the hour music concert at lunchtime. We did eat lunch, it was awesome, with great views of the city from the balcony.

A stunning tribute to a fascinating and very moving history of a family.. The Palace is a privately owned part of the Prague Castle site. Within it is a lovely museum recording the history of the Lobkowicz family and of Bohemia. The audio guide is excellent, easy to use and very moving to listen to. Absolutely fascinating throughout the tour, it is difficult to choose the highlight from the wonderful art, music and porcelain collections but I think it has to be overall experience and the fascinating and moving history of the family itself. The palace was by far the best attraction we visited in Prague. The restaurant is also excellent for lunch and has a superb view of Prague.

Amazing, Amazing, Amazing Lobkowicz Palace. My husband and I were in Prague just last week (5/18-5/25/10). Lobkowicz Palace is very unassuming when you enter. The only reason my husband and I went was because of the reviews on Tripadvisor. WOW! We were blown away. You're told the story of the Lobkowicz family by their own words. We enjoyed all the personal items and paintings, but we were absolutely blown away by the ORIGINAL scores of music from Mozart and Beethoven. It brought tears to my eyes to see these items. The whole museum was unique in that its the opulent history of a family told by the family through paintings and objects. You simply must see this place to believe it.....it was a highlight of our memories. Its near Saint George's Basilica.....but not difficult to find at all.

An incredible story. The admission price is a little high here, but it comes with an audioguide that is well worth it. The current Prince Lobkowicz narrates the guide in a friendly, informative, and winning way. The collection is quite stunning, and the music items and tales are simply a must for all music lovers. I only wish that I had had time to visit the other palace he mentions, a half hour away from Prague. A fantastic story of Czech culture emerging from the dark days of WWII and communist rule.

WOW. I have never been so moved in my life. This museum is filled with Beethoven's manuscripts beautiful gun collections and breath taking paintings. If you do not see this extraordinary Museum in prague you have reallly missed out on quite a treat

A hidden Gem in Prag. A small but exceptional museum in Prag. No crowd and so many interesting things to see, Canalettos, Beethoven manuscripts, Brueghel etc... located in a beautiful palace with an excellent free audioguide.Daily concert at 1 am, which is exceptional in Prag as all concerts usually are in the evening. I visited the museum one day and came back the following day for the concert. The program was very consensual but the musicians were really good.Really a place to visit when in Prag, to see wonders and get away from the crowd.

The Favorite Part of our Trip. My husband and I traveled to Prague from Paris for the second half of our honeymoon. We visited Lobkowicz Palace the last day of our trip and of all we saw after 10 days in Europe; Lobkowicz Palace was our favorite destination. We can’t stop sharing the experience with family and friends. The Palace itself is beautiful but what is truly awe inspiring is the family’s history and collection. Ranging from priceless paintings, china, firearms and musical instruments your eyes never tire but crave more. My husband and I listened to the audio guide and it was fascinating. It is about an hour long and extremely informative without being exhausting. We were also lucky enough to attend one of the afternoon concerts held in the Palace. It was a wonderful way to experience the beauty of the space. Finally, we ended our tour with a lovely lunch in the Lobkowicz Café. Though it was a rainy, cold day we were able to sit on the covered balcony, with blankets to keep us warm, and look out over the city. The view alone is worth the price of admission. If you are traveling to Prague plan a trip to Lobkowicz Palace. It is really a treasure.

What a gem!. This is undoubtedly the best museum in Prague. Highlights included two stunning Canaletto's - showing the River Thames in London in his usual glorious detail - and the original manuscripts of several Beethoven symphonies and Mozart's hand written amendments to Handel's Messiah! What a find - and what a story excellently narrated by one of the family. Can't comment on historical shortcomings (as previous reviewer) but we surely have to be greatful to the Joseph Franz Lobkowicz (1772-1816) for his generous patronage which enabled Beethoven to compose his3rd (Eroica), 4th, 5th AND 6th symphonies and countless other marvellous works! The entry ticket includes the audio guide (excellently narated by William, the current Prince - though they don't use their titles anymore). Ticket also gives 10% off refreshments in the adjacent restaurant which has a terrace with wonderful views over Prague) We had a very good reasonably priced lunch there.After lunch we were lucky enough to meet David Krol, the Executive Director of the museum who showed us a few extra areas not normally open to the publc and explained how the family are working really hard to restore all the treasures (buildings, art, books & manuscripts) being returned to them by the state but in great need of restoration, care & attention. We even met Alexdra Lobkowich (wife of current "Prince") in the corridor who welcomed us warmly on her way to a meeting. You may not be as lucky as we were but this Palace is definately worth a visit

Position in the top 10 is less than spontaneous .... ... don't misunderstand me, i am glad i found these reviews and ditched the castle tour in favour of this Palace. However the visit was soured just a little when i found an exhortation to 'enter a review on Trip Adviser' printed on my entrance receipt. The Palace is managed by highly paid professionals and they are shamelessly doing all they can to exploit the free publicity and have the attraction listed as number one. To be fair, some of the collections is astounding and I found the presentation endearing (barring a middle aged man thanking his 'Mummy' for her contribution to the audio tour). More seriously, i was left deeply disturbed by the lack of any critical analysis of actions of some of the ancestors. Yes it is a lovely legend to think of Polyxena Lobkowicz sheltering the Emperor's ministers under her skirts in 1618 to save them from the Protestant mob, but there is no mention in the commentary that this event then launched the 30 year war which laid waste to 40% of the population of Europe. We are simply asked to admire Polyxena's son's military hardware and achievements on White Mountain, when he helped crush the fight for religious freedom in Bohemia. Nor is there any humble reference to the 27 noble leaders of the insurrection that were later tried and executed in Prague's Old Town Square, which the Palace curators must be aware is part of the tourist trail too. Is the exhortation on the entrance receipt a small symbol of the of the unrepentant arrogance of an aristocratic family which has not yet fully reflected on the burden of their ancestor's collusion with religion, power and money? Whatever the truth is, i think they may be part of the reason why 80% of the Czech people are now atheist. Go and visit this glorious Palace by all means, but it may leave a slightly sour taste in your mouth.

Not to be missed if you're in Prague. A museum that was until fairly recently a family home with historical importance, now showcases an important works of arts and music. We were lucky enough to be in the Palace when the ninth prince was giving a tour - he was charming and considerate, and of course has a wonderful story to tell since his family lost the palace and the art not once but twice (first to the Nazis, then to the communists). Great place for lunch, and concerts are given in an intimate hall within the palace.
No crowds for this wonderful tour. One of our top highlights. Peace and quiet with great (electronic) narration.Highly reccomended!

Simply unmissable. Like others have said, you have to do this! It's a chance to see the most amazing art, soak up the history and culture, and feel like you've really seen something that will stay with you for ever.

A wonderful family collection; the audio-guided tour provides historical context.. This museum gives the visitor a good idea of why Prague was and still is one of the most important cultural centers in Europe. Finding out that Beethoven was sponsored by the Lobkowicz family and seeing the magnificent collection this family has amassed is truly inspiring.The audio-guided tour is a must and contextualizes the highlights of this grand collection.

One of the most important cultural centers in Europe enriched with a personal history of the Lobkowicz family.. The Lobkowicz Collection is a museum of paintings, decorative arts, manuscripts, musical instruments, weapons and more that tells the story of the family from the 16th century that owned the palace, located in Prague Castle. Despite confiscation in WW II and 40 years of Communism, the Lobkowicz family continues to own the Palace, and they have restored much of the original art, history and beauty. William Lobkowicz and his wife and parents can be heard in a most personal manner on the complimentary audio guides. The self guided, audio assisted tour through the museum is an opportunity to experience an epic story about the culture and history of Europe and some of the important music we enjoy today. Be sure to learn to whom Beethoven dedicated many of his compositions, including the "Eroica". Highly recommend the museum shop and the cafe. Enjoy this exceptional treasure.

Beethoven & Lobkowicz: can't get any better!. Two things make the visit to the Lobkowicz Palace truly unforgettable: first, being in the presence of the written parts, in Beethoven's own hand, of some of the greatest pieces of music ever written, including his symphonies no. 5 and 6. For anybody who cares about music it is as deep an experience as, let's say, watching the real parts of the Titanic brought from the bottom of the ocean, or touching stones brought by astronauts from the moon. It is awesome.The second thing about the visit are your guides: The Lobkowicz family. It is almost like being shown around Versailles by a Royal family member, who knew Louis XIV intimately... again, unique experience. Highly recommended!

Must-do museum in Prague. Our 56-member ENMU Choirs sang a performance last week in the Marble Hall of the Lobkowicz Palace, in the presence of Prince William Lobkowicz. While the performance was enjoyable (full and receptive audience) and the meal we were served afterward was first-class, by far the highlight of this experience and of our entire ten-day European tour (Vienna, Salzburg and Prague) was the Museum of the Lobkowicz Palace. We were given only 45 minutes to tour the museum, yet could have spent several hours there (and wish we had). The museum is of the highest quality, with a terrific audio guide by Prince William himself, and is on multiple levels. I found myself literally running through the end of the exhibit to make sure I didn't miss anything (like the Dog Room, etc.). I hated I didn't have more time to take everything in, and do plan to go back one day.The guide who welcomed and hosted us, David Krol, is the most intelligent, informative, and friendliest people we met on our entire tour. He is the perfect face of the Lobkowicz family. I hope they realize what a treasure they have in him. He even told us he scoured the family history for a record of greyhounds in their past (our school mascot is the greyhound), but to no avail. I would say that is a first-class act...truly taking such an interest in your guests that you do your research on them? David, you made our trip wonderful!Kayla Paulk and the ENMU Choirskayla.paulk@enmu.edu

The Highlight of our Prague visit!. This is a "Must Do" if you are visiting Prague. The artwork, the music collection, and the armoury, combined with a very personalised audioguide provide a great background introduction to Prague. We loved all of it and highly recommend you include a visit to this Palace. Good value for money. The audioguide voiced by the current custodians of the Family Lobkowicz Collection was both moving and informative. A fabulous way to while away a couple of hours enjoying some stunning art. The music room will make you catch your breath when you stand before documents written in the hand of Classical Masters. This collection was a highlight of our visit to Prague.

If you only visit one museum, go to the Lobkowicz palace. I discovered the museum following a pack of bored and disrepectful American schoolkids tramping around the Castle. Thank goodness I ducked into the oasis of the Lobkowicz palace and even had the unnatural luck of being alone in most of the rooms on a snowy March morning. The drama that unfolded was unbelievable. The cashier suggested that I take the English version of the audioguide because Mr. Lobkowicz himself narrated the story. AND WHAT A STORY. It begins with the haunting eyes of Max who suffered unbelievable tragedy at the hands of fate and history. But it goes back over 500 years into almost mythical proportions. Did you know that a prince Lobkowicz enabled Beethoven to write his music because of his a far-sighted gift of a salary, freeing the composer up to write as he pleased? And so the story develops. The voices of the family, unpretentious Americans who have inherited this staggering weight of history and property, move the visitor to tears. No museum in Prague, which today sadly resembles a film set haunted by the sinister security forces of communist dictators, brings the city's glorious history of art and culture more emotionally to life. Do yourself a favour and accept the gitt of the Lobkowicz family for the entrance fee - presumably much-needed to keep the heritage alive.

Excellent story from the Lobkowicz Family, worth a visit. This is an excellent museum with a great audio guide.You are drawn into the history of the Lobkowicz family which is extremely interesting.I'm usually not a huge audio guide fan as I slowly begin to loose interest but the museum is really interesting and each room has some interesting story to tell.Recommended

The Lobkowicz Palace - experience the intersection of history, culture, and family.. The Lobkowicz Palace in Prague is a unique museum which invites visitors to experience the intersection of history, culture, and family. Located within the walls of Prague Castle, its warmth and sophistication provide a welcome contrast to the cold, stark medieval grandeur of the castle, and it certainly has a far more professional, polite, and well-trained staff. Additionally, the charming cafe provided a delicious lunch (and welcome heat during the winter visit!). Part of what makes this museum so special is that the continuity of the centuries is portrayed through the interests and relationships of a noble family that had enormous influence on music, art, and political events of the day. Because the audiotour is narrated by members of the Lobkowicz family, a visitor feels that Prince William Lobkowicz is personally "hosting" a tour through his home - certainly a far more intimate experience than that which we usually experience in a museum. As we meandered through the beautifully restored rooms, we could hear strains of the classical music being performed in one of the daily afternoon concerts at the museum. It was a lovely reminder that one of the Lobkowicz princes was a patron of Beethoven - with original manuscripts on site.While the museum has a fantastic collection including art, manuscripts, musical instruments, an armory, etc., it is positioned to be a family history and, as such, highlights the high quality collection from that perspective. It is fascinating to understand how nobility lived through the centuries, but the fact that this family lost their lands, castles, art, etc. first to the Nazis and then again the Communists is especially astounding in that they were able to recover their property each time.We had lovely conversations with Prince William Lobkowicz, his wife Alexandra, and David Krol, the Executive Director of the museum. Each was gracious and informative and personalized an already unique visit. The palace was also an interesting juxtaposition with other historic sections of the city.Do plan to spend a few hours at this museum gem - tour the palace collection, have lunch in the cafe, attend the concert, and then visit the lovely little gift shop. Wear comfortable shoes - especially if you plan to visit the castle also. We visited in freezing February, so we were delighted to thaw out in the heated palace after an uncomfortably cold tour of the castle. All in all, the Lobkowicz Palace Museum was the highlight of our trip to Prague. We would highly recommend it as a "must see."

The best palace and museum in Prague, a walk through the history of one family. We visited Prague for a three night trip on the 15th of Feb 2010 and had a wonderful time in this beautiful city. We had never been before and on our first full day we decided to walk across the Charles Bridge and on up to the Castle, which only took about half an hour from where we stayed at Nametski Republicky. The great thing about Prague is that everywhere seems to be in comfortable walking distance, and you don't have to be Ranulph Fiennes. The Castle site is very large and we bought the long tour (as opposed to the short tour) and audio guide. We duly toured almost the whole complex and it was really interesting, and the area is so large that the fee you pay covers two days so when the Casle closed and we hadn't finished we decided to finish the tour on the next day. We returned on day two and finished off the long tour and as we were leaving we passed a poster of the picture by Velasquez of the little four year old Infanta . Intrigued by this we popped into the building by the entrance to the Castle called the Lobkowicz Palace. The really helpful man at the ticket desk explained that this was a Palace belonging to the Lobkowicz family which had been seized by the Nazis during the war and the collection had been broken up. After the War the possessions had been returned but they were then seized again by the communists after the Prague Spring. On the election of Vaclav Havel the familly once more regained the possessions that had been lost and had opened the Palace as a museum to the public.We bought tickets which included audio guide and set off. The tour was narrated by William Lobkowicz and her explained the family history going back to the 1500s, and the family portraits in the galleries were brought vividly to life by his narrative. We met the strong women and men of the great houses of Europe and heard the parts that they had played in the history of their countries. Dynastic marriages came to life as we toured the palace and various members of the Lobkowicz family also appeared on the guide and gave their view of different aspects of the story, such as Martin Lobkowicz, William's Father, recalling riding his bike along the corridors of Roudnice Castle, another family residence in the area, when he was a child under what he felt was the disapproving gaze of his ancestors.We saw the original of the Velasquez portrait, two magnificent Canalettos and a Breughelas well as a host of less well known paintings. The object d'art and the porcelain, musical instruments and scores by famous composers was a treasure house of pleasure, and the staff of the museum were amongst the most courteous and hospitable of all the people that we met in Prague.I would urge anyone visiting this beautiful city to make the Lobkowicz their prime venue for understanding the importance of Prague in European history.If I could only choose one place to go in Prague it would most definately be The Lobkowicz Palace.

"the" must see of Prague. The collection at Lobkowicz Palace that William Lobkowicz and his family have assembled together again is nothing short of miraculous. The rich history is palatable as you walk through the Palace's magnificent rooms filled with paintings and artifacts, each with a memorable story to tell…I am anxious to return and visit Nelahozeves Castle only a short distance away, north of Prague...

This is a collection is worth visiting over and over again.. This was my last stop during my stay in Prague - and one of the best. The collection housed in the Lobkowicz Palace is rich in history and has such a variety that it is sure to have something for everyone. The free audio guide provided a cohesive tour of the collections.

Very interesting. My husband and I found this palace/art collection much more interesting than we expected. What makes it so captivating is the audio tour, which I usually don't bother with, but this one comes with the cost of admission. Mr. Lobkowicz, who narrates the tour personally in English, is engaging with his personal stories and telling of the history of the objects and home. It was fun -- and the personal items from Mozart and Beethoven in the music room were really amazing. The attached cafe was good too. This is definitely worth your time in Prague, and it's on the same grounds as Prague Castle, so it's conveniently located.

Our Favourite Place in Prague. We almost missed this place - thank goodness we didn't! The history behind the Palace and the amazing artwork on display makes this a "must see" place in Prague. Do get the Audioguide - the current owner of the castle, together with his family, talk you through a fascinating journey of their ancestor's history. We had a lovely coffee & Strudel in the Palace Cafe afterwards and were only sorry that we didn't have lunch there too. Highly recommended

Enjoyable and educational!. This museum was fun, a good value, and I walked away feeling like I learned alot. The audio guide is great, and hearing about the family's history, as told by the family members themselves, really made Czech history come alive for me--much more than during the tours I took of Prague.The collections were interesting and there was alot to see, but it was not overwhelming, and the views from the Palace were great. And...I'm not 100% sure, but I think Prince Lobkowicz himself held the door for me as I was leaving (he was entering at the same moment)--talk about a one of a kind experience!

Live Czech History thru this incredible collection. This is a wonderful museum. It is the perfect combination of history, art, music history, gunship all wrapped up in a heartwarming family story...Do not miss this museum. It's worth the price.

Amazing... One of the greatest museum experiences I've ever had. I was drawn to the museum because a poster indicated that they had a Velazquez portrait of the Infanta Margarita. When I got into the museum, I realized that the breadth of the collection surpassed my highest hopes. To make the experience even better, there is an amazing audioguide (and believe me, my fiancee and I typically despise audioguides) and fantastic descriptions of every piece of art. Instead of wandering around looking at portraits, hoping to recognize a familiar historical figure, visitors have written descriptions at their fingertips and can clearly connect the family portraits with the Lobkowicz family history. Okay, I know, why would you want to see the family history of a name that sounds as obscure as Lobkowicz? Because these people connected with almost every notable character in history, and they kept mementos of each relationship - in the case of Mozart, Beethoven, and Haydn, those include original scores! You have to go. It kills the Palace. I really can't say enough. I didn't want the museum to end, and I have never gotten so close to such unbelievable art.

Lobkowicz - Prague's premier palace. Put simply, its bossman. I was keen to visit after hearing about the family history and wasn't in any way disappointed.The collection of art (especially the Canalettos of London,) music and firearms is simply incredible whilst the palace in itself is very beautiful. Deputy director David Krol was incredibly friendly and helpful and if you seem him around, you should approach him as his insight is fascinating.Certainly not to be missed.

Fantastic New Museum in Prague. On the last day of a wonderful week-long trip to Prague, we visited the best tourist attraction of the city, in our opinion - Lobkowicz Palace. Prague has incredible tourist sites, but this was a hidden gem! The Prague Castle complex, the main tourist attraction, is no longer a palace - it is the seat of government. However, next door is Lobkowicz Palace, a privately-owned palace with all the royal goodies you would expect - beautiful royal portraits, collections of instruments and fabulous dishware. And what a story behind the Lobkowicz family - the prince leaving Czechoslovakia after WWI with only the coat on his back, to the return of his grandson in the 1990's (a Harvard-educated American real estate professional), after the latest Czech Republic was established and offered an opportunity for royals to reclaim their property. The beautiful museum offers a complimentary audio-tour, and the English version was recorded by the Prince himself. We definitely recommend the audio-tour - it included the family's personal story and reflections ("this was the house where my grandfather spent his summers"), not just an art history commentary on the items. The museum also has a charming cafe with an incredible private view of the city. We had the good fortune to bump into the museum's director, Mr. Krol, and his comments added a special dimension to our visit.

Stunning artworks and a fascinating story. Lobkowicz Palace makes art come to life with a interesting audio narrative that makes the works spring to life and envolves them in the core of czech history, a fascinating family story of a heritage gaines/lost/regained/relost... and now available. Seeing Beethovens or Mozart's handwriting, admiring masterworks by Canaletto and Brueghel, a beautiful building restored, welcoming coffee shop and souvenir store, and Mr. Lobkowicz roaming the floor in person while his voice sounds in your head through the earphones. Intending to spend 20minutes I stayed 2 hours and feel I gained and learned about the country in the process. Eclectic but beautiful collection. See it.

Unexpected culture. When spending any amount of time in Prague, it is very understandable to focus on the St. Vitus cathedral when visiting he Prague castle complex. However, to overlook the Lobkowicz Palace in that very same complex would be an incredible oversight. This palace and it's private collection are open to the public for a very modest sum and once inside, the visitor gets treated to a peek inside one of the most influential Czech families of the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries. A friend and I just happend to be walking by when we decided to enter and take the audio tour. The palace is set on two floors and the rooms of portriats are organized according to the family chronology. As we had no prior knowledge of Czech royal history beforehand, we both found this exhibit thoroughly enjoyable and incredibly educational. The audio tour was narrated by the Prince Lobkowicz himself, with whom we had the surprise pleasure of actually meeting while we were exiting the exhibit. The paintings were indeed a look into another time and the feeling of the entire palace was more of a private residence than a display of artifacts, with the proximity we were allowed to get to the works. Our favorite parts were the arms collection (said to be one of the greatest in all of Europe) and the music room, where on display was Mozart's hand-annotated score of Handel's Messiah and a wealth of Beethoven's works. All-in-all, this was THE hightlight of our sightseeing trip in Prague.

Please visit this exceptional museum. I visited the Lobkowicz Palace in November 2009 because of the great reviews on tripadvisor. I am so pleased I went as it was certainly the highlight of my week in Prague. It's very easy to not go there as you have probably already paid and planned to visit the other attractions in the Royal Palace grounds. Please go because you will not be disappointed. The audio guide (free) is brilliant.The other reviews already explain the Palace so I will not repeat their comments.PLEASE DO NOT MISS THIS ATTRACTION!.andrew

Not- To- Be Missed Exhibition At Prague Castle. When visiting sites at Prague Castle be sure to include a stop at the Lobkowicz Palace.It displays a wide array of paintings, china ,armor and other interesting items in a truly elegant environment. Included is a free exceptionally well- done audio tour which blends the country's history with the interesting background of the royal Lobkowicz family and descriptions of the exhibits.There is also an excellent cafe overlooking the city where you can rest and enjoy a bite from a varied and reasonably priced menu. An optional concert is performed daily at 1PM for those interested in another immersion into the musical tradition of the city, which we did not attend

The story of the Lobkowicz Palace has touched our hearts and souls.. We visited many highly rated tourist attractions, but the Lobkowicz Palace would be in our memories for our lifetimes. The audio guide was a gift, narrated by the Lobkowicz family members, whom we were extremely lucky to have met later inside the gift shop. We were bewitched by the story-telling and followed the Lobkowicz history throughout the centuries, as we passed through their many wonderful salons. Our breaths were taken away especially by their Music and Shooting Galleries. We have never seen so many rare and exquisite gun collections anywhere. For Classical Music lovers, we have to be so thankful to the 7th Prince Lobkowicz, that through his patronage, we could appreciate some of the best music of Beethoven today. We were however, disappointed, because we missed the daily concert played inside the Music Room. The restaurant was also a great place to stop by at the end of the tour, and has a refined ambience. The palace was a blessing, and we recommend travellers of all ages and backgrounds to visit it before they leave Prague. William and Alexandra, thank you very much for sharing your lovely palace with us!

Lobkowicz Palace - One of the 'Must See's in Prague!. I visited the Lobkowicz Palace this summer with a friend and would highly recommend it to others. I traveled around Europe for 10 weeks visiting countless museums, but I learned more on my audio tour through the Lobkowicz museum than anywhere else. The audio tour is narrated by one of the Lobkowicz family members, which gives the tour a unique and inspiring personal flair. A trip to Prague isn't complete without a trip to the Castle, and a trip to the Castle isn't complete without stopping by the Lobkowicz Palace. Make it an afternoon to remember and finish off your visit with dinner in the Lobkowicz restaurant with breathtaking views of the city.

A hidden jewel in Prague Castle. The Lobkowicz Palace is within the walls of Prague Castle, hidden on the right as you walk down the hill behind the cathedral. The collection is small and eclectic so it is easily manageable. The headsets are a must as they are done by the family themselves and full of personal touches, giving a history that is unfamiliar to most. The jewel of the art collection is the Brueghel, being the only one of the Seasons series that is not in the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna. But it is the music room that really bowls you over with Beethoven's original score for the 5th Symphony and Mozart's editing of Handel's Messiah. Bonuses include a charming gift store (they ship!), an excellent cafe, and clean restrooms.

This is a can't miss in Prague. When at the Prague Castle it would be easy to miss the Lobkowicz Palace, but don't. It is a truly special place with the finest, most professional (yet personal) audio tour of any museum we've visited. The exhibits are great, especially the musical piece. A rare positive surprise in every respect.Also, don't miss the cafe - great food and views (or ambience in the courtyard).
the best. we had been to prague but hadn't seen this before this last trip. it was recommented by the book Artel Style and was really wonderful.

Do not leave Prague without visiting the Lobkowicz Palace!. I went to Prague this past week with a friend and the highlight was definitely visiting the Lobkowicz Palace at the Prague Castle. We visited the nearby cathedral and then headed to the palace for the afternoon and went on an audio tour of the palace and then then ate a great dinner on the Palace restaurants patio overlooking the city.  Having visited many museums and other attractions around Europe this past month the palace stands out among the group as an extraordinary place to visit. It tells a story while also putting interesting artifacts and family relics on display. By the time that we reached the family living qaurters at the end of the tour I really felt like I knew the centuries of Lobkowiczs who have lived there. The in depth family history from the first room through the different tidbits of special interests like music, dogs, and special family collection like the armour and china and religious relics all created a great picture of where the family started, how it has progressed through time and finally where they are headed over the course of the coming generations. The exhibits really have made me want to look more into my own family history in order to be able to get as firm an understanding of where my ancestors have come from. The restaurant was a great last stop with good food, great views and Lobkowicz beer!  The visit to the palace helped to complete my perspective of the history of the people and traditions of Prague and it was a very fun afternoon.

The best thing to do in Prague!. I have been to many of the world’s finest museums, from the Prado in Madrid to the British Museum to the numerous museums in New York City. But one of the most interesting historical experiences I’ve ever had was my visit to the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague. The whole experience is beautifully orchestrated and classy, but also intensely personal, since the visitor is guided through history--and the various rooms--by the voices of actual family members. Nobody visiting Prague should miss this amazing gem. It’s by far the best thing I did in the city. --Brad New York City

A beautiful collection with a moving and intimate story that takes you through it.. The highlight of my trip to Prague was visiting the Lobkowicz Palace and meeting the family behind the collection. As the audio guide moves you through the rooms, the experience is both personal and moving. It's a great place to start your visit as many of locales mentioned on the tour can be viewed up close and personal, afterward. A visit to the shop is a must!

Best museum in Prague. Ventured in to the museum quite by accident and one couldn't be more complimentary about the whole experience. Starts with the staff who goes out of their way to be helpful, then continues with a wonderfully thought-out and laid-out presentation of the riches the family is willing to share with the public. Of course, this being a private museum of a hundreds of years-old family, there are a large number of family portraits around, but the riches of the whole collection will make all that worthwhile.One of the most important section in my opinion is the Music Room with original scores by Mozart and Beethoven, then to the justifiably celebrated Brueghel painting, then so on.After the museum, if the weather is clement, do take the time to have some refreshment on the terrace of the museum's cafe; you'll enjoy perhaps the best views over Prague from there, together with good food and service.

Lobkowicz Palace offers a unique look at Prague's history. The Lobkowicz family history and collections here at the palace they only recently reclaimed from the Communists gives visitors a personal history of Prague over the centuries. The art collection is very impressive, and the family connection to Beethoven and other musicians is amazing! We also enjoyed a delicious lunch in the cafe - actually met William Lobkowicz, who is a very nice, down-to-earth guy who has brought his family to Prague to re-establish his royal family's roots and preserve some of Prague's important history.

30 minute audio tour that my 7 and 10 yr old sons were riveted by!. This little gem of a museum is a great way to learn about the Lobkowicz Family and their important role in Czech history. I can't imagine visiting without taking the abridged 30 minute audio tour. There's a little bit for everyone... artwork, music manuscripts, firearms, dogs, birds! We wouldn't have gone here if it wasn't listed as the number one attraction on tripadvisor. And we're so glad we went! Surprisingly, my 7 and 10 yr old sons really enjoyed the brief , self guided tour and learned a lot. They were downright enthusiastic about the subject matter which was presented in a very accessible manner. The audio tour was artfully done with lots of beautiful classical music incorporated into the program. We also ate lunch in the cafe which was excellent. The menu had lots of delicious salad offerings that helped offset the heavy Czech food we were inhaling at night. You can get a 10% discount at the cafe if you have purchased tickets to the museum.The museum was virtually empty and there were no lines.The only drawback was that the museum was a bit expensive.

Museum should advertise itself with classical music lover. Sixth price of Lobkowicz has the far sight to finance Beethoven's musical journey, let him compose whatever Beethoven wishes, from Heroic to Pastoral symphonies.
