The only complaint I have for the prince's generousity is, when Napoleon shows up, prince stop finance him, he is left out there with no money to deal with immortal beloved. I wonder if Beethoven should enjoy the happiness of family life, ninth symphony might not come along, he will just continue to write sweet music like moonlight sonata, or be a Chopin before Chopin.  If both prince and Beethoven should pick up where they left off last time, would they do something differently this time around?[--]

BEST MUSEUM IN PRAGUE!. Newly opened, and especially this 2nd week in June, THERE IS BARELY ANYBODY THERE! It's a miracle that this collection was recovered TWICE, first from the Nazis and then from the Communists.  Begin with a one hour concert of Baroque music then take the audio tour for room after room of royal portraits and Czech history. Read private letters that showed arranged marraiges that became real love matches ; "my beloved, I wish that you get all that your heart desires, except for women, because my husband shall have none other than me. I miss you so! Why have you not opened the package of damask that I have sent you?" These Catholic Princes were great patrons of the arts, and the scope of their interests and generosity is mind boggling as you go from room to room. From Velasquez to Cranach- when was the last time you ended up in a room by yourself with an original Brueghel [ Haymaking ] or Canaletto [ Views of London ] ?  Decorative arts begin with a Romanesque Cross c 1125 and proceed through gorgeous Delft porcelain services. Armor, rifles and pistols with magnificent decorations abound. This is after the Piranesi room. The music collection has you survey beautiful lutes, violins and trumpets. There is a special thrill as you learn that the 7th Prince Lobkowicz was one of Beethoven's most generous benefactors. Stand inches from Beethoven's orginal score for the 5th Symphony and note that it was dedicated to the Prince. The 6th Symphony, similarly dedicated, sits beside it. Stand next to Mozar'ts orignal score of his revisions of Handel's Messiah and clearly see the contributions his additions made. The depth and breadth of this collection leaves you awestruck. The Palace is at the extreme Eastern end of Prague Castle and is on the way back down the mountain back towards downtown Prague. IT IS NOT TO BE MISSED!

ABSOLUTELY STUNNING - A MOVING FAMILY HISTORY BRILLIANTLY SET IN ITS HISTORICAL CONTEXT. The story of the Lobkowicz family's misfortunes is set against a turbulent historical background. Their extraordinary personal story makes an even greater impression, however, thanks to the sheer professionalism that clearly informed the design and execution of the exhibition, and indeed of the visitor facilities in general. This combination made our visit to the Castle a very moving, but also uplifting, experience. The audio guide was, quite simply, faultless. And it was a real thrill to see original scores by some of the great European composers. If you're ever in, or near, Prague, DON'T MISS IT!

Don't miss the Lobkowitz Palace when you are in Prague.. I had read about this wonderful palace before we went on our recent trip to Prague to attend the Spring Music Festival. I totally concur with all the great reviews. Our lunch on the terrace overlooking the City was a special treat, and then we attended the concert which we enjoyed. The audioguided tour of the rooms was truly excellent. The family history was well-presented and the displays, particularly the original music manuscripts (e.g. Beethoven's Eroica dedicated to Prince Lobkowitz) were awesome.The Canalettos of London and other fine old master oils gave us great pleasure without the overload which one gets in a large art museum.

beautifully presented gallery. This is primarily a beautifully presented art collection (including two fabulous Canalettos of London), but because it is a private collection, and the audio guide is narrated by the Lobkowicz family, you get a fascinating history of Prague. It was surprisingly quiet for a weekend in May. Really worthwhile.

A Terrific Review of Czech History. We just completed our second visit to Prague and the Lobkowicz Palace. Last year we stumbled on it because of the advertised noon-time concert. This year we went back with my wife's brother and his wife. This museum gives a thorough review of Czech history as lived by the Lobkowicz family. You get a great picture of exactly how things happened in Prague, which was a major player in European history, right up there with Vienna. In the room containing the musical instruments and scores, tears came to my eyes when viewing the original scores used in the first performances of three Beethoven symphonies, the Opus 18 String Quartets, and a re-orchestration of Händel's Messiah in Mozart's own hand. Wow! The museum also contains a really nice restaurant with great beer, produced by Lobkowicz's own brewery. This place is not to be missed.

Lobkowicz Palace - Prague. Walking the grounds of Prague Castle, I caught sight of the Lobkowicz Palace and following my instinct decided to visit it. It was a delightful experience! The property is in excellent condition and the collection of family portraits, furniture and objects well curated. Most important was the audioguide (included in the entrance fee) narrated by Prince William Lobkowicz in English that transforms what would be a museum tour into a living experience of his family and the history of Bohemia for the past four centuries. I strongly recommend a visit to the Palace while in Prague. You may even meet Prince William, as I did, having tea at the cozy coffee shop downstairs and let him give you a personal account of his endeavors to offer visitors a view on his family's heritage.

Beautiful collections, fantastic family-narrated audioguide, fascinating history. The Lobkowicz has one of the best narrated audioguides taking you through the collections and rooms of the Palace - including a highlight of red-numbered audio points for those with limited tour time. But it's actually worth listeining through the entire audio guide, which is narrated mainly by the Lobkowicz scion William, but also by his mother, father and the Palace' s main curator. The history of the family in Hapsburg times as well as through the Nazi occupation and Communist takeover is well-covered and very interesting to listen to. As important arts & music patrons, the family's collection of original Beethoven scores is impressive, as is the Breughel 'Seasons' panel, "The Haymaking" in their art collection.Afterwards, have a drink or meal at the Cafe in the courtyard (or if you can reserve a table - the balcony overlooking Prague town). There should be a 10% discount on your bill with a ticket to the Palace.

#1 for a reason!. This was our favorite museum on our tour. It is a seperate ticket from the Castle ticket but within the Castle complex. If you are short on time skip the castle ticket (but do walk around the castle grounds). The tour is brilliantly laid out and the audio tour gives great information. Typically I get bored quickly with audio tours but this was truly great...they had a great understanding of how much time to spend on the main items they wanted you to walk away with. Just wish we had enough time to visit the Lobkowicz summer palace just outside of Prague.

Best place at Prague Castle to relax. If you will have the opportunity to visit Lobkowicz Museum, don`t miss the restaurant with unique terrace, where you can feel the real atmosphere of Prague Castle. I visit Prague every month and I do not miss any occasion to stop by for local goulash (however the only czech traditional food - but you cannot get better in Prague) or just to have a cup of coffee at a pleasant spot served by very nice staff.David, Vienna

A must-see for lovers of music and art. They are doing everything right at the Lobkowicz Palace. The self-guided tour with headsets lasts about an hour and is well-planned and narrated. The musical manuscripts are the highlight of many beautifully galleries which include an important painting in excellent condition by Pieter Breugel and a perfectly presented collection of firearms. Items in the shop have been carefully chosen, and the lunchroom with its attractive painted ceilings has a good menu. This is certainly one of the top ten sites not to be missed when in Prague.

Fantastic! Do not miss this!. While in Prague be sure to see the Lobkowicz museum at Prague Castle. The audioguide is a big plus to understanding what is before you and experiencing Czech history through this family. After visiting the palace go to the Nelahozeves Castle if you have time. It is 15 miles out of town and easily accesible by train. The project of recovering these two properties from the Nazis and later the Communists and restoring them is a monumental undertaking and the Lobkowicz family is to be applauded for having accomplished so much since the Velvet Revolution in 1989.

A Must See in Prague. We visited the Lobkowicz Museum in early April and thought it was one of the best attractions in Prague. The art, religious artifacts, weaponry, and other items were wonderful to view. However, the highlight was the story behind the family told during the audio tour, which is included in the entry fee. Also, we enjoyed a good meal in their restaurant which allows seating on a balcony overlooking Prague. I recommend getting their hamburger, which was delicious and one of the beers that they brew. The Lobkowicz Palace also offers daily afternoon concerts, which we were not able to see due to its cancellation for President Obama’s visit. To get to Lobkowicz Palace, get off at metro station Malostranska. Outside at the street, turn left and walk a short distance until you see on your left a series of steps and ramps leading up to the Prague Castle grounds. The Lobkowicz Palace is built into the Prague Castle wall. A great part of our Prague visit and something that should not be missed.

Nice, but certainly not #1 in Prague, sorry to disagree. I visited Prague for 3 full days and following TA`s advice I visited this nice museum inside the Castle. While the museum is interesting and has a nice collection that belongs to the Lobkowicz family, I must disagree with this being the #1 "Thing to do" in Prague.It gives fresh air when the Palace is so heavily crowded, the collection of art, items and paintings is indeed interesting but it does not beat, at all, a walk in the Old Town Square, seeing, watching and understanding the great astronomical clock, crossing the Charles Bridge late at night when crowds dissapear, looking at the incredible illumination that beautiful buildings have at dusk, getting lost in the small streets of Prague, and other attractions that are well mentioned here.Better than St. Vitus? No way.

Our favorite museum in Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace Museum , is one of the finest museums we've visited , anywhere . The Lobkowicz family history and their collection of art , musical instruments used by "masters" , original documents of compositions [ almost an emotional experience ] by "masters" , weapons collection , Delft china collection , - and many other very unique / special items --make this museum a "must see " for visitors to Prague . A very special collection , recovered by the family , and now shared !

Prague - Don't miss this. The high point of our Prague visit. An unbelievable collection, especially considering it's private! Within the Prague Castle grounds. Priceless collection and not too much. We went back two times. Have you ever seen an original Beethoven or Mozart manuscript? They've got ém. An important family in European history which we had never heard of until our visit.

Must see Museum when you are in Prague!. My Husband, his Aunt and my Mother by chance struck up a conversation with the curator of this museum in May08 as we were looking for a place to have some ice-cream. Lucky for us he gave us a coupon which gave us a discount for the museum which we were not aware was even there. Of all the museums we toured in on our trip, this was definitely the highlight of our excursion. It was so informative, well laid out and entertaining. I was surprised to learn that the 7th Prince Lobkowicz had provided Beethoven's stipend so that he could develop his musical talent. Definitely worth seeing!!! The view from their cafe was stunning. We celebrated Mother's Day with lunch on the balcony. Truly a memorable event!

Very interesting and good audio tour. Well paced and fascinating trip to this museum. The audio tour is very good and interesting to see the Lobkovicz's connections to Beethoven and Handel. Cost is 275CK and comes well recommended.

Wonderful museum with great interior.... The museum was just fantastic. The audio tour from the Lobkowicz himself was very helpful and its really worth it. It is not just a museum but a mini trip to Bohemian history as you see armory, porcelains and even Beethoven's songbooks. The interior of the last stop was just fantastic and the view of most of the rooms was beautiful too. Next time I will definetely combine the visit with a concert first at the concert hall and lunch or cafe later on the Museum's cafeteria.

Tripadvisor to the rescue!. Wow! I was actually getting quite bored of museums towards the end of our trip and was considering not going to the Lobkowicz. Thank God I did. It was absolutely phenomenally done. The audio tour is done by today's Lobkowicz's which added a real personal touch to the tour (and its free!!!). The layout of the whole museum was really well done and the whole story is just breath-taking, all the pieces that they've managed to recollect after losing it twice! An absolute must see!! Even those who don't like museums must see this. I must admit that I was wondering how fun could a museum about a family really be, but I was blown away and after an hour of touring I wanted more. Surprisingly this place is barren, we were the only people in there the whole time, so you also avoid all the bustling tourists.Oh and a side note, they do on rare occasions close the first floor of the museum for dinners and functions so make sure not to leave this for the last day of your trip as the floor may be closed.

Don't miss this museum !. While you are in Prague, make time to visit the Lobkowitz Museum, located in the palace complex set on the hill above Prague. We stumbled in after touring the cathedral and palaces - what a great stumble! Not only a museum but a history of Czech royalty and culture. Weaponry, porcelains, historical documents, furnishings and much more. The Music room, with a copy of Handel's "Messiah" written in his own hand, Beethoven's signature and written works, incredibly preserved musical instruments - these were great highlights of our European adventure. The rooms in the palace were also beautiful and well preserved. The audio tour was informative without being overbearing or boring, plus you could select just the numbers of items you really wanted to hear about.Definitely a "don't miss this" in Prague.

A Great Museum. After 10 days of visiting the many wonderful museums in Prague, my husband and I decided to "take a chance" on the Lobkowicz Palace even though it was given just a slight mention in only one of our tour books. We're so glad we saw it. The quality and breadth of this family's collections are truly amazing. Everything about this museum is first class -- from the exhibits themselves to the extremely well-produced audio guide. The narrator of the audio guide -- a member of the Lobkowicz Family -- "personalized" the experience for us. He provided the right amount of detail to put the art and artifacts in context, and he did it in an interesting way. Seeing this family's portraits alone would have been worth the price of admission, but there was so much more: historic ceramics in pristine condition, armaments, religious artifacts, original manuscripts by classical composers...the list goes on. I also enjoyed the rich dark hot chocolate in the palace cafe after our tour!

best of Prague. Best day we had in Prague, where every day was wonderful, spent visiting the Lobkowicz Palace on Castle Hill. Got away from the hoardes of tourists and immersed ourelves in the history of this remarkable family who so generously share their rich heritage and holdings, including manuscripts by Beethoven, paintings by masters, etc., all beautifully presented. Would be of interest to anyone, even those not keen on art or museums, to take the audio tour. The cafe was casual, with great food, and the best views of Prague (I recommend the cheeseburger). Shop had gifts for everyone and especially helpful staff. It was not in my guide book because it is open only recently, so don't miss it.

As fantastic as everyone says!. We are in Prague for 3 days. We spent the first two around Old Town, Jewish Quarter, etc.Today, we went over to the Castle side by taking the metro, and then tram 22 to Pohorelec stop and walked downhill the whole way.We saw the changing of the guard that was interesting, and then looked at the tours available. The main palace and golden lane, etc. are pretty expensive, 200 - 350 or so depending on the tour, and the cathedral is free. My husband wanted to go to the cathedral, but the line was pretty long and it looked like a 2 hour wait, so we satisfied ourselves with photos of the outside, and continued on to the low side of the complex where the Lobkowicz Palace is located.I was telling my husband the whole time that it sounded from the reviews I'd read that this was the one thing worth seeing... he was suitably unconvinced and sort of rolling his eyes.The cost was about 275 each, which didn't help his attitiude. However, from the moment we put the included audio guide on and the current heir to the Lobkowicz estate, William Lobkowicz, who grew up in the US, began to tell the family's story, it was magical!The family was exiled from their home in the Czech republic twice: Once by the Nazis and once by the communists, and finally have had their rightful things restored to them, and opened their palaces as museums to display their collections.I'm not one to spend long hours in museums, I tend to get bored and so just glaze over things and look for the most relevant ones. The audio guide at this palace draws your attention to the numbers in red as the main relevant things to look at and punch into the guide if you are short on time (or have a short attention span like I do), but in this case, I found myself slowly punching in more and more of the non-red numbers as everything was quite interesting.The tour started on the second floor with paintings of various ancestors and the family tree, loaded with marriages between the Lobkowicz line and several royal lines, including Austrian, Spanish, etc.As we progressed through the rooms we came to the various treasure rooms, with interesting antiques collected by the various family princes through the past several centuries.... these rooms also had supplemental laminated sheets to explain the individual items in more detail than the audio guide, so be sure to look for these if you are interested and pick one up while in the room to learn more about the items.We then came to a music room. Several of the princes were big supporters of music of the times, and the seventh and eighth princes were benefactors and friends of Beethoven. In this room, there is a huge, long manuscript of one opera with notes in the margins by Beethoven himself and even a note from Beethoven to one of the Lobkowicz princes letting him know that he had received his latest stipend from the family. Apparently the Lobkowicz family was responsible for at least part of Beethoven's ability to spend time writing great works of music by keeping him "on the books" and free to create.In addition, there is a manuscript of Handel's Messiah, which had been edited by Mozart himself... with Handel's music vehemently scribbled over, and new notes written on the other side of the page by Mozart himself.There were also various old instruments in this room which were interesting, but nothing could equal the awe with which one viewed the musical manuscripts.One of the last rooms on the second floor contained a famous work by the Dutch artist Brueghel. I'm not as into paintings as some, but it was lovely, and many would say the highlight of the collection, although for me, the music room was definitely the best.The tour then goes to the first floor, where William's father tells you tales of remembrance from his childhood until he was 10 and the family was kicked out of the country.There are displays on this floor by the women (William's wife and mother) who are into the conservation side of things. There is a "bird room" with recently restored bird paintings, which have real feathers on them, which all had to be recently restored from pest and water damage, and a room devoted to the various family dogs through the centuries.The second floor was more spectacular than the first, but the first floor gave you more of a feel of the contemporary family as it lived in the palace. There were also painted frescoes on the ceilings of the last few rooms, which were quite nice.After the tour, which took us around 1.5 hours, we were starving, and went to the cafe on-site, where we sat out on a balcony of the palace, overlooking Prague, and drank Lobkowicz beer (yes, the family brewery which was recently returned to them) and ate quite yummy czech goulash and schnitzel. We were impressed with the quality of the food at this tourist site, and the setting was fantastic too. You also receive a 10% off voucher for the cafe when you purchase tickets to the Palace, and the meal was not expensive to begin with for a proper sit-down meal in such a nice setting.All-in-all, as others have said here on Tripadvisor, the Lobkowicz Palace is #1 for a reason... it is truly a find. I suppose what made it even better is that not a lot of people seem to know about it, and it was not crowded with tourists as so many other sties are.I would recommend if you only have time or inclination to visit one place in-depth on the castle grounds, this is the one. Truly a find!

Charming!. Such a charming museum. I think the audio tour is one of the best that I've ever heard. The personal stories, the anecdotes, all the touches that make this palace feel more personal to the visitor. You will learn a lot about the Lobkowicz family and their place in Czech as well as European history and culture. Although I'm sure the museum would like to have more visitors, I really liked that there was no crowds around the exhibits and that I had time to examine whatever caught my eye without fighthing for space. Highly recommended!

Amazing Story!. This is by far the best museum we've been in with such a personal touch! Loved the family stories and anecdotes! It certainly gave so much life to the otherwise ordinary exhibit! TIP: Skip the afternoon classical concert. Although the performers are good, it's a bit too pricey for such a simple performance. Save that money for a concert at any church where the acoustic is better and the performers are in costumes!

Simply Amazing. Good ol' Trip Advisor, coming through yet again. Prague is the final stop of my euro 2008 tour and I only had 3 days to see everything that I could. Trip Advisor rates the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague Castle as the number on attraction so I had to go check it out. Like most other people I would have totatly missed this exhibition had it not been for trip advisor. The collection is absoulutly stunning. Every piece looks as good as it did the day it was created. A few of my favorite rooms included the Music room with actually pieces from both Mozart and Beethoven on display, the Armory rooms, and the Piranesi room which as hand drawings of pictures of room that are unreal!!! The audio guide is awesome and is actually nice to listen to. If you can, get there at a time which they are having a live concert in the music room, masterful piano players preforming famous pieces of music. My trip has taking me to Rome, Munich, Ulm, Berlin, and Prague and I have been to some of the most famous musuems out there and would but this one right up there in the top 3. If you are not a museum lover then this is not for you. It takes about and hour+ but you can go at your own speed and probably finish faster. If you like art, you like history, and you like want to see some remarkably well preserved pieces then this is the place for you. Price is a little steep, I paid student price of 175ck which is about 12usd, non students are 250czk but its well worth it. Only bummer was, you aren't allowed to take pictures inside the musuem. oh, and Also there is a nice restraunt down stairs which you will get a 10% off coupon too which is actually really good and has a nice view!

Magical day at Lobkowicz Palace!. If you do nothing else, do this lovely 'palace/house' with the audio tour. What an oasis from the crowds and the cafe was the best meal we've had by far--incredible view and delicious food! We started with an amazing concert in the music room and then toured the palace. We loved the legacy of the Lobkowicz Family--the attention to detail was phenomenal. Highly, highly recommended! Absolutely!

Money well spent!. My friend and I just came back from a weekend in Prague. We decided to visit the Lobkowicz Palace on Sunday (29 June) after reading the TripAdvisor reviews. It is certainly the best museum in Prague, and we thoroughly enjoyed the friendly and well presented audio tour, led by the current owner of the Palace and his family, supported by his curator.The museum opens every day until 6pm. If you follow the audio tour, it will take about 1hr, depending on how much time you spend at each 'stop'. Admission to the museum is about 275czk per adult - we think its money well spent.We also stopped at the Museum Cafe afterwards for some refreshments, and enjoyed a 10% discount on presentation of the museum 'ticket'. Choose a table on the balcony and you'll get a wonderful view of Prague. We also loved the carrot cake!

Charming museum. We learned about this museum during our trip while browsing TripAdvisor, and I'm very happy that we did. This brand new museum, which opened in 2008, is not in any of the tour books (Rick Steves, Fodors, etc) so it's relatively unknown. However, don't let the fact that it's relatively empty turn you off: inside is a charming look into the life of the Lobkowicz family and some Czech history.Be warned that entrance is not too cheap, but it includes an audio guide which will guide you through the entire museum. The audio (at least, the English) is narrated by the current Lobkowicz prince, with occasional cameos from other family members and friends. This family, which at one point owned something like 18 castles and a ton of land and wealth, lost all of it to the Nazis in WWII. After the war ended, they got it back, but only to have the communists take it away again shortly thereafter. The family was forced to flee - reduced from 18 castles to literally nothing - and moved to Massachusetts. After communism fell, they returned, were able to get much of their grounds back, but apparently, none of the wealth. With the costs of taxes, maintenance, repairs, etc, and out of good will, they are now opening up their family property to the public.The exhibits include portraits of family members (wonderfully described in the audio guide), a beautiful china collection, various gorgeous artifacts, an arms & armor collection, works of art, and more. The audioguide is brilliant at walking you through the museum and explaining the importance and background of the various items. You really get an appreciation for a painting you otherwise might have walked by without a second glance. One of my favorite exhibits had original manuscripts from Mozart and Beethoven - both of whom were funded by the Lobkowicz family - including corrections, edits and the like. Moreover, the audioguide features a good deal of their music, really adding to the experience.This may not be the richest or largest museum you'll visit, and perhaps the Lobkowicz family pats themselves on the back just a bit too much in the audioguide, but it's a unique, lovely and memorable experience. Go there now, before everyone else finds out!

This is why Tripadvisor works. On our last day in Prague during a recent trip, I searched Tripadvisor for the best things to do in the city and up popped Lobkowicz Palace. My wife and I had walked right past the palace during a visit to Prague Castle earlier in the week, but didn't go in. We would have missed it completely if not for a last-minute visit to Tripadvisor.What a wonderful find this palace is! They were hosting a special function on the day we visited so we only had access to the 2nd floor. To their credit, they discounted the cost but our experience was so great we would have gladly paid the full fare. The Princely Collections at Lobkowicz Palace are not to be missed. It's all amazing, beautiful, incredible, but the music room is one of the most fascinating museum exhibits I've ever seen. I had chills more than once in the room looking at the incredible pieces of musical history. I won't give it away but please, go see it.Like others, we were fortunate enough to meet William and Alexandra Lobkowicz during our visit, and they were absolutely charming. Do get the free audio tour, it is extremely well done and very interesting.

Crown jewel of Prague. What a joy it was to come out of the heat and crowds of Prague Castle and into the Lobkowicz Palace! The collections are extraordinary, for their artistic merit and for their historic sweep - but they are not overwhelming in size. Instead, one feels one is beingtaken on a personal tour by the members of the Lobkowicz family who present highlights of the collections on an informative audiotape. As for the collections themselves, I have not seen their equal in Prague, and rarely elsewhere. A few examples: In painting, the elder Brueghel's Haymaking; a lovely Madonna by Lucas Cranach the Elder; two outstanding Canaletto views of London. In music, Beethoven scores, and Mozart's own mark-up of Haydn's Messiah. Fine decorative arts; wonderful rifles and armor. But this is not an impersonal museum. The exhibition pulses with the blood of a family, over many centuries. That family's changing tastes and experiences unify the collections and bring to life the history of Central Europe from the Thirty Years' War to the Nazis, the Communist expropriations, the Velvet Revolution and the present day. I cannot overstate how much I relished my visit to the collections in the Lobkowicz Palace.

A Memorable Experience. Visiting Lobkowicz Palace was the first thing we did on our first full day in Prague. It was a perfect way to begin our six day stay. We were familiar with the history of the Lobkowicz Family from recent articles in US publications. However, walking through the streets of Prague Castle to reach the Lobkowicz Palace and then experiencing the beautifully scripted and read audio guide of the Palace interior and family collection was a particular treat. Afterward our family had lunch on the terrace overlooking Prague and shopped in the very upscale gift shop. It was a lovely morning and substantive exposure to an important piece of Czech history.

Don't miss---Best Art/Culture/Musuem/Restaurant in Prague. Should be your first stop in Prague. Inside Prague Castle, this historic family has opened up their treasures to the world including priceless Breughel, Canalettos, Beethoven orignal compositions in a fantastic musuem with hi-tech audio tour. Not one of those boring museums but laced with real history and great exhibits. Topping it off is the impeccable cafe with endless city views and great healthy foods with best ice cream in Prague. Even the gift shop has authentic period jewlery at fair prices and interesting adults/kids stuff that is anything but touristy. You feel like a prince in this home of Prince Lobkowicz. All of this in the best section of Prague and part of Prague Castle.

One of Prague's Best-Kept Secrets. Prague has a lot of attractions, but my favorite was one that is not in most of the guidebooks because it's too new. I realize that it seems strange to say that a 400-year old palace is too new, but it's only been open to the public with its current exhibits in the past year. I first learned about Lobkowicz Palace from an article in the Wall Street Journal in March of 2008, so I immediately put it on my itinerary for our April trip to Prague. I'm glad I did, because it was the highlight of our trip to Prague.The Lobkowicz princes were members of an aristocratic Czech family that came to prominence in the early 1600's, helping the Hapsburgs to rule the Austro-Hungarian Empire. They had at least six castles and palaces in Eastern Europe---mostly in Bohemia. They were very important to art and music, amassing an impressive art collection and also supporting Beethoven and other classical composers. In fact, Beethoven' s Symphony No. 3 (the Eroica) was dedicated to one of the Lobkowicz princes. The Lobkowicz Palace is conveniently located right on the grounds of the Prague Castle, but a little difficult to find. When you go through the main entrance to the castle grounds, go past all the buildings, past St. Vitus Cathedral and all the others, and almost at the end of the grounds, look to the right and you'll see Lobkowicz Palace. Inside, you'll find one of the most impressive art collections in Prague including a couple of Canalettos and an historic painting depicting the Defenestration of Prague. Of course, there are also a lot of great portraits of the Lobkowicz ancestors. Be sure to use the acoustic guide, because the narration is fascinating and goes into the history of the Lobkowicz family, Bohemia and the Austro-Hungarian Empire. What was really interesting to us was the identity of the narrator---none other than William Lobkowicz, descendant of the Lobkowicz princes and current owner of the palace. The Lobkowicz holdings were expropriated first by the Nazis and then by the communists. William Lobkowicz fought a legal battle over many years to reclaim the family's holdings after the fall of communism. He has now restored the palace and put the family's impressive art collection on display to preserve an amazing cultural tradition. William himself is the all-American type, having been born in Massachusetts, graduated from Harvard where he rowed crew and played squash, and then worked as a commercial real estate broker in Boston. He went to Prague after 1989 to reclaim his family's property and decided to stay on and make preserving Czech culture his life's work. Locals told me that he speaks Czech fluently. We had lunch at the museum cafe the day we saw the art collection, but my wife and I liked it so much that we returned for lunch the following day when we were visiting other parts of the Prague castle. We also noticed that there are daily concerts in the palace.A visit to Lobkowicz Palace is highly recommended. Go right away before the word gets out and it gets in all the guidebooks and the crowds will descend on the palace. I was so impressed with Lobkowicz Palace, that I was inspired to take the train the following day to Nelahozeves Castle, another of the Lobkowicz holdings, that is only a half hour outside Prague. That's where I learned even more about this aristocratic Bohemian family.

Art, Music & Culture all wrapped into one.. Visited based on recommendation of a recent Wall Street Journal article. Fabulous collection in a beautiful setting, tied to an inspiring story of family history, struggle, loss and re-birth from WWII through Soviet era, to the present. Met and spoke with the owners, enjoyed a delicious lunch, heard a delightful chamber music concert, all in one location.Highly recommended!Gary V - Cincinnati, OH USA

Americans, don't miss this palace while in Prague!. A museum with history in exhibitions, especially the original oil paintings, family treasures including their remarkable music room with original scores on view from Beethoven and Mozart. Their down to earth "customer friendly" staff warrants mention from restrauant (great food) to the museum shop. David Krol, Deputy Director was informative and best of all was his invitation to sit down for a pleasant chat with Sarah and William Lobowicz about their family history as well as getting back into their possession, all that was taken from them over the years. Lunch was perfect as was the midday classical concert (simply don't miss this event). We enjoyed this outing so much, we took a train on Saturday to see their Renaissance Castle in Nelahozeves. Another terrific morning that we suggest to all those willing to spend a morning including a short train ride to the country. If Prague gives you a glow, which it will, then this palace with make your heart pound and even tempt you to assist in the support of more of this cultural lifestyle.Nancy & Bob, Alpharetta, GA

An absolute gem in Prague. On a recent visit to Prague, I visited Lobkowicz Palace in the Prague Castle Complex. I found it to be a superb experience in many respects. The Lobkowicz collections are vast, covering almost every field of the arts - hugely impressive and the audio tours linking the exhibits with the family history make it more "human". There is great emphasis on music and there is a classical concert every lunchtime. Wonderful. Don't miss it if you find yourself in Prague!

One of the best museums of Prague. The Lobkowicz Palace in Prague is a remarkable museum. Visitors should take time while walking through the many rooms of the palace. The music room is breathtaking and to actually see the original scores of Beethoven’s fourth and fifth symphonies does take your breath away. I was fortunate enough to find myself almost alone in this museum, so I took my time examining the details of Canaletto’s paintings and, of course, the jewel of the crown, Brueghel the Elder’s Haymaking.
My favorite place to see in Prague.. Don't miss this place - it's the best museum in Prague. Seriously.It's got the best art, best food, best shop, best views. Period.

A Must See if You're in Prague!. If you have only even a half day in Prague, check out this palace. I was recently in Prague on a business trip, and with only a couple of hours free, I went to the top of the hill to the Prague Castle complex. I had picked up a flier about some chamber orchestra music at the Lobkowicz Palace, and wandered by. I decided to take in the roughly 1-hour set of (excellent) classical music, and then took an audio guide through the collection. The story of the family is amazing! The 7th Prince Lobkowicz was one of Beethoven's biggest patrons, and 3 of Beethoven's symphonies are dedicated to the Prince (with signed scores in the museum). The family's quest to claim the treasures--taken by the Nazis and then the Communists--is remarkable in itself. The Palace has been beautifully restored, and makes you feel like you've gone back in time. It doesn't take long to go through the collection, and I highly recommend the audio guide. Very much worth the trip.

Terrific small museum. Wonderful, personal museum with some of the most amazing Canalleto's and Breughles anywhere in the world.
Most of all, a fascinating insight into the life of a Princely family who've lost and regained their estates and treasures several times over.
By far the most interesting museum in Prague, other than the Castle itself.

You would be surprised, amazed, and glad not to have missed it. Lobkowicz Palace is a very enjoyable family-run museum. Its entrance is right opposite the place where you emerge from the Golden Street in Prague Castle. Being run by the Lobkowicz family, the Palace requires an admission fee separate from the rest of the castle, but you will not regret paying it. This really is a must see place.It is not a traditional museum with a collection of Roman sculptures, Impressionists, a Picasso or two, etc. This museum is devoted to the Lobkowicz family history, which involves figures as prominent as Mozart and Beethoven; the latter dedicated his Eroica Symphony to a Lobkowicz. The collection features (different) musical scores of both with corrections in their own hands made specifically for the concerts given for the Lobkowiczes. If you thought that "old money" refers to Rockefellers, visit the Lobkowicz Palace, and you will see the difference.The complimentary audioguide is mostly narrated (in English) by the current owner, the Lobkowicz who only recently regained his family treasures and now proudly tells you about them; this makes listening a really personal experience that is also well orchestrated, literally. But he steps down to give the podium to the museum's arts curator in what concerns the most prominent paintings of the collection, which includes such masters as Cranach, Velasquez, and Pieter Brueghel the Elder. Brueghel fans simply must visit the museum to see one of the 5 surviving paintings from his "6 Seasons" series (another one is in Metropolitan Museum in New York with the remaining three in Vienna Kunsthistorisches Museum).An interesting touch to the collection is that almost every historical personage mentioned in the audioguide can be typically seen in portrait somewhere nearby, which creates a kind of a visual accompaniment to the narration.Unlike in most museums, the collection is not overwhelming, though still awe-inspiring. All highlights of the collection are on the 2nd floor. By the way, the museum closes about an hour later than the rest of the castle's attractions. There are curious items, armor, musical instruments, china; in short, there is something for everyone.

A must-see in Prague Castle. This past spring I had the great fortune of travelling through the Czech Republic and spending a good amount of time in Prague. I stepped into the Lobkowicz Palace just for one of their daily concerts (very nice!) and ended up going to the museum and cafe afterwards (you get a 10% discount in the cafe if you visit the musuem). The exhibit was a touching and elegant display of the Lobkowicz family history and treasures (which include rare arms, Canalettoes, Cranachs, a Velasquez, a Brueghel, and music manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart). A free audio guide is narrated by members of the family. The cafe seriously has the best food in Prague Castle--be sure to sit on the balcony for an amazing view of the city!

Excellent, Informative, and Interesting. Was just there about a month ago. This was one of the best Museum's i've ever been to. All of the material was extremely interesting, and I was very impressed with the amount of items and paintings they had on display. They had objects on display ranging from Portraits, to world famous paintings, to original manuscripts by Beethoven and Mozart, and so on. I honestly did not want to leave. The Cafe was awesome as well. The food was delicious and their service was top notch. This is definitely a must visit destination when you're in Prague!!

Lobkowicz Palace--where nonsense and frivolity come alive (without refunds). The following is a review of the Lobkowicz Palace's Princely Collection and accompanying audioguide (not a review of the cafe, which had fairly good food at fairly high prices, not to mention that we ate there before we went to the exhibit, where we received a 10% off coupon to the cafe for having purchased a ticket to the museum--a coupon I had to give away to some other tourists).Merriam-Webster defines a "museum" as "an institution devoted to the procurement, care, study, and display of objects of lasting interest or value." Unfortunately, the Lobkowicz family, in deeming their institution a "museum," failed to comprehend this fundamental purpose. I expected a series of rooms, home to portraiture, fine musical instruments, and an extensive display of old Czech arms, all donated by the noble Lobkowicz family's collection compiled over the course of several centuries. Instead, I was subjected to the incoherent ramblings of Mr. Lobkowicz, who narrated the English version of the free audioguide available with the far-from-free entrance ticket. He pointed out interesting pieces in the museum, how his family acquired them, and how his family fared in the area around Prague. I had to walk around a museum, looking at portraits of his ancestors, and listen to his life story. Information about the original manuscripts by composers like Beethoven was overlooked to provide "more important" highlights about which Lobkowicz received the works' dedications and which Lobkowicz was intelligent, insightful, and wonderful enough to sacrifice time and money to support the struggling composers. Many of the pieces not directly related to the family, including antique stringed instruments, were not covered in the audioguide nor even labeled, which is a basic requirement in museums (I had rather incorrectly assumed). The Lobkowicz family simply arranged a series of paintings and artifacts in their "palace," without feeling the need to explain who the artists were and from what era they originate. The more important pieces in the museum (the pieces not directly telling of the Lobkowicz genealogy), like the famed Bruegel work "Haymaking," were barely outlined in the audioguide (and not narrated by Mr. Lobkowicz, who probably didn't find the paintings interesting because his great-great-great-great-inbred-third cousin was not featured). The irrelevance of the museum reached an all-time high (or low, depending on how you look at it) in the "Bird Room" and the "Dog Room," dedicated to portraiture of dead family pets, with an audio presentation dedicated to nonsense about how museum visitors should donate money to the Lobkowicz family so they can further hire artists to paint pics of their pups to, get this, "preserve the Czech heritage."This "museum"--the worst in Europe--was only opened in April of 2007. If we get the word out about the awful experiences to be had in the museum, hopefully it might be closed and unsuspecting tourists might keep a few more Czech crowns in their pockets. The Prague Castle is a great site to see (toward the end of your visit to Prague), but this particular area of the Castle should be considered strictly off-limits. Preserve your sanity and visit a REAL museum, for they will not refund the price of your ticket.

Best Museum Experience in Prague!!!. I recently visited Prague where I find myself a lot on business. I had the chance to visit the newly openned Princely Collections exhibit at the Lobkowicz Palace in Prague Castle. This is one of the best museum experiences I have had. Definitely worth a stop when you visit Prague. The audio tour is narrated by a family member and the personalized story makes the art work and history come alive. I saw paintings by Brueghl and Cannaletto. Original musical manuscripts by Beethoven. I also had lunch at their cafe which served excellent soups, wraps and dessert (my favorite was their family cheesecake!) and had a great view over the city. Do not miss this one.
